{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"15 Stunning Examples of Small Business Website Design","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/51/small-business-website-are-you-spending-too-much-on-yours.aspx","description":"<p>If you’re a small business, your website has a big impact on your success. Research shows that roughly <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/315709/online-local-business-search-frequency-us-canada/\">a third of people use the web to find local businesses</a>. Honestly, I’m surprised that number isn’t higher.</p>  \n<p>As a small business, you might not have the budget to hire a designer, bring in a development team, or pay for a suite of design tools for your new site. A basic brochure site will probably have to do for now, right?</p> \n<p>But here’s the thing: You don’t need a design portfolio or a branding team to make an effective website. A lot of what makes websites work boils down to clear and intuitive navigation, well-written copy, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/website-color-schemes\">tasteful use of color</a>, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/website-typography\">typography</a>, and images — no design degree necessary.</p> \n<p>Still, it’s one thing to talk about good design, and another to actually <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/30557/6-guidelines-for-exceptional-website-design-and-usability.aspx\">build a website that delivers on all design fronts</a>. Lucky for us, there are many fascinating websites that have figured out what works. So, for help in your design journey, we’ve compiled our favorite examples of excellent small business websites to inspire your own.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=c791aced-6180-48a5-916d-b2d76cec1836&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Free Download: 77 Examples of Brilliant Web Design&nbsp;\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/c791aced-6180-48a5-916d-b2d76cec1836.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Small Business Website Design Examples</h2> \n<p>There are, of course, thousands of small business websites you can draw from, but we think these 15 serve as a good starting point whether you’re planning a redesign or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/website-wireframe\">wireframing</a> your first iteration. By the way, these are all real businesses, so you can click each link to explore the website yourself. Let’s dive in.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.bennett-tea.com/\">Bennett Tea</a></h3> \n<p>Starting off our list is a gorgeous example of what you can accomplish with color palettes, animated page transitions, scrolling effects, and creative layouts. The Bennett Tea shop offers just a handful of premium tea options, but each is presented elegantly through this online store’s unconventional format.</p> \n<p>Typically, stores display their products as grids with links to product pages. On the Bennett Tea website, however, users scroll down to explore each offering, with a life-sized image of the tea box and descriptions of the taste, aroma, and mouthfeel. It’s the perfect visual palette to complement the company’s variety of tastes.</p> \n<p>Also notable is the site’s navigation experience. Upon landing on the website, visitors are shown a splash page stating the company’s mission. They then have the option to continue to the store or go to the About or Contact pages. It may require one additional click to get to the store page, but this choice puts the branding front and center for potential customers.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example bennett tea\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-2.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-2.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://arozjewelry.com/en/\">Aroz</a><a href=\"https://arozjewelry.com/en/\"> Jewelry</a></h3> \n<p>Belgium-based jeweler Aroz has constructed an immaculate website to showcase and sell their items. Offering a variety of accessories, Aroz first greets visitors with a full-width image, below which they present their pieces in a grid slider.</p> \n<p>As users continue scrolling, the website makes frequent use of zoom-in animation, slide-in animation, and fade-in effects for greater visual impact. Each text section establishes the store’s offerings, capped off with a contact form and a social media CTA.</p> \n<p>For those looking to learn more about Aroz, the website also includes a blog featuring new collections as well as customer and designer stories. All of these components work to conjure a professional, sophisticated, and unique brand image — a great example of what an ecommerce site can be.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example aroz jewelry\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-48-PM.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-48-PM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://chicagofrenchpress.com/\">Chicago French Press</a></h3> \n<p>If a tea shop can have a fantastic website, why not a coffee roaster? Chicago French Press sells a variety of rotating flavors while donating a portion of its proceeds to nonprofits and charitable organizations.</p> \n<p>Like Bennett Tea, this website emphasizes the aesthetics of the product packaging. It also implements color backgrounds to distinguish between flavors, as seen in the full-width <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/web-slideshows-standard\">image slider</a> on the homepage.</p> \n<p>The Chicago French Press store is easy to navigate, as visitors can search by different criteria including flavor, brewing method, and bag size. And, if you want to incorporate their flavors with food, the website’s blog includes recipe posts too.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example chicago french press\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-78-PM.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-78-PM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3><br>4. <a href=\"https://www.wildwoodbakery.com.au/\">Wildwood Bakery</a></h3> \n<p>Wildwood Bakery’s website incorporates illustrations in small but stunning ways. The Australian bakery has made a simple but captivating website with little more than some delicate illustrations, a nice orange-and-green color palette, and mouth-watering close-ups of their creations.</p> \n<p>On the homepage, visitors can learn about the bakery and click away to the website’s online store or sourdough subscription service. The bottom of the page sports a footer with social links and other useful resources. Note that the footer is more prominent than usual — the large text draws the eye to other important aspects of the business like sustainability and wholesale.</p> \n<p>Wildwood’s store page is also worth checking out. Customers can filter products by flavors and quickly add anything to the cart. It’s clear that the designers considered everything, as even the card icon itself is a custom illustration. It’s these details that make this site exceptional.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example wildwood bakery\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-48-06-PM.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-48-06-PM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://www.aarkcollective.com/\">AÃRK Collective</a></h3> \n<p>The website for watchmaker AÃRK Collective leaves no question as to what it does — from the start, its timepieces are displayed in full-page, aesthetically pleasing images. The whole thing resembles more of a gallery than an ecommerce site and establishes the brand's commitment to simple and elegant designs.</p> \n<p>But, this is ultimately an online store, and scrolling down reveals AÃRK’s product lines in a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/broken-grid-layouts\">masonry grid style</a>. The presentation is quite minimal, but this lets visitors focus solely on the designs themselves. There’s no other information until you click on an item, which sends you to a product page with all the relevant information, plus many more images to be sure you’re making the right watch purchase.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example aark collective\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-99-PM.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-99-PM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://www.cleenland.com/\">Cleenland</a></h3> \n<p>Not all websites have to be visually elaborate — this is proven with Cleenland’s online store. The Boston-based company sells low-waste home care and personal hygiene products, and the site wastes no time nudging visitors to visit the physical location.</p> \n<p>Visitors can also shop online in Cleenland’s online store, which lists its product categories with images of each product and information about the supplier. This way, you know products are sourced sustainably. There’s even a “popular products” category serving up the best this store has to offer.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example cleenland\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-71-PM.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-71-PM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; width: 650px; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://ladiesgetpaid.com/\">Ladies Get Paid</a></h3> \n<p>Ladies Get Paid is a membership website that offers financial and professional education courses for women. There are online classes, speaker events, and networking events, as well as job postings and online communities, all to fuel career advancement and financial confidence.</p> \n<p>From a visual perspective, Ladies Get Paid does a fantastic job of presenting its variety of benefits in a straightforward manner. Its mission is clear from the start, and the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/header-design\">page header</a> lets guests view each offering in more detail.</p> \n<p>The website also effectively incorporates hints of color in its <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/interactive-websites\">interactive items</a>. Its cards and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/button-design\">buttons</a> match each other for a cohesive feel and incorporate subtle hover effects for a pleasing user experience. Overall, the website is bold but inviting, a difficult but certainly achievable balance.</p> \n<h3><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example ladies get paid\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-45-94-PM.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-45-94-PM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></h3> \n<h3>8. <a href=\"https://www.goodvibesclean.com/\">Good Vibes All Purpose Cleaner</a></h3> \n<p>Maybe I’m just biased toward sustainable cleaning products, but Good Vibes All Purpose Cleaner presents a simple, effective ecommerce site that manages to convey its philosophy and offerings seamlessly.</p> \n<p>Good Vibes has no frill with its product displays — products are shown in a grid format as you might expect. However, the website also prominently features reviews and testimonials from customers below to instill confidence in new buyers.</p> \n<p>Each product page includes a description as well as cleaning instructions, ingredients, reviews, and recommended products. It’s enough to make a positive impression without relying on visual gimmicks.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example good vibes all purpose cleaner\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-3.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-3.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>9. <a href=\"https://www.wisr.com.au/\">Wisr</a></h3> \n<p>I never expected to have this much fun on a financial services website, but here we are — Wisr offers personal loans, financial planning, and, above all, an incredibly amusing homepage. As you scroll, you follow the path of a simulated marble course from start to end. With each obstacle, you learn more about what Wisr does.</p> \n<p>Whether you think this design choice serves as a metaphor for the often unpredictable financial road ahead, or just a cool thing to look at, this website definitely stands out among the rest.</p> \n<p>As another cool secondary feature, the website remembers what page you exit from. So, upon a return visit, you’ll see a prompt inviting you back to the page where you left off. It’s a clever use of cookies that can help get prospects back on the conversion path.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example wisr\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-1.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-1.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>10. <a href=\"https://www.cafeconlibrosbk.com/\">Cafe con Libros</a></h3> \n<p>Intersectional Feminist bookstore Cafe con Libros (Coffee with Books) not only offers espressos with your purchase — it also boasts a fantastic website with everything you need under one domain name.</p> \n<p>This site manages to pack its book inventory, merch store, event calendar, and mission onto the homepage alone without overcomplicating things. Visitors can also order any book from the store — physical, e-book, or audiobook — for pickup or delivery through the site.</p> \n<p>As if that weren’t enough, the website also maintains an active blog with reflections and book reviews, a newsletter, a monthly book subscription service, and a podcast with an on-site player. It’s an excellent balance of quantity of offerings with quality of design.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example cafe con libros\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-48-31-PM.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-48-31-PM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>11. <a href=\"https://www.reformcollective.com/about/\">Reform Collective</a></h3> \n<p>Design agency Reform collective features one of the most cinematic scrolling experiences I’ve seen on a website. It combines fixed scrolling with horizontal scrolling to showcase each section in chunks while keeping visitors on the same page.</p> \n<p>Each individual section mentions some piece of the company, be it their design style and philosophy, a case study, testimonials, or a contact form. If you’re looking for a long-scrolling website that presents information to visitors in a specific linear sequence, try emulating this trick — it ensures users see what you want them to and in what order.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example reform collective\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-54-PM.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-54-PM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>12. <a href=\"https://mysweetdreams.co/\">Sweet Dreams</a></h3> \n<p>Sweet Dreams may create CBD and melatonin products for better rest, but don’t sleep on this website. Combining 2D and 3D illustrations, scrolling animation effects, customer reviews, and even interactive graphics, the homepage for this small business does a great job getting visitors in the mindset of their product before promoting the products themselves.</p> \n<p>Informational sections are interspersed with product links so that new customers, whether sold or skeptical, know what they’re buying and how these products work. To learn more, the About page includes masterful visuals and copy to put visitors at ease. Given what they’re selling, that seems like the right approach.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example sweet dreams\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-18-PM.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-18-PM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>13. <a href=\"https://panache.fr/\">Panache</a></h3> \n<p>The graphic design and branding experts and Panache have proven their abilities with their one-page informational website. This is another example of how scrolling can be much more than a way to traverse the page — here, it triggers colorful transitions and animations that leave a strong impression.</p> \n<p>Panache makes this list because, rather than including a separate gallery for showcasing the work, it blends its aesthetic approach into the construction of the site itself. This ultimately gets potential clients down to the contact form more quickly. There are also navigational links along the left side of the page in case visitors wish to return to a particular section.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example panache\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>14. <a href=\"https://scottscheapflights.com/\">Scott's Cheap Flights</a></h3> \n<p>The goal of Scott’s Cheap Flights is to help U.S. travelers easily and cheaply book vacations to domestic and international destinations. Its membership website is suitably simple: Just sign up and start getting daily emails with the latest discounted flight offerings.</p> \n<p>Once signed in, the website places its offers front-and-center — each one occupies a card with a colorful image of the destination. Clicking a card takes you to a page with information about the destination, instructions on how to book, and ticket prices by airport. Some cards are premium, and the “Upgrade” button lingers in the top right tempting users to subscribe.</p> \n<p>Additionally, this website also provides a ton of extra value to free and premium users in its blog section. In it, there are tips for booking flights, travel advice, and guides for exploring new cities.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example scott's cheap flights\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-38-PM.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-38-PM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h3>15. <a href=\"https://musicaudienceexchange.com/\">Music Audience Exchange</a></h3> \n<p>Finally, Music Audience Exchange (MAX) creates partnerships between brands and musical artists for promotional purposes, with a website that conveys class and professionalism.</p> \n<p>Since it caters to both artists and companies, it features two pages for both types of clients, with step-by-step guides explaining how the process works. It’s an efficient means to channel both brands and musicians alike toward an application form and a conversion.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage for the small business website design example music audience exchange\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-4.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-4.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Big Design Ideas for Small Businesses</h2> \n<p>Designing a website is, without a doubt, a challenge for small businesses. But after some perusing, you can come up with a list of your favorite inspiration sites and what makes them pop, then incorporate these features into your own site. Plus, you probably spend a good deal of time on sleek sites already and have a good sense of what you’ll want.</p> \n<p>Looking for more inspo? Check out all of our <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/resources/website-design\">website design resources</a>, including our Website Design lookbook — just click below.</p> \n<p><a Juviler","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/c791aced-6180-48a5-916d-b2d76cec1836.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn87@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-38-555_982d65f44f0c88fe.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-2.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-2.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn50@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-53-452_ddc52119e335a4ae.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-48-PM.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-48-PM.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn68@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-49-741_621f7e957d3c11b4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-78-PM.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-78-PM.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn89@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-48-774_d8b732e410489654.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-48-06-PM.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-48-06-PM.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn17@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-49-995_ef6adb556b4b9741.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-99-PM.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-99-PM.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn30@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-48-753_f23311ac5546434f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-71-PM.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-71-PM.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn87@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-50-895_a96f2221f235ab2d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-45-94-PM.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-45-94-PM.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn81@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-49-743_f6edb6758ca18c9e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-3.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-3.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn89@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-49-860_fb355dcede8f3ed9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-1.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-1.jpeg":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-48-31-PM.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-48-31-PM.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn73@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-48-768_3b430422633f3d63.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-54-PM.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-54-PM.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn70@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-51-566_1092fddf13d7d7a7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-18-PM.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-47-18-PM.jpeg":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn31@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-51-889_820ce045aa780836.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-38-PM.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-Jun-26-2021-06-49-46-38-PM.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn97@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-50-529_ec031826466f6a8b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-4.jpeg?width=650&name=15%20Stunning%20Examples%20of%20Small%20Business%20Website%20Design-4.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn69@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-48-782_11205dde752a03b6.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/a1077f76-df2c-4b45-8ebc-dc2732f30850.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn30@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-51-431_0b1d1653c463cbc3.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F51%2Fsmall-business-website-are-you-spending-too-much-on-yours.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938162},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"6 Steps to Build a Single Customer View & Improve Customer Experience","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/single-customer-view","description":"<p>Ever see those cool 360-degree cameras on red carpets at award shows?</p>  \n<p>Someone famous will stand in the middle and several cameras positioned all around will simultaneously capture pictures of the star, creating a spectacular image that gives you a 360 view of the person.</p> \n<p>Now, imagine if you could do that with your target audience? Capture them from all angles as they interact with your brand. With a single customer view, you can.</p> \n<p>The issue is, many businesses struggle to know where to start.</p> \n<p>At the end of this article, you’ll understand what a single customer view is and how to create one for your brand.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=12501f7c-8e26-4e3c-9642-7afbe078156a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Free Customer Journey Map Templates\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/12501f7c-8e26-4e3c-9642-7afbe078156a.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>A single customer view combines data from a consumer’s behavior on web and email, social media activity, demographics, interactions with customer service, and purchase history.</p> \n<p>Let’s go through an example of an interaction between a consumer and a brand.</p> \n<p>A consumer, let’s call her Jazmyn, discovers a brand on Instagram. Jazmyn visits the brand’s website through Instagram and downloads a free offer. Said brand adds Jazmyn to an email list and she starts receiving nurturing emails.</p> \n<p>After months of no interactions, Jazmyn rediscovers the brand and makes a purchase. A month after that, she calls customer service regarding an issue with her product.</p> \n<p>In just a few months, Jazmyn has interacted with at least three departments within the company: marketing, sales, and customer service. In many businesses, every department tracks data using its own system.</p> \n<p>For instance, sales teams often use <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/why-your-company-needs-a-crm-system-to-grow?__hstc=45788219.5de9bd98105d63133a8f81787e11a704.1622843200471.1622843200471.1622843200471.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1622843200472&amp;__hsfp=3102107587\">customer relationship management </a>(CRM) software to track their interactions with clients and prospects while marketing teams use marketing platforms and automation tools to generate leads.</p> \n<p>This creates huge data gaps, making it difficult to understand how a user is behaving over an extended period of time beyond a single vertical. It can also lead to duplicate information, leading to dirty data.</p> \n<p>For instance, Jazmyn might receive ads for products she’s already purchased. Or she may get a call from customer service asking about a product she’s already reviewed via email.</p> \n<p>Having a single customer view allows organizations to build personalized interactions with consumers, based on their current stage in the customer lifecycle. This creates a better customer experience, stronger brand loyalty, and better retention rates.</p> \n<p>When you know where your target audience is, you can make enticing offers based on their current needs. It’s personalization at its best.</p> \n<h2>Benefits of a Single Customer View</h2> \n<p>When you invest in a platform with a single customer view, you:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Have cleaner data</strong> – With an integrated system, you remove information silos, which often cause data duplication.</li> \n <li><strong>Gather better insights </strong>– When you have an accurate map of the customer journey, you can better understand how your campaigns are performing and identify areas of improvement.</li> \n <li><strong>Assign proper credit to the right channels </strong>– Proper attribution is a major issue when it comes to audience tracking. With an SCV, you can identify the best and worst-performing channels for future campaigns.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>1. Align your data owners and your KPIs.</h3> \n<p>The first step in creating an SCV is aligning all your data owners across your organization.</p> \n<p>It’s important to align your teams early on key targets and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/choosing-kpis\">key progress indicators</a>. This keeps everyone on the same page and striving toward the same goal.</p> \n<p>So, although everyone will be working on different sections, they’ll all be contributing to the same objective. This is key in keeping everyone in the same mindset and easing the transition to a data-driven approach.</p> \n<p>Your data owners will serve as liaisons between IT and your team, enforcing governance standards and supplying IT with the access they need.</p> \n<p>During this process, your IT team will be instrumental, as they will need to consolidate data from multiple systems and sources.</p> \n<h3>2. Find the right tech.</h3> \n<p>The next step is finding a platform with the capabilities to support your company’s needs.</p> \n<p>Key features to consider when searching for a platform include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Usability and accessibility of software</li> \n <li>CRM Integration</li> \n <li>Data quality tools</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-automation\">Automation</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>You’ll also want to consider the size of your company and the scalability of the software. all-in-one CRM platform like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/get-started\">HubSpot</a>, which combines sales, marketing, customer service data to support a holistic customer experience.</p> \n<h3>3. Hire data managers.</h3> \n<p>Depending on your company size, you may want to onboard roles dedicated to data, such as data miners, data analysts, and data migration specialists.</p> \n<p>The process of migrating data is a costly and time-consuming one that you may not be equipped for. Instead, hire experts with the knowledge and experience to do it right.</p> \n<p>They will be essential not only during the initial building phase but also as you grow your customer base.</p> \n<h3>4. Sort and integrate all data from your legacy systems.</h3> \n<p>If you’re an established brand with a ton of scattered data, you’ll need to sort through your systems.</p> \n<p>Start by conducting an audit of your data quality. From there, clean your data so you can start integrating it with your other systems, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Your data warehouse</li> \n <li>Your point-of-sale systems</li> \n <li>Your marketing automation systems</li> \n <li>Your call center systems</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>5. Set your data governance strategy.</h3> \n<p>As you’re in the process of cleaning out old data, you’ll need a new system for new, incoming data.</p> \n<p>This is where your data governance standards come into play. They serve as operating guidelines for retrieving, storing, and processing data.</p> \n<p>You may wonder, what’s the difference between a data management strategy and a data governance strategy? The former refers to the actions you take to fulfill the guidelines outlined in your governance strategy.</p> \n<p>To learn about how to develop a governance strategy, click <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/data-governance-framework\">here</a>.</p> \n<h3>6. Test your processes.</h3> \n<p>The last step in this process is testing your new centralized system.</p> \n<p>To ensure that your new environment works (i.e., that the data linkage is complete), some test data will need to be used to ensure the data is gathered, stored, and reported correctly on your platform.</p> \n<p>This will likely be an ongoing process as your business scales and you implement new touchpoints.</p> \n<p>The earlier your team can implement a single customer view framework, the better equipped you will be to serve your target audience. While the process can be expensive and time-consuming, it’s a worthwhile investment that will be instrumental in making strategic business decisions.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=dfcc1cf6-fca7-455f-9c43-26ff2fba10ed&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Apply for a job, keep track of important information, and prepare for an  interview with the help of this free job seekers kit.\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/dfcc1cf6-fca7-455f-9c43-26ff2fba10ed.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fsingle-customer-view&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 18 Jun 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/12501f7c-8e26-4e3c-9642-7afbe078156a.png","linkMd5":"6857ff4c03bf710b78b5bf7ea5254b88","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn95@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-38-574_29667f68bce7df45.webp","destWidth":494,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":3880,"destBytes":7698,"author":"mbretous@hubspot.com (Martina Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/12501f7c-8e26-4e3c-9642-7afbe078156a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn95@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-38-574_29667f68bce7df45.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/dfcc1cf6-fca7-455f-9c43-26ff2fba10ed.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn3@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-52-290_a6a20c230b966a35.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fsingle-customer-view&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn7@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-49-437_96c741cba561ff8a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938161},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"The Ultimate Guide to PPC Marketing","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ppc","description":"<p>Marketers, can we be honest with each other for a second? On a scale of 1-10, how much do you <em>really</em> understand the world of paid advertising?</p> \n<p>Although <a href=\"https://themanifest.com/advertising/small-business-advertising-2019\"><span>45% of small businesses</span></a> do some form of online advertising, pay-per-click is still a concept that eludes many of us.</p>  \n<p>As a marketer, PPC is a skill that you should have in your tool belt — or at least have a basic understanding of.</p> \n<p>This guide will help you grasp pay-per-click marketing in its entirety. To start, we’ll begin with the benefits of paid advertising and then get into some key definitions that you’ll need to know.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3242765b-a13a-461a-954d-510ce203b180&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Free Guide, Template &amp; Planner: How to Use Google Ads for Business\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3242765b-a13a-461a-954d-510ce203b180.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>When done right, PPC can earn you quality leads. If you can create a seamless user journey (which you’ll learn how to do later in this piece), it could mean a massive ROI for your PPC efforts.</p> \n<p>Pay-per-click advertising is most common in search engine results pages, like Google or Bing, but is also used on social channels (although CPM is more common).</p> \n<p>If you’re wondering where you can find pay-per-click ads, they’re the results you see before and to the right of the organic search results. For instance, check out the ad that came up in my search for \"cards.”</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/example%20of%20paid%20vs%20organic%20ads.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=example%20of%20paid%20vs%20organic%20ads.jpg\" alt=\"example of paid vs organic ads\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<a></a> \n<h3>PPC Terms and Definitions</h3> \n<p>What’s a marketing channel without a few acronyms and a little jargon?</p> \n<p>If you’re going to enter the paid advertising space, there are a few terms you should know. Below, we review the main elements of a PPC campaign, ranging from broad to the more specific.</p> \n<h4>Search Engine Marketing (SEM)</h4> \n<p>The objective of all forms of digital advertising is to rank for a target keyword, which you can do in several ways. Search Engine Marketing (SEM) refers to any digital marketing (paid or unpaid) done on a search engine, like Google, Yahoo, or Bing.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/insiders/seo-sem-faqs\">SEM</a> is an umbrella term that encompasses both paid advertising <em>and</em> search engine optimization, that is, ranking organically for keywords. It’s important to note that not all PPC occurs on search engines — social media has PPC ads, too (think: Facebook Ads).</p> \n<h4>CPC</h4> \n<p>Cost-per-click (CPC) is the amount that an advertiser pays for each click on your ad. CPC acts as your bid in an auction that determines where your ad will be placed. As you can imagine, a higher bid equates to better ad placement.</p> \n<p>You set your CPC at the maximum price you are willing to pay per click on your ad. What you <em>actually</em> pay is determined by the following formula:</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: bold;\">(Competitor’s Ad Rank / Your Quality Score) + 0.01 = Actual CPC.</p> \n<p>Let’s go over the terms in this equation, so you know what you’re paying for:</p> \n<h4>Ad Rank</h4> \n<p>This value determines the position of an ad on a search engine results page. It’s equal to <strong>Maximum Bid x Quality Score</strong>.</p> \n<h4>Quality Score</h4> \n<p>This is the score that search engines give to your ad based on your clickthrough rate (CTR) — measured against the average CTR of ads in that position — the relevance of your keywords, the quality of your landing page, and your past performance on the SERP.</p> \n<h4>Maximum Bid</h4> \n<p>This is the maximum you're willing to pay per click on your ad.</p> \n<p>Here’s an image by <a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/cost-per-click\">WordStream</a> that illustrates what I mean:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/maximum%20ad%20bid%20example%20.jpg?width=500&amp;name=maximum%20ad%20bid%20example%20.jpg\" alt=\"maximum ad bid example \" width=\"500\" style=\"width: 500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/cost-per-click\" style=\"font-size: 1em;\">Source</a></em></span></p> \n<p>You can set your CPC to <strong>manual</strong>, where you determine the maximum bid for your ads, or <strong>enhanced</strong>, which allows the search engines to adjust your bid based on your goals. One of these enhanced options involves bid strategies that automatically adjust your bids based on either clicks or conversions.</p> \n<h4>CPM (Cost per Mille)</h4> \n<p>CPM, also known as cost per thousand, is the cost per one thousand impressions. It’s most commonly used for paid social and display ads. There are other types of cost-per<em>s</em>… like cost-per-engagement, cost-per-acquisition (CPA), but for the sake of preserving your mental space, we’re going to stick with clicks, a.k.a. CPC.</p> \n<h4>Campaign</h4> \n<p>The first step in setting up your PPC ads is determining your ad campaign. You can think of your campaign as the key message or theme you want to get across with your advertisements.</p> \n<h4>Ad Group</h4> \n<p>One size doesn’t fit all. That’s why you’ll create a series of ads within your campaign based on a set of highly related keywords. You can set a CPC for each ad group that you create.</p> \n<h4>Keywords</h4> \n<p>Each ad within your ad group will target a set of relevant keywords or key terms. These keywords tell search engines which terms or search queries you want your ad to be displayed alongside in SERPs. Once you determine which keywords perform best, you can set a micro CPC specifically for keywords within your ads.</p> \n<h4>Ad Text</h4> \n<p>Your keywords should inform your ad text. Remember, your Quality Score is determined by how relevant your ad is; therefore, the text in your ad (and landing page, for that matter) should match the keyword terms you’re targeting.</p> \n<h4>Landing Page</h4> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-landing-page-builder\">landing page</a> is a critical piece of your paid advertising strategy. The landing page is where users will end up once they click your PPC ad. Whether it’s a dedicated webpage, your homepage, or somewhere else, make sure to follow landing page best practices to maximize conversions.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Best PPC Platforms</h3> \n<p>Now that you understand the PPC basics, I’m guessing your next question is: <em>Where should I advertise?</em></p> \n<p>There are dozens of online spaces where you can spend your coveted ad money, and the best way to vet them is by taking a close look at your potential ROI on each platform.</p> \n<p>The most popular advertising platforms are effective because they’re easy to use and, most importantly, highly trafficked. But for a smaller budget, you might consider a lesser-known alternative to these key players.</p> \n<p>When choosing a platform, some other things to consider are the availability of keyword terms, where your target audience spends their time, and your advertising budget.</p> \n<p>Here a non-exhaustive list of some of the top PPC platforms.</p> \n<h4>Google Ads (formerly known as AdWords)</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/cleaning%20supplies%20google%20ads%20ppc%20example.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=cleaning%20supplies%20google%20ads%20ppc%20example.jpg\" alt=\"cleaning supplies google ads ppc example\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>How many times a day do you hear the phrase “Let me Google that?” Probably more than you can count … hence why Google Ads is the king of paid advertising.</p> \n<p>On average, Google processes over <a href=\"https://www.internetlivestats.com/one-second/#google-band\">90,000 search queries every second</a>, giving you plenty of opportunities to target keywords that will get your intended audience to click. The downside is that keywords are highly competitive on this platform, meaning a larger ad spend.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/template-managing-and-organizing-google-adwords-campaigns?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>If you’re planning to use this popular platform, start with our free Google Ads PPC Kit.</em></a></p> \n<h4>Bing Ads</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/great%20coffee%20at%20home%20bing%20ppc%20ad%20example.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=great%20coffee%20at%20home%20bing%20ppc%20ad%20example.jpg\" alt=\"great coffee at home bing ppc ad example\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>The perks of using Bing Ads over Google Ads is a slightly lower CPC at the expense of a larger audience, of course.</p> \n<h4>Facebook Ads</h4> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/example%20of%20ppc%20ads%20on%20facebook.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=example%20of%20ppc%20ads%20on%20facebook.jpg\" alt=\"example of ppc ads on facebook\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; margin: 0px auto;\">Facebook Ads blend in with other posts on the platform.</span></em></p> \n<p>Facebook Ads is a popular and effective platform for paid ads (more commonly used as CPM than CPC), mainly due to its specific targeting options. Facebook allows you to target users based on interests, demographics, location, and behaviors.</p> \n<p>Also, Facebook allows for native ads, which means ads are introduced and blend into the social feed. Not to mention, you can use Facebook Ads to advertise on Instagram as well.</p> \n<h4>AdRoll</h4> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/example%20of%20ad%20roll.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=example%20of%20ad%20roll.jpg\" alt=\"example of ad roll\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; margin: 0px auto;\">Chipotle retargeting me as I search for dessert recipes.</span></em></p> \n<p>AdRoll is a retargeting platform that advertises to people who have already visited your website. For instance, say someone read your article on cheese making. You can retarget them on other sites they visit with display ads that advertise your online cooking classes.</p> \n<p>While retargeting is possible with Google Ads, the benefit of using AdRoll is that it can display ads on Google <em>and</em> social media sites, which gives you more opportunities to capture clicks or impressions, depending on your goal.</p> \n<h4>RevContent</h4> \n<p>RevContent focuses specifically on promoting content through PPC. It has the same impact as a guest post, where your content is displayed on an external site, except it’s in the form of an ad. You still bid on keywords, and your advertisement is displayed next to content relevant to those keywords. With this platform, you’ll reap the benefits of a low CPC and highly engaged traffic.</p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<p>With that explanation out of the way, now let's look at some benefits of PPC ads.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1.&nbsp;PPC ads are cost-effective.</h3> \n<p>With PPC ad campaigns, you have complete control over how much you’re willing to spend.</p> \n<p>Since you only pay when visitors click the link leading to your website or landing page — with a high chance of conversion — you’ll be getting your money’s worth.</p> \n<h3>2. PPC ads produce fast results.</h3> \n<p>Although organic ranking is great, it sometimes takes months or even years to get on the first page on SERPs.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>If you’re a startup or small business, you likely don’t have the time to wait for the effect of organic, social, or direct traffic to kick in.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>That’s where PPC ads come in.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>With optimized PPC ads, you can shoot yourself to the top of the SERP within hours of launching your campaign.</p> \n<h3>3. You can easily control and test PPC ads.</h3> \n<p>It’s easy to control the keywords you’re targeting, ad placement, or budget with PPC ads. You can also run A/B split tests with different ads to identify the one that produces the highest return on investment. You can then scale the ads that do well until it no longer produces desirable results.</p> \n<h3>4. PPC ads allow you to target your ideal customers.</h3> \n<p>With PPC ads, you can skip right past cold audiences to target a warm audience that’s ready to buy your products and services.</p> \n<p>You can bid on keywords that solution-aware personas would search for online. Aside from keywords, PPC ads also offer targeting options like past online activity or demographics.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Another excellent use of PPC ads is to create retargeting campaigns targeting visitors who didn’t purchase after landing on your site.</p> \n<h3>5. Algorithm changes have little effect on PPC ads.</h3> \n<p>Between the numerous <span>Google algorithm changes</span> and the <a href=\"https://backlinko.com/google-ranking-factors\"><span>200 ranking factors</span></a>, trying to get free traffic from search engines is a bit unstable compared to PPC advertising.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>With PPC ads, you don’t have to worry about algorithm changes but instead focus on how well your campaigns perform.</p> \n<h3>6. PPC ads help you rank even with low domain ratings.</h3> \n<p>Keywords have become increasingly competitive. This makes it more difficult for a business with a low <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/domain-authority?_ga=2.263825157.882265536.1623113042-1188014066.1623113042\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\"><span>domain authority</span></a> to get into the top rankings on a search engine or in front of its target audience on a social platform.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>With PPC advertising, you can quickly rank for keywords your audience is searching, irrespective of your domain ratings.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>7. Data from PPC ads can improve your SEO strategy.</h3> \n<p>You shouldn’t ditch all your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo?_ga=2.263825157.882265536.1623113042-1188014066.1623113042\"><span>search engine optimization (SEO</span></a>) efforts altogether — your paid advertising should <em>complement</em> your SEO strategy instead of replacing it.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>“When people search for your keywords, you know their search intent and can display the most relevant ad to your audience. This means more clicks and a greater chance of conversion.” - Laura Mittelmann, Paid Acquisition at HubSpot</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<h2>How to Build a PPC Campaign</h2> \n<p>Now that you understand the benefits of PPC and have your key terms, let’s dive into crafting a quality PPC campaign using <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33283/A-Simple-Guide-for-Setting-Up-Your-First-Google-AdWords-Campaign.aspx\"><span>Google AdWords</span></a> or some other platform.</p> \n<p>You don’t need to tackle these items step-by-step, but you will need to work through each of them to ensure that you create an effective marketing campaign.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/image-png-Jun-08-2021-01-02-26-45-PM.png\" alt=\"How to build a PPC campaign\"></p> \n<h3>Set Parameters</h3> \n<p>I know I said that you don’t need to do these things in order, but you should do this step first. Without parameters, you risk your ad being untargeted and ineffective.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>You want to put your ad campaigns into the context of your ultimate business goals. Consider how your paid campaigns will contribute to those goals. Then, think about what you want to accomplish with your ads — whether that be visits, sales, brand awareness, or something else — and how much you’re willing to spend to achieve that goal.</p> \n<p>Your ads should encompass a few things:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Who you want to target</li> \n <li>Theme of your campaign</li> \n <li>How you will measure success</li> \n <li>Type of campaign you will run</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Create Goals and Goal Metrics</h3> \n<p>Your campaign goals will give you something to show for your ad spend as long as you determine <em>how</em> you will measure those goals. Your goal metrics should not be confused with your campaign metrics, which we’ll discuss below.</p> \n<p>Let’s touch on some common PPC goals and how to measure them.</p> \n<p><strong>Brand awareness</strong> is how familiar your target audience is with your company. It might be a good idea to look into display ads for this goal so you can supplement your copy with engaging imagery. You can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-awareness\">measure brand awareness</a> through social engagement, surveys, and direct traffic.</p> \n<p><strong>Lead generation</strong> is the direct result of having a relevant and engaging landing page to follow your paid ad. Since you will create a separate landing page for each ad group, you should be able to easily track lead conversions either in the Google Ads interface via a tracking pixel, or through <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">UTM parameters</a>, if you’re using a tool like HubSpot.</p> \n<p><strong>Offer promotion</strong> is great if you’re running a limited-time offer, product or service discount, or contest. You should create a dedicated sign-up page or a unique discount code so you know which users came from your ad.</p> \n<p><strong>Sales</strong> can be measured by how much of your product or service is sold based on your paid ads. You should be able to track this through <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/cms\">CMS software</a> or with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/attribution-reports-definition\">attribution reporting</a>.</p> \n<p><strong>Site traffic</strong> is a great goal if you have high-quality content throughout your website. If you’re going to spend money getting people to visit your site, you want to have some level of confidence that you can keep them there and eventually convert them into leads.</p> \n<h3>Choose Your Campaign Type</h3> \n<p>You don’t only need to know where you’ll advertise but also <em>how</em>. There are many different types of paid advertising campaigns, and the one you choose depends on where you can reach your audience. That isn’t to say that you can’t advertise through various means; you can also try a combination of campaign types as long as you’re consistently testing and revising.</p> \n<p><strong>Search Ads</strong> are the most common type of PPC and refer to the text ads that show up on search engine results pages.</p> \n<p><strong>Display Ads</strong> allow you to place ads (usually image-based) on external websites, including social. There are several ways to buy <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-use-online-advertising-effectively\">display ads</a>, including Google Display Network (GDN) and other ad networks.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-use-online-advertising-effectively?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Learn how to integrate Display Ads into your inbound marketing plan.</em></a></p> \n<p><strong>Social</strong> refers to any ads that you see on social media, including Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter, and Instagram. You can pay to show up in your target audience’s social feed or somewhere else within their profile, depending on the platform.</p> \n<p><strong>Remarketing</strong> can use either cookies or a list of contacts that you upload to target people who have previously engaged with your company through some action. That action could be filling out a form, reading a blog, or simply visiting a page on your website.</p> \n<p><strong>Google Shopping</strong> is most <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ppc-opportunities-ecommerce-marketers\">effective for ecommerce sites</a>. Your ad — including image, price, and a short product description — will show on a carousel on a search page based on your target keywords.</p> \n<h3>Perform Keyword Research</h3> \n<p>Each ad group you create needs to be assigned a set of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-keyword-research-ht\">keywords to target</a> — that’s how search engines know when and where to display your ad. The general rule of thumb is to select between one to five keywords per ad group, and those keywords should be extremely relevant — your Quality Score depends on it.</p> \n<p>Select keywords that are closely aligned with the specific theme of your ad group. If you find keywords you want to target that fall outside of one theme, you should create a separate ad group for them.</p> \n<p>It’s important to note that you’re not stuck with the keywords you start with. In fact, you should closely monitor your keyword list throughout your campaign — eliminating those that don’t bring in the types of visitors that you’re looking for and increasing your bids on those that do. Do your best to select the most relevant keywords, but don’t feel pressured to get it 100% right the first time around.</p> \n<h3>Set Up Google Analytics and Tracking</h3> \n<p>Google Analytics is free to use, so there’s no reason why you shouldn’t <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1008015?hl=en\">install it on your website</a>. The tool provides insights into how your website is performing, how users interact with your pages, and what content is attractive to visitors. The information gathered from Google Analytics can be used for PPC and beyond.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Best Practices for a Quality PPC Strategy</h2> \n<p>You didn’t think we’d let you spend your hard-earned money on advertisements without providing some best practices to follow, did you? Of course not. We want to make sure you succeed with your next PPC campaign. So, let’s get into some PPC strategies that will help you maximize your efforts <em>and</em> your budget.</p> \n<p>As a note, we’re going to dive specifically into paid search ads (those little guys you see in search engines) here.</p> \n<h3>PPC Ad Copy</h3> \n<p>Bidding on targeted keywords will get your ad in front of the right people; <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-create-click-ppc-ads-ht\">good ad copy</a> will get those people to click on your ad. Like your keywords, your ad needs to solve for the intent of the searcher — you need to give the searcher exactly what they’re looking for <em>and</em> make sure that is clear through the words you use.</p> \n<p>Search ads are comprised of a headline, a URL, and a short description, and each of these has limited <a href=\"https://support.google.com/adspolicy/answer/6021630?hl=en\">character requirements</a> to follow. To make the most of this space, make sure your ad copy does the following:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Speak directly to your target persona.</li> \n <li>Include the main keyword that you’re bidding on.</li> \n <li>Provide an actionable CTA so the searcher knows what to do next.</li> \n <li>Make the offer appealing.</li> \n <li>Use language that matches your landing page copy.</li> \n <li>Perform A/B Split tests with your copy.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Landing Page Best Practices</h3> \n<p>Arguably the most important element of PPC (after your ad copy) is the page that you send leads to <em>after</em> they click on your ad. This page needs to be highly targeted, relevant to your ad, deliver what was promised, and present a seamless experience.</p> \n<p><em>Why?</em> Because the point of your landing page is to <a href=\"https://www.impactbnd.com/blog/landing-page-examples\">convert your new visitor</a> into a lead or customer. Not only that, but a high-converting landing page will improve your Quality Score, leading to better ad placements. There’s nothing that will diminish PPC profits like a poorly crafted landing page.</p> \n<p>What should a PPC landing page include to increase conversions? Glad you asked.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Strong headline that mirrors your search ad</li> \n <li>Clean design and layout</li> \n <li>Responsive form that is easy to use with a stand-out CTA button</li> \n <li>Copy that is very specific and relevant to your target keywords</li> \n <li>Presents the offer that was promised in your ad</li> \n <li>A/B tested</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>A/B Testing Your PPC Ads</h3> \n<p>As a marketer, you’ll rarely throw something out to your audience that works without testing it. PPC campaigns are no different. A/B testing is as critical to your paid ad campaign as is every other element. The goal of testing your ad is to increase both your clickthrough rate and your conversion rate.</p> \n<p>The good news is that ads comprise just four parts that you’ll need to test: headline, description, landing page, and target keywords. Minor tweaks to just one of these elements can significantly alter your results, so you want to make changes one at a time so you can keep track of where improvements come from.</p> \n<p>Since there are many variations that you could test one at a time, it’s a good idea to list out all the potential tests you can run and prioritize them by most significant impact. Finally, you should allow your ads to run long enough to gather the data you need and test them early enough, so you don’t waste budget on a poor-performing ad.</p> \n<h3>Maximizing Your ROI</h3> \n<p>At a high level, maximizing ROI on your ad campaigns means considering customer lifetime value and customer acquisition costs, which will help you determine how much is worth spending on a new lead and how much of that spend can come from paid advertising.</p> \n<p>To get more granular, we need to talk inputs and outputs, that is 1) lowering your input (cost per lead [CPL]) and 2) increasing your return (revenue).</p> \n<p>There are a few factors to keep an eye on that will affect both, so let’s break it down.</p> \n<h4>Ways to Decrease Inputs</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Determine an <a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2013/08/29/ppc-budget-guide\">ad budget</a> before you get started.</li> \n <li>Create more relevant ads. The more relevant, the lower your CPC.</li> \n <li>Improve your Quality Score. The <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-save-ppc-quality-score-ht\">higher your QS</a>, the less search engines will charge you for clicks.</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Ways to Increase Revenue</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Follow landing page best practices to increase conversion rates.</li> \n <li>Go after quality leads by being specific with your ad. The more quality your leads, the more likely they will convert and eventually become customers.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Additional PPC Tips and Tricks</h3> \n<p>There are a few other things you can do to maximize the ROI of your paid ads, whether it’s time spent, budget, clicks, or conversions.</p> \n<h4>Audiences</h4> \n<p>Google allows you to <a href=\"https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/2611404?hl=en\">tailor your audience</a> so you save marketing dollars <em>and</em> get in front of the right people. You can upload a customer list so that you don’t waste money on people who have already bought from you.</p> \n<p>Google also has options for prospecting audiences. For instance, <a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/products/in-market-audiences/\">In-Market Audiences</a> employs user behavior tracking to put you in front of prospects who are in the market for a product or service like yours.</p> \n<p>You can also increase your bid for more relevant subgroups within your target audience — a practice called layering audiences. For example, HubSpot may layer on people who are in the market for CRM software and add a 30% bid adjustment because those people may be more likely to convert.</p> \n<h4>Bid Adjustments</h4> \n<p>Bid adjustments allow you to increase or decrease your bids based on performance. You can even make these adjustments based on different categories, like device, demographics, language, and more.</p> \n<p>For example, if a keyword isn’t performing as well on mobile as on desktop, you can add a negative bid adjustment so that when someone searches your keyword on mobile, you’ll bid X% lower than your normal bid.</p> \n<h4>Custom Ad Scheduling</h4> \n<p>You can set up <a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/6372656?hl=en&amp;co=ADWORDS.IsAWNCustomer%3Dfalse\">ad scheduling in Google Ads</a> to display your ad only during specific days and times. This can cut down on ad spend and improve relevance for your target audience.</p> \n<h4>Sitelink Extensions</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/2375416?hl=en\">Sitelink extensions</a> allow you to supplement your ad with additional information. For instance, if you’re running an ad for a seasonal promotion at a local store, you can add a sitelink extension to display your store hours and location. These extensions take up more real estate on SERPs and, therefore, stand out. Not only that, but they play a role in improving your Ad Rank.</p> \n<h4>Conversion Tracking</h4> \n<p>Conversion tracking monitors how your landing page is performing via a tracking code that you place on the page where people land after completing your form (usually a “Thank You” page). By <a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2014/02/13/tracking-conversions-in-adwords\">enabling this feature</a>, you’ll be better equipped to make adjustments that can improve your conversions.</p> \n<h4>Keyword Monitoring</h4> \n<p>Don’t let too much time pass before you check how your keywords are performing. You can place higher bids on the keywords that are creating the best results for your campaign, and “defund” or eliminate others.</p> \n<h4>Match Types</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/6337842?hl=en\">Match Types in Google Ads</a> allows you to choose how closely related you want your ad group to be associated with a search team. There are four match types: broad, modified broad, phrase, and exact match. Google will display your ad in results according to your selection.</p> \n<p>For example, if your keyword phrase is “how to catch geese” and you select “broad match,” then Google will display your ad for queries that include any word in your key phrase in any order, including “geese catch” and “geese catch how.”</p> \n<h4>Negative Keywords</h4> \n<p>A negative keyword list tells search engines what you <em>don’t </em>want to rank for, which is equally as important as what you do. You might know some of these upfront, but likely you’ll determine these keywords by what isn’t performing so well within your campaign.</p> \n<h3>Social Media Ads</h3> \n<p>Although CPM is more common on social platforms, social media sites do offer PPC that works similarly to search engine ads in that you set a budget and bid on ad placements.</p> \n<p>The difference is social media ads can show up directly in your news feed on most platforms, decreasing the effectiveness of ad blockers. Social platforms, like Facebook, let you set targeted demographics and target people based on interests. While paid search is more keyword-focused, paid social broadens into a demographic focus, leading to more ways to target your persona.</p> \n<p>Social media has two paid ad functions that are critical to ad success — retargeting and <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/a/lookalike-audiences\">Lookalike Audiences</a>. Retargeting is remarketing to people based on site visits or manually uploaded contact lists. Lookalike Audiences reviews the people on your marketing list and creates an audience that parallels your list, expanding your potential target. Paid social also allows for a wider variety of ad types, like images, videos, text, and more.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>PPC Management and Tracking</h2> \n<p>Paid advertising is not “set it and forget it.” You need to manage and constantly monitor your ads to ensure that you’re reaching optimal results. Management, analysis, and tracking are crucial to a PPC campaign because they provide you with valuable insights and help you create a more effective campaign.</p> \n<h3>What is PPC management?</h3> \n<p>PPC management covers a wide range of techniques, including creating and adjusting goals, split testing, introducing new keywords, optimizing conversion paths, and shifting plans to reach goals.</p> \n<p>Managing your PPC means looking at your strategy and ad spend. On the one hand, it means iterating on your plan to optimize keyword effectiveness. On the other hand, it means thinking about how to allocate resources to specific keywords and how to adjust those resources to maximize ROI.</p> \n<p>A good management strategy also pays attention to providers — like search engines, social platforms, and ad networks — to monitor changes and updates that could affect paid campaigns.</p> \n<p>Overall, PPC management is a hefty undertaking, which is why investing in solid PPC management tools could be a great idea.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/template-managing-and-organizing-google-adwords-campaigns?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Use our PPC management tool to monitor all of your paid campaigns.</em></a></p> \n<h3>PPC Tools and Software</h3> \n<p>With all of the variables that you need to track, PPC management tools should make things easier. You can opt to monitor your ads within the platform, but if you’re looking for additional assistance and organization, a robust, easy-to-read spreadsheet or sophisticated software that gives you insight into your ad performance is vital.</p> \n<p>If you plan to go the software route, there are some features that you want to look for: multi-user support, cross-platform management, A/B testing, scheduling, reporting, and ad grading.</p> \n<p>Here’s a list of some popular, highly-rated PPC software and resources.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/template-managing-and-organizing-google-adwords-campaigns?_ga=2.66692782.1265650744.1541980008-1486891521.1541011710\">HubSpot</a> offers a robust template to help you monitor and manage the moving parts of your campaign, making it easy to keep track of your ad groups, keywords, and A/B tests.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/ppc-software\">WordStream</a> automates the tedious parts of setting up and managing your PPC campaign.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.ninjacat.io/\">NinjaCat</a> lets you combine all of your analytics from multiple platforms into one report so you can track your entire campaign in one location.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.optmyzr.com\">Optmyzr</a> has end-to-end PPC support, from creation to reporting, and it offers a free trial of its software.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.semrush.com/features/ppc-keyword-tool/\">SEMRush</a> can help you manage the most important part of your PPC campaign — keywords. You can find relevant keywords, manage and optimize your keyword lists, and create negative lists.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.unbounce.com/\"><span>Unbounce</span></a> is a landing page builder you can use to create landing pages for each of your different PPC campaigns.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.databox.com/\"><span>Databox</span></a> helps businesses track the performance of their ads and displays key metrics across a single dashboard. You can also use Databox’s predictive analysis to estimate how well your ads would do in the future.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.ahrefs.com/\">Ahrefs</a> is more than just another SEO tool. You can use Ahrefs to check how well your PPC ads are performing. You can also spy on your competitors’ keywords with Ahrefs.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://about.ads.microsoft.com/en-us/solutions/tools/editor\"><span>Microsoft Advertising Editor</span></a> (formerly Bing Ad Editor) is a management tool for PPC ads you run through Bing. With this tool, you can manage your bids, research keywords, and make changes to your ads.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>PPC Metrics to Track</h3> \n<p>Metrics are everything (but you already knew that). Here are some key metrics to track within your PPC campaign.</p> \n<p><strong>Clicks</strong> refer to the total number of clicks you receive on an ad. This metric is affected by your keyword selection and the relevance of your ad copy.</p> \n<p><strong>Cost per click (CPC)</strong> measures the price you pay for each click on your ad.</p> \n<p><strong>Clickthrough rate (CTR)</strong> is the percentage of ad views that result in clicks. This metric determines how much you pay (CPC). <a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2010/04/26/good-click-through-rate\">CTR benchmarks</a> vary by industry.</p> \n<p><strong>Impressions</strong> are the number of times an ad is viewed. Cost per mille (CPM) is determined for every thousand impressions. Impressions are most relevant for brand awareness campaigns.</p> \n<p><strong>Ad spend</strong> is the amount you are spending on your ads. You can optimize this by improving your Quality Score.</p> \n<p><strong>Return on ad spend (ROAS)</strong> is the ROI of your ad campaign. This metric calculates the revenue received for every dollar spent on ads.</p> \n<p><strong>Conversion rate </strong>refers to the percentage of people that complete the call-to-action on your landing page and become a lead or customer.</p> \n<p><strong>Cost per conversion</strong> refers to the cost to generate a lead. This is calculated as the total cost of an ad divided by the number of conversions.</p> \n<p><strong>Quality Score (QS)</strong> determines ad positioning, so it’s an important metric to keep an eye on.</p> \n<p>By paying close attention to each of these metrics, you can increase the ROI of your paid campaign and spend less for better results.</p> \n<h2>Go Paid!</h2> \n<p>Whether you just started your business yesterday or have been around for decades, PPC just might be the boost you need to get an edge on your competition — or at least ahead of them in the SERPs.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Applying the lessons found in this guide about building a PPC campaign and the best practices for a quality PPC strategy would set you well on your way to improving your website’s traffic and conversions.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August, 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=c5cea574-dc9b-436a-8cc5-0d208bf2cbd9&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/c5cea574-dc9b-436a-8cc5-0d208bf2cbd9.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img
