\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 01 Jul 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3242765b-a13a-461a-954d-510ce203b180.png","linkMd5":"a06363ccca0ae63185cadba8d36a0f75","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn25@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-589_37786f1e2b3f2dfc.webp","destWidth":630,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":5566,"destBytes":9538,"author":"cperricone@hubspot.com (Christina Perricone)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3242765b-a13a-461a-954d-510ce203b180.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn25@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-589_37786f1e2b3f2dfc.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/example%20of%20paid%20vs%20organic%20ads.jpg?width=1500&name=example%20of%20paid%20vs%20organic%20ads.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn87@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-50-517_39ca042254195473.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/maximum%20ad%20bid%20example%20.jpg?width=500&name=maximum%20ad%20bid%20example%20.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn55@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-50-395_9790c385d1e31885.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/cleaning%20supplies%20google%20ads%20ppc%20example.jpg?width=1500&name=cleaning%20supplies%20google%20ads%20ppc%20example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-51-290_fcb2f736d2d21cc0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/great%20coffee%20at%20home%20bing%20ppc%20ad%20example.jpg?width=1500&name=great%20coffee%20at%20home%20bing%20ppc%20ad%20example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn21@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-53-579_47c81c269f7b69f4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/example%20of%20ppc%20ads%20on%20facebook.jpg?width=1500&name=example%20of%20ppc%20ads%20on%20facebook.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn4@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-52-435_0015d77ec5ebbed6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/example%20of%20ad%20roll.jpg?width=1500&name=example%20of%20ad%20roll.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn1@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-48-947_7d21afe15b08f06f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/image-png-Jun-08-2021-01-02-26-45-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn61@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-49-297_3df02a2013179405.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/c5cea574-dc9b-436a-8cc5-0d208bf2cbd9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn34@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-50-873_c90fcbcd44a0eec6.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fppc&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn53@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-50-751_d6cfcaf02d00c911.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938142},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"5 Steps to Build an Enterprise Data Strategy, Straight From an Expert","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/enterprise-data-strategy","description":"<p>Data can be a scary word.</p> \n<p>It shouldn't be, but it is. Mostly because people struggle with how to manage it.</p> \n<p>Many companies have reached the point where they have so much data, they don't know where to go next. Others believe they are so small, there's no need to invest in an enterprise data strategy.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5f39f863-0316-486f-a5f3-849d76490a30&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Free Growth Strategy Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f39f863-0316-486f-a5f3-849d76490a30.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>The truth is, regardless of the size of your company and the current state of your data, you will benefit from implementing a data strategy.</p> \n<p>To help you get started, we've enlisted the expertise of <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/zosia-kossowski-02567140/\">Zosia Kossowski</a>, the group product manager for the business intelligence team at HubSpot (i.e. our in-house data strategy expert.)</p> \n<p>By the time you finish reading this article, you'll have a better idea of your company's current data maturity level, what factors to consider before you build your strategy, and some steps to help along the way.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Despite popular belief, an enterprise data strategy isn't solely for big companies with large volumes of data. In fact, small businesses can benefit from investing in a data strategy early on and set the foundation that will help them scale.</p> \n<h2>Benefits of an Enterprise Data Strategy</h2> \n<p>The common pitfall many organizations face is that while they are collecting a lot of data, every team is interpreting it in their own way. There's no standard reporting method and each team might be reporting a different value for the same metric.</p> \n<p>This means that everyone ends up with different data with no clear understanding of what's accurate. When there's no single source of truth, it becomes incredibly difficult to trust your data and pull valuable insights.</p> \n<p>\"Data doesn't just exist in a silo,\" said Kossowski. \"The marketing team is not just going to use marketing-specific data that no other team has any influence over. They're going to want to pull information from different areas as well.\"</p> \n<p>She continues, \"And so, an element of governance and standardization and a common language is really important in making sure that those teams can communicate with one another.\"</p> \n<p>So, by implementing an EDS, you prevent information silos, allow for trust in the data, and enable decision making.</p> \n<h2>What To Consider When Building an Enterprise Data Strategy</h2> \n<h3>1. Your Current Data Maturity Level</h3> \n<p>The first thing Kossowski recommends doing before building out your strategy is a self-assessment.</p> \n<p>Ask yourself: Where does your company fall in the data maturity stage?</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.delltechnologies.com/en-us/index.htm\">Dell </a>has a widely used \"Data Maturity Model\" that helps companies determine how data-driven their company actually is. There are four stages:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Data aware </strong>– Your company has not standardized its reporting system and there's no integration between your systems, data sources, and databases. Plus, there's a lack of trust in the data itself.</li> \n <li><strong>Data proficient </strong>– There's still a lack of trust in the data, specifically its quality. You may have invested in a data warehouse but there are still some pieces missing.</li> \n <li><strong>Data savvy </strong>– Your company is empowered to make business decisions from your data. However, there are still some kinks to work out between business leaders and IT, as IT works to provide reliable data on demand.</li> \n <li><strong>Data driven </strong>– IT and business are working closely together and are on the same page. Now, the focus is on scaling the data strategy because the foundation work (particularly integrating data sources) has already been successfully implemented.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>What's most important here is being realistic about where your company falls.</p> \n<p>\"I think the biggest pitfall that I see is not being really honest with yourself about where your company is in the data maturity stage,\" said Kossowski.</p> \n<p>She adds that it's not enough to look at the feelings you have about how data driven you <em>think </em>your company is. Look at the facts.</p> \n<p>Start by identifying the data problems your company currently faces, as that is a great indicator of where you stand.</p> \n<h3>2. Your Industry and Company Size</h3> \n<p>The industry you're in and the size of your company will determine whether you take a centralized or distributed approach to your data strategy.</p> \n<p>But before we break down those approaches, let's talk about two data strategy frameworks: offense and defense.</p> \n<p>During my conversation with Kossowski, she brought up how this framework (explained in detail <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2017/05/whats-your-data-strategy\">here</a>) has helped HubSpot develop its own strategy.</p> \n<p>Data defense prioritizes things like data security, access, governance, and accuracy while data offense focuses on gaining insights that will enable decision making.</p> \n<p>Every company needs a balance of offense and defense. However, some lean more on one end of the spectrum based on their industry.</p> \n<p>A healthcare organization or financial institution, for instance, likely deals with highly sensitive data, where data privacy and security is paramount.</p> \n<p>Getting real-time data and quick insights is likely not a top priority whereas providing guardrails for who can access data probably is. As such, they will lean more toward a defense framework.</p> \n<p>On the flip side, you have tech companies, an industry that tends to move quickly and relies more heavily on a quick turnaround of data insights.</p> \n<p>So, they lean more on offense. With that said, there are certainly departments within tech companies (and other fast-moving industries) that will focus more on defense, such as finance.</p> \n<p>Now back to centralized and distributed strategies.</p> \n<p>The framework you use will inform which strategy serves your company best.</p> \n<p>In a centralized structure, you have a centralized reporting or business intelligence (BI) team that manages and prepares the data as well as the reports.</p> \n<p>\"That [structure] can work a lot better at a smaller organization, and especially in an organization that's prioritizing defense because you're going to move slower,\" said Kossowski. \"You're going to be the bottleneck but you also have tight control over every piece of it.\"</p> \n<p>A distributed model, on the other hand, works better for larger teams who take the offensive approach. This way, each team can move quickly and is empowered to do work in a way that works for them.</p> \n<p>In this model, BI simply is responsible for the platforms and setting the guardrails while the teams do the development work, Kossowski explains.</p> \n<p>\"If you think about an organization, as the company gets larger, with a more centralized team, it becomes more and more difficult to scale,\" she said. \"You end up having to just hire more and more people to be able to achieve that.\"</p> \n<p>\"So I think at a certain size of the company, you're going to end up moving more and more toward [a] decentralized [strategy] anyways.\"</p> \n<p>So, once you understand which framework works best for your industry and size, you can implement the appropriate strategy.</p> \n<h3>3. Your Data Management Team</h3> \n<p>Data science is the hot topic right now in data management, according to Kossowski. And she's not wrong.</p> \n<p>In 2012, Harvard Business Review named it <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2012/10/data-scientist-the-sexiest-job-of-the-21st-century\">the sexiest job of the 21st century</a>. Nearly 10 years later, <a href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/List/Best-Jobs-in-America-LST_KQ0,20.htm\">Glassdoor </a>has named it the second best job in America.</p> \n<p>But if you're debating what role to add to your data management team, a data scientist shouldn't be your first option.</p> \n<p>Kossowski highlights that your data science is only going to be as good as the data that's powering it. And if that data isn't trustworthy, you're not going to get valuable insights.</p> \n<p>\"Data science is not a magic wand that magically turns bad data into insights. Regardless, you're still going to need that data foundation,\" she adds. \"So, jumping into doing something because it's the next big thing, I think that's a big concern.\"</p> \n<p>If you're in the earlier stages of the data maturity model, Kossowski has a suggestion on where to focus your efforts.</p> \n<p>\"A data warehouse architect or even a data analyst who is experienced in writing SQL and building out SQL tables,\" she says. \"If you're only going to hire one person and you don't have that much data, that can be a really powerful hire because there's a lot that one person can do when you're at a smaller scale. They can wear many different hats and learn different things.\"</p> \n<p>When it comes to the more technical tasks, like ingesting data into the warehouse, there are third-party tools you can use to do that for you.</p> \n<p>At this stage, what you really need is someone to help you with structuring your data.</p> \n<h3>1. Outline your data architecture.</h3> \n<p>The first thing you want to do is understand your data at a granular level.</p> \n<p>Ask yourself these questions:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Where will the data live?</li> \n <li>What type of data will you be collecting and from what sources?</li> \n <li>How will the data be organized?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The goal here is to understand the structure of your data.</p> \n<p>If there's no understanding of the structure, you can't build a comprehensive plan on how to manage your data.</p> \n<h3>2. Define the relationship between BI and your teams.</h3> \n<p>When it comes to data strategy, one of the most important steps is defining the teams involved in the process and setting expectations for BI.</p> \n<p>In a large organization that hasn't thought about data strategy before, you'll often find that every team follows a different model and has a different relationship with BI, making it hard for BI to operate in a streamlined and standard fashion.</p> \n<p>It also blurs the lines between the roles of the data analyst and BI.</p> \n<p>The data analyst should know the business logic that is specific to their team and the structure of the data being collected. BI, on the other hand, shouldn't need to have specific knowledge on the operational area it is supporting, and should instead be focusing on the data source and managing the platform to support the analyst.</p> \n<p>When BI is regularly adjusting its process to match the team's specific business logic, it slows everything down and creates a constant need for relearning.</p> \n<p>Kossowki's suggestion? Strip the business logic out of the BI layer and work on things that are relevant to as many teams as possible.</p> \n<p>In addition, come up with a standard analyst profile and a model for the relationship between BI and teams.</p> \n<p>\"There are still going to be some places where we're working on data sets and not the whole platform,\" said Kossowski, \"but as much as we can, it's cleaning up the base data, making it easy to join, but not actually doing those joins and the logic for them.\"</p> \n<h3>3. Assign ownership.</h3> \n<p>After establishing the relationship between your teams and BI, the next step is defining who will own what.</p> \n<p>It's typical to have a different owner for each part of the data. For example, one person or team may own the operational data while another owns the reporting data.</p> \n<p>You may also need to assign owners at different stages in the pipeline. The BI team may own the data at a particular stage then pass it on to the analysts.</p> \n<p>Kossowski believes ownership starts with the teams who are producing the data.</p> \n<p>\"They need to feel some level of ownership over the data and have some level of accountability if something's wrong,\" she said. \"Because if it's wrong at the source, there's very little that BI can do.\"</p> \n<p>She continues, \"And if you try to put in patch patches at that level, you're just going to run into more problems down the line, so that relationship is important as well.\"</p> \n<h3>4. Establish data governance.</h3> \n<p>Data governance is a set of policies and regulations that inform how data will be collected and stored to ensure accuracy and quality.</p> \n<p>In simple terms, data governance is saying \"<em>Hey, you want to use and be a part of this source of truth data we've created? Then you've got to meet this criteria.</em>\"</p> \n<p>This can include meeting coding standards, having a certain number of reviewers, and following a specific documentation process.</p> \n<p>\"When we think about governance and adoption, it's really about the mechanisms you can put into place toward adherence,\" said Kossowski.</p> \n<p>There are two pieces that you have to consider when it comes to governance: the cultural piece and the technological aspect.</p> \n<p>From a cultural perspective, how do you get your teams to adopt these standards? And from a technical perspective, which processes can you automate so that everything does not require behavior modification?</p> \n<p>As you think of these two pieces, you have to consider both the analyst side and the engineer (or source team) side.</p> \n<p>Kossowski explains that for engineering teams, it can be hard to think about what data looks like when it comes into the warehouse because it's not a core part of their product or responsibility.</p> \n<p>They may not see the tangible benefits of the data unless it's a data-driven organization that works tightly with its analysts. In this case, the analysts can relay that the data is powering X decision, so until the data means Y requirements, decisions can't be made.</p> \n<p>For analysts, it's easier to see the benefits because they're closer to the business and can see the direct impact. They can realize that following data governance standards means less reliance on BI, which makes things move more quickly.</p> \n<p>\"The insights from the data have to be powering decisions being made about the product because that's the only way you're going to get the product and engineering teams</p> \n<p>bought into the value of data and thinking about their data as it is exported,\" said Kossowski.</p> \n<h3>5. Reassess regularly.</h3> \n<p>Wherever you fall on the data maturity model, your data strategy will always need some tweaking.</p> \n<p>\"[At HubSpot], we have a three-year plan and all these ideas of what happens in each of those years,\" said Kossowski. But I fully expect that a year from now, when we look at it, there are things we're going to want to tweak based on how things have changed.\"</p> \n<p>For instance, say you introduce a new feature in your product or service and now are collecting more sensitive customer data. This may require taking a more defensive approach. If your company grows exponentially, you may need to shift toward a distributed strategy instead of a centralized one.</p> \n<p>Even if there are no changes in how your company operates, you may still need to reassess. Here are two major indicators it's time to review your data strategy:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>There is frustration with how long things are taking.</li> \n <li>There's a lack of trust in the data.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Kossowski says finding the balance between those two is key.</p> \n<p>\"You don't want BI doing everything because then it's just going to take a long time,\" she said, \"but you also don't want to have so much freedom in the analyst population that you can't really rely on any data.\"</p> \n<p>A good rule of thumb is to review your strategy every six months to a year. Speak with business leaders, IT, and your teams to understand how everyone feels about your progress and determine what changes need to be made.</p> \n<p>The process for building an EDS will vary from one company to the next, as your data maturity level, industry, and company size all play a role in the steps you take.</p> \n<p>By taking stock of where your company currently stands, you can develop a strategy that meets the specific needs of your business.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b7b5fa30-b069-48d5-8c08-517ef6d0f6b0&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b7b5fa30-b069-48d5-8c08-517ef6d0f6b0.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fenterprise-data-strategy&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 01 Jul 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f39f863-0316-486f-a5f3-849d76490a30.png","linkMd5":"f5d5ff6533ab7cc286e5c10dbf86b878","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn44@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-355_fa30b986c2b6e15d.webp","destWidth":422,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":4889,"destBytes":6654,"author":"mbretous@hubspot.com (Martina Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f39f863-0316-486f-a5f3-849d76490a30.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn44@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-355_fa30b986c2b6e15d.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b7b5fa30-b069-48d5-8c08-517ef6d0f6b0.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn51@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-49-595_1b9fb426b1a877bc.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fenterprise-data-strategy&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn60@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-51-665_52855e66b57dfb01.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938151},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"How Consumer Spending Habits Could Change in 2021 [New Data]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/post-reopening-spending-habits","description":"<p>As businesses and economies closed down due to the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, consumers also tightened up their budgets.</p> \n<p>According to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/why-consumers-changed-brands-this-year?_ga=2.243549255.354359694.1623873392-1940116527.1623873392\">data from McKinsey</a>, most consumers were more conscientious about purchases than before the pandemic. Because of this, most households primarily budgeted around essential products and services.</p> \n<p>But, now, as economies begin to swiftly reopen following mass vaccinations, business owners and marketers might also be wondering what this could mean for the next year of revenue.</p> \n<p>Specifically, many business leaders are asking, \"Will consumers continue to spend cautiously, or will they spend more freely in 2021?\"</p> \n<p>To help businesses prepare and navigate for the coming months, I asked nearly 300 random consumers, \"Which best describes your budgeting plan for the next year?\"</p> \n<p>Here's what they said and tips for how to navigate future spending behaviors.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Download Now: State of Marketing in 2021 Report\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7.png\"></a></p> \n<h2>How Consumers Will Spend Money in the Next Year</h2> \n<p>As economies reopen, people return to work, and household revenues start to rise again, you might think that people will be racing to online or physical stores to shop for all the things they didn't have the budget for in 2020.</p> \n<p>However, when looking at the results of our small survey, it seems that people are cautiously optimistic about their 2021 budget.</p> \n<p>Although one-third of respondents say they plan to \"loosen\" their budgets and spend more money than they did in 2020, a whopping 43% plan to keep the same budget they had in 2020. Meanwhile, nearly one-quarter of respondents will tighten their budget and spend less money in the next year.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Consumer%20Spending%20Habits%20Could%20Change%20in%202021%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png\"><img alt=\"poll results for the question which best describes your budget plan for the next year with most respondents saying their budget will remain the same.\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Consumer%20Spending%20Habits%20Could%20Change%20in%202021%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png?width=600&amp;name=How%20Consumer%20Spending%20Habits%20Could%20Change%20in%202021%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 600px;\" title=\"\" width=\"600\"></a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 10px;\"><em><a href=\"http://luc.id\" style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Data Source</a></em></p> \n<p>If you sell non-essential products or services or rely on your customers to have a larger budget, you shouldn't panic just yet. Keep in mind that this is just one small survey of a random consumer group. Additionally, had we polled people in different industries, locations, or age ranges, the results might have been different.</p> \n<p>However, what this survey does remind us of is that people are still more conscientious than ever about the products and services they're purchasing -- and likely will remain that way for months to come.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, to turn audiences into customers, it's still more important than ever to market your offering's value -- even if you don't sell something that's considered \"essential.\"</p> \n<h2>Tips for Marketing Your Product or Service in Uncertain Financial Times</h2> \n<h3>1. Make your value proposition a priority.</h3> \n<p>When someone is on a tight budget, each dollar they spend has to be worth it. This means that the products or services they buy have to help them do something essential, solve a common pain point, save them time or money, or fulfill other major needs.</p> \n<p>As a marketer or business owner, it's important to learn the ins and outs of your buyer persona, their needs, and what motivates them to make a purchase. Then, you must use your messaging to explain why your offering will be worth their money.</p> \n<h3>2. Differentiate yourself from competitors.</h3> \n<p>As a budget-minded person myself, I -- like many others -- do detailed research before purchasing a product or service. When I decide I need to buy something, I look at all the brands that sell it, their reviews, and the product's cost. While I might buy the cheapest version of something, I also might consider a higher-end version of a product if something about it is better quality than the more affordable option.</p> \n<p>For example, I recently helped my parents pick out their first smart TV. While almost all of today's smart TVs have similar apps and features, we chose a Roku TV because Roku's marketing emphasized a simple, easy-to-understand user interface and setup. While it was also quite affordable, the UX alone was the reason for purchasing it over other competitors. &nbsp;</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Roku TV web page showing Roku UX and how the product easily works.\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Consumer%20Spending%20Habits%20Could%20Change%20in%202021%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png?width=624&amp;name=How%20Consumer%20Spending%20Habits%20Could%20Change%20in%202021%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\"></p> \n<p>As a marketer, it's important to remember that people look into many different factors when making a purchase decision -- especially when it will be a larger investment. And, sometimes, the price of the product isn't the only deciding factor. That's why it's important to market elements of your product that are different or better than a competitor's.</p> \n<h3>3. Leverage customer-generated content.</h3> \n<p>If you're struggling to differentiate your product or service, but know you have loyal customers who love your brand, leverage them in your marketing.</p> \n<p>Research shows that prospects trust <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/user-generated-content-stats\">customer reviews, videos, how-tos, and other user-generated content</a> similarly to how they'd trust a word-of-mouth recommendation. Ultimately, when a prospect sees that someone like them has benefited from your brand's offerings, they trust that you sell something of good quality and value and might be more motivated to buy your product than a cheaper alternative from a competitor with poor or minimal reviews.</p> \n<p>Need some examples of how to collect and market excellent UGC, testimonials, or reviews? <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-reviews-testimonials\">Check out this guide</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>4. Consider discounts or sales.</h3> \n<p>If your brand can afford to offer small discounts or sales, this can be a great way to attract people with tighter budgets to your brand. Even if your discounts or sales are temporary, a prospect might purchase an on-sale product, love its quality, and return to the brand later because they've gained a sense of trust and loyalty to it.</p> \n<p>If it isn't possible to offer sales or discounted services, you could also consider a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/update-7-customer-loyalty-programs-that-actually-add-value\">customer loyalty or rewards program</a>&nbsp;that allows frequent shoppers to eventually receive a free or heavily discounted product. This way, they might feel like every penny they spend could go towards a reward in the future.</p> \n<h3>5. Highlight your brand's mission or purpose.</h3> \n<p>In 2020, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/why-consumers-changed-brands-this-year?_ga=2.187788394.354359694.1623873392-1940116527.1623873392\">the same McKinsey survey</a>&nbsp;mentioned at the beginning of this post, also found that people were beginning to also shop at brands that shared a similar set of values to their own. With this in mind, it's becoming more common for brands to invest in purpose-driven marketing, or campaigns that highlight a mission, purpose, or set of values the company is serious about.</p> \n<p>For example, Kréyol, a Black woman-run fashion brand, embraces Haitian culture and global female empowerment with its clothing and product lines. The company's \"For women, by women\" mission aims to improve the lives of women, artisans, and entrepreneurs around the globe by featuring their clothing and designs on the Kréyol site.</p> \n<p>\"The whole idea behind Kréyol was for me to be able to provide a platform for artisans, specifically women of color, to be able to highlight the wonderful work that they do,” CEO Joelle Wendy Fontaine said <a href=\"https://www.baystatebanner.com/2020/11/25/joelle-fontaines-kreyol-collection-celebrates-diverse-female-artisans/\">in an interview</a>.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 600px; max-height: 339px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.5%; margin: 0px;\">\n   <iframe width=\"200\" height=\"113\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/NVDmR6stjoE?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </div>\n</div> \n<p>While Kréyol's marketing and business strategy spreads awareness of beautiful artisan fashion, prospects might also be more driven to support the brand because of its trustworthy and authentic mission to improve the lives of women around the world.</p> \n<h2>Navigating Changing Purchasing Behaviors</h2> \n<p>As the world continues to reopen and evolve following the pandemic, so will spending habits. While some people will start to begin spending more, others will remain cautious for the next year or beyond.</p> \n<p>As a marketer or business owner, you'll need to listen to your audiences and continue to follow data about your target persona's to learn how their approaches to money are changing and what efforts you'll need to take on to continue to win them over.</p> \n<p>To learn more about the latest marketing trends and consumer behaviors, check out our recently published State of Marketing Report.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"state of marketing\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fpost-reopening-spending-habits&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 28 Jun 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7.png","linkMd5":"57b76bbad2f41846fcfe30a4648a7845","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn5@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-586_88b93bfb7be7b212.webp","destWidth":442,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5404,"destBytes":7216,"author":"pbump@hubspot.com (Pamela Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn5@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-586_88b93bfb7be7b212.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Consumer%20Spending%20Habits%20Could%20Change%20in%202021%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png?width=600&name=How%20Consumer%20Spending%20Habits%20Could%20Change%20in%202021%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn43@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-51-733_4fb267f0d0737ec1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Consumer%20Spending%20Habits%20Could%20Change%20in%202021%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png?width=624&name=How%20Consumer%20Spending%20Habits%20Could%20Change%20in%202021%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn49@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-49-012_0c1244a80e830946.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn78@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-48-782_ba6ee21c8b9c368e.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fpost-reopening-spending-habits&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn23@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-50-273_f6b9fe3761c36dac.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938136},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"Facebook Analytics is Going Away: Should Marketers Really Worry?","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-analytics-discontinued","description":"<p>As marketers, we crave data.</p>  \n<p>Each day, our analytics platforms help us define who our audience is, measure how well we’re tracking them, and determine what strategies we should take on next.</p> \n<p>And, if an analytics platform is free or affordable to use, that’s an even bigger bonus to teams in SMBs or startups.</p> \n<p>That’s why many marketers were caught off-guard when <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/966883707418907\">Facebook announced</a> that it will be sunsetting its free Facebook Analytics tool on June 30th.</p> \n<p>But, while Facebook’s announcement might seem a bit scary, it might only impact a small number of businesses.</p> \n<p>\"Even though this tool is going away, we continue to invest in measurement products that provide insights and data analysis capabilities,\" the short <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/966883707418907\">Facebook announcement</a> said.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Below, we’ll explain why Facebook's removing its Analytics feature, why you might not need to panic, and alternatives you can use to get similar data about your audiences.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3dc1dfd9-2cb4-4498-8c57-19dbb5671820&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Social Media Trends in 2021 [Free Report]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3dc1dfd9-2cb4-4498-8c57-19dbb5671820.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2>Why Facebook is Sunsetting Analytics</h2> \n<p>Facebook Analytics launched in 2018 as a free alternative to platforms like Google Analytics (GA). On top of tracking all your Facebook Business Page data in one place, users could also create and embed Facebook tracking pixels on their websites to see how audiences behaved and what their customer journey looked like.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://oneppcagency.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Facebook-Analytics-UI-1024x528.png\" alt=\"Facebook Analytics UI\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://oneppcagency.co.uk/facebook-ads/facebook-analytics/\" style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><em>Image Source</em></a></p> \n<p>Facebook Analytics could also give brands a look at your Facebook page’s details and audience demographics to help brands better inform their strategies.</p> \n<p>Because much of the information shown on Facebook Analytics can now be found through other competitive and affordable data platforms — as well as Facebook’s Insights, Business Suite, Ads Manager, and Events Manager — Facebook decided to discontinue Analytics in an effort to <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/966883707418907\">consolidate its tools</a>.</p> \n<p>While Facebook hasn’t said if online privacy trends were a factor in its decision, the pivot comes at a time when Google and Apple have already begun to limit data tracking through the planned <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/third-party-cookie-phase-out?_ga=2.30497151.1379079422.1624456662-2110117211.1624456662\">phase-out of third-party cookies</a>&nbsp;and Apple’s recent <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/apple-ios-release-and-privacy-change?_ga=2.222958939.1379079422.1624456662-2110117211.1624456662\">IOS 14.5 opt-in requirements</a>&nbsp;for mobile app tracking.</p> \n<p>Because of the ongoing moves towards data privacy, it seems that Facebook could also prevent future data concerns with the streamlining of nearly extraneous Analytics tools.</p> \n<h2>How Marketers Can Prepare</h2> \n<p>Until June 30, brands can still access Facebook Analytics and download reports of all the data they might need.</p> \n<p>To export data into a CSV file from Facebook Analytics on your desktop, click the [share icon] <span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">in the top-right corner of each chart or table,\" <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/966883707418907\">Facebook advises</a>.&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Aside from downloading data, brands that used the tool should also consider alternatives that can highlight similar data. Although Facebook Analytics was a helpful tool for some businesses looking for free or cheap platforms, there are affordable alternatives that can help you track your customer’s journey from social media to on-site conversion.</p> \n<p>Below is just a quick list of Facebook Analytics alternatives to consider.</p> \n<h2>Facebook Analytics Alternatives</h2> \n<h3>Free Tools</h3> \n<h4>Facebook Business Suite</h4> \n<p>Once Facebook Analytics is no more, Facebook will encourage Business Page admins to use its Business Suite, which allows users to connect and track <a href=\"https://business.facebook.com\">multiple Instagram and Facebook Business Pages</a>&nbsp;at once.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"Facebook Business Suite dashboard\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-1.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 10px;\"><em><a href=\"https://business.facebook.com/\" style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<p>At the moment, Facebook Business Suite is still rolling out and might not be available for some admins just yet. However, the tools below can help you fill your data gaps as you wait.</p> \n<h4>Facebook Insights</h4> \n<p>Facebook Insights is an analytics dashboard where you can track business page user behavior and post performance. You can also see insights like page views, post reach for paid and organic posts, and competitor page data.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Facebook Insights Dashboard\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-2.png?width=624&amp;name=Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-2.png\" style=\"margin-left: 0.00px;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\"></p> \n<p>If you have a Facebook Business Page, you’ve probably used Facebook Insights to gather data that can fuel your social media tactics. Luckily, Facebook says <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/966883707418907\">Insights won’t be impacted by the removal of Facebook Analytics</a>.</p> \n<p>To learn more about Facebook Insights if you’ve never used it before, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-insights?_ga=2.30497151.1379079422.1624456662-2110117211.1624456662\">check out this blog pos</a>t.</p> \n<h4>Facebook Ads and Events Managers</h4> \n<p>Facebook Ads Manager and Facebook Events Manager help you launch and track ads and website conversion events attached to your Facebook Business Page.</p> \n<p>While Ads Manager lets you view, edit, and track your Facebook campaigns, ads, and ad sets, Events Manager lets you use Facebook's pixel and Conversions API to track and report on actions visitors take on your website, app, or even in your physical store. To use Events Manager, you'll need to add the Facebook Pixel code to your website to make it trackable. Instructions for this can be found <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/898185560232180?id=1205376682832142\">on Facebook's business knowledge base</a>.</p> \n<h3>Paid Tools</h3> \n<h4>HubSpot</h4> \n<p><em><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/social-inbox?_conv_v=vi%3A1*sc%3A17*cs%3A1624455057*fs%3A1623688813*pv%3A74*seg%3A%7B10031564.1%7D*exp%3A%7B%7D*ps%3A1624377482&amp;_conv_s=si%3A17*sh%3A1624455057048-0.9975592202346393*pv%3A4&amp;_ga=2.194600557.1379079422.1624456662-2110117211.1624456662\">HubSpot’s Social Media Management Software</a></em> not only enables you to link and share posts on your Facebook account, but you can also track conversions and other engagements.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-analytics?_ga=2.194600557.1379079422.1624456662-2110117211.1624456662\">HubSpot's social media tools</a>&nbsp;can help you understand which of your marketing tactics are working best among your audience, determine how your marketing efforts are impacting your bottom line, see if your campaigns result in more paid or organic social media sessions, and learn about your search engine optimization (SEO)-related ROI.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"social media post analytics\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-3.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\"></p> \n<p>Additionally, if your website is built on HubSpot's CMS or has a HubSpot tracking code installed, you can track<a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/reports/analyze-your-site-traffic-with-the-traffic-analytics-tool\">&nbsp;site conversions, traffic, and traffic sources</a>&nbsp;to learn more about where your audiences are coming from and what they engage with.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"page analytics and traffic sources on HubSpot analytics\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\"></p> \n<h4>Google Analytics</h4> \n<p>While Google Analytics is often seen as a high-end analytics tool, it certainly has a lot of great features that have helped marketers around the globe to transform their strategy.</p> \n<p>While it will likely take a bit of onboarding and training for your team GA allows you to see traffic patterns, traffic sources, visitor demographics, and visitor behavior among a plethora of other helpful insights.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Google analytics panel showing traffic to a page\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-4.png?width=624&amp;name=Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-4.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\"></p> \n<p>For a crash course on Google Analytics with photos, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-analytics?_ga=2.235502273.1379079422.1624456662-2110117211.1624456662\">check out this Ultimate Guide</a>.</p> \n<h2>Navigating Data Software Shifts</h2> \n<p>As the world evolves towards more online privacy and streamlined technology, Facebook probably isn't&nbsp;the only platform that will change or evolve in years to come.</p> \n<p>As a modern marketer, it’s important to know when to invest in new analytics platforms, alternatives, or workarounds if the tools you use are no longer relevant.</p> \n<p>For tips on developing effective data-driven strategies, download the free resource below.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5fc2491c-cd3c-4adb-ad3c-b082ce2793d3&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5fc2491c-cd3c-4adb-ad3c-b082ce2793d3.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img (Pamela Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3dc1dfd9-2cb4-4498-8c57-19dbb5671820.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn22@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-374_ebc276d76ef14084.webp","https://oneppcagency.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Facebook-Analytics-UI-1024x528.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn70@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-48-902_8af060bdeefffba9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn31@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-48-780_652a2009a51277c6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-2.png?width=624&name=Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn38@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-50-793_8aa1cad0c0d1aa48.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-3.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn56@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-48-851_5e6fa7355fe8ddc7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-4.png?width=624&name=Facebook%20Analytics%20is%20Going%20Away%20Should%20Marketers%20Really%20Worry%3F-4.png":null,"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5fc2491c-cd3c-4adb-ad3c-b082ce2793d3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn52@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-51-882_73ab6e288063122a.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffacebook-analytics-discontinued&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn46@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-52-531_69506aecf349d909.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938149},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"The Top 7 Free Alternatives to Adobe Illustrator of 2021","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/adobe-free-alternatives","description":"<p>Adobe Illustrator is a popular tool for designing vector graphics, logos, icons, and more.</p> \n<p>But when you’re a web or graphic designer with a small budget, you probably can’t afford Adobe Illustrator’s steep <a href=\"https://www.adobe.com/products/illustrator/pricing-info.html\">$239.88/yr&nbsp;pricing</a>.</p> \n<p>Luckily, there are plenty of top-notch free alternatives on the market, some of which offer features unparalleled by Illustrator. In this post, we’re sharing the top seven free alternatives to Adobe Illustrator so you can produce beautiful designs on a budget.</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=06411f7b-e9c8-4b5c-a14a-51e6acf4bc72&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Take the crash course in visual content creation that delights customers on  every digital channel.\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/06411f7b-e9c8-4b5c-a14a-51e6acf4bc72.png\" align=\"middle\"></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>If you’re shopping for a program that offers features comparable in quality to Adobe’s product, check out our list of the top free alternatives to Illustrator.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://inkscape.org/en/\">Inkscape</a></h3> \n<p>One of the most comparable substitutes to Adobe Illustrator, Inkscape has plenty of similar sketching, illustrating, and editing tools, including keys to move and rotate by screen pixels, bitmap tracing, color painting over objects, and edit gradients with handles.</p> \n<p>You can create complex textures and gradients in Inkscape, too. Unlike some free tools, this tool allows layering, grouping, and locking objects so you can completely customize the look and feel of a project while maintaining a streamlined workflow.</p> \n<p>Inkscape is a quality product for pro- or semi-pro web designers working within SVG file format. It also offers an open source vector graphics package, so if you have the technical skills, you can incorporate Inkscape into your other software programs.</p> \n<h4>Best for:</h4> \n<p>Pro and semi-pro illustrators and web designers</p> \n<h4>Platform:</h4> \n<p>Mac, Windows, Linux</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Inkscape Free Adobe Illustrator Alternative\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-Jun-28-2021-09-57-33-69-PM.png?width=650&amp;name=The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-Jun-28-2021-09-57-33-69-PM.png\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://inkscape.org/~doctormo/%E2%98%85blur\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.gimp.org/\">GIMP</a></h3> \n<p>GIMP, which stands for GNU Image Manipulation Program, has limited vector functions but has similar tools to Photoshop, making it an impressive image editor with powerful image manipulation options. Better still, GIMP provides options for customization and third party plug-ins, so if your image editing needs are somewhat unique, you might want to check this tool out.</p> \n<p>GIMP is free and open source, so there is a market of third party plugins to enhance your productivity and design capabilities. If this sounds technically advanced, GIMP offers <a href=\"https://www.gimp.org/tutorials/\">tutorials for newcomers</a> to the tool so you get the most out of it.</p> \n<h4>Best for:</h4> \n<p>Advanced designers who need a custom tool to create illustrations and graphics</p> \n<h4>Platform:</h4> \n<p>Mac, Windows, Linux</p> \n<p><img alt=\"GIMP Free Adobe Illustrator Alternative\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-Jun-28-2021-09-57-33-11-PM.png?width=624&amp;name=The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-Jun-28-2021-09-57-33-11-PM.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\"></p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://boxy-svg.com/\">BoxySVG</a></h3> \n<p>BoxySVG runs as an extension in Google Chrome, so it’s easy to store vector graphics including icons, charts, and illustrations on the web. It provides options for Google Fonts integration and has an Open Clip Art Library, as well as illustrator tools including pens, bezier curves, groups, shapes, text, and more.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, BoxySVG is simpler than Illustrator, and while this means less advanced tools, it also means a quicker and easier process for creating vector graphic files.</p> \n<p>The intuitive user interface gives you a clean workspace so you can complete your workflow without clutter or overlapping toolboxes. Keyboard shortcuts keep tools accessible without switching between tabs or searching through several icons.</p> \n<p>The 15-day free trial includes these features. After that, you’ll have the option to purchase either the <a href=\"https://boxy-svg.com/\">premium or standard plan</a>.</p> \n<h4>Best used for:</h4> \n<p>Designers who produce a low volume of designs, but still need a quality tool</p> \n<h4>Platform:</h4> \n<p>Mac app, Windows app, Chrome app, Web app</p> \n<p><img alt=\"BoxySVG Free Adobe Illustrator Alternative\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-1.png?width=650&amp;name=The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-1.png\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\"></p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://pixlr.com/\">Pixlr</a></h3> \n<p>Pixlr offers plenty of features for editing, creating, and sharing creative images. While it’s less advanced in function than Illustrator, it’s cloud-based and supported on mobile, desktop, or the web.</p> \n<p>Pixlr has two options: Pixlr E for photo editing and Pixlr X for graphic design. Pixlr X includes regularly updated templates for social media, presentations, resumes, business cards, newsletters, and event invitations. Pixlr E includes a photo collage maker that combines your favorite photos into a clean, cohesive design.</p> \n<h4>Best used for:</h4> \n<p>Individuals whose position requires them to work from different devices to create images</p> \n<h4>Platform:</h4> \n<p>Windows, Mac, Web, Mobile</p> \n<h3><img alt=\"Pixlr Free Adobe Illustrator Alternative\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-3.png?width=650&amp;name=The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-3.png\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\"></h3> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://gravit.io/\">Gravit</a></h3> \n<p>You’ll find plenty of your basic vector-editing tools in Gravit, including pen, line, knife, slice, bezigon, gradient editor. It also has more advanced features, such as boolean operations, symbols, international text support, and more.</p> \n<p>Plus, it’s designed in a user-friendly interface and offers video tutorials. Gravit works from right within any browser, which means you can edit and export your files anywhere with wifi. It also supports cmyk rendering, so you can print quality images without downloading anything.</p> \n<p>You can also import and export files in a variety of formats including pdf, png, jpg, svg, and sketch — which makes this option more flexible than Illustrator.</p> \n<h4>Best used for:</h4> \n<p>Freelance illustrators and designers who need a robust design tool</p> \n<h4>Platform:</h4> \n<p>Mac, Linux, Windows, Chrome, Any Browser</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Gravit Free Adobe Illustrator Alternative\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-2.png?width=650&amp;name=The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-2.png\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\"></p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://affinity.serif.com/en-gb/designer/\">Affinity Designer</a></h3> \n<p>With rasterizing controls, infinite zooming, a precision-engineered pen tool, automatic snapping points, colors that pop, and an extensive array of vector editing tools, this system truly compares in design and function to Adobe Illustrator. The full version is $49.99, but the 90-day trial version is free and offers plenty of the full version tools.</p> \n<p>What’s unique about this tool is that it supports vector and raster workspaces — with the click of a button you can switch between the two for a versatile design experience.</p> \n<p>Your workflow is the foundation of a great design, so Affinity Designer gives you unlimited artboards, detailed version history, customizable keyboard shortcuts, and the ability to save your file in the most popular vector and raster formats.</p> \n<h4>Best used for:</h4> \n<p>Experienced designers with a need for advanced vector and raster tools</p> \n<h4>Platform:</h4> \n<p>Mac, Windows, iPad</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Affinity Design Free Adobe Illustrator Alternative\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-4.png?width=650&amp;name=The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021-4.png\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\"></p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://www.designevo.com/\">DesignEvo</a></h3> \n<p>Although this design tool is free, it brings a lot of value. With over 10,000 design templates to get you started, this app is ideal for the designer who’s just starting out. DesignEvo helps you perfect your style, develop your workflow, and build your portfolio — all without spending a penny on expensive software.</p> \n<p>You’ll have access to royalty-free fonts, color schemes, and an easy-to-use logo editor (plus&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.designevo.com/create/\">dozens of logo categories</a>). When you’ve designed the perfect vector, logo, or icon, export it from DesignEvo and into your preferred storage cloud in the most popular high-resolution formats.</p> \n<h4>Best used for:</h4> \n<p>Individuals starting a business who need a logo and other assets</p> \n<h4>Platform:</h4> \n<p>Mac</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Design Evo Free Adobe Illustrator Alternative\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021.png?width=650&amp;name=The%20Top%207%20Free%20Alternatives%20to%20Adobe%20Illustrator%20of%202021.png\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\"></p> \n<h2>Adobe Alternatives for Any Budget</h2> \n<p>Creating professional vector graphics doesn't have to be an expensive line item in your budget. If you're just starting out in the graphic design field or if you're an experienced designer looking for budget-friendly tools, one of these free alternatives is sure to work well for you.</p>
