02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"26 Examples of Brilliant Email Marketing Campaigns [Template]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-marketing-examples-list","description":"<p>On any given day, most of our email inboxes are flooded with a barrage of automated email newsletters that do little else besides giving us another task to do on our commutes to work -- namely, marking them all as unread without reading or unsubscribing altogether.</p>  \n<p>It may not seem like a good idea to add to all the noise. However, according to <a href=\"https://blogs.constantcontact.com/what-is-the-roi-of-email-marketing/\">Constant Contact</a>, the average ROI for email marketing is $42 for every $1 spent. Needless to say, email is an important component of a marketing strategy, and its success relies largely on how well you craft your email campaigns.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=a7d79d5b-7a5d-4ce7-a057-81068f1fdac9&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Email Marketing Planning Template&nbsp;\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/a7d79d5b-7a5d-4ce7-a057-81068f1fdac9.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>Email campaigns are an important part of <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/inbound-marketing\">inbound marketing</a>, an ongoing process where marketers meet buyers in whatever stage of the journey they're in.</p> \n<p>Inbound marketing acknowledges that not everyone is ready to buy from you <em>at this exact moment</em>. That's why email is such an important channel.</p> \n<p>Through email, you're able to stay top-of-mind by providing communication to their personal inbox, and you can do it at scale with <a href=\"https://hubspot.com/products/marketing/marketing-automation\">marketing automation software</a>. It's important that an email campaign's recipients have opted in to receive this content and that each piece offers something valuable.</p> \n<p>Here are some examples of different purposes your email campaign may set out to accomplish:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Traffic generation</strong> - Email can be an effective promotion channel for the high-value content you create on your website.</li> \n <li><strong>Awareness</strong> - Not everyone who opts into your email list is ready for a purchasing decision. You can use email marketing to stay top of mind while providing the educational content that is most relevant to them.</li> \n <li><strong>Lead nurturing</strong> - As you stay top of mind, you may also consider ways to identify the leads you have with the highest purchase intent and provide conversion-focused content that <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/understanding-lead-nurturing\">\"nurtures\" them toward a sale</a> (or at least toward becoming sales-ready).</li> \n <li><strong>Revenue generation</strong> - You can create email marketing campaigns for your existing customers to promote <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/cross-selling\">upsell and cross-sell</a> opportunities. You can also create campaigns to capture a sales conversion from leads who are close to a purchasing decision. (One example might be creating \"abandon cart\" campaigns for recovering lost sales conversions.)</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The options for effective email marketing are endless. Check out these 10 email marketing tips in 60 seconds:</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0px;\">\n   <iframe width=\"480\" height=\"270\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/My8g1TkwmD8?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </div>\n</div> \n<p>Ready to take a deeper dive? <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/email-marketing?hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-marketing-examples-list&amp;_ga=2.96517343.1399008408.1559534064-1093622293.1516842654\">Effective email marketing campaigns</a> need to be cleverly written to attract attention in busy inboxes. Let's get into how to create an effective email marketing campaign of your own.</p> \n<h3>1. Use an email planning template.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/email-marketing-planning-template?hubs_post-cta=image&amp;__hstc=45788219.78214bbb56125046cd2ba46e4539e61d.1623807888260.1623807888260.1623807888260.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1623807888260&amp;__hsfp=2686128884&amp;_ga=2.241991940.788778564.1623807886-247698671.1623807886\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/laptop%20email.png\" alt=\"Email Planning Template in Excel\"></a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/email-marketing-planning-template?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom\">Download This Planning Template</a></p> \n<p>It's imperative to make a plan before you start emailing your entire customer database. That's why HubSpot created <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/email-marketing-planning-template?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom\">this free email planning template</a> to help you iron out who you're emailing, who you're suppressing from your contact list, and what the email's message is. Download the template now to get your email campaign planning organized.</p> \n<h3>2. Identify your goal for the campaign.</h3> \n<p>Figure out the outcome that you want:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Is it to clean up your list?</li> \n <li>Promote a new product?</li> \n <li>Follow-up from an abandoned cart event?</li> \n <li>Stay top of mind with your audience?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Different <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-marketing-guide\">email campaigns</a> will have different outcomes, requiring different tactics to get there. Once you determine the purpose of your campaign, you can then <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/metrics-email-marketers-should-be-tracking\">create the targets you want to hit</a>. Include specific metrics in your goal so that you can determine if your campaign was a success based on quantitative data.</p> \n<h3>3. Understand who you're emailing.</h3> \n<p>Have you ever heard the saying from Meredith Hill, \"When you speak to everyone, you speak to no one\"? What Hill is getting at here is that if you're watering down your message to apply to your entire audience, you're leaving opportunity on the table -- opportunity for creating high-value, specific, relevant content that speaks directly to the recipient.</p> \n<p>With this in mind, the key to a great email marketing campaign is identifying your audience and using <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-list-segmentation\">email segmentation</a> to ensure you're delivering to the right people at the right time. If you can accomplish this and build it into your strategy, you can get more creative and specific with your messaging.</p> \n<h3>4. Put yourself in the shoes of the buyer persona.</h3> \n<p>After you've identified the outcome and the goals you want to hit, you now need to strategize how to provide value to your buyer persona so that they convert, engage, or take the action you want them to take. Some things to ask yourself might include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>How did they subscribe in the first place?</li> \n <li>What matters to them?</li> \n <li>What can I provide that will engage and delight them?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>5. Build a targeted list and define enrollment criteria.</h3> \n<p>You know who you're targeting and what you want them to do. From there, you must build the segment. Thinking about your buyer persona, what properties do they all have in common? How does your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm\">CRM</a> describe those properties?</p> \n<p>Your software is smart, but it's not smart enough to automatically know which recipients you're sending to. Will the recipients receive the emails at the same time, or is there <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/workflows/understand-contact-based-workflow-types\">certain criteria they have to meet before they are enrolled in the sequence or campaign</a>?</p> \n<h3>6. Determine the timeline you want the campaign to run.</h3> \n<p>You may be running a seasonal campaign that only requires one or two emails, or you might be building a long-term top-of-mind nurturing campaign. Tailor the length of your email sequence to the length of the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/sales-cycle\">buying cycle</a> and stage the persona is at in the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/what-is-the-buyers-journey\">buyer's journey</a>. In other words, deliver the right message at the right time.</p> \n<h3>7. Plan your emails and follow-ups.</h3> \n<p>Once you know who you're emailing and why, it's time to strategize how to move them from A (where they are) to B (where you want them to be, the goal of the campaign).</p> \n<p>Over the course of the campaign's timeline, you may want multiple touchpoints. You may also even consider follow-ups based on the actions that each recipient takes. Plan these emails out, outlining the core message and take-away for each email.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind that you can't expect a single email to do everything. Your email campaign can be made up of multiple emails, so consider taking your email recipients on a journey with each email serving a single purpose. This will increase the odds of each email being successful in its role toward reaching your goal.</p> \n<p>For example, if you're doing a lead nurturing campaign, you might have a few educational emails to take them from the awareness stage to the consideration stage before providing more conversion-focused content.</p> \n<p>The longer the buying process and sales cycle, the more emails you'll need.</p> \n<h3>8. Write click-worthy subject lines.</h3> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/improve-your-email-subject-line\">subject line</a> is the gate keeper of the rest of your email. Your buyer persona will not be exposed to your content unless they first click the subject line. With that in mind, use this precious real estate for copy that compels them to read further. You can do that by:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Piquing their interest</li> \n <li>Promising value</li> \n <li>Opening a loop (that will be closed in the body of the email)</li> \n <li>Using your unique voice to start the conversation</li> \n <li>Using personalization</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>9. Write copy that's suited for them.</h3> \n<p>Once you know the purpose of each email you're sending and you have the subject lines, you can write the copy that will engage your list. Consider where your audience is in their <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/what-is-the-buyers-journey\">buying journey</a> and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage\">provide the type of content that they'll find useful</a>. For example, it doesn't make sense to promote products if you're emailing a segment of subscribers who are largely in the awareness stage of the buying journey.</p> \n<h3>10. Create your brand assets.</h3> \n<p>Few people want to read an email that simply gives them a wall of text. Visuals help your recipients quickly understand the point of the email. In fact, <a href=\"https://www.impactbnd.com/blog/images-vs.-no-images-in-marketing-emails-newsletters\">intentional and well-placed imagery can increase click-through rates</a>, so put thought into not just what you want to say but how you want to say it, using visuals to support your message.</p> \n<h3>11. Put it all together with a comprehensive email builder.</h3> \n<p>Once you've written the copy for your emails, you'll want to build them out in the email software client you're intending to use.</p> \n<p>There are several options depending on your needs, including <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email\">HubSpot</a>, <a href=\"https://mailchimp.com/\">MailChimp</a>, <a href=\"https://www.pabbly.com/email-marketing/?utm_source=hubspot-email-marketing-examples&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=hubspot-email\">Pabbly Email Marketing</a> and <a href=\"https://www.constantcontact.com/index.jsp\">Constant Contact</a>.</p> \n<p>With a comprehensive email builder, you can create, optimize, and personalize your own email campaigns without needing any technical or graphic design experience.</p> \n<h3>12. Include clear calls to action.</h3> \n<p>Remember, if you're taking up your audience's time -- and inbox space -- with another email, your message must have a point to it. Consider what you want your email recipients to take away from the email.</p> \n<p>In most cases, you'll want to add a call-to-action (CTA) for them to take further action.</p> \n<p>Don't confuse your email contacts by providing too many options. For each email you send, there should be a single action that you want the reader to take. Then, instruct them to take that action and set expectations for what will happen when they do.</p> \n<p>Your goal behind the CTA may vary depending on the audience's buyer's journey stage and what you want to accomplish with your email campaign. For example, you may simply want to engage them further with another piece of content, or you might want to get them to make a purchase.</p> \n<p>Regardless of what it is, you should follow CTA best practices such as making the ask with clear language and emphasizing it with contrasting design elements.</p> \n<h3>13. Include personalization elements.</h3> \n<p>Consider the experience. Do your email recipients want to feel like one among hundreds of other people in your database? Or do they want a personalized experience as though you're talking directly with them?</p> \n<p>Automation helps save time, but it should never be at the cost of the experience. Marketing emails need to be personalized to the reader and contain information that is relevant to them.</p> \n<p>At the very least, swap out the \"Dear Sir/Madam\" in favor of their name using <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/website-pages/personalize-your-content\">personalization tokens</a>.</p> \n<h3>14. Always provide a way for them to opt out.</h3> \n<p>People who don't want to read your emails don't belong on your list. Keeping them only skews your open rates down and increases the number of people marketing your emails as spam. Besides, according to <a href=\"https://www.ftc.gov/tips-advice/business-center/guidance/can-spam-act-compliance-guide-business\">CAN-SPAM guidelines</a>, you should always provide a way for them to opt out of email if they no longer want to receive communications from you. Typically, this opt-out link lives in the footer of each email you send.</p> \n<h3>15. Test your emails and make sure they work on all devices.</h3> \n<p>Once your emails are built out, check them over before hitting the send button. Effective email marketing campaigns are designed for all devices on which users can read their emails -- desktop, tablet, and mobile. Consider sending them as a test to a colleague and checking them across multiple devices and email clients.</p> \n<h3>16. Monitor your metrics.</h3> \n<p>As the campaign runs, take notes. Are your open rates and click rates what you expected? What went well vs. not well? Are you on track to hitting your goals with the campaign?</p> \n<p>The more you pay attention to the data, the more you can understand what's working and what's not for your audience, leading to more effective campaigns in the future.</p> \n<p>Want a quick refresher on how to master marketing email? Check out this helpful video:</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0px;\">\n   <iframe style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/P4LzwX31Egg?feature=oembed\" width=\"480\" height=\"270\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n  </div>\n </div>\n</div> \n<p>Now that you know how to responsibly wield email marketing, grab some inspiration from the masterful email marketing campaigns below.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"></p> \n<h2>Best Email Marketing Campaign Examples</h2> \n<p>If you're reading this, you probably have an email address (or two, or three ...). In fact, you've probably been sending and receiving emails for years, and you've <em>definitely</em> received some questionable deliveries in your inbox.</p> \n<p>Whether they were unexpected, uninformative, or had a subject line tHaT wAs fOrmAtTeD liKe tHiS, we bet you didn't hesitate to direct them towards the trash, right?</p> \n<p>While email has managed to stand the test of time, many marketers have failed to update their strategies since its inception. So to ensure you're sending modern emails that warrant some of your recipients' precious time and attention, we've compiled a list of effective email examples to inspire your next campaign.</p> \n<h3>1. ModCloth</h3> \n<h4>Marketing Campaign: Email Preferences</h4> \n<p>Great companies are always evolving, and your customers expect to experience change. What they <em>don't</em> expect (because too many companies haven't lived up to this end of the bargain) is to be told about those changes.</p> \n<p>That said, this email from ModCloth serves as a refreshing change of pace. If you're going to change the way you communicate with a lead or customer, give them clear, fair warning so, if they aren't on board, they can make the necessary adjustments to keep their inbox clean.</p> \n<h4>Why It Works</h4> \n<p>It sets expectations for communication moving forward so that the buyer persona can choose what's best for them.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/modcloth_email_marketing.jpg?width=450&amp;name=modcloth_email_marketing.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Modcloth - &quot;We're making changes to our email program!&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>2. Tory Burch</h3> \n<h4>Marketing Campaign: Promotion</h4> \n<p>Did you see that? Did you see it move? Pretty cool, right? This small bit of animation helps to separate this email from Tory Burch from all of the immobile emails in their recipient's inboxes. They also leverage exclusivity by framing the promotion as a \"private\" sale. Oftentimes, this type of positioning makes the recipient feel like they're specially chosen, which encourages them to take advantage of the special opportunity they've been presented with.</p> \n<h4>Why It Works</h4> \n<p>Emails can get static, boring, and impersonal. This email subverts those expectations without going overboard.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Tory_Burch_Private_Sale-2.gif?width=450&amp;name=Tory_Burch_Private_Sale-2.gif\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Tory Burch - Private Sale Invitation\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>3. RunKeeper</h3> \n<h4>Marketing Campaign: Re-Engagement Campaign</h4> \n<p>RunKeeper makes an effort to reengage lost users with this friendly, informational email. By highlighting their app's most recent changes and benefits, the copy works to entice recipients to give the app another chance. It also discusses benefits that the recipient may not know about since the last time they used the service.</p> \n<h4>Why It Works</h4> \n<p>Small inclusions like the \"Hi friend\" greeting and the \"You rock\" closing makes the content feel welcoming and less aggressive.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/RunKeeper_Reengage.png?width=450&amp;name=RunKeeper_Reengage.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 450px;\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: RunKeeper - &quot;RunKeeper Elite is looking pretty fresh these days and we'd love for you to give it another try!&quot;\" width=\"450\"></p> \n<h3>4. Litmus</h3> \n<h4>Marketing Campaign: Promotion</h4> \n<p>Here's another great example of animation being used to create a more interesting email marketing design. Unlike static text, the swipe motion used to provide recipients with a look \"under the hood\" of their email tool is eye-catching and encourages you to take a deeper dive into the rest of the content. Not to mention the header does an excellent job of explicitly stating what this email is about.</p> \n<h4>Why It Works</h4> \n<p>The animation is subtle, and it's executed in a way that serves to enhance the email's body copy. Even better, it works well with the design of the email, creating a matching but contrasting focal point before the reader dives into the rest of the copy below.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/litmus-1.gif?width=450&amp;name=litmus-1.gif\" alt=\"Email M arketing Campaign Example: Litmus - &quot;Tried in vain to see how that responsive design works under the hood?&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 450px;\"></p> \n<h3>5. Loft</h3> \n<h4>Marketing Campaign: Email Preferences</h4> \n<p>This email from Loft aims to demonstrate their understanding of your crazy, mixed-value inbox. In an effort to provide you with emails that you actually want to open, Loft asks that their recipients update their preferences to help them deliver a more personalized experience. This customer-focused email is super effective in making the recipient feel like their likes, dislikes, and opinions actually matter.</p> \n<h4>Why It Works</h4> \n<p>It centers the recipient's needs with the slogan \"Happy Inbox, Happy Life.\" Paired with a low-friction CTA, the copy is simple and effective.</p> \n<h3><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Loft_Tell_Us_About_You.jpg?width=450&amp;name=Loft_Tell_Us_About_You.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Loft - &quot;Happy Inbox, Happy Life&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></h3> \n<h3>6. UncommonGoods</h3> \n<h4>Marketing Campaign: Promotion</h4> \n<p>You've heard it a million times (and a few thousand of those times may have been from us): You should create a sense of urgency with your calls-to-action. That's what makes a lead take action, right? Well, this email from UncommonGoods succeeds in creating a sense of urgency by focusing on the <em>value</em> of acting now.</p> \n<h4>Why It Works</h4> \n<p>Instead of saying, \"Order your Mother's Day gift NOW before Preferred Shipping ends!\", this email asks, \"Don't you think Mom would've liked a faster delivery?\" Why yes, she would. Thank you for reminding me before it's too late -- I don't want to be in the dog house because my gift arrived after Mother's Day.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/uncommon_goods_email_marketing.jpg?width=450&amp;name=uncommon_goods_email_marketing.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Uncommon Goods - &quot;Don't you think Mom would've liked a faster delivery?&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<div class=\"hs-migrated-cms-post\"> \n <h3>7. JetBlue</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Customer Delight</h4> \n <p>Confession: We have a serious email marketing crush on JetBlue. And they continue to deliver their lovable marketing in this cheeky email campaign that aims to humorously reengage customers. Every element from the header, to the three witty points, to the actionable, contrasting CTA work together to create a lovable campaign that's promotional without being pushy.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>This copy is bursting with friendly personality and airline jokes. The email is relatable and reads as though it comes from a friend, which will help earn a positive reaction.</p> \n <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/JetBlue_Anniversary.jpg?width=450&amp;name=JetBlue_Anniversary.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: JetBlue - &quot;It's our one year anniversary&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n</div> \n<div class=\"hs-migrated-cms-post\"> \n <h3>8. Harpoon Brewery</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Customer Delight</h4> \n <p>My friends at Harpoon are so thoughtful, aren't they? This simple, timely email really does feel like it's coming from a friend, which is why it's so effective. In an age of email automation, it's easy for email campaigns to feel a little robotic. And while I'm certain that this email was, in fact, automated, it <em>feels</em> really human.</p> \n <p>If you're looking to strengthen the relationship you have with your existing customers, consider taking the time to set up a quick email like this to let them know you're thinking of them.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>Personalization: From the timing of the email (birthday) to the personalized salutation, this email was sent to the right person at the right time.</p> \n <h3><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/harpoon-brewery-email-example.jpg?width=449&amp;name=harpoon-brewery-email-example.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Harpoon Brewery - &quot;Happy Birthday Carly!&quot;\" width=\"449\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 449px;\"></h3> \n <h3>9. Rip Curl</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Promotion</h4> \n <p><em>\"JOIN THE REVOLUTION.\"</em></p> \n <p>That's quite powerful, wouldn't you agree? Rip Curl, an Australian surfing sportswear retailer, combines urgency and our psychological need to be part of something to create an email headline that jumps off the page. This positioning is designed to lead people to believe that there's a \"revolution\" taking place and it's their turn to get in on the action.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>At the end of the day, people want to be part of something that's bigger than themselves, and this email aims to motivate them to do so by purchasing this sleek watch.</p> \n <p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ripcurl.jpg?width=450&amp;name=ripcurl.jpg\" width=\"450\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 450px;\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Ripcurl - &quot;Join the revolution&quot;\"></p> \n <h3>10. J.Crew Factory</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Promotion</h4> \n <p>For many of us, when it comes to wrapping gifts, <em>the struggle is real</em>. J.Crew Factory recognized this problem and then created this email to serve as a solution for those incapable of pulling off a Pinterest-esque wrap job: gift cards. The email offers up two different ways to pick up a gift card -- in store or online -- in an effort to avoid excluding anyone.</p> \n <p>They've also included a map of the nearest store location at the end of the email to lower the purchasing barrier even further.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>It combines humor with a low-stress, low-friction solution.</p> \n <p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/JCrew_Gift_Card_Email.jpg?width=450&amp;name=JCrew_Gift_Card_Email.jpg\" width=\"450\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 450px;\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: J.Crew Factory - &quot;If your wrapping looks like this, you may want to get them a giftcard&quot;\"></p> \n <h3>11. charity: water</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Engagement</h4> \n <p>When people talk about email marketing, lots of them forget to mention transactional emails. These are the automated emails you get in your inbox after taking a certain action on a website. This could be anything from filling out a form to purchasing a product to updating you on the progress of your order. Often, these are plain text emails that marketers set and forget.</p> \n <p>Well, charity: water took an alternate route. Once someone donates to a charity: water project, her money takes a long journey. Most charities don't tell you about that journey at all -- charity: water uses automated emails to show donors how their money is making an impact over time. With the project timeline and accompanying table, you don't even really need to read the email -- you know immediately where you are in the whole process so you can move onto other things in your inbox.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>It keeps the audience engaged and shows the impact that their actions have made on the organization in the effort of staying top-of-mind and increasing future participation.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2560593787-png/charity-water-email-example-1.png?noresize&amp;width=450&amp;name=charity-water-email-example-1.png\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: charity.water - &quot;Progress Update&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>12. Brooks Sports</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Engagement</h4> \n <p>When Desiree Linden won the 2018 Boston Marathon, she became the first American woman to win the race in more than 30 years. To her shoe and apparel sponsor, Brooks Sports, it was an opportunity to celebrate their long partnership together. The resulting email campaign focuses almost entirely on the Olympic marathoner's amazing accomplishment.</p> \n <p>Email campaigns like this one allow companies to demonstrate their loyalties and add value to the products their best users have chosen. Not pictured is a blue CTA button at the bottom of the email that reads, \"See Desiree's go-to gear.\" What better products to call attention to than the stuff worn by America's latest legend?</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>After Desiree's victory, everyone knew her name. Brooks Sports struck while the iron was hot with a proud email that was sure to be opened and forwarded.</p> \n <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/brooks-running-des-linden-email-marketing-campaign.jpg?width=388&amp;name=brooks-running-des-linden-email-marketing-campaign.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Brooks Sports - &quot;Boston 2018 - One for the History Books&quot;\" width=\"388\" style=\"width: 388px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n <h3>13. Uber</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Engagement</h4> \n <p>The beauty of Uber's emails is in their simplicity. Email subscribers are alerted to deals and promotions with emails like the one you see below. We love how brief the initial description is, paired with a very clear CTA -- perfect for subscribers who are quickly skimming the email.</p> \n <p>For the people who want to learn more, these are followed by a more detailed (but still pleasingly simple), step-by-step explanation of how the deal works.</p> \n <p>We also love how consistent the design of Uber's emails is with its brand. Like its app, website, social media photos, and other parts of the visual branding, the emails are represented by bright colors and geometric patterns.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>All of its communications and marketing assets tell the brand's story -- and brand consistency is one tactic Uber's nailed in order to gain brand loyalty.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/uber-email-campaign.jpg?width=450&amp;name=uber-email-campaign.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Uber - &quot;Connect your calendar, streamline your schedule&quot;\" width=\"450\" title=\"uber-email-campaign.jpg\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>14. TheSkimm</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Customer Delight</h4> \n <p>We love TheSkimm's daily newsletter -- especially its clean design and its short, punchy paragraphs. But newsletters aren't TheSkimm's only strength when it comes to email. Check out its subscriber engagement email below, which rewarded one of their subscribers for being subscribed for two years.</p> \n <p>Emails triggered by milestones, like anniversaries and birthdays, are fun to get -- who doesn't like to celebrate a special occasion? The beauty of anniversary emails, in particular, is that they don't require subscribers to input any extra data, and they can work for a variety of senders. Plus, the timeframe can be modified based on the business model.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>The folks at TheSkimm took it a step further by asking Mineo if she'd like to earn the title of brand ambassador as a loyal subscriber -- which would require her to share the link with ten friends, of course.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/the-skimm-email-example.png?noresize&amp;width=450&amp;name=the-skimm-email-example.png\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: TheSkimm - &quot;Happy Skimmversary&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>15. Mom and Dad Money</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Questionnaire</h4> \n <p>Think you know all about the people who are reading your marketing emails? How much of what you \"know\" about them is based on assumptions? The strongest buyer personas are based on insights you gather from your actual readership, through surveys, interviews, and so on -- in addition to the market research.</p> \n <p>That's exactly what Matt Becker of Mom and Dad Money does -- and he does it very, very well.</p> \n <p>Here's an example of an email I once received from this brand. Design-wise, it's nothing special -- but that's the point. It reads just like an email from a friend or colleague asking for a quick favor.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>Not only was this initial email great, but his response to my answers was even better: Within a few days of responding to the questionnaire, I received a long and detailed personal email from Matt thanking me for filling out the questionnaire and offering a <em>ton </em>of helpful advice and links to resources specifically catered to my answers. I was very impressed by his business acumen, communication skills, and obvious dedication to his readers.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/matt-becker-email-example.png?noresize&amp;width=450&amp;name=matt-becker-email-example.png\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Mom and Dad Money - &quot;can you help me real quick?&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>16. Birchbox</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Promotion</h4> \n <p>The subject line of this email from beauty product subscription service Birchbox got my colleague <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/pamelavaughan\">Pam Vaughan</a> clicking. It read: \"We Forgot Something in Your February Box!\" Of course, if you read the email copy below, Birchbox didn't actually forget to put that discount code in her box -- but it was certainly a clever way to get her attention.</p> \n <p>As it turned out, the discount code was actually a bonus promo for Rent the Runway, a dress rental company that likely fits the interest profile of most Birchbox customers -- which certainly didn't disappoint. That's a great co-marketing partnership right there.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>It gained her attention and delivered some unexpected delight.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/birchbox-email-example.jpg?width=450&amp;name=birchbox-email-example.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Birchbox - &quot;Oops!&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>17. Postmates</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Promotion</h4> \n <p>I have to say, I'm a sucker for GIFs. They're easy to consume, they catch your eye, and they have an emotional impact -- like the fun GIF in one of Postmates' emails that's not only delightful to watch, but also makes you crave some delicious Chipotle.</p> \n <p>You, too, can use animated GIFs in your marketing to show a fun header, draw people's eyes to a certain part of the email, or display your products and services in action.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>It centers the product in a fun, attractive way.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/chipotle-gif.gif?width=450&amp;name=chipotle-gif.gif\" alt=\"Email Campaign Example: Animated Nachos Gif\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/postmates-email-example.png?noresize&amp;width=450&amp;name=postmates-email-example.png\" alt=\"Email Campaign Example: Postmates - &quot;What do you call a tortilla chip that works out? A macho nacho.&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>18. Dropbox</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Re-Engagement</h4> \n <p>You might think it'd be hard to love an email from a company whose product you haven't been using. But Dropbox found a way to make its \"come back to us!\" email cute and funny, thanks to a pair of whimsical cartoons and an emoticon.</p> \n <p>Plus, the email was kept short and sweet, to emphasize the message that Dropox didn't want to intrude -- it just wants to remind the recipient that the brand exists, and why it could be helpful. When sending these types of email, you might include an incentive for recipients to come back to using your service, like a limited-time coupon.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>It uses the Dropbox logo in a way that's creative and unique to demonstrate their product as a solution.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2562063987-png/dropbox-email-example.png?width=450&amp;name=dropbox-email-example.png\" alt=\"Email Campaign Example: Dropbox - &quot;Recently your Dropbox has been feeling kind of lonely&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>19. InVision App</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Newsletter</h4> \n <p>Every week, the folks at InVision send a roundup of their best blog content, their favorite design links from the week, and a new opportunity to win a free t-shirt. (Seriously. They give away a new design every week.) They also sometimes have fun survey questions where they crowdsource for their blog. This week's, for example, asked subscribers what they would do if the internet didn't exist.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>Not only is InVision's newsletter a great mix of content, but I also love the nice balance between images and text, making it really easy to read and mobile-friendly -- which is especially important, because its newsletters are so long (below is just an excerpt). We like the clever copy on the call-to-action (CTA) buttons, too.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/invision-email-example.jpg?width=450&amp;name=invision-email-example.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Invision - &quot;Designing with your developer in mind&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>20. Cook Smarts</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Newsletter</h4> \n <p>I've been a huge fan of Cook Smarts' \"Weekly Eats\" newsletter for a while. The company sends yummy recipes in the form of a meal plan to my inbox every week. But I didn't just include it because of its delicious recipes -- I'm truly a fan of its emails.</p> \n <p>I especially love the layout of Cook Smarts' emails: Each message features three distinct sections: one for the menu, one for kitchen how-to's, and one for the tips. That means you don't have to go hunting to find the most interesting part of its blog posts -- you know exactly where to look after an email or two.</p> \n <p>I also love Cook Smarts' \"Forward to a Friend\" CTA in the top-right of the email.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>Emails are super shareable over -- you guessed it -- email, so you should also think about reminding your subscribers to forward your emails to friends, family, or coworkers.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/cooksmart-email-example.jpg?width=450&amp;name=cooksmart-email-example.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Cook Smarts - &quot;Weekly Eats&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>21. HireVue</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Email Preferences</h4> \n <p>\"Saying goodbye is never easy to do… So, we thought we’d give you a chance to rethink things.\" That was the subject of this automated unsubscribe email from HireVue. We love the simple, guilt-free messaging here, from the funny header images to the great CTA button copy.</p> \n <p>Not only are the design and copy here top-notch, but we applaud the folks at HireVue for sending automated unsubscribe emails in the first place. It's smart to purge your subscriber lists of folks who aren't opening your email lists, because low open rates can seriously hurt email deliverability.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>The button copy is a pattern interrupt that will prompt the recipient to pause and think if they want to take the action.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hirevue-unsubscribe-email-example.jpg?width=450&amp;name=hirevue-unsubscribe-email-example.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Hirevue - &quot;Don't Let Me Go&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>22. Paperless Post</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Promotion</h4> \n <p>When you think of \"holiday email marketing,\" your mind might jump straight to Christmas, but there are other holidays sprinkled throughout the rest of the year that you can create campaigns around. (<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/email-marketing-planning-template?utm_campaign=Marketing%20Blog%20-%20Internal%20Links%20%5BSeptember%5D&amp;utm_medium=15%20of%20the%20Best%20Email%20Marketing%20Campaign%20Examples%20You%27ve%20Ever%20Seen&amp;utm_source=Blog\">Download these email marketing planning templates to keep yourself organized throughout the year.</a>)</p> \n <p>Take the email below from Paperless Post, for example. I love the header of this email: It provides a clear CTA that includes a sense of urgency. Then, the subheader asks a question that forces recipients to think to themselves, \"Wait, when is Mother's Day again? <em>Did </em>I buy Mom a card?\"</p> \n <p>Below this copy, the simple grid design is both easy to scan and quite visually appealing. Each card picture is a CTA in and of itself -- click on any one of them, and you'll be taken to a purchase page.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>It earns a positive sentiment by prompting the recipient to do something they may have forgotten (send a card). This provides a solution and saves the recipient the pain of feeling guilty about forgetting Mother's Day.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/paperless-post-email-example.jpg?width=450&amp;name=paperless-post-email-example.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Paperless Post - &quot;You didn't forget Mother's Day, did you?&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>23. Stitcher</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Engagement</h4> \n <p>I love on-demand podcast/radio show app Stitcher's \"Recommended For You\" emails. I tend to listen to episodes from the same podcast instead of branching out to new ones. But Stitcher wants me to discover (and subscribe to) all the <em>other</em> awesome content it has -- and I probably wouldn't without this encouragement.</p> \n <p>I think this email also makes quite a brilliant use of responsive design. The colors are bright, and it's not too hard to scroll and click -- notice the CTAs are large enough for me to hit with my thumbs. Also, the mobile email actually has features that make sense for recipients who are on their mobile device. Check out the CTA at the bottom of the email, for example: The \"Open Stitcher Radio\" button prompts the app to open on your phone.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>As humans, we tend to crave personalized experiences. So when emails appear to be created especially for you, you feel special -- you’re not just getting what everyone else is getting. You might even feel like the company sending you the email knows you in some way, and that it cares about your preferences and making you happy.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/stitcher-email-example.jpg?width=256&amp;name=stitcher-email-example.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Stitcher - &quot;Recommended for you&quot;\" width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>24. RCN</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Update</h4> \n <p>Internet providers and bad weather are natural enemies. You'd think telecommunications companies wouldn't want to call attention to storm-induced power outages -- the one thing that sets off customers' impatience. Then, there's RCN.</p> \n <p>RCN, a cable and wireless internet service, turned this email marketing campaign into a weather forecast just for its customers. This \"storm update\" got the company out ahead of an event that threatened its service, while allowing its users to get the weather updates they need right from the company they count on for Wi-Fi.</p> \n <p>As you can see below, the email even advises personal safety -- a nice touch of care to go with the promise of responsive service. At the bottom of the email, RCN also took the opportunity to highlight its social media channels, which the company appropriately uses to keep users informed of network outages.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>It simply offers an update. No promoting, no selling. The recipient's best interests are in mind, and they're setting expectations for something that they may imminently care about.</p> \n <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rcn-email-marketing-campaign.png?width=450&amp;name=rcn-email-marketing-campaign.png\" alt=\"Email Marketing Example: RCN - &quot;RCN is preparing for winter storm Quinn&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>25. Trulia</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Newsletter</h4> \n <p>I'm a huge advocate of thought leadership. To me, some of the best companies gain customer loyalty by becoming the go-to source for expertise on a given topic. Trulia -- a property search engine for buyers, sellers, and renters -- is that expert in the real estate biz. How do I know? Just read their emails, much like the one below.</p> \n <p>\"Why aren't millennials moving?\" The subject line of this email campaign reads before citing interesting data about relocation trends in the U.S. Trulia doesn't benefit from people who choose not to move, but the company <em>does</em> benefit from having its fingers on the pulse of the industry -- and showing it cares which way the real estate winds are blowing.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>It opens a loop by posing a question that the recipient needs to take action to get the answer to.</p> \n <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/trulia-email-marketing-campaign-1.png?width=450&amp;name=trulia-email-marketing-campaign-1.png\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: Trulia - &quot;Younger Americans Aren't Moving Like They Used To - What's Changed?&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n <h3>26. RedBubble</h3> \n <h4>Marketing Campaign: Promotion</h4> \n <p>This email marketing campaign crushes it, and for so many reasons.</p> \n <p>Not only is the design below super eye-catching -- without looking cluttered -- but the artwork is user-made. RedBubble sells merchandise featuring designs from artists all over the world. This presents a golden opportunity to feature popular submissions across the RedBubble community.</p> \n <p>The example below showcases artwork from \"Letter Shoppe,\" and when that artist sees RedBubble featuring her content, she's more likely to forward it to friends and colleagues.</p> \n <p>In addition to linking to Letter Shoppe's designs (available on merchandise that is ultimately sold by RedBubble), the email campaign includes an endearing quote by the Featured Artist: <em>\"Never compromise on your values, and only do work you want to get more of.\"</em> RedBubble's customers are likely to agree -- and open other emails in this campaign for more inspiring quotes.</p> \n <h4>Why It Works</h4> \n <p>The email lets the items speak for themselves, showcasing them as art rather than products.</p> \n <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/redbubble-email-marketing-campaign.jpg?width=450&amp;name=redbubble-email-marketing-campaign.jpg\" alt=\"Email Marketing Campaign Example: RedBubble - &quot;Featured Artist: Letter Shoppe&quot;\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <p>These are just some of our favorite emails. Don't just follow best practices when it comes to your marketing emails. Every email you send from your work email address also can be optimized to convert with a little planning.</p> \n <p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in October 2013 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n <p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=7f4dab33-585c-49b4-b50f-3b0166aa5443&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img =450&name=dropbox-email-example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn39@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-51-606_325beeb99b324325.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/invision-email-example.jpg?width=450&name=invision-email-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn82@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-50-954_f06087953b0f8ae9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/cooksmart-email-example.jpg?width=450&name=cooksmart-email-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn36@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-52-130_26cd3ffcbc78d6a6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hirevue-unsubscribe-email-example.jpg?width=450&name=hirevue-unsubscribe-email-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn74@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-50-821_2e368cbaff7c7aae.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/paperless-post-email-example.jpg?width=450&name=paperless-post-email-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn20@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-52-912_79abe37d90a28751.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/stitcher-email-example.jpg?width=256&name=stitcher-email-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn42@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-53-512_fe2ed8cfa9235f53.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rcn-email-marketing-campaign.png?width=450&name=rcn-email-marketing-campaign.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn22@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-49-371_4cf236434cc33cea.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/trulia-email-marketing-campaign-1.png?width=450&name=trulia-email-marketing-campaign-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn97@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-49-662_87c47b4d1c2d5ca2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/redbubble-email-marketing-campaign.jpg?width=450&name=redbubble-email-marketing-campaign.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn45@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-50-438_87f4d56f79644631.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/7f4dab33-585c-49b4-b50f-3b0166aa5443.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn54@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-49-256_e3468e8c795d5dbc.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Femail-marketing-examples-list&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn71@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-50-563_b508b46fcd5228ca.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938119},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"39 Simple Ways to Grow Your Email List","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32028/25-clever-ways-to-grow-your-email-marketing-list.aspx","description":"<p>I have some bad news — your email marketing contact database degrades over time.</p> \n<p>Your contacts’ email addresses change as they move from one company to another, opt-out of your email communication, or abandon an address they only used to fill out forms on websites.</p> \n<p>As a marketer, it’s your job to make sure you’re constantly adding fresh contacts to your email lists so you can continue generating growth. While <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32892/why-purchasing-email-lists-is-always-a-bad-idea.aspx?_ga=2.185337515.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">purchasing emails</a> is an option, it’s not always the best way to go about this.</p> \n<p>In this post, discover high-quality strategies to help you grow your email list to ensure that you have a large audience of subscribers eager to hear what you have to say and likely to make purchases and contribute to your business growth.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=53e8428a-29a5-4225-a6ea-bca8ef991c19&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: The Beginner's Guide to Email Marketing [Free Ebook]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/53e8428a-29a5-4225-a6ea-bca8ef991c19.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Sometimes called subscriber lists, email lists can get smaller if members unsubscribe and grow as you continue to collect more and more addresses through lead generation.</p> \n<p>If you’re not working on building your email list already, or you’ve run out of ideas on how to do so, here are 39 simple ways to grow your email list. Please note that, with these methods, it’s essential to allow people to opt-in to receiving additional emails from your company, as some may not be interested.</p> \n<h2>39 Creative List Building Techniques</h2> \n<h3>How To Grow Your Email List Using Email</h3> \n<h4>1. Create unique email content.</h4> \n<p>Want to retain your current subscribers and have them help you grow your list? Create unique<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email-hosting?_ga=2.185337515.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">&nbsp;email content</a>. If your emails are entertaining, informative, and valuable, recipients will always look forward to receiving them and will be more likely to forward them to their networks. This helps you gain exposure and obtain additional subscribers.</p> \n<h4>2. Encourage subscribers to share and forward your emails.</h4> \n<p>Include social sharing buttons and an “Email to a Friend” button on your marketing emails. By doing this, you’ll gain access to recipients' friends, colleagues, and networks to expand your contact list. At the bottom of your emails, include a “Subscribe” CTA as a simple text-based link so that the people receiving the forwarded emails can easily opt-in too.</p> \n<h4>3. Segment your email lists by buyer persona.</h4> \n<p>Email recipients are more likely to click through emails that cater to their specific interests, so using varying types of email subscriptions to send targeted content to different <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/persona-templates?_ga=2.185337515.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">segments of your audience</a>&nbsp;is worth considering.</p> \n<p>If you create multiple targeted subscriber types, you’ll increase the chance that visitors will subscribe to one of them. In fact, marketers who used segmented campaigns noted as much as a <a href=\"https://www.campaignmonitor.com/resources/guides/email-marketing-new-rules/\">760% increase in revenue</a>.</p> \n<h4>4. Reinvigorate a stale email list with an opt-in campaign.</h4> \n<p>Do you have an older list that you suspect is mostly decayed? Create an engaging opt-in message and send it to your old list and encourage contacts to re-opt in if they’d like to, but also promising to remove all contacts who don’t respond.</p> \n<p>Though it may seem counterintuitive to remove folks from your email list to grow them, emailing contacts that you know are engaged can improve your deliverability and increase the odds of your email being shared with those outside your current database.</p> \n<h4>5. Add an opt-in link to your employees' signatures.</h4> \n<p>Hyperlinked email signatures can lead people to a landing page where they can sign up for your mailing list. Plus, if you’re already in a natural email conversation with them, subscribing to more emails can be a natural next step.</p> \n<h3>How To Grow Your Email List With New Content</h3> \n<h4>6. Create a new lead-generation offer.</h4> \n<p>Create a new <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ungated-content-free?_ga=2.185337515.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">gated</a>&nbsp;lead-generation offer, like a free <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates?_ga=2.185337515.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">ebook</a>, and host it on a landing page that asks visitors to provide their email to download it.</p> \n<h4>7. Create a free online tool or resource that requires sign-up.</h4> \n<p>Free online tools make your users' lives easier, especially if all they have to do is sign up with their email address. For example, we've created quite a few free tools, like <a href=\"https://website.grader.com/\">Website Grader</a>, to gather email addresses.</p> \n<h4>8. Create additional bonus content.</h4> \n<p>Not all gated content is worth it to a website visitor. Sometimes, to gain their interest, you need to give them free content first. You can begin with a blog post that offers beginner advice on a subject, then offer additional bonus content with more advanced tips that they can access by submitting their email address via a <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/landing-pages?_ga=2.185337515.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">landing page</a>.</p> \n<h3>How To Grow Your Email List Using Social Media</h3> \n<h4>9. Promote an online contest.</h4> \n<p>Use your social media accounts to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33352/everything-you-need-to-run-a-successful-social-media-contest.aspx\">host a free giveaway</a>&nbsp;that requires contact information to enter. You can encourage your followers to click through to your website and sign up using their email addresses.</p> \n<h4>10. Promote a lead gen offer on Twitter.</h4> \n<p>Create a Twitter campaign to promote an ebook or free resource to your followers that requires using an email address to redeem.</p> \n<h4>11. Use Pinterest to promote gated visual content.</h4> \n<p>Pinterest plays host to visual content that encourages visitors to sign up to see more content. Use this to your advantage, and promote your gated visual content on the platform, so users are eager to learn more from you and submit their email to get more high-quality information.</p> \n<p><strong>Featured Resource: </strong><strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-use-pinterest-for-business\">12 Pinterest Templates for Business</a></strong></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-use-pinterest-for-business\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Pinterest-Templates-Cover.jpg?width=474&amp;name=Pinterest-Templates-Cover.jpg\" alt=\"Pinterest-Templates-Cover\" width=\"474\" style=\"width: 474px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></a><br></strong></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-use-pinterest-for-business\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Download These Templates for Free</a></p> \n<h3>How To Grow Your Email List Using Facebook</h3> \n<h4>12. Make your email newsletter the theme of your profile cover photo.</h4> \n<p>Your Facebook profile cover photos are a great place to call attention to something specific, especially your email newsletter. If you create a high-quality graphic that highlights and calls attention to its value, you can entice users to submit their email to gain further benefit from the content you offer.</p> \n<p><strong>Featured Resource: </strong><strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/templates-shareable-graphics-social-media?_ga=2.116482820.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">Five Free Facebook Cover Photo Templates</a></strong></p> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/templates-shareable-graphics-social-media?_ga=2.69870610.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\" style=\"font-style: italic;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-templates-1.png?width=452&amp;name=social-templates-1.png\" alt=\"social-templates-1\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 452px;\" width=\"452\">Get These Customizable Templates</a></p> \n<p>If you do this, you should also consider leveraging our next tip, making it easy for users to seamlessly submit their emails once you’ve attracted their attention.</p> \n<h4>13. Add a call-to-action button to the top of your Business’s Facebook page.</h4> \n<p>The value of this list-building technique is in the destination: add a CTA button to your Facebook page that links users to your sign-up landing page or a gated featured resource that requires email access. We added CTAs to our HubSpot Academy Facebook page, as displayed in the image below.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot%20academy%20facebook.jpg?width=2108&amp;name=hubspot%20academy%20facebook.jpg\" alt=\"hubspot academy facebook profile page with sign up CTA button\" width=\"2108\" style=\"width: 2108px;\"><a href=\"http://www.facebook.com/hubspotacademy\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><em>Image Source</em></span></a></p> \n<p>In addition, placing a sign-up CTA button within your profile makes it easier for users, as they won’t need to leave Facebook and go to your site — they simply click the link, and you take them there.</p> \n<p>Here’s <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/help/977869848936797\">a guide</a>&nbsp;from Facebook on how to add one to your profile.</p> \n<h4>14. Share newsletter previews on your profile.</h4> \n<p>Creating a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-post-ideas?_ga=2.116482820.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">Facebook post</a>&nbsp;that showcases a snippet of your email newsletter is a great way to attract your audiences and entice them to join your email list. They’ll get a preview of what you have to offer, become eager to learn more, and sign up to continue generating value from your business. Within this post, you can include a link to your sign-up page for easy and quick sign-up.</p> \n<h4>15. Promote content through Facebook that requires an email address to access.</h4> \n<p>Promote content in your Facebook posts that encourage email submission to access. This content can be something like a gated ebook, joining a giveaway or contest, or even saying that email subscribers get early access to new products.</p> \n<p>Be sure to add social sharing buttons to your landing and thank-you pages to encourage your leads to share within their networks.</p> \n<h3>How To Grow Your Email List Using YouTube</h3> \n<h4>16. Add engagement features to your YouTube videos.</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-end-screen?_ga=2.69870610.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">End screens</a>, also called video outros, are a tool that YouTube offers creators to direct viewers to take additional action after finishing a video, like clicking on a link to your website or watching another video on your channel. As they are used to generate further engagement from your viewers, it’s worth considering adding hyperlinks to your sign-up landing page in your end cards to grow your email list.</p> \n<p>This tip is beneficial if you have created an informative video with mostly surface-level content. A more advanced view is provided in a gated offer or your email newsletter.</p> \n<h4>17. Use your header and images to promote your email newsletter.</h4> \n<p>Capture leads by placing a link to your sign-up landing page in your channel header. This image is front and center on your profile, and if your <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/youtube-templates\">banner is eye-catching</a>, well designed, and calls attention to your content offer, users will be drawn to it, which places the CTA link in their direct line of sight.</p> \n<p>The red arrow in the image below points to a CTA on the HubSpot Academy YouTube page that leads users to a course enrollment offer that requires an email to sign up.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot%20academy%20youtube.jpg?width=2306&amp;name=hubspot%20academy%20youtube.jpg\" alt=\"hubspot academy youtube channel sign up link CTA\" width=\"2306\" style=\"width: 2306px;\"></p> \n<h4>18. Promote your emails in your video descriptions.</h4> \n<p>Your YouTube video descriptions talk about the content within your videos, so viewers know what they’re about to watch. Each of your descriptions will likely contain unique elements, but it’s worth plugging your email sign-up landing page link within each of them.</p> \n<p>This tip can be especially useful if you create how-to style videos, and you can entice users to sign up for more informative content and instruction by clicking the link in your description.</p> \n<p><strong>Featured Resource: </strong><strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/youtube-templates\">7 YouTube Description Templates [Free Prompts]</a></strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/youtube-templates\"><strong><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/youtube%20description%20template.png?width=444&amp;name=youtube%20description%20template.png\" alt=\"free youtube description template\" width=\"444\" style=\"width: 444px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></strong></a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/youtube-templates\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Download These Customizable Prompts</a></p> \n<h3>How To Grow Your Email List Using Instagram</h3> \n<h4>19. Add a call to action to your Instagram bio.</h4> \n<p>Your Instagram bio is a great place to share information with your audience, like a CTA that calls attention to your email list and a link to your sign-up form.</p> \n<p>Your CTA text should entice users by explaining the benefit they get from signing up, like obtaining bonus info, access to exclusive offers, or a general business newsletter. Placing the link directly in your bio also reduces customer effort, as they can simply click and sign up in a pop-up window within the app.</p> \n<h4>20. Share posts that lead users to click the call-to-action email link in your bio.</h4> \n<p>While you may not share posts that outright say “Give us your email,” you can certainly see success from sharing posts that entice users to share their contact info.</p> \n<p>For example, you can advertise a giveaway and let users know that they can enter by clicking the link in your bio and submitting their email addresses. In another case, if you post an informative video about how to use your products, you can entice users to sign up because your emails will offer more informational content about how to use your products.</p> \n<h4>21. Use the swipe-up feature to share your landing page.</h4> \n<p>If you have an Instagram Business profile and more than 10k followers, you can add a clickable link to your Stories that users can access by swiping up on the story.</p> \n<p>This feature is an excellent opportunity to share a link to your sign-up page or another offer on your site that collects email addresses in exchange for value, like a free trial. You can also use this feature to link to something like an informative blog post with a lead generation offer that your audience will be excited to sign up for.</p> \n<p><strong>Featured Resource: </strong><strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/instagram-templates-for-business?_ga=2.117640203.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">8 Instagram Story Templates</a></strong></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/instagram%20story.jpg?width=373&amp;name=instagram%20story.jpg\" alt=\"sample instagram story swipe up template\" width=\"373\" style=\"width: 373px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/instagram-templates-for-business\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Download These Free Templates</a></p> \n<h4>22. Add an email button to your business profile.</h4> \n<p>A more direct way to get user emails is to add an email button to your business page. This tool is primarily used for service needs so that customers can reach out to you for support inquiries. Still, it gives you the opportunity for further lead nurturing by asking if customers want to opt-in to receiving more emails.</p> \n<p>Here’s <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/help/instagram/1419650861499317\">a guide</a>&nbsp;on how to add one to your profile.</p> \n<h3>How To Grow Your Email List Using LinkedIn</h3> \n<h4>23. Send readers to a landing page for email sign-up.</h4> \n<p>After having conversations on LinkedIn, you can share links to your sign-up pages. You’re allowing users to continue the interaction you’ve just had, as your email will provide them with further high-quality information and content related to your business. &nbsp;</p> \n<p>You can send these links in InMail messages, comment threads, and personal 1:1 direct messages.</p> \n<h4>24. Post about your email newsletter.</h4> \n<p>If you have an email newsletter, you can post snippets of its content on LinkedIn and let users know that, if they sign up, they’ll get access to the entire piece and every newsletter from there on out.</p> \n<h4>25. Publish links to gated offers.</h4> \n<p>When you share a post on LinkedIn that contains high-quality information your audience can benefit from, round it out by encouraging users to sign up for your email list. If what you’ve said has resonated with them, they’ll recognize that receiving emails from you will give them additional access to the high-quality content you offer.</p> \n<p>You can also do this in appropriate and relevant LinkedIn group discussions — just be mindful of the topic being discussed to ensure your offer is a welcome addition to the conversation.</p> \n<h3>How To Grow Your Email List On Your Website</h3> \n<h4>26. Ask website visitors for feedback</h4> \n<p>People enjoy offering feedback on information that pertains to them. On your site pages, include a form that asks visitors what questions they might have about your business, and collect email addresses to follow up with them.</p> \n<h4>27. Shorten the length of your lead-capturing forms</h4> \n<p>It’s tempting to collect as much information on a user as possible right away, but adding too many fields to your landing pages and lead-capturing forms can drive people away. Reduce the length of your forms to just two to three fields — you can collect more information from them once you start a conversation.</p> \n<h4>28. Link to offers across your website that capture email signups</h4> \n<p>Create CTAs that link to your offers across your website that captures email sign-ups. Some key places to consider include your website’s homepage, your ‘About Us’ page, and your ‘Contact Us’ page.</p> \n<h4>29. A/B test different campaign copy</h4> \n<p>You might be doing all the right things to generate leads — landing pages, gated content, contests, and more, but not seeing the success you’re looking for. The problem may be that the design or copy itself isn’t driving the engagement you need.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing?_ga=2.117640203.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">A/B test </a>different aspects of your list-building campaigns with different versions of the same content. This includes the call-to-action text, the color of the gated offer, and even where these sign-up forms are placed on your website. Sometimes a small change can drive hundreds more conversions. &nbsp;</p> \n<p><strong>Featured Resource: </strong><strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ab-testing-kit\">The Complete A/B Testing Kit</a></strong></p> \n<p><strong><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/a_b%20testing-1.jpg?width=414&amp;name=a_b%20testing-1.jpg\" alt=\"free A/B testing kit cover page\" width=\"414\" style=\"width: 414px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><br></strong></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ab-testing-kit\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Download the Free Kit</a></p> \n<h4>30. Create a blog that readers can subscribe to.</h4> \n<p>If you don’t already blog, you should. Blog posts help you increase your ranking on search engines and generate blog subscribers to upgrade to more actionable email campaigns over time.</p> \n<h4>31. Guest blog for other websites and share a call-to-action.</h4> \n<p>There are many websites and publishers out there that cater to your audience — and larger portions of it. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/guest-blogging?_ga=2.70528018.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">Guest blogging</a>&nbsp;for these websites helps you expand your contact list through exposure to a new audience.</p> \n<p>When you create guest blogging content, include a CTA for readers to subscribe to your sites’ blog or email newsletter.</p> \n<h4>32. Include customer reviews on your sign-up landing pages.</h4> \n<p>It’s one thing for you to tell people to sign up for a campaign, but it’s another thing for your happiest customers to say it too. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-reviews-testimonials?_ga=2.70528018.302710988.1623444582-1034280639.1623444582\">Customer reviews</a>&nbsp;are the social proof that encourages people to join in on something, and you should publish these reviews on your website, especially landing pages with sign-up forms. Including reviews will add genuine value to your content when people are on the fence about submitting contact information.</p> \n<h3>How To Grow Your Email List With a Partner</h3> \n<h4>33. Run a promotion on a partner website or email newsletter.</h4> \n<p>Similar to guest blogging, partner websites can help you target a new audience. Use this partner source to direct visitors to your website, where you’re already sharing sign-up forms.</p> \n<h4>34. Host a co-marketing offer with a partner.</h4> \n<p>Creating an ebook or webinar with a partner can split up the work of content creation and allow you to share the audience of a similar business. After you release your content, split the leads you generate with your partner.</p> \n<p>Creating an ebook or webinar with a partner can split up the work of content creation and allow you to share the audience of a similar business. If the content is gated, you’ll collect email addresses from a new audience for nurturing.</p> \n<h3>How To Grow Your Email List With Traditional Marketing</h3> \n<h4>35. Collect email addresses at a trade show.</h4> \n<p>Offline events like trade shows are highly anticipated growth opportunities for professionals in your industry. Demo your latest product at an appropriate conference and collect signups in person.</p> \n<p>Once you’re back at the office, import these signups into your contact database, and be sure to send a welcome email that confirms their opt-in to your list.</p> \n<h4>36. Host your own offline, in-person events.</h4> \n<p>Meetups, seminars, hackathons, educational panels, and your conferences place you front and center of a networking event. Those who attend are often more qualified to be contacted because they came to your event. Take the opportunity to collect email addresses from attendees, and send a welcome email and encourage opt-in.</p> \n<h4>37. Host an online webinar.</h4> \n<p>Webinars are the perfect opportunity to talk about your industry and access the audience of thought leaders that you may want to present with. The best part? Webinars are normally registered for via email, so you have audience emails to add to your list for further nurturing upon registration.</p> \n<h4>38. Add QR codes to your display ad.</h4> \n<p>Incorporate a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/29449/how-to-create-a-qr-code-in-4-quick-steps.aspx\">QR code</a> into your print marketing collateral that people can scan for more information on the printer content. You can set it so that your codes require email addresses to access additional content so that you can grow your list.</p> \n<h4>39. Collect emails in-store.</h4> \n<p>If you have a brick-and-mortar store where you interact with customers face-to-face, launch a store membership that they can sign up for via email at the register. You can create an email campaign designated to walk-in customers, which can help you keep in touch and reward loyalty to your product.</p> \n<p>The examples above are all things you can do to increase your business’s email list. The best way to do so is to leverage multiple strategies on this list, helping you reach your audiences from a wide variety of angles and increase the chances of growing your list.</p> \n<p>As you grow your email list with fresh, opt-in contacts, you'll be able to nurture them with middle-of-the-funnel offers that allow you to convert early-stage leads into sales-ready leads.</p> \n<p></p>
