%2F25-clever-ways-to-grow-your-email-marketing-list.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn99@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-52-124_dc7e4e15d6fa6fc3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938154},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"20 of the Best Infographic Examples to Inspire Your Next Design","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-infographics-2016","description":"<p>There's a lot to like about well-designed infographics — whether it’s the beautiful typography, concise messaging, clever layouts, or bold graphics.</p> \n<p>Not to mention that people retain <a href=\"http://brainrules.net/vision/\">65% of information passed along with an image</a> compared to only 10% when they listen to the same piece of information.</p> \n<p>As the fourth most-used type of content marketing, infographics pop up all over the place — from social media posts to whitepapers. But don't be fooled. They require just as much strategic thinking as a blog post or video.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=dc2acf6a-f8c1-44a8-ac28-b628a791cd9d&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: 15 Free Infographic Templates\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/dc2acf6a-f8c1-44a8-ac28-b628a791cd9d.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>Yet, as this list of the best infographic examples shows, the effort is worthwhile. Adding them to your marketing strategy can <a href=\"http://0ca36445185fb449d582-f6ffa6baf5dd4144ff990b4132ba0c4d.r41.cf1.rackcdn.com/Infograhic%20-%20visual%20content%20-%209-17.jpg\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">increase web traffic by 12% </a>and help you stay competitive in the B2B crowd, where <a href=\"https://contentmarketinginstitute.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/2018-b2b-research-final.pdf\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">65% of marketers use infographics</a>.</p> \n<p>Luckily, there are numerous <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/resources-for-creating-infographics?_ga=2.244628805.119037023.1622227875-266303385.1622227875\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">resources to create beautiful infographics</a> of your own.</p> \n<p>To help inspire your next visual creation, here are a handful of stunning branded infographics to kickstart your creativity.</p> \n<h2>Best Infographic Examples to Get Inspired</h2> \n<h3>Simple Infographic Examples</h3> \n<h4>1. <a href=\"https://www.chairoffice.co.uk/blog/10-world-records-you-can-break-working-from-home/\">10 Records You Can Break Working From Home</a>, by ChairOffice</h4> \n<p>Although it’s essential to complete your tasks and remain productive while working from home, many employees often find themselves working too hard without any breaks.</p> \n<p>This brilliant, yet straightforward infographic from ChairOffice contains 10 world records you can attempt as you take necessary breaks from work.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/10-records-break-from-home.jpg?width=455&amp;name=10-records-break-from-home.jpg\" alt=\"WFH records to break infographic\" width=\"455\" style=\"width: 455px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\">With vibrant colors, animated characters, and text, this infographic shares a simple message: take breaks. Who knows? You might be breaking a world record.</p> \n<h4>2. <a href=\"https://www.spielcreative.com/blog/shooting-video-by-yourself/\">A Simple Guide to Shooting Video By Yourself</a>, by Spielcreative</h4> \n<p>Although <a href=\"https://www.wyzowl.com/video-marketing-statistics-2020/\">86% of businesses</a> use videos as part of their marketing strategy, only a few get it right.</p> \n<p>Whether it’s background noises, poor lighting, or some other distraction, the videos don’t usually come out the right way.</p> \n<p>This infographic from Spielcreative offers tips you’d need to create incredible videos all by yourself.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/shooting-video-yourself.jpg?width=530&amp;name=shooting-video-yourself.jpg\" alt=\"guide to shooting video yourself\" width=\"530\" style=\"width: 530px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\">The use of simple graphics and arrow pointers makes the visualization easy to follow and understand. You also don’t have to strain your eyes to read the text, as it's big enough to read from afar.</p> \n<h4>3. <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/106161273/Infographic-style/modules/609149733\">A Purposeful Life</a>, by Studio Patten</h4> \n<p>This free infographic from Studio Patten collects different survey results concerning living a purposeful life and presents the data with visually appealing charts.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/a-purposeful-life.jpg?width=597&amp;name=a-purposeful-life.jpg\" alt=\"infographic for living a purposeful life\" width=\"597\" style=\"width: 597px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Although the topic of a purposeful life might be a deep one, this infographic does a great job of presenting the information simply.</p> \n<p>There’s also a nice balance between the use of text and data visualization elements.</p> \n<h4>4. <a href=\"https://www.towerelectricbikes.com/most-bike-friendly-cities\">The Most and Least Bike-Friendly Cities In America</a>, by Tower Electric Bikes</h4> \n<p>Knowing whether a city is bike-friendly or not is a factor cyclists consider when moving.</p> \n<p>Naturally, questions about the city’s bike lanes, cyclist fatality rates, and the number of people using bikes would come up in a cyclist’s mind. Tower Electric Bikes answers these questions using this simple infographic.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bike-friendly-cities.jpg?width=601&amp;name=bike-friendly-cities.jpg\" alt=\"infographic of bike friendly cities\" width=\"601\" style=\"width: 601px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>To make sense of the infographic, Tower Electric Bikes used color gradation (going from green to red) to help its audience of cyclists understand how friendly the different cities in the United States are.</p> \n<p>Cyclists can take a look and tell they’d need to avoid the Los Angeles areas if they want to enjoy sunny days out on their bikes.</p> \n<h4>5. <a href=\"https://ivypanda.com/blog/how-to-actually-enjoy-studying/\">How to Enjoy Studying</a>, by IvyPanda</h4> \n<p>Studying doesn’t always have to be a chore. IvyPanda created this excellent infographic design to help students enjoy studying instead of feeling burned out or turning to social media because of boredom.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/enjoy-studying.jpg?width=447&amp;name=enjoy-studying.jpg\" alt=\"infographic on how to enjoy studying\" width=\"447\" style=\"width: 447px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>The use of bright colors and minimalist animated design is brilliant from IvyPanda.</p> \n<h3>Business Infographic Examples</h3> \n<h4>6. <a href=\"https://www.zendesk.com/blog/smb-sales-teams-keeping-2020/\">How SMB Sales Teams Are Keeping Up in 2020</a>, by Zendesk</h4> \n<p>We all know 2020 led to massive changes in the way we work, buy, and enjoy leisure time. But this infographic by Zendesk hones in on a specific group (SMB sales teams) to show how they keep up with the times.</p> \n<p>Through research-backed data, clear visuals, and concise copy, the main point comes across crystal clear: Know customers' expectations to meet them where they are.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/SMB-sales-teams.jpg?width=604&amp;name=SMB-sales-teams.jpg\" alt=\"an infographic on SMB sales teams\" width=\"604\" style=\"width: 604px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>This infographic does an excellent job following one theme, from start to finish. Readers can answer \"<em>What's the point?</em>\" within the first few sentences — a best practice, according to <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/infographic-best-practices/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">CoSchedule</a>.</p> \n<p>This helps focus your infographic and avoids cramming too much information into one piece, which is why Zendesk flowed from the research and stats to how SMB sales teams adopt new technology to keep up.</p> \n<p>It even includes the benefits of<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/crm/e010a?\"> CRM technology</a>, like a 52% increase in productivity from sales reps. Of course, the benefits align with the customer service software Zendesk offers, making the infographic a good sales tool for its team.</p> \n<h4>7. <a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/en-uk/marketing-solutions/blog/posts/content-marketing-in-times-of-uncertainty/2020/Infographic-How-has-2020-affected-your-content-strategy\">Content Marketing in Times of Uncertainty</a>, by LinkedIn</h4> \n<p>More than eight out of 10 people want brands to act as a news source in uncertain times, foster a sense of community, and provide educational resources. Whew.</p> \n<p>As a content marketer, those are significant expectations to live up to. LinkedIn realized the changing global landscape would alter customer expectations and, as a result, content marketing strategies. So the team put together this handy infographic to help marketers focus on what matters most.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/content-marketing-in-times-of-uncertainty.jpg?width=525&amp;name=content-marketing-in-times-of-uncertainty.jpg\" alt=\"content marketing infographic example\" width=\"525\" style=\"width: 525px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>This infographic example features several design elements from LinkedIn's current brand. The graphics adhere to its primary and complementary color scheme, include diverse illustrations, and relate to the work-from-home times.</p> \n<p>It also uses color block banners to add visual interest and break up chunks of text. But my favorite part? The ruler graphic on how to measure ROI and show why your efforts are worthwhile.</p> \n<h4>8. <a href=\"https://blog.bannersnack.com/working-from-home/\">How to Be Productive While Working From Home</a>, by Bannersnack</h4> \n<p>Working from home isn't the pajama party many people (used to) imagine. As offices closed and millions turned dining tables into home office spaces, Bannersnack created this infographic to help its employees transition to a different way of working. As a freelancer working remotely for the past five years, I found it full of practical tips and valuable tools.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/WFH-productivity-tips.jpg?width=782&amp;name=WFH-productivity-tips.jpg\" alt=\"productivity infographic for working from home\" width=\"782\" style=\"width: 782px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Beyond essential elements like brand colors, Bannersnack includes information people can immediately put to use. While it's easy to stay planted on your couch all day, Bannersnack recommends finding multiple workspaces for different tasks — an inspirational spot for creative thinking and another for deep work and crunched deadlines.</p> \n<p>Tips like this may seem small once you've been working remotely for a while, but for newcomers, it's one less thing you have to learn while adjusting to a different routine.</p> \n<h4>9. <a href=\"https://www.netcredit.com/blog/45-slack-tricks-impress-boss/\">45 Slack Tricks That Will Impress Your Boss</a>, by Net Credit</h4> \n<p>A tool as powerful as Slack has many features most people will never use, yet this infographic makes it easy to look like the cool \"Slack-er\" at the company even if you've only mastered the /giphy shortcut until now.</p> \n<p>Net Credit starts with a handful of stats to inform readers and give an idea of Slack's scope. Who knew people spend 50 million hours on the platform in <em>one week</em>? I'm intrigued and want to keep reading.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/slack-tips.jpg?width=584&amp;name=slack-tips.jpg\" alt=\"slack tips infographic\" width=\"584\" style=\"width: 584px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>As you scroll down the graphic, you see a combination of direct headlines \"Read Channel Highlight\" followed by text instructions and visual cues. As a visual learner, I appreciate how these cues mirror the actual interface.</p> \n<p>Each section is organized to help you find what you're looking for, whether it's \"#channel\" or \"message\" tips. Finance may be Net Credit's bread and butter, but this infographic shows how its team is adaptable and helpful — exactly what you want in a financial partner.</p> \n<h4>10. <a href=\"https://www.tdinsights.com/infographics/how-bad-data-affects-business/\">How Bad Data Affects Businesses</a>, TD Insights</h4> \n<p>A bad egg spoils the whole bunch, but what effect does bad data have on businesses? TD Insights answers that question with this excellent infographic design.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how-bad-data-affects-business.jpg?width=433&amp;name=how-bad-data-affects-business.jpg\" alt=\"infographic on how bad data affects business\" width=\"433\" style=\"width: 433px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>The use of contrast makes this infographic visually appealing. Any reader can quickly identify the main themes and points of the design because of the creative use of different fonts.</p> \n<h3>Timeline Infographic Examples</h3> \n<h4>11. <a href=\"https://www.visualcapitalist.com/techs-bizarre-beginnings-lucrative-pivots/\">Tech's Bizarre Beginnings &amp; Lucrative Pivots</a>, by Visual Capitalist</h4> \n<p>The beauty of infographics? They can be used by dozens of industries for hundreds of different purposes. But the best ones are often unexpected.</p> \n<p>Take this graphic designed by Visual Capitalist. It reveals the wild origin stories of some of the biggest tech companies today. I had no idea YouTube began as a video dating site with the tagline \"Tune In. Hook Up.\"</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/tech-bizarre-beginnings.jpg?width=603&amp;name=tech-bizarre-beginnings.jpg\" alt=\"youtube origins infographic\" width=\"603\" style=\"width: 603px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>As a growing online publication that focuses on data and technology news, Visual Capitalist's audience is likely interested in stories around company pivots that led to success.</p> \n<p>That information, coupled with a simple timeline structure, fun graphics, and hard-hitting metrics, makes it tough to look away from this infographic. Plus, we all need reminders that it's not where you start but where you're going.</p> \n<h4>12. <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/106161273/Infographic-style?tracking_source=search_projects_recommended%7Cinfographic\">Power Shifts</a>, Studio Patten</h4> \n<p>The United States is a powerful nation, but that wasn’t the case centuries ago.</p> \n<p>In this infographic, Studio Patten takes us on a journey through the years that show the most powerful nations at different times in history.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/power-shifts.jpg?width=601&amp;name=power-shifts.jpg\" alt=\"infographic on power shifts\" width=\"601\" style=\"width: 601px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>This infographic is simple, but it also uses creative images and text to provide a history lesson.</p> \n<h4>13. <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/109330107/Infographic-The-Evolution-of-US-Vaccines?tracking_source=search_projects_recommended%7Cinfographic\">The Evolution of US Vaccines</a>, by Janet Haniak</h4> \n<p>Humans have been fighting diseases and pandemics long before COVID-19. Here is one of the many infographics that make it easy to learn about past vaccines created to combat these diseases.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/evolution-of-US-vaccines.jpg?width=604&amp;name=evolution-of-US-vaccines.jpg\" alt=\"infographic on the evolution of US vaccines\" width=\"604\" style=\"width: 604px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>The use of real-life images instead of cartoon characters makes this infographic more believable. Instead of complicating the infographic, the designer made the timeline appear on a single line, with the notable event branching out of that line.</p> \n<h4>14. <a href=\"https://www.bluemailmedia.com/the-journey-of-oprah-winfrey.php\">The Journey of Oprah Winfrey</a>, by Blue Mail Media</h4> \n<p>Oprah Winfrey is one of the most powerful women alive today. But did you know she grew up in a poverty-stricken family and had a tough childhood?</p> \n<p>This infographic from Blue Mail Media allows us to look into Oprah's early life and how she grew to become who she is today.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/journey-of-oprah-winfrey.jpg?width=280&amp;name=journey-of-oprah-winfrey.jpg\" alt=\"oprah winfrey infographic\" width=\"280\" style=\"width: 280px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\">Although this infographic has a prominent blue background, the other bright colors make engaging with it easy. The quote breaks also add personality to the infographic.</p> \n<h4>15. <a href=\"https://www.viziononline.co.uk/apple-timeline/\">Apple History Timeline</a>, by Viziononline</h4> \n<p>Apple is the subject of this creative infographic created by Viziononline, and why not? Apple is one of the largest corporations in the world. In fact, you’re likely reading this article on your iPhone, iPad, or Mac.</p> \n<p>But was Apple always this big?</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/apple-history-timeline.jpg?width=494&amp;name=apple-history-timeline.jpg\" alt=\"infographic of apple's history\" width=\"494\" style=\"width: 494px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>With one look, a reader can tell that this visualization is about Apple because of the different products that appear throughout the infographic.</p> \n<h3>Interactive Infographic Examples</h3> \n<h4>16. <a href=\"https://www.fda.gov/medical-devices/coronavirus-covid-19-and-medical-devices/center-devices-and-radiological-healths-response-coronavirus-covid-19-infographic\">Response to COVID-19</a>, by the U.S Food and Drug Administration</h4> \n<p>It wouldn't be a 2021 round-up without mentioning the global pandemic that kept many of us at home for months. The bright spot? There are infographics galore educating people on how to wash their hands and social distance properly.</p> \n<p>The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) also relied on this visual medium to share how their regulatory department addressed COVID-19.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/COVID-response.jpg?width=604&amp;name=COVID-response.jpg\" alt=\"COVID-19 infographic\" width=\"604\" style=\"width: 604px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>This infographic example made our list for several reasons. First, to show how infographics can highlight the impact, instead of sharing step-by-step instructions or research-oriented content.</p> \n<p>The impact of each action is organized into separate columns and given a distinct color to help your eyes track from top to bottom. While this flow breaks the typical left-to-right reading pattern, it's not distracting or difficult to follow.</p> \n<p>The healthcare worker design at the top of the page nods to those on the frontlines, the colors align with the brand, actual numbers are easy to read, and the page isn't crowded with text.</p> \n<p>So the next time you need to explain the fruits of your labors to your boss, help win them over with an impact-driven infographic.</p> \n<h4>17. <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/108639369/Green-Blue-Gruppo-Gedi-2020?tracking_source=search_projects_recommended%7Cinfographic%202020\">Pianeta Plastica</a>, by Manuel Bortoletti for GEDI Gruppo</h4> \n<p>“<em>Che bello”</em> is the first thought that comes to mind for this design. The stunning data visualizations, oceanic color scheme, and easy-to-understand layout let the visuals do the talking. Visme explains how an infographic follows this <a href=\"https://visme.co/blog/infographic-best-practices/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">essential best practice</a> if it makes sense with all of the text removed.</p> \n<p>That may seem impossible, but designer <a href=\"https://www.manuelbortoletti.com/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Manuel Bortoletti</a> pulls it off with informative maps accompanied by clear keys and a bar graph that uses oil tankers to inform readers about how oil circulates the globe.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pianeta-plastica.jpg?width=580&amp;name=pianeta-plastica.jpg\" alt=\"ocean pollution infographic\" width=\"580\" style=\"width: 580px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Even with my incredibly limited Italian, I understand that the main point of the piece is to inform readers about the impact of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. And since this infographic was designed for the Italian media outlet GEDI Gruppo, it stays on-brand with a more formal editorial tone.</p> \n<h4>18. <a href=\"https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/conditions-and-diseases/coronavirus/proper-mask-wearing-coronavirus-prevention-infographic\">How to Properly Wear a Mask</a>, by John Hopkins Medicine</h4> \n<p>Education is the crux of an infographic. And when you have mere seconds to capture <a href=\"https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/04/190415081959.htm\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">people's increasingly narrow attention span</a>, the information better be easy to learn.</p> \n<p>That's why one of the best infographic examples comes from John Hopkins Medicine. They designed an infographic to share tips on a crucial COVID-19 procedure: wearing a mask.</p> \n<p>Is covering your nose important? You bet. What about wearing a bandana as a mask? No way. Hopkins uses a combination of straightforward graphics and copy to make the do's and don'ts very clear.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how-to-wear-a-mask.jpg?width=592&amp;name=how-to-wear-a-mask.jpg\" alt=\"infographic on how to wear a mask\" width=\"592\" style=\"width: 592px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>As a renowned medical institution, Hopkins has the experience and authority to educate people on this topic, so it fits its brand and is helpful for everyone's health — a true win-win.</p> \n<h4>19. <a href=\"https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/report/2020/overview/\">The Sustainable Development Goals Report</a>, by the United Nations</h4> \n<p>Infographics are a great way to add visual flavor to otherwise dry content, like annual reports and whitepapers.</p> \n<p>What stands out in this infographic example is how it can be used as one visual or divided into 17 sections — one for each Sustainable Development Goal. This allows the content team to choose which type of content best fits the target audience.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sustainable-development-goals-report.jpg?width=612&amp;name=sustainable-development-goals-report.jpg\" alt=\"sustainable development infographic\" width=\"612\" style=\"width: 612px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>If the UN is speaking to organizations that empower women and girls, they can share the \"Gender Equality'' graphic. But a non-profit that promotes all of the UN goals will likely be interested in the entire design.</p> \n<p>While a lot of information is packed into each graphic, it's never overwhelming. Each goal is separate from the other with bold headers and distinct colors, which are also used to differentiate the UN's marketing efforts.</p> \n<h4>20. <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/116182411/Ocean-Pollution?tracking_source=search_projects_recommended%7Cinfographic\">Ocean Pollution</a>, by Stephanie Phung</h4> \n<p>Designer Stephanie Phung created this engaging visualization to make more people aware of the ocean’s current state of pollution.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-28%20at%2012.59.58%20PM.jpg?width=603&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-28%20at%2012.59.58%20PM.jpg\" alt=\"pollution infographic\" width=\"603\" style=\"width: 603px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>This free infographic uses art to tell a story about the financial and environmental implications of ocean pollution. The designer also uses colors and design elements — the blue color for the sea — that people are already familiar with.</p> \n<h2>Ready to start designing stunning infographics?</h2> \n<p>Now that your creativity is sparked, it's the perfect time to start creating your infographics.</p> \n<p>While the infographics you create might be different from those on this list, ensure they’re colorful and engaging. And most importantly, that the infographics pass across information in a manner that’s easy to understand.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=533acc01-d1a9-4b4c-a5b3-d746ecdf1855&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/533acc01-d1a9-4b4c-a5b3-d746ecdf1855.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img %20at%2012.59.58%20PM.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn44@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-52-243_c9584d81d0745d3a.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/533acc01-d1a9-4b4c-a5b3-d746ecdf1855.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn35@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-53-044_876c8c95ff1634c4.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbest-infographics-2016&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn77@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-51-630_2ffe473314022096.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938163},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"38 Fun Corporate Team-Building Activities & Outing Ideas Everyone Will Enjoy","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/creative-team-outing-ideas","description":"<p>Are you starting to notice some droopy shoulders around the office? It sounds like it's time to plan a team outing.</p>  \n<p>Team outings are a great way to facilitate bonding with your team members, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/avoidable-problems-stressing-out-marketing-employees?_ga=2.160203966.2020453271.1624402001-1385980291.1624402001\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">reduce employee stress</a>, and give them the chance to get to know one another outside of the office.</p>  \n<p>And, you know, they're entertaining.</p> \n<p>But how do you find ideas for a great team outing? Maybe you start with a Google search for \"team outing ideas\" and stumble upon an article that suggests \"field trips\" and \"professional development activities.\" It sounds like a starting point, but where's the real excitement?</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3f403048-fd8e-426f-bddd-4fce020ae24b&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Free Company Culture Code Template&nbsp;\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3f403048-fd8e-426f-bddd-4fce020ae24b.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>Next time you plan an outing for your team, cut the trust-falls and get one of these ideas on the calendar instead. We have something for everyone — from perfect activities for remote teams to large or small in-house groups to events that enhance teamwork and events that all team members can enjoy outdoors.</p> \n<h2>Why should you do team-building activities for work?</h2> \n<p>Team building activities can be embarrassing for coworkers, and some don’t even add anything that relates to the workplace. For example, while ‘trust falls’ seems like an excellent idea, forcing it doesn’t improve trust among coworkers, and what is worse, it can result in injuries when pairings are not even.</p> \n<p>However, not all team-building activities are detrimental to your workers, as you would see from the ideas we highlight in this post.</p> \n<p>One of the most significant advantages of the right team-building activities is that it boosts morale among your workforce. Team members get to work together on exciting and challenging activities and can display their skills and talents.</p> \n<p>Team-building activities and games that boost morale can break down barriers among employees and create an environment that is nice to work in, which is vital to a successful and well-functioning business.</p> \n<p>The ultimate goal of team-building activities is to get your team members to bond and build trust with each other. People with different backgrounds, needs, ambitions, and personalities make up teams.</p> \n<p>By engaging in the right team-building activities, you can bring these different people together to build a bonded, trusting team.</p> \n<p>When your team bonds, it results in several benefits for the company. <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Some of these benefits include:</span></p> \n<h3>1. Improved Communication Skills</h3> \n<p>Communication between staff and departments is essential to a company’s success. Team-building exercises put people in a relaxed environment and encourage them to communicate while completing tasks.</p> \n<h3>2. Improved Productivity</h3> \n<p>Better communication skills will have a domino effect on productivity levels. When your employees work together and communicate, there is less work duplication and less friction between workers.</p> \n<h3>3. Identifies Leaders</h3> \n<p>Another benefit from team-building exercises is that managers can discover leaders within the workforce while engaging in team-building activities.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Regardless of the type of event that you want to enjoy, here are eight essential things to consider:</p> \n<h3>1. Define your goals.</h3> \n<p>You must determine clear areas of focus that you want to enhance during team-building events. Only after selecting the activity’s goals can you successfully choose the activities and challenges that would best fit the occasion.</p> \n<h3>2. Set a budget.</h3> \n<p>A budget needs to be determined after you have decided on your priorities. With a realistic budget, you can ensure that the price of the event doesn’t run out of control.</p> \n<h3>3. Set up a planning team.</h3> \n<p>As you begin planning, you will discover how difficult it can be for one person to organize a team-building event. There are so many things you need to prepare for, and the best way to deal with these things is to delegate responsibilities.</p> \n<h3>4. Invite and involve the right people.</h3> \n<p>Sometimes, it is easy to determine who to invite. Some other times, it can be challenging choosing who to invite. To help you, ask yourself (or the planning team these questions):</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Is it a compulsory event?</li> \n <li>What is the maximum number of people that the budget and venue can accommodate?</li> \n <li>Will remote employees be invited?</li> \n <li>Can anyone attend the event?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Answering these questions can make it easier for you to invite the right people.</p> \n<h3>5. Select the right activities.</h3> \n<p>After determining the goals of the team-building event, you should have a clear idea of activities that will align with these goals.</p> \n<p>It is best to choose activities that are interactive, engaging and that build collaboration among employees.</p> \n<h3>6. Choose a great time.</h3> \n<p>The best time for a team-building event depends on the schedule and personal lives of those you plan to invite. Ensure that invitees are free before you commit to a day and time. You also need to take the weather and season into account when choosing a date - especially if organizing an outdoor activity.</p> \n<h3>7. Choose a good location.</h3> \n<p>The location is one of the factors that can make or mar your event. You need to avoid places that’ll not accommodate enough people or that aren’t suitable for the activities you’ve planned.</p> \n<h3>8. Market the event internally.</h3> \n<p>Marketing the event internally will likely build excitement among employees. Developing and distributing an “Event Day Agenda” that highlights all the activities employees will enjoy will increase expectations for the day and get folks excited.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>Remote Team Building Activities</h3> \n<h4>1. Virtual Break Room</h4> \n<p>The simple chats that happen on the office floor are sorely missed. Since most members of your team still work remotely, a virtual break room is an excellent team-building activity.</p> \n<p>You can create this via Zoom or some other platform where staff can log in and join over their lunch or break - allowing them to catch up with coworkers as they would in a physical office.</p> \n<p>You can also keep water cooler moments alive by encouraging workers to share interesting photos or videos.</p> \n<h4>2. Virtual Escape Room</h4> \n<p>Since the pandemic made physical escape rooms impossible to visit, a <a href=\"https://theescapegame.com/remote-adventures/?utm_source=snacknation&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=virtual-team-building\">Virtual Escape Room</a> brings the mystery to your workers right in their homes!</p> \n<p>Depending on the Escape Room you choose, team members have to pass through different rooms, solve the puzzles they encounter, solve a murder, and so much more!. It is just as fun as it sounds, and what is more, it builds collaboration and communication among staff.</p> \n<h4>3. Beer Making</h4> \n<p>In this team-building exercise, team members become brewers for a day right from their homes. The process does not require prior knowledge as <a href=\"https://www.citybrewtours.com/at-home-corporate-craft-beer-events/beer-making-experience/\">Beer Making Experience</a> walks participants through each step of the journey. Kits are also delivered to interested staff.</p> \n<h4>4. Virtual Scavenger Hunt</h4> \n<p>You can quickly organize this team-building activity over a Zoom call. On the call, challenge team members to collect different items from around their homes.</p> \n<p>The first person to show all the required items wins the hunt!</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/Rd_ojgOM2MrLUGRVDlxpt-c4xrkIIdlGnQbrXo1pgWZ6YEC02KNI563gKDV4aYU0rOXBX_dZJl4FVUEZBqD0iM9bEQGBKoXy1WuLiIHF9p4iM_9x6P6TBDAADsft2gWa8t-dLzMF\" width=\"600\" alt=\"host a virtual scavenger hunt for a corporate team-building activity\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><span style=\"font-size: 11px; font-style: italic;\">Source: <a href=\"https://www.scavify.com/\" style=\"font-size: 11px; font-style: italic;\">Scavify</a></span></p> \n<h4>5. Set Competitive Challenges</h4> \n<p>A little friendly competition never hurts any team - on the contrary, it can strengthen the bonds of unity.</p> \n<p>Setting up challenges for your teams can give them a goal to work towards. One popular challenge is the fitness challenge. It provides healthy competition between teams and improves their health.</p> \n<h4>6. Icebreaker Quizzes</h4> \n<p>These quizzes are an exciting and safe way to do team-building weekly. You can choose an online ice-breaker quiz like Quizbreaker, which sends out a new round of quizzes weekly to the team. It can work wonders to bringing remote teams closer as they learn more about each other while having loads of fun.</p> \n<h4>7. Visit Paris Virtually</h4> \n<p>One challenge many HR departments face is onboarding new hires. Virtually visiting new places with tools like <a href=\"https://woyago.com/home/virtual-team-building-hangouts/?utm_medium=affiliate&amp;utm_source=blog.weekdone.com&amp;utm_campaign=wayago&amp;utm_content=team-building\">Woyago </a>is a unique and exciting ice-breaker. The virtual tour offered by Woyago has real-life Parisian guiding participants while throwing challenges along the way.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/D0cKfQXT82JJCn2azANLlIbxAecvHyq31ymycCOL52kkdL04qqrCxcdOSoBmV7lV_svyLrE8K8VaAzoOymubvaRiohoTNdRv9Kp4DNDV91poq6SagNf95ck6cTiDoSVW4kOQgHNT\" width=\"600\" alt=\"visit paris virtually for a corporate team-building activity\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><span style=\"font-size: 11px; font-style: italic;\">Source: <a href=\"https://woyago.com/home/\" style=\"font-size: 11px; font-style: italic;\">Woyago</a></span></p> \n<h3>Large Group Team Building Activities</h3> \n<h4><strong>8. Scavenger Hunt</strong></h4> \n<p>Find a beautiful day, break everyone out into groups, and have a scavenger hunt around the city. You can organize one yourself or use a creative service like <a href=\"https://www.thegogame.com/team-building-games\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">The Go Game</a> (which lists companies like Netflix, Facebook, and HBO among clients) or <a href=\"https://www.strayboots.com/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Stray Boots</a>.</p> \n<p>Your team members will feel nice and rejuvenated after some fresh air and fun challenges. Be sure to take plenty of silly pictures — you can even have a slideshow when everyone regroups at the end.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, you might try a \"Random Acts of Kindness\" hunt. For instance, Outback Team Building &amp; Training <a href=\"https://www.outbackteambuilding.com/event/random-acts-of-kindness/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">offers this team building activity</a>, which requires teams to split up into groups, download Outback's app, and complete a series of challenges to benefit strangers in the community.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/qOPuetA9bL5l18nqCjXZJvaL82R9Mv-R9KkaM_9sVibwViTNdBioeLldu8twy0XD1g06T0RC_btPN5s8gJ8lUM4NXtxdIZwceeK1jDAoGvY0ydppPztuDTTTOsweuY9nPP8em84O\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"host a scavenger hunt for a corporate team-building activity\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 9px;\">Image credit: </span></em><a href=\"https://www.thegogame.com/\" style=\"font-size: 9px; color: #0091ae;\"><em>The Go Game</em></a></p> \n<h4>9. What’s My Name?</h4> \n<p>You might have seen this game played before. It goes by different names, and the more people who play, the better it is.</p> \n<p>What's My Name is an activity where each player is assigned the name of a person — dead or alive — and displays that name on their back, head, or part of their body such that only the other players can read the name. You can write these names on index cards or Post-it notes.</p> \n<p>Once team members have been assigned a name, the players mingle with one another, treating their coworkers the way they'd treat the person listed on that coworker's card. They can also ask questions about their own hidden identity until they correctly guess who they are.</p> \n<p>What's My Name has no complicated rules or potential for competitiveness. It's simply an empathy-builder — a critical ingredient of good company culture — allowing team members to find out what it would be like to be treated the way someone very different from them might be treated every day.</p> \n<h4><strong>10. Cook-Off</strong></h4> \n<p>Here's a culinary team-building activity that could end in dessert or disaster — in a fun way. Creating new dishes together requires creativity and will require everyone to put their team and leadership skills into action.</p> \n<p>Divide your team into smaller teams, pick a food category, and challenge each team to whip up something delicious. The category could be anything from ice cream, to salsa, to pizza.</p> \n<p>One fun twist you could add? Pick a single ingredient that all teams <em>must </em>use, like maple syrup or Oreos. Or, have each team get creative thinking caps on with the shape of its food — you can make pizzas into almost any shape.</p> \n<h4><strong>11. Sneak a Peek</strong></h4> \n<p>What do you get when you add a test of memory to a game of Pictionary? Sneak a Peek. In this game, team members break off into groups of at least four and take turns recreating objects from memory.</p> \n<p>Using LEGOs, clay, building blocks, or a similar set of construction items, one game leader will craft an object or structure for every group to recreate. A member of each group then has 10 seconds to \"sneak a peek\" at the structure (which is hidden), return to their groups, and describe what they saw to the rest of the group so they can recreate it.</p> \n<p>Each group has its LEGOs, clay, or building blocks. If it isn’t complete after a minute of recreating the structure, another member of each group sneaks a 10-second peek at the game leader's object and comes back to instruct the group further.</p> \n<p>This rotation continues until a group is confident they have recreated the item. The object of the game? Be the first group to recreate it.</p> \n<p>Not only does this game help team members practice project management, but it shows you how to accomplish tasks using input from a variety of sources. It's also just a fun way to see how good your coworkers are at retaining information.</p> \n<h4><strong>12. Board Game Tournament</strong></h4> \n<p>Here's one way to spark your team members' competitive sides without having to leave the office. Organize a team-wide board game tournament.</p> \n<p>Especially if your team is pretty big, it might be easiest to pick a single game, then have one team member sign up for specific time slots when they're free to leave their desks and spend some time playing the game.</p> \n<p>Some great games with reasonable play times include Boggle, Jenga, or even games using good ol' playing cards. Don't forget to incentivize with prizes for first, second, and third place.</p> \n<h4><strong>13. Office Trivia</strong></h4> \n<p>Who says trivia night only takes place at the bar? Office trivia is the perfect way to bring a large group of colleagues together and challenge the brain in areas that don't necessarily apply to their daily jobs. Break the company into teams of four or more and offer small prizes for the teams who score the most points.</p> \n<p>Want to write your own trivia questions? For reference, trivia questions are generally sorted into categories — four or five trivia questions per category — with optional bonus questions at the end of the game.</p> \n<p>While you can give each question a point value, you can also assign each team a certain amount of points per category that they can <em>bet</em>, instead. Each team can then bet as many or as few points as they want per question until they've used all their points for that category.</p> \n<p>Not prepared to create your own trivia questions? Hire a trivia organization to host a trivia night at your office. There are tons of national trivia companies who'd be happy to host an event right on site — <a href=\"http://www.district-trivia.com/where/is-trivia\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">District Trivia</a>, <a href=\"http://www.thetriviafactory.com/where-to-play/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">The Trivia Factory</a>, and the <a href=\"http://www.bigquizthing.com/private-corporate-trivia-events/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Big Quiz Thing</a> are just a few of them.</p> \n<h4>14. 4-Question Mingle</h4> \n<p>This activity has each team member moving around and meeting each person individually. It is excellent for teams that have spent some time apart or groups that have just been formed. Armed with four questions, each person gets to know coworkers better.</p> \n<h3>Small-Group Team Building Events</h3> \n<h4><strong>15. Improv Workshop</strong></h4> \n<p>Comedy and improv events are fun, interactive experiences that'll have your employees roaring with laughter while teaching them useful communication and soft skills, like focus and trust.</p> \n<p>Depending on your budget, you could do anything from simply <a href=\"http://www.inc.com/magazine/201404/adam-bluesteint/improv-exercises-for-the-office.html\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">playing improv games</a> with your employees to bringing in professionals to run competitive, fast-paced activities.</p> \n<h4><strong>16. Two Truths and One Lie</strong></h4> \n<p>This is a classic house party fun activity, but it's also an excellent ice-breaker when integrating coworkers who don't yet know one another.</p> \n<p>Two Truths and a Lie is simple: Start by organizing the entire group into a circle and give each person the floor to introduce themselves. In addition to providing their name, however, every team member also says three things about themselves —only two of which are true. It's up to the rest of the group to guess which statement is the lie.</p> \n<h4><strong>17. Karaoke Night</strong></h4> \n<p>What better way to get your employees to break out of their shells than to have them get up and sing some karaoke? You can even have a contest for the best group karaoke performance.</p> \n<p>Bonus points if there are feather boas and cowboy hats involved. This activity works best for a more extroverted group, so if your team isn't into strutting their stuff on stage, consider an idea on this list that caters more to those personalities.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/5qS3ihOYJQutiA6gW6k9oyY5H1XKCYWCKNdMw1xHO8J_2UsnxiBuvGA694PQLl0wyh5XHG7K60joztyFk7_pHoWtQCbooWgCcBGkzYdkO0AgS30GDZaWZ7vEb9Poa1SYSMfl94pE\" width=\"600\" alt=\"go to karaoke for a corporate team-building activity\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 10px; font-style: italic;\">Source: <a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/derekgavey/4917447111\" style=\"font-size: 10px; color: #0091ae; font-style: italic;\">derekgavey</a></span></p> \n<h4><strong>18. The \"Suddenly\" Story</strong></h4> \n<p>If you've ever told stories around a campfire, you might have narrated a variation of The \"Suddenly\" Story. This activity is the choose-your-own-adventure book of team-building.</p> \n<p>However, putting activities. You're not just telling a story — you're piecing a story together using the (often hilarious) imaginations of your coworkers.</p> \n<p>To tell The \"Suddenly\" Story, gather your team in a circle, and offer the opening three sentences to a story about anything. At the end of the three sentences, say \"Suddenly ...\" and pass the story onto the person next to you.</p> \n<p>It's their job to take your three sentences and build on the story with another three sentences, followed by \"Suddenly ...\" Each mention of \"Suddenly\" allows the story to take a turn. What that turn looks like is up to the next person in the circle.</p> \n<p>The \"Suddenly\" Story helps people find ways of building on existing content while also being creative when all ears are on them. Try it the next time you want to get your department together for a break, and you're sure to get everyone laughing.</p> \n<h4><strong>19. Go-Kart Racing</strong></h4> \n<p>There’s nothing like a bit of competition to bond a group together. An adrenaline-pumping activity like kart racing is a great way to get employees to interact with one another in a totally new and fun way. Just make sure everyone pays attention during the safety lecture.</p> \n<h4><strong>20. Concentration (Marketing Edition)</strong></h4> \n<p>Here's a professional spin on the 1960s game show. The original game show, called <a href=\"https://fiftiesweb.com/tv/concentration/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Concentration</a>, put 30 numbered tiles up on a board, each tile with an identical tile somewhere else on the board. What made them similar? They had matching prizes on the back.</p> \n<p>Over time, as contestants opened up more tiles, they had the opportunity to select tiles they knew would match up and win the prize written on the back.</p> \n<p>Businesses — especially marketing departments — can have a field day putting logos, slogans, and company names on the back of their own tiles and having players match up every piece of the brand.</p> \n<p>As your business grows, you can even put the names of your products, employees, and job titles on the backs of your tiles to see how well your coworkers know the company they work for.</p> \n<h4>21. Sales Exercise</h4> \n<p>This activity is perfect for your marketing team but can still be enjoyed by all types of teams and encourages creative thinking. In this building exercise, each group is given an item, from the mundane to the strange. The teams each have five minutes to come up with a creative advert. The team with the most creative advert wins each round.</p> \n<h3>Teamwork Team Building Activities</h3> \n<h4>22. Professional Development Workshop</h4> \n<p>Want to encourage team bonding while providing each team member with an opportunity to learn and further their career?</p> \n<p>Offer a shared learning experience either at your office or at an off-site workshop or conference. The activity could be specifically related to your employees' jobs, or it could be something broader, like a negotiation or leadership skills workshop.</p> \n<h4><strong>23. Jigsaw Puzzle Race</strong></h4> \n<p>Jigsaw puzzles can be a tedious thing to put together alone. Maybe you have one set up at home and make progress on it for a couple of hours every weekend.</p> \n<p>However, putting your numerous brilliant colleagues on the case makes a jigsaw puzzle an enjoyable problem-solving activity. Break the company into teams for a multi-puzzle race, and suddenly you have a test of teamwork that electrifies the entire office.</p> \n<p>Grab several copies of the same puzzle and turn your weekend activity into a contest to see which team can complete the puzzle first. Offer prizes just like you would in a game of office trivia.</p> \n<p>Just be sure each team has the same number of people and choose your puzzle size wisely. A 1000-piece puzzle, for example, might be a bit time-consuming for a team of just five or six people.</p> \n<h4><strong>24. Room Escape Games</strong></h4> \n<p>Here's a great bonding activity that requires leadership skills, teamwork, logic, and patience. Room escape games — Escape the Room, Puzzle Break, AdventureRooms, etc. — have become a wildly popular team-building exercise for groups around the globe.</p> \n<p>Here's how it works: A group of people gets \"locked\" in a room for one hour. During that time limit, they have to find hidden objects, solve puzzles, and figure out clues to locate the key that will set them free. And it's not easy: <a href=\"http://www.bostonmagazine.com/arts-entertainment/blog/2015/02/09/escape-the-room-boston/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Only 20% of players</a> actually make it out before the hour is up.</p> \n<p>If you're not sure how to convert your office space into an escape room, you can always hire a service to do it for you. Companies like <a href=\"https://www.outbackteambuilding.com/event/corporate-escape-rooms/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Outback Team Building &amp; Training</a> host events that turn your office into a team-building escape challenge. And, this can invoke some great, positive memories into a space where your team works every day.</p> \n<h4><strong>25. The Egg Drop Challenge</strong></h4> \n<p>Chances are, you played this in school or summer camp. The <a href=\"https://buggyandbuddy.com/egg-drop-challenge-and-free-planning-printable-science-invitation-saturday/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Egg Drop Challenge</a> is a beloved tradition that challenges teams of kids to create small structures around an uncooked egg to protect the egg from a high fall onto hard ground.</p> \n<p>Each group is given specific items to build the structure that protects the egg, but nothing more. So, why not offer the same challenge to your coworkers?</p> \n<p>Straws, newspaper, tape, and cardboard are just some everyday items provided during the Egg Drop Challenge — as you can see in the sample egg fortress below. However, consider making it even more challenging for your coworkers and allow them to use simply anything available in the office.</p> \n<p>The height of the fall is up to you. But ensure to set an altitude that's consistent with the materials each team has to work with.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/1h-A4f_qR6OyCCYS9ZNeufpQ3AYjItE18uWXrMeQbIuDz4MVYLH1e_BQBkNYpkTC4v7jBkNS1MpUcB4B-rWuFRgHQu-RHVpRAUncULU6fL8zQKXYj-TYYVN2Fxfa511rkWdA_bUp\" width=\"600\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 600px;\" alt=\"egg drop challenge for a corporate team-building activity\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 10px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://buggyandbuddy.com/egg-drop-challenge-free-planning-printable-2014/\" style=\"font-size: 10px; color: #0091ae;\"><em>Buggy and Buddy</em></a></span></p> \n<h4><strong>26. Laser Tag</strong></h4> \n<p>Another great way to get your adrenaline pumping? A good old game of laser tag. Not only is it great fun, it's also an opportunity for employees to exercise their strategy and logic skills, as well as teamwork skills. Bonus: Determine teams ahead of time and have people dress up.</p> \n<h4><strong>27. Catch Phrase</strong></h4> \n<p>In this classic party game, players team up and take turns describing words and phrases to their teammates without saying the word or phrase itself. Phrases can include celebrities, expressions, or just simple things found around the house.</p> \n<p>If my phrase is \"needle in a haystack,\" for example, a clue I might give to my teammates could be \"a pointy object buried inside farm equipment.\"</p> \n<p>Catch Phrase is the perfect way to get your employees together and teach them how to communicate with one another. (Don't worry, everyone will be having so much fun, they won't realize that's what you're doing.)</p> \n<p>This game is often played with a basket of phrases on slips of paper, but it became so popular, Hasbro made an <a href=\"https://shop.hasbro.com/en-us/product/catch-phrase-game:2C79D3B5-5056-9047-F535-614A0B4DE1C0\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">electronic version</a>.</p> \n<h4>28. Game of Possibilities</h4> \n<p>To play this game, give an object to anyone in each group. Then ask each person to demonstrate in front of their group — without talking — what the object is used for. The rest of the team has to guess what object the person is demonstrating. Demonstrations must be creative and original. It can be played in small groups and only requires random objects.</p> \n<h3>Outings and Events Team Building Activities</h3> \n<h4><strong>29. Volunteer</strong></h4> \n<p>Giving time to support a good cause isn't just good for the soul; it's also an excellent way for your team members to bond. Place-based volunteering ideas include volunteering at a local soup kitchen, helping build a <a href=\"http://www.habitat.org/cd/giving/lander/default.aspx?link=271&amp;source_code=DHQOW1407W1GGP&amp;iq_id=62228274-VQ6-77521786995-VQ16-c-VQ14-88743918&amp;gclid=CMbk48HlkMoCFYUYHwodPXkPnA\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Habitat for Humanity</a> house, or delivering gifts to children's hospitals during the holidays.</p> \n<p>Skill-based volunteering is a terrific way to stretch your employees' expertise: It's when your team volunteers its time and uses its professional skills — anything from marketing to app development to writing — to help a nonprofit.</p> \n<p>Try <a href=\"http://volunteermatch.org/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">VolunteerMatch.org</a> for either type of volunteering opportunity and <a href=\"https://www.catchafire.org/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Catchafire.org</a> for skill-based volunteering opportunities.</p> \n<h4><strong>30. Mystery Dinner</strong></h4> \n<p>Mystery dinners are one of the most beloved traditions here at HubSpot. On a single night, you send a group of folks from different teams within your company to dinner somewhere in your city (or at someone's house).</p> \n<p>The dinner is hosted by one of your company's leaders and paid for by the company. These dinners allow random groups of people from the same company to spend an evening chock full of good food and conversation together.</p> \n<p>What makes them a mystery dinner? The only thing participants should know about the dinner ahead of time is the date and time. Send each group an email with the name of the restaurant they're going to and who they'll be going with, so they can arrange transportation together.</p> \n<p>Optional: Give every dinner host the name of a restaurant or bar to invite everyone to congregate once the dinners are over.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/EmPeGD_jJuB3rkfiRV36P-2GaFGarpNiS_BlKjnukDyGWSVU53wxQPxQ4WCbajz0CnZ2DjZA3uV6zwFYUgL8kajo-tnM8VSRkXSClRHcDVJM_CPUa7ie54opBnvzGF16-tTAUv-M\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"host a mystery dinner for a corporate team-building activity\"></p> \n<h4><strong>31. Kayaking/Canoeing</strong></h4> \n<p>Nothing says \"let's work together,\" quite like trying not to end up in the water. Want to take advantage of the outdoors? Grab a paddle and head down to the closest river for a great spring or summer outing.</p> \n<p>Many public rivers and ponds have boat houses where you can rent kayaks and canoes — and you can encourage folks to rent multi-person ones and pair up with people they don't usually work with.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/K1-Fd-v1erM5_qwVarB_obz6WBGoeWWgUeWn6JIAV6rg_Z2PmYpVsLwl47wGeQo8oN0dzQMPblYC7O956ab7rBn6yFsXSBgUk9yuWUqCLt3PUCpERVtQRkvyqmdBzHUPGInhajWo\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"go kayaking or canoeing for a corporate team-building activity\"></p> \n<h4><strong>32. Trampoline Park</strong></h4> \n<p>Hey, who says trampolines are just for kids? Take your team to a trampoline park for some jumping fun and a chance to work off the day's stress. Many cities have local places with trampoline activities — if you're in the Boston area, check out <a href=\"http://www.skyzone.com/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Skyzone</a> for trampoline dodgeball and basketball games.</p> \n<h4><strong>33. Something Touristy</strong></h4> \n<p>Embrace your city! Pick a hot tourist destination and go as a team. You can even do a Segway tour. (Fanny packs: optional.) It'll be nice to laugh at how silly it feels to be a tourist in your own city, and you might even learn something new.</p> \n<h4><strong>34. Painting Class</strong></h4> \n<p>If you're looking for a slightly more relaxing activity, take a group painting class. <a href=\"http://www.paintnite.com/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Paint Nite</a> hosts painting classes by local artists at various bars throughout major cities for painting on canvases, wine glasses (like in the picture below), and so on. It's a great way to let your team members unwind, catch up over some drinks, and express their creativity.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/EVlA_tpPV7WUPBZZ9Q22Hk8ZPliRE_2Z1MO21hVk9C3gWT-d4qSU8919iLCBugsv3MPeqn2yxcOy4D7dpok4c0BZ88RNF2LcCPZLEiKDk21Gf_HSwfi2XwgiCqcq7NcWSn7PzxF4\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"go to a painting class for a corporate team-building activity\"></p> \n<h4><strong>35. Cooking Class</strong></h4> \n<p>In the mood for something a little more culinary? Change up the usual outing to a bar or your local restaurant, and try a cooking class. Through a service such as <a href=\"https://www.kitchensurfing.com/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">Kitchensurfing</a>, you can hire a professional chef to cook a fancy meal for you in your home or office kitchen.</p> \n<p>Between the multiple courses prepared before your eyes, your team will have plenty of time to strike up a conversation and enjoy the delicious aromas.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/riYuonwEDe4_XdoA26jB31lupln_Rh9a1D2vi0UvDP20XmVUDfrZAsVXCBFt9JcF3DJF-gcE5HjJAK1WWNSbBj8LG4On7ni5IXodLQazr6kWdUt43frxznLGx-4FDcv2xAUh8FM6\" width=\"600\" height=\"393\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"go to a cooking class for a corporate team-building activity\"></p> \n<h4><strong>36. Explore a New Place</strong></h4> \n<p>Few things are more fun than getting out of the city and exploring for a day. So, why not do it with your team?</p> \n<p>For bigger events — maybe every quarter, when you have more budget to use for outings — charter a bus and take your team to a new place. You can all take a historical tour of the new place, grab lunch at a restaurant serving the town's finest, or take in a local attraction together.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/Nv7Y5-sDD36sXTrEQQY1SsXJDR-QkTQFgcHnhsAgc-lGHUpRuaJJ_PDpRRzb2xkjFwWu3S0q6o2TlTy2tvrUp0PbXhtxYU1awmyfTNKeKXmXITWQgG7XgStL3EkLqYWlJRgL6Dq8\" width=\"600\" height=\"449\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"explore a new place for a corporate team-building activity\"></p> \n<h4><strong>37. Sports Game</strong></h4> \n<p>Round up the team and head out to a sports game. What a fantastic way to rev up team spirit while combining both competition and camaraderie.</p> \n<h4>38. Go Camping</h4> \n<p>Get away from the hustle and bustle of work and city life by heading out to a camping site in your area.</p> \n<p>Bond with your coworkers over camp stories, marshmallows, and campfires. Walk into the woods as coworkers and come out as friends!</p> \n<h2>Bring Fun To The Workplace!</h2> \n<p>These are just some fun team-building activities that you can use to get the best out of your team. Be sure to use any of the activities listed above to build a firm foundation of trust and purpose between your employees.</p> \n<p>Now you're ready to show your team a great time while increasing their happiness <em>and</em> creating a great company culture. And hey, you might just be the \"cool boss\" now. How cool would <em>that</em> be?</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><em><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=4bbcf7f8-3c11-4d5b-b284-c5f6a9d419c9&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img
