02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"4 Easy Steps to Get a Custom Email Domain [+ Key Features to Look For]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/custom-email-domain","description":"<p>There are a few things in life that can earn you that \"official\" status.</p> \n<p>For me, it's anytime I see someone with a blazer or suit. I think \"<em>Oh, that person is definitely handling business today.</em>\" Probably because in Miami, the only time anyone subjects themselves to multiple layers in this heat is for official business.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=53e8428a-29a5-4225-a6ea-bca8ef991c19&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"→ Download Now: The Beginner's Guide to Email Marketing [Free Ebook]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/53e8428a-29a5-4225-a6ea-bca8ef991c19.png\" /></a></p> \n<p>Online, a verification badge gives you some official points. A great-looking website takes it that much further. But a custom email domain? Well, that's peak official. It signals structure and organization.</p> \n<p>Let's talk about the benefits of getting a custom email domain and how to get one.</p> \n<p>Personalized email domains can be used for both your employees and the departments in your company.</p> \n<p>There are two types of personalized email domains:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>A regular custom email domain</strong> – This includes an inbox and has all the features of a regular email service.</li> \n <li><strong>A forwarding email domain</strong> – This is only a customer-facing alias used to forward emails and doesn't have an inbox. Ex: You set up <a href=\"mailto:support@yourcompany.com\">support@yourcompany.com</a> and have all emails sent to that address forwarded to <a href=\"mailto:martina@yourcompany.com\">martina@yourcompany.com</a> or <a href=\"mailto:martina@gmail.com\">martina@gmail.com</a>.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you're a small business and don't anticipate a high volume of emails, you can start out with a forwarding custom email domain. It looks professional and you don't have to sift through a separate inbox, as all emails will go to another inbox.</p> \n<p>However, as your company grows, you'll likely need to invest in a separate inbox for your business emails.</p> \n<h2>Benefits of a Custom Email Domain</h2> \n<p>We've already covered how a personalized email domain looks \"official,\" but let's talk about what that means in concrete terms.</p> \n<p>Back in 2016, <a href=\"https://aboutus.godaddy.net/newsroom/press-releases/press-release-details/2016/Consumer-Trust-In-Online-Small-Businesses-Strengthened-By-Professional-Email/default.aspx\">GoDaddy</a> ran a survey and found that 75% of Americans think a domain-based email is a key factor in trusting a small ecommerce business. They even ranked it as three times more important than having an active social media channel.</p> \n<p>The report also revealed that some consumers (about 24%) would hesitate to share their personal information with a seller using a personal email address.</p> \n<p>It's likely that these figures have gone up recently, given the prevalence of email phishing attacks. Today, consumers may be a little bit warier of a business without a custom email domain and with one that doesn't match its website.</p> \n<p>When you have a custom email domain, it adds to your credibility and serves as another way to show consumers that you are a reputable company.</p> \n<p>In addition, a personalized email domain helps you organize your incoming emails based on the various departments within your company.</p> \n<p>For instance, you can have <a href=\"mailto:info@yourcompany.com\">info@yourcompany.com</a> for consumers to send their general inquiries. You could have <a href=\"mailto:shipping@yourcompany.com\">shipping@yourcompany.com</a> for order-specific inquiries, and countless others based on your business needs.</p> \n<p>This can be incredibly helpful in managing incoming and outgoing emails, especially as your company grows. You may also want to designate a team member to be the directly responsible individual (DRI) for that email account.</p> \n<p>Lastly, it's important to have a separate email domain for your business to streamline your email marketing efforts. As you develop a plan for your email communications with your consumers, You'll likely invest in <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email-b\">email marketing software</a> to manage, track and analyze your activities.</p> \n<p>Having a custom email domain will ensure your personal data doesn't get mixed in with your business analytics and dirty your data.</p> \n<p>Before you select your email provider, here are a few things to know and features to consider:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>The cost per user </strong>– Some email providers charge by user while others offer unlimited users for one monthly price.</li> \n <li><strong>The storage size </strong>– Email providers typically offer various packages, each with a different storage amount, ranging from 5GB to unlimited. Consider the volume of emails you expect to receive and use that to guide which one you select.</li> \n <li><strong>Aliases </strong>– If you want to use a forwarding email, look for an email provider that allows you to create domain aliases that can be sent to other inboxes.</li> \n <li><strong>Spam filter </strong>– Look for a provider with advanced filtering capabilities to avoid filling up your inbox with spammy emails.</li> \n <li><strong>Your website domain </strong>– Most providers require you to have a website domain associated with your custom email domain.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>1. Select an email provider.</h3> \n<p>There are many email providers to choose from, including <a href=\"https://workspace.google.com/\">Google Workspace</a> (formerly G Suite), <a href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/business/compare-all-microsoft-365-business-products?&amp;activetab=tab:primaryr2\">Microsoft 365</a>, <a href=\"https://www.hostinger.com/email-hosting\">Hostinger</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.ionos.com/office-solutions/create-an-email-address\">Ionos</a>.</p> \n<p>Many web hosting and designing companies like <a href=\"https://www.wix.com/business/email-address\">Wix</a> and <a href=\"https://www.godaddy.com/email/professional-business-email\">GoDaddy</a> allow you to create your own custom domain right on the platform (usually from Google Workspace and Microsoft 365) and connect it with your website.</p> \n<p>This feature can be included in your current package or available at an additional monthly cost, depending on the platform.</p> \n<h3>2. Purchase or connect your domain.</h3> \n<p>Once you select a provider, you'll likely have to connect it to your website domains.</p> \n<p>Google Workspace, for instance, requires users to have a linked website to create a custom email domain.</p> \n<p>In most cases, you can connect the provider to an existing domain or purchase one on the spot.</p> \n<h3>3. Select your users and/or aliases.</h3> \n<p>Now that you have your personalized email domain, it's time to select your users.</p> \n<p>Let's say you have employees, you may need to create accounts for them. This is something only an administrator can manage through your admin dashboard. Some providers only allow a certain number of users per plan.</p> \n<p>Now, onto the departments. Decide if you want to create aliases for specific departments that get forwarded to other email addresses <strong>or</strong> want designated email addresses.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you're a small team, you may create a <a href=\"mailto:support@yourcompany.com\">support@yourcompany.com</a> email that goes right in your <a href=\"mailto:personalemail@gmail.com\">personalemail@gmail.com</a> inbox. If the volume gets high, you may want to make <a href=\"mailto:support@yourcompany.com\">support@yourcompany.com</a> its own user to have a designated inbox for all support-related inquiries.</p> \n<p>Knowing what you'll need ahead of time will help decide which provider and plan best suits your business needs.</p> \n<h3>4. Choose an email address format.</h3> \n<p>When you have custom email addresses, consistency and simplicity are key. This makes it easy for people to reach you.</p> \n<p>For your employees, you can have the following formats:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"mailto:firstname.lastname@yourcompany.com\">firstname.lastname@yourcompany.com</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"mailto:firstletter.lastname@yourcompany.com\">firstletter.lastname@yourcompany.com</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"mailto:role@yourcompany.com\">role@yourcompany.com</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>Select the one that makes the most sense for your business.</p> \n<p>For your departments, try to keep it to one or two words. Here are a few examples:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>General inquiries</strong> – info@, contact@, hello@, questions@</li> \n <li><strong>Customer service </strong>– support@, billing@, shipping@, returns@, orders@</li> \n <li><strong>Sales</strong> – sales@, demo@</li> \n <li><strong>Marketing</strong> – press@, media@, pr@</li> \n <li><strong>Human Resources</strong> – hr@, jobs@, careers@</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Getting a personalized email domain for your business is a key step in achieving an \"official\" stamp from your audience online. It's a worthy investment that can strengthen consumer trust in your brand and make them more likely to purchase from you.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b229b0b2-204e-4bdf-9079-572da882b84d&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b229b0b2-204e-4bdf-9079-572da882b84d.png\" /></a></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcustom-email-domain&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 28 Jun 2021 19:27:12 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/53e8428a-29a5-4225-a6ea-bca8ef991c19.png","linkMd5":"320755f24ebb4ea8675c23c4c398838f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn38@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-38-555_717deba97acb3439.webp","destWidth":653,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":6873,"destBytes":10226,"author":"mbretous@hubspot.com (Martina Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/53e8428a-29a5-4225-a6ea-bca8ef991c19.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn38@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-38-555_717deba97acb3439.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b229b0b2-204e-4bdf-9079-572da882b84d.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn65@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-51-747_314ba14066d2faeb.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcustom-email-domain&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn45@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-53-453_a5c6c9953f9e00a8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938152},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"How to Use Excel Like a Pro: 18 Easy Excel Tips, Tricks, & Shortcuts","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-use-excel-tips","description":"<p>Sometimes, Excel seems too good to be true. All I have to do is enter a formula, and pretty much anything I'd ever need to do manually can be done automatically. Need to merge two sheets with similar data? Excel can do it. Need to do simple math? Excel can do it. Need to combine information in multiple cells? Excel can do it.</p>  \n<p>The only problem is that it can be difficult to use for beginners. While inputting the data manually is easy, it can be a nightmare to learn all the formulas and shortcuts you need to master the tool. Plus, even if you use the formulas correctly, there’s always a chance you’ll run into <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/common-excel-error-messages?_ga=2.223270747.1152862421.1623954511-2147369115.1623954511\">error messages</a>. Simply put, Excel can be extremely hard to use.</p> \n<p>Not to worry. In this post, I’ll go over the best tips, tricks, and shortcuts you can use right now to take your Excel game to the next level. No advanced Excel knowledge required.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=9ff7a4fe-5293-496c-acca-566bc6e73f42&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download 9 Excel Templates for Marketers [Free Kit]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9ff7a4fe-5293-496c-acca-566bc6e73f42.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2>What is Excel?</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/microsoft-excel\">Microsoft Excel</a> is a spreadsheet software that marketers, accountants, data analysts, and other professionals use to store, organize, and track data sets. It’s part of the Microsoft Office suite of products. Alternatives include Google Sheets and Numbers. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/excel-alternatives\">Find more Excel alternatives here</a>.</p> \n<p>To jumpstart your Excel education, check out a video below on how to use Excel for beginners.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/2Fs6d0SPTHI?controls=0\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p></p> \n<p>Excel is primarily used for creating financial documents because of its strong computational powers. You’ll often find the software in accounting offices and teams because it allows accountants to automatically see sums, averages, and totals. With Excel, they can easily make sense of their business’ data.</p> \n<p>While Excel is primarily known as an accounting tool, professionals in any field can use its features and formulas — especially marketers — because it can be used for tracking any type of data. It removes the need to spend hours and hours counting cells or copying and pasting performance numbers. Excel typically has a shortcut or quick fix that speeds up the process.</p> \n<p>Not sure how you can actually use Excel in your team? Here is a list of documents you can create:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/income-statement\">Income Statements</a>: You can use an Excel spreadsheet to track a company’s sales activity and financial health.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/balance-sheet\">Balance Sheets</a>: Balance sheets are among the most common types of documents you can create with Excel. It allows you to get a holistic view of a company’s financial standing.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/make-calendar-google-sheets\">Calendar</a>: You can easily create a spreadsheet monthly calendar to track events or other date-sensitive information.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Here are some documents you can create specifically for marketers.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-manage-marketing-budget-free-budget-templates\">Marketing Budgets</a>: Excel is a strong budget-keeping tool. You can create and track marketing budgets, as well as spend, using Excel. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketing-budget-templates\"><em>If you don’t want to create a document from scratch, download our marketing budget templates for free</em></a>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/running-marketing-reports-ht\">Marketing Reports</a>: If you don’t use a marketing tool such as Marketing Hub, you might find yourself in need of a dashboard with all of your reports. Excel is an excellent tool to create marketing reports. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/monthly-marketing-reporting-template?_ga=2.232231003.59128635.1623702827-2105701715.1623702827\"><em>Download free Excel marketing reporting templates here</em></a>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/business-blog-editorial-calendar-templates\">Editorial Calendars</a>: You can create editorial calendars in Excel. The tab format makes it extremely easy to track your content creation efforts for custom time ranges. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/editorial-calendar-templates\"><em>Download a free editorial content calendar template here</em></a><em>. </em></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/inbound-marketing-calculator\">Traffic and Leads Calculator</a>: Because of its strong computational powers, Excel is an excellent tool to create all sorts of calculators — including one for tracking leads and traffic. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/inbound-marketing-calculator\"><em>Click here to download a free premade calculator</em></a><em>.</em></li> \n</ul> \n<p>This is only a small sampling of the types of marketing and business documents you can create in Excel. We’ve created an <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/business-templates/excel\">extensive list of Excel templates</a> you can use right now for marketing, invoicing, project management, budgeting, and more.</p> \n<p>You can also download Excel templates below for all of your marketing needs.&nbsp;</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>After you download the templates, it’s time to start using the software. Let’s cover the basics first.</p> \n<h2>Excel Basics</h2> \n<p>If you're just starting out with Excel, there are a few basic commands that we suggest you become familiar with. These are things like:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Creating a new spreadsheet from scratch.</li> \n <li>Executing basic computations like adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing.</li> \n <li>Writing and formatting column text and titles.</li> \n <li>Using Excel's auto-fill features.</li> \n <li>Adding or deleting single columns, rows, and spreadsheets. Below, we'll get into how to add things like multiple columns and rows.</li> \n <li>Keeping column and row titles visible as you scroll past them in a spreadsheet, so that you know what data you're filling as you move further down the document.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>For a deep dive on these basics, check out our <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/microsoft-excel\">comprehensive Microsoft Excel guide</a>.</p> \n<p>In the spirit of working more efficiently and avoiding tedious, manual work, here are a few Excel formulas and functions you’ll need to know.</p> \n<h2>Excel Formulas</h2> \n<p>It’s easy to get overwhelmed by the wide range of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/excel-formulas-keyboard-shortcuts\">Excel formulas</a> that you can use to make sense out of your data. If you’re just getting started using Excel, you can rely on the following formulas to carry out some complex functions — without adding to the complexity of your learning path.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Equal sign: </strong>Before creating any formula, you’ll need to write an equal sign <strong>(=)</strong> in the cell where you want the result to appear.</li> \n <li><strong>Addition</strong>: To add the values of two or more cells, use the <strong>+</strong> sign. Example: <em>=C5+D3</em>.</li> \n <li><strong>Subtraction</strong>: To subtract the values of two or more cells, use the <strong>-</strong> sign. Example: <em>=C5-D3</em>.</li> \n <li><strong>Multiplication</strong>: To multiply the values of two or more cells, use the <strong>*</strong> sign. Example: <em>=C5*D3</em>.</li> \n <li><strong>Division</strong>: To divide the values of two or more cells, use the <strong>/ </strong>sign. Example: <em>=C5/D3</em>.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Putting all of these together, you can create a formula that adds, subtracts, multiplies, and divides all in one cell. Example: <em>=(C5-D3)/((A5+B6)*3)</em>.</p> \n<p>For more complex formulas, you’ll need to use parentheses around the expressions to avoid accidentally using the <a href=\"https://www.mashupmath.com/blog/pemdas-rule-math-order-of-operations\">PEMDAS order of operations</a>. Keep in mind that you can use plain numbers in your formulas.</p> \n<h2>Excel Functions</h2> \n<p>Excel functions automate some of the tasks you would use in a typical formula. For instance, instead of using the <strong>+</strong> sign to add up a range of cells, you’d use the SUM function. Let’s look at a few more functions that will help automate calculations and tasks.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/sum-function-043e1c7d-7726-4e80-8f32-07b23e057f89\">SUM</a>: The SUM function automatically adds up a range of cells or numbers. To complete a sum, you would input the starting cell and the final cell with a colon in between. Here’s what that looks like: <strong>SUM(Cell1:Cell2)</strong>. Example: <em>=SUM(C5:C30)</em>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/average-function-047bac88-d466-426c-a32b-8f33eb960cf6\">AVERAGE</a>: The AVERAGE function averages out the values of a range of cells. The syntax is the same as the SUM function: <strong>AVERAGE(Cell1:Cell2). </strong>Example: <em>=AVERAGE(C5:C30)</em>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/if-function-69aed7c9-4e8a-4755-a9bc-aa8bbff73be2\">IF</a>: The IF function allows you to return values based on a logical test. The syntax is as follows: <strong>IF(logical_test, value_if_true, [value_if_false])</strong>. Example: <em>=IF(A2&gt;B2,\"Over Budget\",\"OK\")</em>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/vlookup-function-0bbc8083-26fe-4963-8ab8-93a18ad188a1\">VLOOKUP</a>: The VLOOKUP function helps you search for anything on your sheet’s rows. The syntax is: <strong>VLOOKUP(lookup value, table array, column number, Approximate match (TRUE) or Exact match (FALSE))</strong>. Example: <em>=VLOOKUP([@Attorney],tbl_Attorneys,4,FALSE).</em></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/index-function-a5dcf0dd-996d-40a4-a822-b56b061328bd\">INDEX</a>: The INDEX function returns a value from within a range. The syntax is as follows: <strong>INDEX(array, row_num, [column_num])</strong>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/match-function-e8dffd45-c762-47d6-bf89-533f4a37673a\">MATCH</a>: The MATCH function looks for a certain item in a range of cells and returns the position of that item. It can be used in tandem with the INDEX function. The syntax is: <strong>MATCH(lookup_value, lookup_array, [match_type])</strong>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/countif-function-e0de10c6-f885-4e71-abb4-1f464816df34\">COUNTIF</a>: The COUNTIF function returns the number of cells that meet a certain criteria or have a certain value. The syntax is: <strong>COUNTIF(range, criteria). </strong>Example: <em>=COUNTIF(A2:A5,\"London\"). </em></li> \n</ul> \n<p>Okay, ready to get into the nitty-gritty? Let's get to it. (And to all the Harry Potter fans out there ... you're welcome in advance.)</p> \n<p><strong>Note</strong>: The GIFs and visuals are from a previous version of Excel. When applicable, the copy has been updated to provide instruction for users of both newer and older Excel versions.</p> \n<h3>1. Use Pivot tables to recognize and make sense of data.</h3> \n<p>Pivot tables are used to reorganize data in a spreadsheet. They won't change the data that you have, but they can sum up values and compare different information in your spreadsheet, depending on what you'd like them to do.</p> \n<p>Let's take a look at an example. Let's say I want to take a look at how many people are in each house at Hogwarts. You may be thinking that I don't have too much data, but for longer data sets, this will come in handy.</p> \n<p>To create the Pivot Table, I go to <strong>Data</strong> &gt; <strong>Pivot Table</strong>. If you’re using the most recent version of Excel, you’d go to <strong>Insert</strong> &gt; <strong>Pivot Table</strong>. Excel will automatically populate your Pivot Table, but you can always change around the order of the data. Then, you have four options to choose from.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Report Filter</strong>: This allows you to only look at certain rows in your dataset. For example, if I wanted to create a filter by house, I could choose to only include students in Gryffindor instead of all students.</li> \n <li><strong>Column Labels</strong>: These would be your headers in the dataset.</li> \n <li><strong>Row Labels</strong>: These could be your rows in the dataset. Both Row and Column labels can contain data from your columns (e.g. First Name can be dragged to either the Row or Column label — it just depends on how you want to see the data.)</li> \n <li><strong>Value</strong>: This section allows you to look at your data differently. Instead of just pulling in any numeric value, you can sum, count, average, max, min, count numbers, or do a few other manipulations with your data. In fact, by default, when you drag a field to Value, it always does a count.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Since I want to count the number of students in each house, I'll go to the Pivot table builder and drag the House column to both the Row Labels and the Values. This will sum up the number of students associated with each house.<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-pivot-table.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-pivot-table.gif\" alt=\"Excel pivot table creation\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>2. Add more than one row or column.</h3> \n<p>As you play around with your data, you might find you're constantly needing to add more rows and columns. Sometimes, you may even need to add hundreds of rows. Doing this one-by-one would be super tedious. Luckily, there's always an easier way.</p> \n<p>To add multiple rows or columns in a spreadsheet, highlight the same number of preexisting rows or columns that you want to add. Then, right-click and select \"Insert.\"</p> \n<p>In the example below, I want to add an additional three rows. By highlighting three rows and then clicking insert, I'm able to add an additional three blank rows into my spreadsheet quickly and easily.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2424242854-gif/Insert_Spaces_GIF.gif?width=650&amp;name=Insert_Spaces_GIF.gif\" alt=\"insert Spaces on Excel\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" title=\"insert Spaces\"></p> \n<h3>3. Use filters to simplify your data.</h3> \n<p>When you're looking at very large data sets, you don't usually need to be looking at every single row at the same time. Sometimes, you only want to look at data that fit into certain criteria.</p> \n<p>That's where filters come in.</p> \n<p>Filters allow you to pare down your data to only look at certain rows at one time. In Excel, a filter can be added to each column in your data — and from there, you can then choose which cells you want to view at once.</p> \n<p>Let's take a look at the example below. Add a filter by clicking the Data tab and selecting \"Filter.\" Clicking the arrow next to the column headers and you'll be able to choose whether you want your data to be organized in ascending or descending order, as well as which specific rows you want to show.</p> \n<p>In my Harry Potter example, let's say I only want to see the students in Gryffindor. By selecting the Gryffindor filter, the other rows disappear.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-filters.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-filters.gif\" alt=\"Excel filters in action\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><strong>Pro Tip</strong>: Copy and paste the values in the spreadsheet when a Filter is on to do additional analysis in another spreadsheet.</p> \n<h3>4. Remove duplicate data points or sets.</h3> \n<p>Larger data sets tend to have duplicate content. You may have a list of multiple contacts in a company and only want to see the number of companies you have. In situations like this, removing the duplicates comes in quite handy.</p> \n<p>To remove your duplicates, highlight the row or column that you want to remove duplicates of. Then, go to the Data tab and select \"Remove Duplicates\" (which is under the Tools subheader in the older version of Excel). A pop-up will appear to confirm which data you want to work with. Select \"Remove Duplicates,\" and you're good to go.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-duplicates-removal.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-duplicates-removal.gif\" alt=\"Removing duplicates in Excel\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>You can also use this feature to remove an entire row based on a duplicate column value. So if you have three rows with Harry Potter's information and you only need to see one, then you can select the whole dataset and then remove duplicates based on email. Your resulting list will have only unique names without any duplicates.</p> \n<h3>5. Transpose rows into columns.</h3> \n<p>When you have rows of data in your spreadsheet, you might decide you actually want to transform the items in one of those rows into columns (or vice versa). It would take a lot of time to copy and paste each individual header — but what the transpose feature allows you to do is simply move your row data into columns, or the other way around.</p> \n<p>Start by highlighting the column that you want to transpose into rows. Right-click it, and then select \"Copy.\" Next, select the cells on your spreadsheet where you want your first row or column to begin. Right-click on the cell, and then select \"Paste Special.\" A module will appear — at the bottom, you'll see an option to transpose. Check that box and select OK. Your column will now be transferred to a row or vice-versa.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-transpose.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-transpose.gif\" alt=\"Transpose tool in Excel\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>On newer versions of Excel, a drop-down will appear instead of a pop-up.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-transpose-new.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-transpose-new.gif\" alt=\"Excel transpose tool in newer versions\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>6. Split up text information between columns.</h3> \n<p>What if you want to split out information that's in one cell into two different cells? For example, maybe you want to pull out someone's company name through their email address. Or perhaps you want to separate someone's full name into a first and last name for your email marketing templates.</p> \n<p>Thanks to Excel, both are possible. First, highlight the column that you want to split up. Next, go to the Data tab and select \"Text to Columns.\" A module will appear with additional information.</p> \n<p>First, you need to select either \"Delimited\" or \"Fixed Width.\"</p> \n<ul> \n <li>\"Delimited\" means you want to break up the column based on characters such as commas, spaces, or tabs.</li> \n <li>\"Fixed Width\" means you want to select the exact location on all the columns that you want the split to occur.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>In the example case below, let's select \"Delimited\" so we can separate the full name into first name and last name.</p> \n<p>Then, it's time to choose the Delimiters. This could be a tab, semi-colon, comma, space, or something else. (\"Something else\" could be the \"@\" sign used in an email address, for example.) In our example, let's choose the space. Excel will then show you a preview of what your new columns will look like.</p> \n<p>When you're happy with the preview, press \"Next.\" This page will allow you to select Advanced Formats if you choose to. When you're done, click \"Finish.\"</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-text-to-column.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-text-to-column.gif\" alt=\"Excel text to column tool\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>7. Use formulas for simple calculations.</h3> \n<p>In addition to doing pretty complex calculations, Excel can help you do simple arithmetic like adding, subtracting, multiplying, or dividing any of your data.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>To add, use the + sign.</li> \n <li>To subtract, use the - sign.</li> \n <li>To multiply, use the * sign.</li> \n <li>To divide, use the / sign.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You can also use parentheses to ensure certain calculations are done first. In the example below (10+10*10), the second and third 10 were multiplied together before adding the additional 10. However, if we made it (10+10)*10, the first and second 10 would be added together first.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-simple-math.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-simple-math.gif\" alt=\"Excel simple formulas in action\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>8. Get the average of numbers in your cells.</h3> \n<p>If you want the average of a set of numbers, you can use the formula <strong>=AVERAGE(Cell1:Cell2)</strong>. If you want to sum up a column of numbers, you can use the formula <strong>=SUM(Cell1:Cell2)</strong>.</p> \n<h3>9. Use conditional formatting to make cells automatically change color based on data.</h3> \n<p>Conditional formatting allows you to change a cell's color based on the information within the cell. For example, if you want to flag certain numbers that are above average or in the top 10% of the data in your spreadsheet, you can do that. If you want to color code commonalities between different rows in Excel, you can do that. This will help you quickly see information that is important to you.</p> \n<p>To get started, highlight the group of cells you want to use conditional formatting on. Then, choose \"Conditional Formatting\" from the Home menu and select your logic from the dropdown. (You can also create your own rule if you want something different.) A window will pop up that prompts you to provide more information about your formatting rule. Select \"OK\" when you're done, and you should see your results automatically appear.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-conditional-formatting.gif?width=1232&amp;name=excel-conditional-formatting.gif\" alt=\"Excel conditional formatting\" width=\"1232\" style=\"width: 1232px;\"></p> \n<h3>10. Use the IF Excel formula to automate certain Excel functions.</h3> \n<p>Sometimes, we don't want to count the number of times a value appears. Instead, we want to input different information into a cell if there is a corresponding cell with that information.</p> \n<p>For example, in the situation below, I want to award ten points to everyone who belongs in the Gryffindor house. Instead of manually typing in 10's next to each Gryffindor student's name, I can use the IF Excel formula to say that if the student is in Gryffindor, then they should get ten points.</p> \n<p>The formula is: <strong>IF(logical_test, value_if_true, [value_if_false])</strong></p> \n<p>Example Shown Below: <strong>=IF(D2=\"Gryffindor\",\"10\",\"0\")</strong></p> \n<p>In general terms, the formula would be IF(Logical Test, value of true, value of false). Let's dig into each of these variables.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Logical_Test</strong>: The logical test is the \"IF\" part of the statement. In this case, the logic is D2=\"Gryffindor\" because we want to make sure that the cell corresponding with the student says \"Gryffindor.\" Make sure to put Gryffindor in quotation marks here.</li> \n <li><strong>Value_if_True</strong>: This is what we want the cell to show if the value is true. In this case, we want the cell to show \"10\" to indicate that the student was awarded the 10 points. Only use quotation marks if you want the result to be text instead of a number.</li> \n <li><strong>Value_if_False</strong>: This is what we want the cell to show if the value is false. In this case, for any student not in Gryffindor, we want the cell to show \"0\". Only use quotation marks if you want the result to be text instead of a number.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-if-formula.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-if-formula.gif\" alt=\"Excel IF formula in action\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p><strong>Note</strong>: In the example above, I awarded 10 points to everyone in Gryffindor. If I later wanted to sum the total number of points, I wouldn't be able to because the 10's are in quotes, thus making them text and not a number that Excel can sum.</p> \n<h3>11. Use dollar signs to keep one cell's formula the same regardless of where it moves.</h3> \n<p>Have you ever seen a dollar sign in an Excel formula? When used in a formula, it isn't representing an American dollar; instead, it makes sure that the exact column and row are held the same even if you copy the same formula in adjacent rows.</p> \n<p>You see, a cell reference — when you refer to cell A5 from cell C5, for example — is relative by default. In that case, you're actually referring to a cell that's five columns to the left (C minus A) and in the same row (5). This is called a relative formula. When you copy a relative formula from one cell to another, it'll adjust the values in the formula based on where it's moved. But sometimes, we want those values to stay the same no matter whether they're moved around or not — and we can do that by turning the formula into an absolute formula.</p> \n<p>To change the relative formula (=A5+C5) into an absolute formula, we'd precede the row and column values by dollar signs, like this: <strong>(=$A$5+$C$5)</strong>. (Learn more on Microsoft Office's support page <a href=\"https://support.office.com/en-nz/article/Switch-between-relative-absolute-and-mixed-references-538396b3-990e-4b44-9d9c-28b4151d7d21\">here</a>.)</p> \n<h3>12. Use the VLOOKUP function to pull data from one area of a sheet to another.</h3> \n<p>Have you ever had two sets of data on two different spreadsheets that you want to combine into a single spreadsheet?</p> \n<p>For example, you might have a list of people's names next to their email addresses in one spreadsheet, and a list of those same people's email addresses next to their company names in the other — but you want the names, email addresses, and company names of those people to appear in one place.</p> \n<p>I have to combine data sets like this a lot — and when I do, the VLOOKUP is my go-to formula.</p> \n<p>Before you use the formula, though, be absolutely sure that you have at least one column that appears identically in both places. Scour your data sets to make sure the column of data you're using to combine your information is exactly the same, including no extra spaces.</p> \n<p>The formula: <strong>=VLOOKUP(lookup value, table array, column number, Approximate match (TRUE) or Exact match (FALSE))</strong></p> \n<p>The formula with variables from our example below: <strong>=VLOOKUP(C2,Sheet2!A:B,2,FALSE)</strong></p> \n<p>In this formula, there are several variables. The following is true when you want to combine information in Sheet 1 and Sheet 2 onto Sheet 1.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Lookup Value</strong>: This is the identical value you have in both spreadsheets. Choose the first value in your first spreadsheet. In the example that follows, this means the first email address on the list, or cell 2 (C2).</li> \n <li><strong>Table Array</strong>: The table array is the range of columns on Sheet 2 you're going to pull your data from, including the column of data identical to your lookup value (in our example, email addresses) in Sheet 1 as well as the column of data you're trying to copy to Sheet 1. In our example, this is \"Sheet2!A:B.\" \"A\" means Column A in Sheet 2, which is the column in Sheet 2 where the data identical to our lookup value (email) in Sheet 1 is listed. The \"B\" means Column B, which contains the information that's only available in Sheet 2 that you want to translate to Sheet 1.</li> \n <li><strong>Column Number</strong>: This tells Excel which column the new data you want to copy to Sheet 1 is located in. In our example, this would be the column that \"House\" is located in. \"House\" is the second column in our range of columns (table array), so our column number is 2. [<strong>Note</strong>: Your range can be more than two columns. For example, if there are three columns on Sheet 2 — Email, Age, and House — and you still want to bring House onto Sheet 1, you can still use a VLOOKUP. You just need to change the \"2\" to a \"3\" so it pulls back the value in the third column: =VLOOKUP(C2:Sheet2!A:C,3,false).]</li> \n <li><strong>Approximate Match (TRUE) or Exact Match (FALSE)</strong>: Use FALSE to ensure you pull in only exact value matches. If you use TRUE, the function will pull in approximate matches.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>In the example below, Sheet 1 and Sheet 2 contain lists describing different information about the same people, and the common thread between the two is their email addresses. Let's say we want to combine both datasets so that all the house information from Sheet 2 translates over to Sheet 1.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-vlookup.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-vlookup.gif\" alt=\"Excel VLOOKUP function\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>So when we type in the formula <strong>=VLOOKUP(C2,Sheet2!A:B,2,FALSE)</strong>, we bring all the house data into Sheet 1.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind that VLOOKUP will only pull back values from the second sheet that are to the right of the column containing your identical data. This can lead to some limitations, which is why some people prefer to use the INDEX and MATCH functions instead.</p> \n<h3>13. Use INDEX and MATCH formulas to pull data from horizontal columns.</h3> \n<p>Like VLOOKUP, the INDEX and MATCH functions pull in data from another dataset into one central location. Here are the main differences:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>VLOOKUP is a much simpler formula. If you're working with large data sets that would require thousands of lookups, using the INDEX and MATCH function will significantly decrease load time in Excel.</li> \n <li>The INDEX and MATCH formulas work right-to-left, whereas VLOOKUP formulas only work as a left-to-right lookup. In other words, if you need to do a lookup that has a lookup column to the right of the results column, then you'd have to rearrange those columns in order to do a VLOOKUP. This can be tedious with large datasets and/or lead to errors.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>So if I want to combine information in Sheet 1 and Sheet 2 onto Sheet 1, but the column values in Sheets 1 and 2 aren't the same, then to do a VLOOKUP, I would need to switch around my columns. In this case, I'd choose to do an INDEX and MATCH instead.</p> \n<p>Let's look at an example. Let's say Sheet 1 contains a list of people's names and their Hogwarts email addresses, and Sheet 2 contains a list of people's email addresses and the Patronus that each student has. (For the non-Harry Potter fans out there, every witch or wizard has an animal guardian called a \"Patronus\" associated with him or her.) The information that lives in both sheets is the column containing email addresses, but this email address column is in different column numbers on each sheet. I'd use the INDEX and MATCH formulas instead of VLOOKUP so I wouldn't have to switch any columns around.</p> \n<p>So what's the formula, then? The formula is actually the MATCH formula nested inside the INDEX formula. You'll see I differentiated the MATCH formula using a different color here.</p> \n<p>The formula: <strong>=INDEX(table array, MATCH formula)</strong></p> \n<p>This becomes:<strong> <strong>=INDEX(table array, MATCH (</strong><strong>lookup_value, lookup_array))</strong></strong></p> \n<p>The formula with variables from our example below: <strong>=INDEX(Sheet2!A:A,(MATCH(Sheet1!C:C,Sheet2!C:C,0)))</strong></p> \n<p>Here are the variables:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Table Array</strong>: The range of columns on Sheet 2 containing the new data you want to bring over to Sheet 1. In our example, \"A\" means Column A, which contains the \"Patronus\" information for each person.</li> \n <li><strong>Lookup Value</strong>: This is the column in Sheet 1 that contains identical values in both spreadsheets. In the example that follows, this means the \"email\" column on Sheet 1, which is Column C. So: Sheet1!C:C.</li> \n <li><strong>Lookup Array</strong>: This is the column in Sheet 2 that contains identical values in both spreadsheets. In the example that follows, this refers to the \"email\" column on Sheet 2, which happens to also be Column C. So: Sheet2!C:C.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Once you have your variables straight, type in the INDEX and MATCH formulas in the top-most cell of the blank Patronus column on Sheet 1, where you want the combined information to live.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-index-match.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-index-match.gif\" alt=\"Excel INDEX and MATCH functions in action\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>14. Use the COUNTIF function to make Excel count words or numbers in any range of cells.</h3> \n<p>Instead of manually counting how often a certain value or number appears, let Excel do the work for you. With the COUNTIF function, Excel can count the number of times a word or number appears in any range of cells.</p> \n<p>For example, let's say I want to count the number of times the word \"Gryffindor\" appears in my data set.</p> \n<p>The formula: <strong>=COUNTIF(range, criteria)</strong></p> \n<p>The formula with variables from our example below: <strong>=COUNTIF(D:D,\"Gryffindor\")</strong></p> \n<p>In this formula, there are several variables:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Range</strong>: The range that we want the formula to cover. In this case, since we're only focusing on one column, we use \"D:D\" to indicate that the first and last column are both D. If I were looking at columns C and D, I would use \"C:D.\"</li> \n <li><strong>Criteria</strong>: Whatever number or piece of text you want Excel to count. Only use quotation marks if you want the result to be text instead of a number. In our example, the criteria is \"Gryffindor.\"</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Simply typing in the COUNTIF formula in any cell and pressing \"Enter\" will show me how many times the word \"Gryffindor\" appears in the dataset.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-countif.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-countif.gif\" alt=\"Excel COUNTIF function\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>15. Combine cells using &amp;.</h3> \n<p>Databases tend to split out data to make it as exact as possible. For example, instead of having a column that shows a person's full name, a database might have the data as a first name and then a last name in separate columns. Or, it may have a person's location separated by city, state, and zip code. In Excel, you can combine cells with different data into one cell by using the \"&amp;\" sign in your function.</p> \n<p>The formula with variables from our example below: <strong>=A2&amp;\" \"&amp;B2</strong></p> \n<p>Let's go through the formula together using an example. Pretend we want to combine first names and last names into full names in a single column. To do this, we'd first put our cursor in the blank cell where we want the full name to appear. Next, we'd highlight one cell that contains a first name, type in an \"&amp;\" sign, and then highlight a cell with the corresponding last name.</p> \n<p>But you're not finished — if all you type in is =A2&amp;B2, then there will not be a space between the person's first name and last name. To add that necessary space, use the function <strong>=A2&amp;\" \"&amp;B2</strong>. The quotation marks around the space tell Excel to put a space in between the first and last name.</p> \n<p>To make this true for multiple rows, simply drag the corner of that first cell downward as shown in the example.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-combine-function.gif?width=650&amp;name=excel-combine-function.gif\" alt=\"Excel combination of cells\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>16. Add checkboxes.</h3> \n<p>If you're using an Excel sheet to track customer data and want to oversee something that isn't quantifiable, you could insert checkboxes into a column.</p> \n<p>For example, if you're using an Excel sheet to manage your sales prospects and want to track whether you called them in the last quarter, you could have a \"Called this quarter?\" column and check off the cells in it when you've called the respective client.</p> \n<p>Here's how to do it.</p> \n<p>Highlight a cell you'd like to add checkboxes to in your spreadsheet. Then, click DEVELOPER. Then, under FORM CONTROLS, click the checkbox or the selection circle highlighted in the image below.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-checkboxes.png?width=300&amp;name=excel-checkboxes.png\" alt=\"Excel checkboxes\" width=\"300\" style=\"width: 300px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Once the box appears in the cell, copy it, highlight the cells you also want it to appear in, and then paste it.</p> \n<h3>17. Hyperlink a cell to a website.</h3> \n<p>If you're using your sheet to track social media or website metrics, it can be helpful to have a reference column with the links each row is tracking. If you add a URL directly into Excel, it should automatically be clickable. But, if you have to hyperlink words, such as a page title or the headline of a post you're tracking, here's how.</p> \n<p>Highlight the words you want to hyperlink, then press Shift K. From there a box will pop up allowing you to place the hyperlink URL. Copy and paste the URL into this box and hit or click Enter.</p> \n<p>If the key shortcut isn't working for any reason, you can also do this manually by highlighting the cell and clicking <strong>Insert</strong> &gt; <strong>Hyperlink</strong>.</p> \n<h3>18. Add drop-down menus.</h3> \n<p>Sometimes, you'll be using your spreadsheet to track processes or other qualitative things. Rather than writing words into your sheet repetitively, such as \"Yes\", \"No\", \"Customer Stage\", \"Sales Lead\", or \"Prospect\", you can use dropdown menus to quickly mark descriptive things about your contacts or whatever you're tracking.</p> \n<p>Here's how to add drop-downs to your cells.</p> \n<p>Highlight the cells you want the drop-downs to be in, then click the Data menu in the top navigation and press Validation.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-drop-down-menu.png?width=300&amp;name=excel-drop-down-menu.png\" alt=\"Excel drop-down menu option\" width=\"300\" style=\"width: 300px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>From there, you'll see a Data Validation Settings box open. Look at the Allow options, then click Lists and select Drop-down List. Check the In-Cell dropdown button, then press OK.</p> \n<h2>Other Excel Help Resources</h2> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-build-excel-graph\">How to Make a Chart or Graph in Excel [With Video Tutorial]</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/excel-graph-tricks-list\">Design Tips to Create Beautiful Excel Charts and Graphs</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-with-excel-templates-list\">Totally Free Microsoft Excel Templates That Make Marketing Easier</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/learn-excel-resources\">How to Learn Excel Online: Free and Paid Resources for Excel Training</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2>Use Excel to Automate Processes in Your Team</h2> \n<p>Even if you’re not an accountant, you can still use Excel to automate tasks and processes in your team. With the tips and tricks we shared in this post, you’ll be sure to use Excel to its fullest extent and get the most out of the software to grow your business.</p> \n<p><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">Editor's Note: This post was originally published in August 2017 but has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" fs/excel-if-formula.gif?width=650&name=excel-if-formula.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn35@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-51-798_47ef3e49944d63c2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-vlookup.gif?width=650&name=excel-vlookup.gif":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-index-match.gif?width=650&name=excel-index-match.gif":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-countif.gif?width=650&name=excel-countif.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn31@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-54-331_eec8c320bacf559a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-combine-function.gif?width=650&name=excel-combine-function.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn59@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-51-338_6dfbcf5800d44ff8.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-checkboxes.png?width=300&name=excel-checkboxes.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn20@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-52-066_2f45dd9412ec0ab2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-drop-down-menu.png?width=300&name=excel-drop-down-menu.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn87@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-50-595_ec74f2f7800b0f50.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/7912de6f-792e-4100-8215-1f2bf712a3e5.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn16@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-52-003_5cfe01436a49f100.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/be0ee5c2-3622-42e2-b581-f1e31a956b00.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn44@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-49-831_5bef18b3513bf3d5.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-use-excel-tips&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn39@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-49-524_7fc49fb609200a8d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938168},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"5 Dos and Don'ts When Making a SMART Goal [Examples]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/smart-goal-examples","description":"<div> \n <p>When I was 14, my dream was to play college baseball. But I had one small problem — I only weighed 100 pounds and could barely hit the ball out of the infield. Even though I still had four years to bulk up and improve my skills, I knew I had a long way to go before I could play at the collegiate level.</p> \n <p>Fortunately, my high school coach always gave me opportunities to shoot for that kept my drive alive. After a grueling practice or workout, he would harp on how a long-term goal is just a series of short-term goals, and he made us write down our off-season training goals every year. But he didn't just accept the first draft of your goal sheet. He would make you edit it until you knew exactly what your goals were and how you were going to achieve them.</p> \n <p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=a482387e-c9f6-456b-b92f-4ba795780b19&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download your free marketing goal-setting template here.&nbsp;\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/a482387e-c9f6-456b-b92f-4ba795780b19.png\" align=\"middle\" /></a></p> \n <p>Setting a goal like \"improve upper body strength\" wasn't enough. You had to write down how much you would improve your bench press by and how many times you would work out per week.</p> \n <p>Every year, I set off-season SMART goals, and since I had a plan and clear direction, I always achieved them. By the time I was a senior in high school, I had gained 70 pounds and earned a baseball scholarship.</p> \n <p>In this post, you'll learn exactly what SMART goals are and how you can set one today. Want to skip to the information you need most? Click on one of these headlines to jump to that section.</p> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/smart-goal-examples#what-are-smart-goals\">What are SMART Goals?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/smart-goal-examples#why-are-smart-goals-important\">Why Are SMART Goals Important?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/smart-goal-examples#examples\">SMART Goal Examples</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/smart-goal-examples#how-to-make-a-smart-goal\">How to Make a SMART Goal</a></li> \n </ul> \n <h6 style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-determine-your-smart-marketing-goals?hubs_post-cta=image\"><img alt=\"SMART Goals Template from HubSpot\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/5%20Dos%20and%20Donts%20When%20Making%20a%20SMART%20Goal%20%5BExamples%5D.png?width=624&amp;name=5%20Dos%20and%20Donts%20When%20Making%20a%20SMART%20Goal%20%5BExamples%5D.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-determine-your-smart-marketing-goals?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom&amp;_ga=2.39611873.398126922.1624283745-941898656.1624283745\">Download this Template for Free</a></h6> \n <p>In the working world, the influence of SMART goals continues to grow. The reason why successful marketing teams always hit their numbers is that they also set SMART goals. Use the template above to follow along and create your own SMART goals.</p> \n <a></a> \n <h2>What are SMART goals?</h2> \n <p>SMART goals are concrete targets that you aim to hit over a certain period. These goals should be carefully drafted by a manager and their direct report to set them up for success. \"SMART\" is an acronym that describes the most important characteristics of each goal.</p> \n <p>The \"SMART\" acronym stands for \"specific,\" \"measurable,\" \"attainable,\" \"relevant,\" and \"time-bound.\" Each SMART goal should have these five characteristics to ensure the goal can be reached and benefits the employee. Find out what each characteristic means below, and how to write a SMART goal that exemplifies them.</p> \n <a></a> \n <h2>Why are SMART goals important?</h2> \n <p>When you make goals that are specific, measurable, attainable, relevant, and time-bound, you're increasing your odds for success by verifying that the goal is achievable, identifying the metrics that define success, and creating a roadmap to reach those metrics.</p> \n <p>SMART goals are important to set as they:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Help you work with clear intentions, not broad or vague goals</li> \n  <li>Provide a method to gauge your success by setting benchmarks to meet</li> \n  <li>Give sensible objectives that are realistic and achievable</li> \n  <li>Cut out unnecessary or irrelevant work that could take away from what’s important</li> \n  <li>Set a clear beginning and end to adhere to in reaching your goals</li> \n </ul> \n <p>If your goals are abstract, if you don't know what it will take to achieve success, or if you don't give yourself a deadline to complete steps, you may lose focus and fall short of what you want to accomplish.</p> \n <h3>Do SMART goals actually work?</h3> \n <p>In short — yes, <em>if done correctly</em>. Setting unrealistic goals and trying to measure them without consideration of previous performance, overly short time frames, or including too many variables will lead you off course.</p> \n <p>These goals work if formulated properly and if they take into account the motive and cadence of those working on them. Additionally, your SMART goals can only succeed when the employees working towards them have the means to achieve them.</p> \n <p>Let’s take a look at some realistic examples of SMART goals to paint a clearer picture of what they are.</p> \n <a></a> \n <p></p> \n <h3>1. Blog Traffic Goal</h3> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Specific</strong>: I want to boost our <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/increase-website-traffic\">blog's traffic</a> by increasing our weekly publishing frequency from five to eight times a week. Our two bloggers will increase their workload from writing two posts a week to three posts a week, and our editor will increase her workload from writing one post a week to two posts a week.</li> \n  <li><strong>Measurable</strong>: Our goal is an 8% increase in traffic.</li> \n  <li><strong>Attainable</strong>: Our blog traffic increased by 5% last month when we increased our weekly publishing frequency from three to five times a week.</li> \n  <li><strong>Relevant</strong>: By increasing blog traffic, we'll boost brand awareness and generate more leads, giving sales more opportunities to close.</li> \n  <li><strong>Time-Bound</strong>: End of this month</li> \n  <li><strong>SMART Goal</strong>: At the end of this month, our blog will see an 8% lift in traffic by increasing our weekly publishing frequency from five posts per week to eight posts per week.</li> \n </ul> \n <h3>2. Facebook Video Views Goal</h3> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Specific:</strong> I want to boost our average views per native video by cutting our video content mix from eight topics to our five most popular topics.</li> \n  <li><strong>Measurable: </strong>Our goal is a 25% increase in views.</li> \n  <li><strong>Attainable: </strong>When we cut down our video content mix on Facebook from 10 topics to our eight most popular topics, our average views per native video increased by 20%.</li> \n  <li><strong>Relevant: </strong>By increasing average views per native video on Facebook, we'll boost our social media following and brand awareness, reaching more potential customers with our video content.</li> \n  <li><strong>Time-Bound: </strong>In six months</li> \n  <li><strong>SMART Goal: </strong>In six months, we'll see a 25% increase in average video views per native video on Facebook by cutting our video content mix from eight topics to our five most popular topics.</li> \n </ul> \n <h3>3. Email Subscription Goal</h3> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Specific: </strong>I want to boost the number of email blog subscribers by increasing our Facebook advertising budget on blog posts that historically acquire the most email subscribers.</li> \n  <li><strong>Measurable: </strong>Our goal is a 50% increase in subscribers.</li> \n  <li><strong>Attainable: </strong>Since we started using this tactic three months ago, our email blog subscriptions have increased by 40%.</li> \n  <li><strong>Relevant: </strong>By increasing the number of email blog subscribers, our blog will drive more traffic, boost brand awareness, and drive more leads to our sales team.</li> \n  <li><strong>Time-Bound: </strong>In three months</li> \n  <li><strong>SMART Goal: </strong>In three months, we'll see a 50% increase in the number of email blog subscribers by increasing our Facebook advertising budget on posts that historically acquire the most blog subscribers.</li> \n </ul> \n <h3>4. Webinar Sign-Up Goal</h3> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Specific: </strong>I want to increase the number of sign-ups for our Facebook Messenger webinar by promoting it through social, email, our blog, and Facebook Messenger.</li> \n  <li><strong>Measurable: </strong>Our goal is a 15% increase in sign-ups.</li> \n  <li><strong>Attainable: </strong>Our last Facebook messenger webinar saw a 10% increase in sign-ups when we only promoted it through social, email, and our blog.</li> \n  <li><strong>Relevant: </strong>When our webinars generate more leads, sales have more opportunities to close.</li> \n  <li><strong>Time-Bound: </strong>By April 10, the day of the webinar</li> \n  <li><strong>SMART Goal: </strong>By April 10, the day of our webinar, we'll see a 15% increase in sign-ups by promoting it through social, email, our blog, and Facebook messenger.</li> \n </ul> \n <h3>5. Landing Page Performance Goal</h3> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Specific: </strong>I want our landing pages to generate more leads by switching from a one-column form to a two-column form.</li> \n  <li><strong>Measurable: </strong>My goal is a 30% increase in lead generation.</li> \n  <li><strong>Attainable: </strong>When we <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing\">A/B tested</a> our traditional one-column form versus a two-column form on our highest-traffic landing pages, we discovered that two-column forms convert 27% better than our traditional one-column forms, at a 99% significance level.</li> \n  <li><strong>Relevant: </strong>If we generate more content leads, sales can close more customers.</li> \n  <li><strong>Time-Bound: </strong>One year from now</li> \n </ul> \n <strong>SMART Goal: </strong>One year from now, our landing pages will generate 30% more leads by switching their forms from one column to two columns. \n <br> <h3>6. Link-Building Strategy Goal</h3> \n  <ul> \n   <li><strong>Specific:</strong> I want to increase our website's organic traffic by developing a link-building strategy that gets other publishers to link to our website. This increases our ranking in search engine results, allowing us to generate more organic traffic.</li> \n   <li><strong>Measurable:</strong> Our goal is 40 backlinks to our company homepage.</li> \n   <li><strong>Attainable:</strong> According to our <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-analysis-tools?_ga=2.39611873.398126922.1624283745-941898656.1624283745\"><span>SEO analysis tool</span></a>, there are currently 500 low-quality links directing to our homepage from elsewhere on the internet. Given the number of partnerships we currently have with other businesses, and that we generate 10 new inbound links per month without any outreach on our part, an additional 40 inbound links from a single link-building campaign is a significant but feasible target.</li> \n   <li><strong>Relevant:</strong> Organic traffic is our top source of new leads, and backlinks are one of the biggest ranking factors on search engines like Google. If we build links from high-quality publications, our organic ranking increases, boosting our traffic and leads as a result.</li> \n   <li><strong>Time-Bound:</strong> four months from now</li> \n   <li><strong>SMART Goal:</strong> Over the next four months, I will build 40 additional backlinks that direct to www.ourcompany.com. To do so, I will collaborate with Ellie and Andrew from our PR department to connect with publishers and develop an effective outreach strategy.</li> \n  </ul> <h3>7. Reducing Churn Rate Goal</h3> \n  <ul> \n   <li><strong>Specific:</strong> I want to reduce customer churn by 5% for my company because every customer loss is a reflection of our service’s quality and perception.</li> \n   <li><strong>Measurable:</strong> Contact 30 at-risk customers per week and provide customer support daily for five new customers during their onboarding process.</li> \n   <li><strong>Attainable:</strong> Our product offering has just improved and we have the means to invest more into our customer support team, and could potentially have five at-risk customers to upscale monthly.</li> \n   <li><strong>Relevant:</strong> We can set up a customer knowledge base to track customers’ progression in the buyer’s journey, and prevent churn by contacting them before they lose interest.</li> \n   <li><strong>Time-Bound: </strong>In 24 weeks</li> \n  </ul> \n  <ul> \n   <li><strong>SMART Goal:</strong> In 24 weeks, I will reduce the churn rate by 5% for my company. To do so, we will contact 30 at-risk customers per week and provide/invest in customer support to assist five new customers during onboarding daily and track their progress through a customer knowledge base.</li> \n  </ul> <h3>8. Brand Affinity Goal</h3> \n  <ul> \n   <li><strong>Specific:</strong> I want to increase our podcast listener count as we are trying to establish ourselves as thought leaders in our market.</li> \n   <li><strong>Measurable: </strong>A 40% increase in listeners is our goal.</li> \n   <li><strong>Attainable: </strong>We can increase our current budget and level our podcaster’s cadence, to have the means to hold insightful conversations for our listeners to tune into.</li> \n   <li><strong>Relevant: </strong>We created a podcast and have dedicated a team to source interesting guests, sound mixing, and eye-catching thumbnails to get it started.</li> \n   <li><strong>Time-Bound: </strong>In four months</li> \n   <li><strong>SMART Goal: </strong>In four months, we'll see a 40% increase in average listener count in Apple Podcasts by providing our team the budget and cadence to make insightful podcasts with quality sound mixing and eye-catching thumbnails.</li> \n  </ul> Now that you’ve seen examples of SMART goals, let’s dive into how to make your own. <a></a> <p></p> <h3>1. Use specific wording.</h3> <p>When writing SMART goals, keep in mind that they are \"specific\" in that there's a hard and fast destination the employee is trying to reach. \"Get better at my job,\" isn't a SMART goal because it isn't specific. Instead, ask yourself: What are you getting better at? How much better do you want to get?</p> <p>If you're a marketing professional, your job probably revolves around <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/choosing-kpis\">key performance indicators</a> or KPIs. Therefore, you might choose a particular KPI or metric that you want to improve on — like visitors, leads, or customers. You should also identify the team members working toward this goal, the resources they have, and their plan of action.</p> <p>In practice, a specific SMART goal might say, \"Clifford and Braden will increase the blog's traffic from email ...\" You know exactly who's involved and what you're trying to improve on.</p> <h4>Common SMART Goal Mistake: Vagueness</h4> <p>While you may need to keep some goals more open-ended, you should avoid vagueness that could confuse your team later on. For example, instead of saying, \"Clifford will boost email marketing experiences,\" say \"Clifford will boost email marketing click rates by 10%.\"</p> <p></p> <h3>2. Include measurable goals.</h3> <p>SMART goals should be \"measurable\" in that you can track and quantify the goal's progress. \"Increase the blog's traffic from email,\" by itself, isn't a SMART goal because you can't measure the increase. Instead, ask yourself: How much email marketing traffic should you strive for?</p> <p>If you want to gauge your team's progress, you need to quantify your goals, like achieving an X-percentage increase in visitors, leads, or customers.</p> <p>Let's build on the SMART goal we started three paragraphs above. Now, our measurable SMART goal might say, \"Clifford and Braden will increase the blog's traffic from email by 25% more sessions per month ... \" You know what you're increasing, and by how much.</p> <h4>Common SMART Goal Mistake: No KPIs</h4> <p>This is in the same light of avoiding vagueness. While you might need qualitative or open-ended evidence to prove your success, you should still come up with a quantifiable KPI. For example, instead of saying, \"Customer service will improve customer happiness,\" say, \"We want the average call satisfaction score from customers to be a seven out of ten or higher.\"</p> <h3>3. Aim for realistically attainable goals.</h3> <p>An \"attainable\" SMART goal considers the employee's ability to achieve it. Make sure that X-percentage increase is rooted in reality. If your blog traffic increased by 5% last month, try to increase it by 8-10% this month, rather than a lofty 25%.</p> <p>It's crucial to base your goals on your own analytics, not industry benchmarks, or else you might bite off more than you can chew. So, let's add some \"attainability\" to the SMART goal we created earlier in this blog post: \"Clifford and Braden will increase the blog's traffic from email by 8-10% more sessions per month ... \" This way, you're not setting yourself up to fail.</p> <h4>Common SMART Goal Mistake: Unattainable Goals</h4> <p>Yes. You should always aim to improve. But reaching for completely unattainable goals may knock you off course and make it harder to track progress. Rather than saying, \"We want to make 10,000% of what we made in 2021,\" consider something more attainable, like, \"We want to increase sales by 150% this year,\" or \"We have a quarterly goal to reach a 20% year-over-year sales increase.\"</p> <h3>4. Pick relevant goals that relate to your business.</h3> <p>SMART goals that are \"relevant\" relate to your company's overall business goals and account for current trends in your industry. For instance, will growing your traffic from email lead to more revenue? And, is it actually possible for you to significantly <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/23965/9-email-marketing-best-practices-to-generate-more-leads.aspx\">boost your blog's email traffic</a> given your current email marketing campaigns?</p> <p>If you're aware of these factors, you’re more likely to set goals that benefit your company — not just you or your department.</p> <p>So, what does that do to our SMART goal? It might encourage you to adjust the metric you're using to track the goal's progress. For example, maybe your business has historically relied on organic traffic for generating leads and revenue, and research suggests you can generate more qualified leads this way.</p> <p>Our SMART goal might instead say, \"Clifford and Braden will increase the blog's organic traffic by 8-10% more sessions per month.\" This way, your traffic increase is aligned with the business's revenue stream.</p> <h4>Common SMART Goal Mistake: Losing Sight of the Company</h4> <p>When your company is doing well, it can be easy to say you want to pivot or grow in another direction. While companies can successfully do this, you don't want your team to lose sight of how the core of your business works.</p> <p>Rather than saying, \"We want to start a new B2B business on top of our B2C business,\" say something like, \"We want to continue increasing B2C sales while researching the impact our products could have on the B2B space in the next year.\"</p> <h3>5. Make goals time-bound by including a timeframe and deadline information.</h3> <p>A \"time-bound\" SMART goal keeps you on schedule. Improving on a goal is great, but not if it takes too long. Attaching deadlines to your goals puts a healthy dose of pressure on your team to accomplish them. This helps you make consistent and significant progress in the long term.</p> <p>For example, which would you prefer: increasing organic traffic by 5% every month, leading to a 30-35% increase in half a year? Or trying to increase traffic by 15% with no deadline and achieving that goal in the same timeframe? If you picked the former, you're right.</p> <p>So, what does our SMART goal look like once we bound it to a timeframe? \"Over the next three months, Clifford and Braden will work to increase the blog's organic traffic by 8-10%, reaching a total of 50,000 organic sessions by the end of August.”</p> <h4>Common SMART Goal Mistake: No Time Frame</h4> <p>Having no timeframe or a really broad span of time noted in your goal will cause the effort to get reprioritized or make it hard for you to see if your team is on track. Rather than saying. \"This year, we want to launch a major campaign,\" say, \"In quarter one, we will focus on campaign production in order to launch the campaign in quarter two.\"</p> <h2>Make Your SMART Goals SMART-er</h2> <p>Now that you know what a SMART goal is, why it's important, and the framework to create one, it's time to put that information into practice. Whether you're setting goals for a personal achievement or as part of hitting important marketing milestones, it's good to start with what you want to achieve and then reverse-engineer it into a concrete SMART goal.</p> <p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in December 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> <p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=25ef9b24-9a2a-479e-9994-c7e62e7037f7&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call to action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/25ef9b24-9a2a-479e-9994-c7e62e7037f7.png\" /></a></p> \n  <div> \n   <a class=\"close\"> </a> \n   <a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=e6052733-6314-48b7-b224-1d42c04561fe&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/e6052733-6314-48b7-b224-1d42c04561fe.png\" /></a> \n  </div> </br>\n</div> \n<img
