\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 01 Jul 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1d7211ac-7b1b-4405-b940-54b8acedb26e.png","linkMd5":"9f5aa0594357953ac3f19f35e7685259","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn60@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-38-381_ac504860637ee534.webp","destWidth":368,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":4411,"destBytes":6042,"author":"Danielle Rohe","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1d7211ac-7b1b-4405-b940-54b8acedb26e.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn60@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-38-381_ac504860637ee534.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/market-research-section-min.png?width=771&name=market-research-section-min.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn41@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-50-734_a89ba6dbddd53983.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email-alert-min.png?width=648&name=email-alert-min.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn50@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-51-195_b93aba6cf21898be.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/compare-min.png?width=1053&name=compare-min.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn14@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-49-889_0e494696da191877.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rising-related-queries-min.png?width=1161&name=rising-related-queries-min.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn41@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-50-560_e19033e8acd985f0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/realtimetrends-min.png?width=952&name=realtimetrends-min.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/category-explore-min.png?width=943&name=category-explore-min.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/news-articles-barchart-min.png?width=1158&name=news-articles-barchart-min.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn8@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-52-845_eff0ce32735fe73b.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/8835eaa3-be7b-4697-81d2-488e03708d34.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn64@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-48-795_be9ebc9bbdc9c6d5.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fgoogle-trends&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn38@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-52-602_e7a712787936a5f4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938162},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"How to Be a Good Manager [Data + Expert Tips]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/people-manager-skills","description":"<p>Why do people really quit their jobs?</p> \n<p>Before you say \"salary,\" \"benefits,\" or \"workload,\" take a second to think about the worst boss you've ever had.</p> \n<p>Were they bad at giving feedback, not helpful, or just plain mean? Did they have you feeling unmotivated, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/psychological-safety-according-to-edmondson\">too nervous to offer ideas, or fearing that you'd lose your job</a> with the slightest miss-step?</p> \n<p>Once you let those memories sink in, you probably won't second guess the statement: <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2018/01/why-people-really-quit-their-jobs\">\"People quit their managers, not their jobs.\" </a></p> \n<p>Over the years, this fact hasn't changed. <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2018/01/why-people-really-quit-their-jobs\">Study after study</a> has emphasized that companies need good managers to retain good employees.</p> \n<p>But what makes for a good manager? And what skills or strategies can you develop to ensure you're considered a good one?&nbsp;</p> \n<p>To explore this issue, we polled people and asked them to check off all the qualities they felt were most important for a great manager.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/great%20manager%20skills.png?width=1104&amp;name=great%20manager%20skills.png\" alt=\"great manager skills\" width=\"1104\" style=\"width: 1104px;\">Recipients listed \"they trust me to work autonomously\", \"They are empathetic and understanding\", and \"They give me useful, clear feedback\", as the three most important qualities a good manager needs to have.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Along with this data, I consulted my colleagues to get their thoughts on what makes a people manager effective. Regardless of whether you're interested in managing a team, or just want to know if a prospective boss is actually a good manager, here are 7 crucial qualities of a great team leader.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Click here to download leadership lessons from HubSpot founder, Dharmesh  Shah [Free Guide].\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">7 Skills People Managers Must Master, According to HubSpot Employees</h2> \n<h3>1. Good managers help employees navigate change.</h3> \n<p>Consider the last time you experienced change within your organization. Maybe a beloved leader retired, or perhaps your team experienced a reorg. Maybe you even acquired a new company.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Whatever the reason, I'm willing to bet the change felt daunting at times. Fortunately, good managers can mitigate the negative or ambivalent emotions that arise from change.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>For instance, Christine McLaughlin, a Senior Project Manager on HubSpot's Sales Leadership Enablement team, told me: \"The strongest managers are ones who can help their teams navigate change in a very personal way. I'm a firm believer that every challenge presents an opportunity. But, because we're human, we can't always see the opportunity from the start.\"&nbsp;</p> \n<p>McLaughlin adds, \"Our personal life, mental health, physical health, the last meeting we had, the next meeting we're preparing for, all play a role in influencing how we perceive change. Do we view it as a challenge? An opportunity? A setback? A relief?\"</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">\"Strong managers can translate change for each individual on their team. They meet their teammate where they're at and help to answer their questions and concerns to bring them to where they need to go.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>So … how can you do this? Start by fostering psychological safety, so your employees feel comfortable mentioning how they feel about a certain business change. Then, listen carefully to their concerns and work on providing solutions for those issues.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>For instance, let's say your team has experienced a reorg and one of your direct reports is concerned her role is going to change as a result.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>To mitigate those concerns, consider creating a document that outlines which (if any) of her responsibilities might change as a result of the reorg — along with some new opportunities she can pursue to continue developing her professional skills.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>2. Good managers are open and transparent.</h3> \n<p>Trust and transparency are undeniably critical components of good leaders — and, post-pandemic, this is continuing to rise in importance. In fact, Edelman's most recent <a href=\"http://edelman.com/trust/2021-trust-barometer\"><span>2021 benchmark barometer on trust</span></a> in leaders found employees ranked \"good employee communication\" 44 points higher than in the previous year.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Keri Polmonari, HubSpot's Manager of Customer Success on the SMB team, believes transparency to be one of the most important attributes a good leader can possess.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>She says, \"Being transparent and forthcoming with your team creates an open and honest dialogue and ensures everyone is on the same page. Business changes — like changes in department goals, processes, or personnel — can be difficult and overwhelming. [But] when everyone understands the <em>why</em> behind these business changes, they are more open and understanding of implications this could have on their jobs, both positive and negative.\"</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Polmonari says,\"Transparency builds trust, fosters relationships, and creates organizational alignment, all key components of a company's, department's, and individual's success.\"</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/1-Jun-10-2021-02-38-06-55-PM.png?width=1104&amp;name=1-Jun-10-2021-02-38-06-55-PM.png\" alt=\"what does it mean to be a good manager? Keri's quote on the importance of transparency.\" width=\"1104\" style=\"width: 1104px;\"></p> \n<h3>3. Good managers encourage vulnerability.</h3> \n<p>Consider the last time your manager started your 1:1 with a slightly more personal question, like, \"How was your birthday this past weekend?\" or \"Read any good books lately?\"&nbsp;</p> \n<p>These questions ultimately help encourage vulnerability by creating space for you to share information about your life outside of work — and they can go a long way towards creating stronger bonds.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>As Jill Callan, VP of Marketing at <a href=\"https://www.trustedhealth.com/\"><span>Trusted Health</span></a>, told me, \"Whenever I start a new role or inherit a new team, I begin by enabling and encouraging vulnerability. This helps me forge strong bonds with my direct reports and allows them to be comfortable to share ideas and admit weaknesses.\"</p> \n<p>Callan adds, \"I'm also very intentional about getting to know my team as individuals, and learn about their lives outside of work. Taking the time upfront to build a strong, authentic relationship with my direct reports helps us tackle inevitable tough challenges down the line.\"&nbsp;</p> \n<p>To encourage vulnerability, consider how you might increase your own openness with your team. For instance, perhaps you admit when you're feeling overwhelmed with childcare duties, mention a Netflix show you've been binging, or simply chat about the gardening hobby you've picked up.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>And embrace vulnerability by admitting when you've made a mistake or you're feeling overwhelmed — it will help your employees feel comfortable admitting the same.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/2-Jun-10-2021-02-38-07-06-PM.png?width=1104&amp;name=2-Jun-10-2021-02-38-07-06-PM.png\" alt=\"what does it mean to be a good manager? Jill's quote on the importance of building authentic relationships.\" width=\"1104\" style=\"width: 1104px;\"></p> \n<h3>4. Good managers find ways to supplement their team member's weaknesses.</h3> \n<p>I once had a manager who repeatedly sought out learning and development opportunities for the areas we'd determined as weaknesses of mine. She would often email me public speaking courses, or data &amp; analytics workshops.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>As a result, I continued to grow professionally, and I felt challenged. This is what a good manager does: Continues to keep a direct report's weaknesses in-mind, and provides guidance to help that employee improve.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>HubSpot Senior Manager Christina Perricone concurs, telling me, \"Good managers find ways to supplement their team member’s weaknesses. Each of us has skills that come naturally to us, as well as skills we’re not so great at.\"</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"An attuned manager can identify an individual's weak areas and will surface resources or offer guidance to assist in those areas.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Consider how you might similarly foster growth by taking stock of your team's weaknesses, and actively pursuing resources that can help your team develop their weaker skills.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Additionally, use the hiring process to create a more well-rounded team by identifying strengths and weaknesses of existing employees.</p> \n<p>As Perricone says, \"Good managers are skilled at balancing out their teams by recruiting talent that can fill in the skill and experience gaps, thereby creating a more well-rounded unit.\"</p> \n<h3>5. Good managers work for their employees — not above them.</h3> \n<p>You might be thinking, \"Managers work for their employees? Isn't it the other way around?\"</p> \n<p>Actually, a manager, like an employee, is more effective when they're an active team player.</p> \n<p>But, while an employee's job is to fulfill tasks within a job description, a manager's job is to make his or her team successful. To do this, a manager shouldn't be afraid to chime in during meetings, assist on projects, or help their team grow or succeed in other ways.</p> \n<p>For instance, consider asking your direct reports during a 1:1, \"Is there anything you need me to do?\"&nbsp;</p> \n<p>This question can be translated in multiple positive ways, including, \"Are there any blockers I can remove for you?\", \"Are you waiting on a decision from me on anything?\", \"Are you working on an idea that you want to share with me?\" or even, \"Is there something going on in your world outside of work that's competing for your time and attention?\"</p> \n<p>Ultimately, a good manager considers it her primary job to make her employees successful in their projects and careers.</p> \n<h3>6. Good managers are always aiming to improve their emotional intelligence.</h3> \n<p>Emotional intelligence — or the skill that requires you to understand your own emotions, learn how to manage them, and know how to respond to the emotions of others on your team — is a vital component of good leadership.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Emotional intelligence can help you ensure you're giving clear directions, and allows you to be empathetic to the needs of others. In short, it can help you foster stronger professional relationships and communicate effectively.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Most importantly, emotional intelligence enables you to stay calm during high-stress or unexpected situations — which can prevent you from making rash decisions as a leader, or stressing your team out unnecessarily.</p> \n<h3>7. Good managers can establish and promote psychologically-safe environments.</h3> \n<p>The ability to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/psychological-safety-according-to-edmondson?_ga=2.239486723.1440891060.1623184284-154229254.1623184284\"><span>cultivate psychological safety</span></a> is a critical asset that Jennifer Stefancik, a HubSpot Academy Marketing Manager, values in her own people manager.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">\"Feeling supported, heard, and understood is the foundation I need to be able to come to work every day with the right mindset to do good work,\" Stefancik says.&nbsp;</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Stefancik adds, \"Genuine empathy and psychological safety are hard to fake, and it's something that I think everyone should master before they consider the people management path.\"</p> \n<p>Psychological safety fosters innovative thinking and the ability to adapt well to change — and yet, according to a <a href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/organization/our-insights/psychological-safety-and-the-critical-role-of-leadership-development\"><span>2020 McKinsey Global Survey</span></a>, only a handful of business leaders often demonstrate the behaviors associated with psychological safety.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>If you're a manager or hoping to be a better leader, it's important you take time to identify aspects of your management style or overall office culture that could benefit from psychological safety.</p> \n<p>For example, rather than using language that makes your team members feel scared of missing deadlines or goals, keep an open and supportive dialogue with them so they can confidently come to you with successes, learnings from failure, or concerns while they're working on high-pressure projects.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how%20to%20be%20a%20good%20manager,%20quote%20from%20Jennifer%20on%20the%20importance%20of%20feeling%20supported%20by%20managers.png?width=1104&amp;name=how%20to%20be%20a%20good%20manager,%20quote%20from%20Jennifer%20on%20the%20importance%20of%20feeling%20supported%20by%20managers.png\" alt=\"how to be a good manager, quote from Jennifer on the importance of feeling supported by managers\" width=\"1104\" style=\"width: 1104px;\"></p> \n<p>Alternatively, if a team member is having trouble with a project, you should offer advice or assistance to help them remove blockers, rather than telling them to just get it done.</p> \n<p>Supportive communication with team members allows them to learn from mistakes and grow as employees, rather than work tirelessly on projects because they fear that they'll lose their jobs.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">How to Be a Good Manager&nbsp;</h2> \n<p>As outlined in the data above, there are a few key traits required of any good manager. These include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Providing coaching and mentoring when necessary, but enabling your team to work autonomously and trusting them to get the job done.</li> \n <li>Showing empathy towards your direct reports as people with lives outside of work, and creating a sense of psychological safety for your employees to feel comfortable admitting when they're struggling or need help.</li> \n <li>Being clear and direct with feedback.</li> \n <li>Taking the time to go the extra mile to help foster your employees' professional growth through trainings, learning &amp; development opportunities, or 1:1 sessions in which you coach them on certain skills.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<p>However, a good manager looks different depending on the department or role — a good sales manager, for instance, requires different skills than that of a good marketing manager. Let's dive into those, now.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>How to Be a Good Sales Manager</h3> \n<p>Being a good sales manager requires a few unique skills outside of those listed above.</p> \n<p>Along with setting clear expectations, communicating effectively, and inspiring your sales reps to perform at their best, a good sales manager needs to demonstrate a positive mindset, build team unity, and learn how to best support each sales rep in the unique way that will serve him or her best.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>A few other notes on being a good sales manager:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Use a dashboard or <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/task-management\">task management tool</a> to easily track metrics for each sales rep. This enables you to avoid taking up too much time in your meetings discussing metrics — instead, you can now use that time to identify how you can best help, support, and coach your reps.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Plan team outings or events that allow your team to build relationships with one another. Sales can be high-pressure and stressful, so it's important you provide dedicated time to enable your sales reps to connect with one another and feel that they're part of a support system.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Look for trainings and development opportunities so your sales reps can continue to improve. In 1:1 meetings, focus on how you can help them achieve their goals; in team meetings, figure out what types of trainings can help the entire team perform better.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Motivate your team by focusing on the 'bigger purpose' to ensure they feel intrinsically motivated. Sales isn't just about hitting quota and making money — it's also (oftentimes) about selling a product or service that can help people in large or small ways. Remind your team of your company's bigger purpose to ensure they feel fulfilled and motivated.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Looking for more sales manager tips? Take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/modern-sales-leader\">Here's What Sales Leaders Should Prioritize in 2021 According to a Sandler Expert</a> or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/things-i-wish-i-knew-before-becoming-a-sales-manager\">10 Things I Wish I Knew Before Becoming a Sales Manager.</a></p> \n<h3>How to Be a Good Marketing Manager</h3> \n<p>Marketing managers are often in-charge of leading a team, but they're typically also responsible for a content property or program, which means their tasks can vary greatly.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Here are a few skills of a good marketing manager:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>The ability to think big-picture; using metrics and data to create a strong long-term strategy, and knowing when to pivot when an existing strategy isn't working out as expected.</li> \n <li>Communicating effectively with various stakeholders — this includes inspiring and motivating your direct reports, communicating team goals cross-functionally and to leadership, and creating clear external communications, as well.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Delegating and organizing tasks effectively. Learn about your direct report's strengths, interests, and areas for growth, and facilitate that growth by giving them projects when they align with their interests. This doesn't mean handing off any unwanted tasks from your to-do list — if you find a project that aligns with your direct report's interests and you feel it's mutually beneficial with team goals, then you'll want to shuffle some of their existing tasks to ensure you don't burn your team out.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<p>To learn more about managing a marketing team, take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-management\">What Is a Marketing Manager?</a></p> \n<h3>How to Be a Good Project Manager</h3> \n<p>To be a good project manager, you need a few additional technical skills compared to the other managers in this list. Project managers need a deep technical understanding of the project at-hand in order to understand which tasks need to be assigned to whom, and to keep the process running smoothly.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>A few other project manager skills and responsibilities include:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Being able to set realistic goals, and understanding what resources are required. A project manager needs to be able to set timelines on certain aspects of a project, and she also needs to understand what resources — including employees, external consultants, tools, or budgeting — are required to make it happen.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Having good organization and communication skills. A good project manager needs to remain organized and detail-oriented in order to effectively delegate tasks to the right teams, and stay on-top of identifying what needs to happen next for the project to go smoothly. A good project manager also needs to be able to clearly articulate the full scope of a project to various stakeholders to ensure each team is aligned on bigger-picture strategy.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Analyzing and determining potential risks. A good project manager needs to be able to foresee potential roadblocks in any given project, and analyze either internal metrics or industry data to determine the best way to mitigate those risks.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<p>A good project manager also uses the best tools at his or her disposal to create a streamlined process, keep track of responsibilities and timeline, and delegate effectively. Take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/free-project-management-software\">16 Free Project Management Software Options to Keep Your Team On Track</a> to choose the best tool for your needs.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>And that's it! You're well on your way to become a better manager yourself. Remember, like any other role, becoming a good manager requires time, patience, dedication, and a consistent desire for feedback from your direct reports to iterate and grow over time.&nbsp;</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5f7685cd-6442-4846-afea-a28dcbad007c&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 21 Jun 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"970283010554650944e48788414a215d","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/great%20manager%20skills.png?width=1104&name=great%20manager%20skills.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn61@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-53-589_fb2f8760df1988af.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn16@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-38-375_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/1-Jun-10-2021-02-38-06-55-PM.png?width=1104&name=1-Jun-10-2021-02-38-06-55-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn66@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-51-007_e83890bd45db019b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/2-Jun-10-2021-02-38-07-06-PM.png?width=1104&name=2-Jun-10-2021-02-38-07-06-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn23@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-48-955_e9271876379bb8c1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how%20to%20be%20a%20good%20manager,%20quote%20from%20Jennifer%20on%20the%20importance%20of%20feeling%20supported%20by%20managers.png?width=1104&name=how%20to%20be%20a%20good%20manager,%20quote%20from%20Jennifer%20on%20the%20importance%20of%20feeling%20supported%20by%20managers.png":null,"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f7685cd-6442-4846-afea-a28dcbad007c.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn8@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-52-482_15a22acbc5258093.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fpeople-manager-skills&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938161},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"10 Ways to Reach Customers Who Don’t Know They Need You","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/10-ways-to-speak-to-customers-who-dont-know-they-need-you","description":"<p>Event planner, lawyer, daycare owner, tow truck driver. Regardless of our chosen professions, it's fair to say that we all want to build our businesses' customer bases. It's how we thrive. So it's only natural for us to want to market our products or services to everyone, in hopes of capturing a larger audience and thus making more money.</p> \n<p>But every business has a few \"unreachables.\" Now, some of these people are placed in that category for a reason. If you sell retirement plans, for instance, your unreachables might be children because they're simply too young to purchase your product. But that doesn't mean they have to remain that way forever. Even the most unexpected groups of people could be your biggest advocates later on. You just need to know how to speak to them.</p> \n<p>Here are some tips for successfully reaching your unreachables.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=6baeae42-e710-4ecd-beb9-ceb2fb9f0877&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: State of Marketing Report [2021 Version]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/6baeae42-e710-4ecd-beb9-ceb2fb9f0877.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2>How to Reach Customers</h2> \n<h3>1. Make a list of your unreachables.</h3> \n<p>This is an important step you won't want to skip. Before you start trying to reach all different types of groups, you'll want to find out who your individual unreachables actually are. They may or may not be whom you think they are. That's why researching and surveying are important parts of this process.</p> \n<p>You might look at your current demographics for visitors to your website or social media platforms and determine which audiences aren't connecting with you. You might also try comparing your demographics to your competitors' to see if they're reaching an audience you might not be. Or, you could conduct interviews and send out questionnaires to gather additional information. Whatever methods of obtaining this data, be sure that in the end, you have answers to questions like:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Why are these groups uninterested/uninformed about my business?</li> \n <li>Are they also uninterested/uninformed about the products/services I sell, too?</li> \n <li>Do they know they might want/need what I'm offering?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Develop a persona for your unreachables.</h3> \n<p>At this point, you've narrowed down exactly who your unreachables are, but the research stage isn't over just yet. You still want to find out what their likes and dislikes are, where they live, where they work, etc.</p> \n<p>Researching the specifics of their day-to-day lives can be helpful when brainstorming the message and channels to reach them. It can help you create a story that appeals to multiple audiences.</p> \n<p>You can create campaigns that are effective because they appeal to multiple audiences by finding common ground through storytelling.</p> \n<h3>3. Customize your approach to appeal to <em>them,</em> not your current customers.</h3> \n<p>This is a continuation of the previous action. When brainstorming ways to speak to your unreachables, it's important to remember that the same message that works really well for your current audience probably won't be received well by another—or at least not as effectively.</p> \n<p>A successful example of this is <a href=\"https://www.convinceandconvert.com/digital-marketing/killing-it-with-digital-marketing-campaigns/\">Dollar Shave Club's</a>&nbsp;marketing efforts. Marketers realized that they could reach a lot of the younger generations with humorous and quick-witted branding. The success of the brand stemmed from the viral nature of the ads that spoke to a much broader group of people than ever before.</p> \n<h3>4. Offer them something truly unique.</h3> \n<p>As wisely stated by <em>Entrepreneur</em> contributor Murray Newlands in his article, <a href=\"http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/237040\">\"The 8 Fundamentals for a Successful Inbound-Marketing Strategy\"</a>, \"Think of your website as a hub, not a megaphone.\" This applies to all areas of your brand's presence—both online and offline. Treat your unreachables as if they are already your most loyal customers, rewarding them with valuable resources they can really use. Because if you can provide them with something they can't find elsewhere, it will build trust and credibility—two things that give you an instant leg up on your competition.</p> \n<p>Some valuable, yet still free/affordable resources you can offer include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Educational information, like e-books, guides, infographics, blog articles, webinars, tips, downloadable templates, etc.</li> \n <li>Coupons/exclusive discounts for first-time customers</li> \n <li>Product/service samples</li> \n <li>Branded merchandise</li> \n</ul> \n<p>As many in the industry may know already, this method of marketing (<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/inbound-marketing\">inbound marketing</a>) has proven to be one of the most successful ways to promote your brand or business.</p> \n<h3>5. Generate awareness of the want/need for what you have to offer.</h3> \n<p>Your unreachables are most likely in the awareness stage of the buyer's journey—unsure whether or not they even want or need the product/service you're offering, let alone if they want it from your specific company. That's why you have to create reasons why someone might need you.</p> \n<p>Let's say you're a hotel that's running a special vacation package. An example of the awareness-stage buyers would be a mother and father who just found out they're able to take a vacation with their family soon but aren't yet sure if they want to stay local, travel abroad, or go on a cruise. By marketing your vacation package as the most all-inclusive, affordable, and family-friendly offer available, you're successfully generating awareness and a desire for your offer.</p> \n<h3>6. Demonstrate how your product/service could be the only solution they need.</h3> \n<p>Maybe your business offers a variety of products or services (i.e. multi-platform digital solutions). Or, maybe it offers something a little more niche (i.e. all-organic coffee). But no matter what you offer, there's always a way to position yourself as their all-purpose solution.</p> \n<p>Your unreachables might not even know your business can handle multiple problems they're experiencing. They might not know that just how well you've mastered your very specific product/service. Or, they might not know they need you. Either way, you'll want to demonstrate how you're the only solution.</p> \n<h3>7. Position your business in the most positive light possible.</h3> \n<p>Though it may hard to conceive, most people want to find out how you can help them, even if they're not actively seeking you out. If you've piqued their interest in some way, they'll want to find the good in your business, so they can have a product or service that provides a solution or added convenience to their lives.</p> \n<p>A few suggestions for keeping your efforts upbeat and positive:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Use up-to-date content, design, and resources in your marketing efforts</li> \n <li>Use language that is confident and inviting, not cocky or abrasive</li> \n <li>Avoid negative messaging that puts down specific competitors (it's tacky)</li> \n <li>Highlight what specifically makes you better than the rest, but say it in a way that makes you look like the hero</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>8. Find ways to get your advocates to promote to them.</h3> \n<p>What's better than having happy customers who love your products/services? Having happy customers who willingly <em>promote</em> your products/services to others. If they're happy enough, they'll do it for free, too. It's like free advertising.</p> \n<p>This is your opportunity to reward your #1 fans with things like:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Refer-a-friend offers/discounts/coupons</li> \n <li>Exclusive content</li> \n <li>Donations to fan-favorite charities</li> \n <li>Answered questions/concerns, personalized shout-outs, and Q&amp;A sessions on social media platforms</li> \n <li>Fan-appreciation events</li> \n <li>Featured fan videos/photos/etc.</li> \n <li>Project involvement</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Whether your business is able to spend a lot or a little toward rewarding your advocates, remember that there's a huge benefit in having people promote your business for you.</p> \n<h3>9. Show many forms of credibility.</h3> \n<p>In addition to having testimonials on top-rated review sites (or on your own website), there are a lot of ways to demonstrate that you are credible and trustworthy.</p> \n<p>Find unique (yet still truthful) ways to display this in your marketing efforts, such as:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Noteworthy awards or certifications (place a badge on your website, post a link to your social media platforms with information about the award/certification, etc.)</li> \n <li>Support a local charity (display information about it on a dedicated landing page on your site, post about it on social media, etc.)</li> \n <li>Mention any environmentally sustainable efforts you make at your business (recycling, volunteering for eco-friendly organizations, etc.</li> \n <li>Case studies and testimonials</li> \n</ul> Though this is certainly helpful for your current customers to confirm they've made the right choice with you, those who might not know they need you yet might find your business more desirable than another, simply for your credibility. Research the industry-specific materials you can provide your potential customers to let them know you are not just a viable option, but the best option. \n<h3>10. Do all of this in stages—not all at once.</h3> \n<p>Last, but certainly not least, make sure you do these things in different phases. Because it's not realistic to believe anyone's effort will magically attract everyone to your business, you should set goals, follow a strategic plan, and measure your results. Rinse and repeat as necessary for each audience.</p> \n<p>There are plenty of ways to speak to those who seem unreachable. You just have to find ways to make it about them and why they (specifically) would want or need you. If you're not sure how to get started, try these tips for expanding your reach.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in April 2015 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"state of marketing\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2F10-ways-to-speak-to-customers-who-dont-know-they-need-you&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 01 Jul 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/6baeae42-e710-4ecd-beb9-ceb2fb9f0877.png","linkMd5":"86679d143d5e41ed0864dfb7a4a7a752","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-363_0a6311d55189482b.webp","destWidth":505,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":6246,"destBytes":8242,"author":"danielle@marketingzillas.com (Danielle Irigoyen)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/6baeae42-e710-4ecd-beb9-ceb2fb9f0877.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-363_0a6311d55189482b.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn78@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-48-782_ba6ee21c8b9c368e.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2F10-ways-to-speak-to-customers-who-dont-know-they-need-you&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn83@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-50-497_10e18042c8776074.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938117},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"SEO vs. PPC: When to Optimize and When to Pay for Traffic","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tabid/6307/bid/1514/paid-search-vs-organic-search.aspx","description":"<p>Imagine you’ve just created an excellent new product, and you're excited to share your business with the world.</p> \n<p>Unfortunately, you have no idea how to share this revolutionary product with as many of your target users as possible.</p>  \n<p>You’re not alone. Like you, many businesses face a similar problem regarding how to get their products in front of potential customers.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3d0bc27a-898d-40d5-aa46-8696ed81c4ee&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: HubSpot's Annual State of Marketing Report\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3d0bc27a-898d-40d5-aa46-8696ed81c4ee.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>Most of the time, the solution to your problem boils down to choosing between two marketing strategies: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-search-engine-optimization?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065&amp;_ga=2.61221103.2124293733.1621995984-1118394532.1621995984\">search engine optimization (SEO)</a> or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ppc?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065&amp;_ga=2.61221103.2124293733.1621995984-1118394532.1621995984\">pay-per-click (PPC)</a> campaigns.</p> \n<p>But which method is suitable for you? Is it better to pursue an organic-first approach and find consumers through search engine rankings, or is it better to invest in an advertisement at the top of a keyword results page?</p> \n<p>In this article, we've explored what you can expect to achieve from each of these two acquisition strategies. We’ve also provided some pros and cons of SEO and PPC along with descriptive statistics and real-life examples to help you decide whether your business is best suited for SEO or PPC — or both.</p> \n<h2><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">What is SEO?</span></strong></h2> \n<p>Search engine optimization is the process of enhancing your website’s visibility to make it rank and gain organic traffic from search engines.</p> \n<p>Just as you turn to your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/top-search-engines?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065&amp;_ga=2.61221103.2124293733.1621995984-1118394532.1621995984\">favorite search engines</a>, such as Google or Bing, to look up a new marketing acronym or where to get good pizza, so do your consumers. When you invest in SEO, you're increasing the likelihood of your target audience finding you when they make a Google search for keywords related to your product or service.</p> \n<p>For example, here’s Hubspot appearing at the top of Google’s organic results page for the term “inbound marketing,” thanks to the SEO strategy we have in place.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/1kbrv85xTSRPX7Ta5cDVs6NSmghWRWxDYxYtCEu4EhcpfXRjV177HJcHJgjdEgml0sGZA71aMFQcku9aP2R3CMTPnq0-2Td9bL8HYuEtrxNggKqvWC8y1AAc3I-XPmcO0UoG9R97\" width=\"600\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 600px;\" alt=\"example of seo \"></p> \n<p>Most SEO strategies center around Google because it holds <a href=\"https://gs.statcounter.com/search-engine-market-share\">92.24%</a> of the search engine market share. As such, you’ll need to learn about <a href=\"https://backlinko.com/google-ranking-factors\">Google’s 200 ranking factors</a>, technical SEO, <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/link-building-tutorial?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065&amp;_ga=2.31360252.2124293733.1621995984-1118394532.1621995984\">link building</a>, content creation, and so much more if you want to appear higher up on the search engine results page.</p> \n<h3>Pros of SEO</h3> \n<p>Here are some advantages of SEO:</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">1. SEO is cheaper in the long run.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>Although SEO might cost time and money —to pay freelancers or agencies, and for SEO tools — it’s still cheaper than PPC in the long run.</p> \n<p>When you create content that ranks and drives traffic to your website, you no longer have to keep spending money to make your target customers see it. And when these customers decide to click on your link, it comes at zero cost, unlike a PPC campaign where you pay per click.</p> \n<p>In the following image, you see that according to Ahrefs, Hubspot’s traffic value is a little over $22 million. Imagine we had to pay for every click we get.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/rVH49Md83LafOL4B3XoK8DCbmGQ5GAEiSLJTD_6Fo1Kp2a8kLegKaDAi1ZaQC6es463G-HEnW_C1FTajSNusume0RTWP2iZpDU7jYwiSie3iQF0TUzpkUoXZOI6FzLzyBuFAcF18\" width=\"600\" alt=\"pros of seo\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Organic traffic is also very scalable and cost-effective.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">2. You can target different funnel stages with SEO.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>Not all of your audience is at the same stage of the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/sales-funnel?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065\">sales funnel</a>.</p> \n<p>Some are just getting to know your brand at the top of the funnel. And others are already at the bottom of the funnel, ready to pull out their wallets.</p> \n<p>With SEO, you can create different content types (blog posts, guides, case studies) that meet each segment of your audience exactly where they are in the sales funnel.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">3. Search traffic is more stable.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>Once you rank on Google, you can be sure of free traffic to your website or web pages as long as you keep optimizing them.</p> \n<p>There’s also no off-and-on switch with SEO, unlike PPC marketing, where your website stops appearing on search results once your marketing budget dries up.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">4. Organic listings build brand authority.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>Appearing consistently on search results for keywords related to your products and services helps build trust and brand authority with your target audience.</p> \n<p>It also signifies to Google that you’re an expert on that topic or subject.</p> \n<h3><strong><span style=\"font-size: 14px;\">Cons of SEO</span></strong></h3> \n<p>Here are some reasons why you might not love SEO:</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">1. Search engine algorithms change.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>Search engines, especially Google, have <a href=\"https://www.searchenginejournal.com/google-algorithm-history/\">changed their algorithm</a> many times over the years. These changes mean that you’ll have to keep a close eye on your marketing strategy and organic results.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">2. You’ll need to optimize your website regularly.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>Your job doesn’t end when you get your website to rank for target keywords. Over time, you’ll have to regularly optimize your content and web pages so that it continues to rank.</p> \n<p>Optimization might include refreshing old articles and removing old/expired links.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">3. SEO takes time to show results.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>If your website or domain is new, it’s unlikely that you’ll enjoy immediate results from SEO. The reason is that many factors affect how Google ranks websites.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">2. It requires high-level skills and expertise.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>If you’re not hiring a professional, you’ll need to be an excellent writer and SEO expert to optimize your site for search engines properly.</p> \n<p>It’s undoubtedly time-consuming and overwhelming to run a business while taking <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/results?q=seo&amp;library=true&amp;_ga=2.11489021.830295185.1621993439-1955934222.1621993439&amp;__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065\">technical SEO</a>, writing, and link-building classes.</p> \n<h3>What is PPC?</h3> \n<p>PPC, or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ppc?_ga=2.11489021.830295185.1621993439-1955934222.1621993439\">pay-per-click</a>, is a form of search engine marketing (SEM) where an advertiser pays a publisher (such as Google or Facebook) every time someone clicks on the ad. This model allows advertisers to pay only when consumers interact with their ads — meaning you attract people interested in your offer and ready to make a purchase.</p> \n<p>This method is mainly associated with search engines as advertisers bid on search keywords relevant to their target markets. You may have noticed that the top search results are tagged with an \"Ad\" marker.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/4-hoOTBDh1tBOpOsMe9rzc0dxyIVkBIO1-wCEU5dsff1mDLduMwJQac--2-utPu_-TVwOg5iZVliwQD6VD7kSXKNkmSXCkU2bSwbtBAqWsli8u2z59TLOB_zHgwWFzMOicrfSXT1\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"what is ppc\"></p> \n<p>The cost of PPC ads usually depends on your industry and the search volume of the keyword you’re targeting.</p> \n<p>PPC advertising can help your business stay competitive in a crowded market and quickly get in front of their target consumers if you don’t have the domain authority to get your site ranking organically on search engines.</p> \n<h3>Pros of PPC</h3> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">1. PPC offers quick results.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>While it can take months to see results from your SEO strategy, it can take a few hours to see results from your PPC campaign.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">2. PPC ads appear above organic rankings.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>When you run a PPC campaign for your target keyword, your website would appear first on the search engine result page. This ranking makes your audience notice you first before scrolling to see other results.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">3. PPC allows you to pinpoint your target audience.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>While setting up a PPC campaign, you get to choose who you want to target with your ads.</p> \n<p>Do you want people from a specific geographic area? Or people of a particular age? Marital status? Or interest? If so, then you should use PPC.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">3. You can quickly run A/B tests on a PPC ad.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>With a PPC campaign, you can run two different ads simultaneously to measure the one that converts better.</p> \n<p>All you’ll have to do is change some ad elements like the ad copy and allow them to run for a period. Depending on the performance, you can decide to either “kill” the Google ads or continue optimization to improve your results.</p> \n<h3>Cons of PPC</h3> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">1. PPC ads are expensive.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>Without money, you cannot run a PPC campaign.</p> \n<p>You have to pay for every link that your audience clicks, meaning once your budget dries up, so does your traffic.</p> \n<p>Also, a PPC ad can get even more expensive (as high as $40) when you’re in a competitive industry like legal or insurance.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">2. Lower profit margins.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>While a PPC campaign might bring short-term wins, it’ll usually result in lower profit margins. Because PPC is a “pay to play” system, your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/what-does-cac-stand-for?_ga=2.243230795.830295185.1621993439-1955934222.1621993439\">customer acquisition costs</a> (CAC) would continue to get higher without a significant increase in the prices of your products and services.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">3. PPC ads become stale after a while.</span></strong></h4> \n<p>You have limited control over your paid ad because of the rule set by ad platforms like Google. As such, your copy might have similar wording to your competitors, which makes it easy for your audience to pass over quickly.</p> \n<h2>SEO vs. PPC</h2> \n<p>Search engine optimization (SEO) can help your content rank high on search engines, making it more likely that your audience would click and trust your content.</p> \n<p>SEO is also more effective for local searches and can grow your online presence for longer. Pay-per-click (PPC), on the other hand, is an acquisition strategy that requires you to spend ad money to get your content in front of an audience when they search for specific keywords online.</p> \n<h3>SEO vs. PPC: Which is better?</h3> \n<p>Asking which is better between SEO and PPC is like asking whether it’s better to eat with a fork or spoon — it depends.</p> \n<p>Serving pasta? Sure, I’d love a fork. Soup? I’d rather have a spoon.</p> \n<p>In the same way, different situations exist where SEO is better than PPC and vice versa.</p> \n<p>Let’s now look at some of these situations.</p> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">Use SEO if...</span></strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Your marketing budget is low.</li> \n <li>You want to build your brand authority.</li> \n <li>You’re looking to maximize your long-term return-on-investment (ROI).</li> \n <li>You want to create content that reaches your audience at different stages of the sales funnel.</li> \n</ul> \n<h4><strong><span style=\"color: #666666;\">Use PPC if...</span></strong></h4> \n<p>You’d get better results with PPC in situations where:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>You want quick results.</li> \n <li>Your product is novel or first-of-its-kind.</li> \n <li>You’re promoting a time-sensitive offer, like a holiday sale.</li> \n <li>You want to direct your audience to a sales or landing page.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>How to Make SEO and PPC Work For You</h2> \n<p>Instead of choosing between SEO or PPC, why not combine the two strategies and make them work for you?</p> \n<p>Here’s how you can get the best of both worlds.</p> \n<h3>1. Create retargeting ads.</h3> \n<p>Did someone visit your site, probably the pricing or check-out page, without buying?</p> \n<p>You can easily use a retargeting ad to prompt these visitors, even after they’ve left your site, to come back and make a purchase.</p> \n<h3>2. Promote website content with social media ads.</h3> \n<p>While you want your content to rank organically, you can give it a quick boost by promoting it on social media.</p> \n<p>Not only do these kinds of ads help with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-distribution?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065&amp;_ga=2.31360252.2124293733.1621995984-1118394532.1621995984\">content distribution</a>, but they could potentially help you acquire essential backlinks that’d boost your rankings.</p> \n<p>Also, it’s going to be a shame not to promote your latest blog post, guide, report, or case study after spending hours creating it.</p> \n<h3>3. Collect data From ads to improve your SEO strategy.</h3> \n<p>PPC campaigns grant you access to a lot of data — keyword search volumes, keywords your competitors are bidding for, highest converting calls-to-action, and so on.</p> \n<p>Aimed with all of this data, you’d be able to create better SEO strategies with less effort.</p> \n<h2>SEO vs. PPC Statistics</h2> \n<h3>SEO</h3> \n<ol> \n <li>Google is responsible for over <a href=\"https://sparktoro.com/blog/2018-search-market-share-myths-vs-realities-of-google-bing-amazon-facebook-duckduckgo-more/\">92%</a> of global web traffic.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ahrefs.com/blog/search-traffic-study/\">90.63%</a> of online content get zero traffic from Google, with only 0.21% getting over 1000 visits per month.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://sparktoro.com/blog/less-than-half-of-google-searches-now-result-in-a-click/\">46.40%</a> of browser-based Google searches resulted in an organic link click.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ahrefs.com/blog/search-traffic-study/\">99.2%</a> of website pages have less than 100 backlinks.</li> \n <li>Google processes over <a href=\"https://www.internetlivestats.com/google-search-statistics/\">7 billion</a> searches per day (or 2.5 trillion searches per year.)</li> \n <li>SEO drives almost <a href=\"https://videos.brightedge.com/research-report/BrightEdge_ChannelReport2019_FINAL.pdf\">100%</a> more traffic than paid traffic.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/marketing-strategies/app-and-mobile/smartphone-user-search-behavior-statistics/\">60%</a> of smartphone users have contacted a business directly using the search results (e.g., “click to call” option).</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing/seo-trends?_ga=2.47785070.830295185.1621993439-1955934222.1621993439\">64%</a> of marketers actively invest in SEO.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://videos.brightedge.com/research-report/BrightEdge_ChannelReport2019_FINAL.pdf\">76%</a> of B2B search traffic is trackable.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/advertising-channels/search/how-advertisers-can-extend-their-relevance-with-search-download/\">18%</a> of local smartphone searches led to a purchase within a day, whereas only 7% of non-local searches led to a sale.</li> \n</ol> \n<h3>PPC</h3> \n<ol> \n <li><a href=\"https://clutch.co/seo-firms/resources/search-engine-marketing-why-people-click-paid-search-ads\">390 out of 506</a> surveyed by Clutch say they recognize a paid search ad when they see it.</li> \n <li>The Google Display Network reaches <a href=\"https://ads.google.com/intl/en_ng/home/campaigns/display-ads/#:~:text=Display%20ads%20can%20help%20you,sites%20like%20Gmail%20and%20YouTube.\">90%</a> of Internet users worldwide.</li> \n <li>Search advertising spend is expected to exceed <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/outlook/dmo/digital-advertising/search-advertising/worldwide\">$170 billion</a> in 2021.</li> \n <li>More than <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/435252/adblock-users-worldwide/\">763 million devices use Adblock</a>. As a consumer, Adblock is amazing. It stops all those eerily targeted ads from popping up on your Facebook feed. However, as a marketer, it can be frustrating to invest in PPC if vast numbers of your target consumers will never see your ad. Additionally, ad blocking has increased <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics?hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tabid/6307/bid/1514/paid-search-vs-organic-search.aspx&amp;hubs_post-cta=grown%2015-30%25&amp;_ga=2.46015213.830295185.1621993439-1955934222.1621993439\">15-30%</a> in the last four years.</li> \n <li>PPC Ads can <a href=\"https://cleverclicks.com.au/blog/best-ppc-stats-trends-2018/\">boost awareness by 80%</a>. Despite ad blockers, PPC is still effective in increasing your brand's reach and awareness.</li> \n <li>The highest average monthly cost-per-click (CPC) in Google Ads search advertising is in the insurance industry at <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/1115432/us-search-advertising-cpc/\">$18.57 per click</a>.</li> \n <li>The cheapest CPC in Google Ads search advertising is in the electronics industry at <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/1115432/us-search-advertising-cpc/\">83 cents per click</a>.</li> \n <li>The average Facebook Ads Click-Through Rate across all industries is <a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2019/11/12/facebook-ad-benchmarks\">0.89%</a>. The Pets and Animals industry has the highest CTR while the lowest rates come from the Science industry.</li> \n <li>The average Facebook Ads cost-per-click (CPC) is <a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2019/11/12/facebook-ad-benchmarks\">$1.68</a> across industry. Advertisers in the Finance industry have the highest average CPC ($3.89), while Food and Drinks have the lowest average CPC ($0.42)</li> \n <li>Google's algorithm updates don't affect PPC. While not a stat per se, a significant benefit of PPC is that it's immune to Google's changing SERP ranking algorithm. In 2018, Google reported that they had updated their algorithm <a href=\"https://moz.com/google-algorithm-change\">3,234 times</a>! If you're using the SEO method, you have to adjust your content optimization to rank better according to the updated algorithm requirements.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://clutch.co/seo-firms/resources/search-engine-marketing-why-people-click-paid-search-ads\">75% of marketers from Clutch’s survey</a> say it's easier to find what they're looking for from paid ads. The first page of search engine results — especially the few hits — gets the vast majority of clicks due to the combination of ease of use and finding what the searcher is looking for. Bidding on target keywords through PPC accomplishes both of these needs: the paid ads are easy to find at the top of the SERP, and they answer the searcher’s question.</li> \n</ol> \n<h2>Final Thoughts</h2> \n<p>Whether you choose to go with SEO or PPC ultimately depends on your business situation. So take your time to evaluate the pro and cons of both SEO and PPC to see which is the right fit for you. And if possible, integrate the two strategies to see even more outstanding results for your business.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in July 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img
