02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"How to Write the Perfect Email to Apply for an Unlisted Role [Infographic]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-for-unlisted-role-infographic","description":"<p>Maybe you've been refreshing the Careers page at your dream company for months.</p>  \n<p>Alternatively, perhaps you've heard glowing reviews about a company from friends — but whenever you check, they're still not hiring for any roles for which you'd qualify.</p> \n<p>Whatever the case, if you feel a company's culture could be a great fit for you, you might consider sending a cold email so hiring managers can keep you in-mind if a role becomes available.</p> \n<p>But that's easier said than done. If you sound too pushy, you risk alienating the hiring manager. A good cold email should be concise and focus on how you can add value to the team. When done correctly, a cold email is a good opportunity to network and get your name in front of the right people.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=4ec95757-585e-40cf-9189-6b3885074e98&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: 12 Resume Templates [Free Download]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4ec95757-585e-40cf-9189-6b3885074e98.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>Fortunately, the folks at <a href=\"https://resume.io/\">Resume.io</a>&nbsp;put together an infographic, which details the 8 essential elements of a persuasive email you can use to apply at your dream company. Take a look now, and then check out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/letter-of-interest?_ga=2.82490070.1777984721.1624641870-1974937752.1624641870\">How to Write a Letter of Interest in 2021 [Examples + Template]</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How-to-Write-a-Persuasive-Email%20(1)-min.png?width=1200&amp;name=How-to-Write-a-Persuasive-Email%20(1)-min.png\" alt=\"How-to-Write-a-Persuasive-Email (1)-min\" width=\"1200\" style=\"width: 1200px;\"></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=a326f8db-3615-44c1-b837-d4a402320bd6&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-Action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/a326f8db-3615-44c1-b837-d4a402320bd6.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Femail-for-unlisted-role-infographic&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 05 Jul 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4ec95757-585e-40cf-9189-6b3885074e98.png","linkMd5":"9e68b245d4597f8ba1a53528b9b81d0b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn13@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-38-377_9bba382fc5511278.webp","destWidth":516,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":3814,"destBytes":7908,"author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4ec95757-585e-40cf-9189-6b3885074e98.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn13@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-38-377_9bba382fc5511278.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How-to-Write-a-Persuasive-Email%20(1)-min.png?width=1200&name=How-to-Write-a-Persuasive-Email%20(1)-min.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn42@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-51-927_590eca6e0bcf65fd.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/a326f8db-3615-44c1-b837-d4a402320bd6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn38@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-53-602_dcbb1a2d1e6bf726.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Femail-for-unlisted-role-infographic&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn85@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-49-103_7bd8c9418f67acae.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938126},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Relationship Marketing","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/relationship-marketing","description":"<p>There are plenty of studies that highlight the importance of customer retention — oftentimes, customer retention has been found to be even more critical to your company's success than customer acquisition.<a href=\"https://media.bain.com/Images/BB_Prescription_cutting_costs.pdf\">Frederick Reichheld of Bain &amp; Company</a> found as little as a five percent increase in customer retention can result in an increase in company revenue by 25-95%.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://business.adobe.com/content/dam/dx/us/en/resources/reports/adobe-digital-economic-index-april-2021/Digital_Economy_Index_April_2021.pdf\">Adobe learned</a> that returning customers spend more than newer customers. Why? Because existing customers understand the value of your products and services and they're invested loyally in your brand. If a customer feels satisfied with their interaction with you, it’s a no-brainer for them to turn to your business for their needs, again and again.</p> \n<p>No matter if you’re a team of one or leading a scaling enterprise, you can cultivate a deeper relationship with your existing audience without the typical costs associated with acquiring new customers. The key is strategic relationship marketing.</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: Free Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png\" align=\"middle\"></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>“But isn’t all marketing relationship marketing?” Not exactly. Some marketing tactics are solely about gaining traffic and conversions to get potential customers into the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/flywheel\">customer flywheel</a>. From there, you’ll have even more marketing tactics that get that potential customer to make their first purchase.</p> \n<p>The perfect time to start a relationship marketing strategy is when the customer has made a purchase (or several). Your goal with relationship marketing is to get these new customers to become brand-loyal patrons of your business. To do that, you’ll want to take a personalized approach and become integrated into their lives in a way that feels natural and genuine.</p> \n<p>Here, let's take a look at some relationship marketing examples and the tactics they use to make this strategy work. Then, we’ll explore how you can implement a strong relationship marketing strategy today.</p> \n<p></p> \n<br> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.capitalone.com/\">Capital One</a></h3> \n<p>Capital One understands its customers deeply — all the way down to the small inconveniences that plague them most. One of those annoyances is the long TSA line at the airport.</p> \n<p>Capital One <a href=\"https://www.capitalone.com/learn-grow/money-management/tsa-precheck-global-entry-credit/\">reimburses all venture cardholders up to $100</a> when they pay the TSA PreCheck fee. All they have to do is pay for it with their Capital One credit card.</p> \n<p>TSA PreCheck expires after five years, and this benefit can be used every time the cardholder wants to renew their PreCheck status. This benefit speaks to a relevant pain point for Capital One customers and makes keeping an account open with Capital One well worth it in the long run.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.fairwayindependentmc.com/\">Fairway Independent Mortgage Corporation</a></h3> \n<p>Any homeowner knows that purchasing a home is one of the biggest and most important decisions one can make. Mortgage lenders know this, too. During the process of buying a home, buyers typically shop around for the lowest rate, but they’re also shopping for a reliable team that will make the process as smooth as possible.</p> \n<p>Fairway Independent Mortgage Corporation is a great example of a business that takes the relationship marketing approach to customer relations. When the real estate market is moving quickly, Fairway stands out and offers its buyers more than just low interest rates. For example, I received a birthday email from Fairway which came right around the time I needed to make some decisions about my lender. In addition to that, the loan consultant was sure to send over some marketing documents with their value proposition and benefits for me as a buyer.</p> \n<p>All of this showed me that the company was committed to being responsive, respectful, helpful, and most importantly — closing on time. This is a recipe for success in the mortgage industry as referrals are the <a href=\"https://bombbomb.com/blog/8-tips-to-increase-mortgage-referral-business/\">“bread and butter of any successful loan officers business.”</a></p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://www.ge.com/\">GE</a></h3> \n<p>Relationship marketing is ultimately about offering both new and existing customers valuable content regardless of where they are in the buyer’s journey. Good relationship marketing should appeal to the first-time viewer as powerfully as it appeals to your long-term customers to ensure your customers can grow with you over time.</p> \n<p>GE does a great job of diversifying its content, and the platforms on which it promotes, to ensure it satisfies as many people as possible. For instance, <a href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/lifeafter-the-message/id1045990056\">GE created two sponsored podcasts</a> in the sci-fi genre. It seems strange, but GE positions itself as an “inventor of the future of industry,” so it makes sense that the company might dabble in the world of what-ifs in the sci-fi genre. Additionally, the company has a popular <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/GE/featured\">YouTube channel</a> that features <a href=\"https://youtu.be/D9fsQkjUNrQ\">historic, innovative stories</a> from the perspective of GE employees. Whether you’re an existing customer or a prospective employee, content like this places GE directly into the lives of customers in a natural, helpful, and even entertaining way.</p> \n<p>By consistently offering a diverse range of quality content, GE shows its desire to satisfy its long-term customers even at the expense of short-term wins.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.dominos.com/en/?lang=en\">Domino's</a></h3> \n<p>In the past couple of years, Domino's has taken its fair share of risks for the sake of innovation and improvement, including a series of ads called <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AH5R56jILag\">Pizza Turnaround</a>, in which they showcased a series of negative customer reviews, read by real Domino's employees, before promising a new and improved recipe.</p> \n<p>These self-deprecating ads appeal genuinely to viewers but clearly go against any traditional sales playbook... which is why they work. By admitting an area of opportunity, Domino's re-invented its brand as transparent and honest — and who wouldn't want to buy from a company like that?</p> \n<p>Additionally, Domino's has conducted other genius marketing campaigns like the <a href=\"https://dominosweddingregistry.com/\">Domino's wedding registry</a>, in which soon-to-be-married couples can create their own pizza registry, and <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5sxP2cBA8OA\">Avoid the Noid</a>, where the company partnered with every state in the US to repair potholes to limit the number of damaged pizzas being delivered. Domino's has also done a fantastic job tapping into their digital audience — at one point, the company even allowed people to order pizza using a <a href=\"https://www.eater.com/2015/5/13/8597819/how-to-order-dominos-pizza-emoji\">simple pizza emoji</a>. Now, <a href=\"https://biz.dominos.com/about/fun-facts/#:~:text=TECHNOLOGY%20%26%20ONLINE%3A&amp;text=Domino's%20generated%20more%20than%2070,international%20markets%20feature%20online%20ordering.\">70% of Domino's sales</a> are through digital channels.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, there are plenty of innovative steps Domino's has taken to cultivate a loyal, long-term customer base. They accepted short-term losses for long-term gains by slowly and strategically re-inventing their product and their brand while still engaging with their customers on their favorite digital platforms.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://www.panerabread.com/en-us/home.html\">Panera</a></h3> \n<p>Panera’s commitment to health and convenience has resulted in <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/aliciakelso/2020/08/04/paneras-coffee-subscription-is-such-a-success-the-chain-wants-to-do-more-such-programs/#:~:text=While%20the%20results%20of%20Panera's,loyalty%20programs%20in%20any%20industry.\">40 million Panera loyalty members</a>.</p> \n<p>In 2014, Panera <a href=\"https://adage.com/article/cmo-strategy/panera-bread-cleans-act/307387/\">issued a statement</a> promising its customers it would remove all artificial flavors, sweeteners, and preservatives from all Panera products by the end of 2016. The company remained transparent throughout the process, <a href=\"https://www.panerabread.com/en-us/our-beliefs/who-we-are.html\">publishing progress reports</a> to demonstrate a level of accountability and transparency to its customers.</p> \n<p>Undoubtedly, it was a risky decision to admit they'd previously used unhealthy ingredients in their food — but it paid off big-time in 2016 when the brand could officially say \"100% of our food is 100% clean\".</p> \n<p>Additionally, the brand continues to focus on cultivating strong relationships with its customers through personalization. For instance, Panera alerts loyalty members about new food offerings they feel will meet the member's \"flavor profile\" based on past purchases.</p> \n<p>The company also meets its customers where they are — <a href=\"https://www.pymnts.com/news/retail/2020/panera-dials-up-online-grocery-business/\">starting an online grocery business</a> as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic. Panera even offers home and business delivery, rapid pickup, and catering in an effort to better serve its customers.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://www.marriott.com/default.mi\">Marriott</a></h3> \n<p>Undoubtedly, a 35-minute film is not the most traditional avenue a hotel can take when it wants to increase sales — and yet, that's exactly what Marriott chose to do with their film, \"<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUIeA1i6V5I\">Two Bellmen Three</a>\".</p> \n<p>This film enables Marriott to appeal to a younger demographic and build brand awareness on dominant platforms like Snapchat. Best of all, their content rarely resembles an advertisement and is typically focused on providing an audience with fun, or helpful, information on various travel destinations.</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://www.armorsuit.com/\">ArmorSuit</a></h3> \n<p>ArmorSuit's <a href=\"https://www.armorsuit.com/pages/warranty\">warranty policy</a> begins like this — \"Most warranties are limited to 30 days or one year, but with our Lifetime Replacement Warranty, our customers can request for a replacement screen protector for a lifetime. This way, you never need to purchase a whole new kit when a replacement is needed.\"</p> \n<p>This way, you never need to purchase a whole new kit — a phrase you'll likely never hear in traditional sales transactions. ArmorSuit's lifetime warranty represents the company's steadfast commitment to keeping its customers satisfied. While it might seem ridiculous to offer a lifetime warranty, it makes sense for building strong relationships with ArmorSuit's customers — when the company's customers then need other products related to tech, they'll most likely check out ArmorSuit's website first.</p> \n<p>Next, let’s explore how you can create a strong relationship marketing strategy for your own business.</p> \n<br> \n<h3>1. Provide personalized, customer-focused service.</h3> \n<p>When you're creating a relationship marketing strategy and engaging with your customers, your primary concern should never be focused on your product or service. Instead, your concerns should always revolve around the customer — Would the customer want to see this ad? Would the customer be excited about this Instagram post? Does our new product delight the customer?</p> \n<p>Additionally, it's critical that you create channels for direct support when your customers need help. Perhaps you implement a Facebook Messaging Bot for service-related concerns. Alternatively, maybe you answer your customer's questions via Instagram DM. By meeting your customers on platforms they use most, you're proving your willingness to help them despite the hassles it might entail for your overall business process.</p> \n<h3>2. Engage with the customer where they are.</h3> \n<p>The reason Marriott's strategy works isn't only because of the content they create — it's also where they post that content. Creating videos specifically for Snapchat enables Marriott to appeal to a younger demographic on a platform already popular with that audience.</p> \n<p>Research which platforms are most popular for your ideal demographic. By reaching out to them through their preferred channels, you're demonstrating a level of helpfulness and understanding that will encourage those users to interact with your brand.</p> \n<h3>3. Incorporate technology to work more effectively.</h3> \n<p>Technology might seem counterintuitive to building organic relationships that are personalized, but it can be the key to solving customer pain points. As your company grows, it’ll become increasingly more difficult to connect one-on-one with each customer.</p> \n<p>Using an automated marketing system can ensure that every customer receives communication from your business and has the opportunity to engage. Tools like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing\">HubSpot’s Marketing Hub</a> can automate workflows and email cadences so that you never miss a customer milestone.</p> \n<h3>4. Offer incentives and rewards for customer loyalty.</h3> \n<p>To cultivate a long-term relationship with your customers and create lasting brand loyalty, continue engaging with customers even after they've purchased a product. Consider what you can offer them once they've become customers — perhaps they can get a discount on additional products, or receive personalized recommendations based on their preferences.</p> \n<p>By creating a loyalty rewards program, Panera continues to incentivize its customers to purchase additional products and slowly forms a more meaningful relationship by gathering information about each customer and then using that information to offer unique suggestions depending on their individual food preferences.</p> \n<h3>5. Create valuable content that tells a compelling story.</h3> \n<p>If a customer has already purchased your product, they don't need to see additional product advertisements to become brand loyalists — instead, they need to feel your business offers value regardless of their purchase intent.</p> \n<p>Marriott's film isn't meant to immediately convert a viewer into a paying customer. Instead, its purpose is to increase brand awareness, so that down the road, when that viewer is ready to book a hotel for an upcoming trip, they'll remember the compelling film they saw once and think of Marriott.</p> \n<h3>6. Collect feedback regularly.</h3> \n<p>A relationship works two ways — to truly develop a meaningful connection with your customers, then, it's vital you ask them for feedback. What do they want to see from your brand? What do they like about your product? What do they wish you wrote about on your blog? This information improves your relationship marketing strategy to best fit the needs of your specific audience.</p> \n<h2>Play the Long Game With Relationship Marketing</h2> \n<p>There’s a time and place for quick marketing wins and they’re paramount in hitting goals and KPIs each quarter. However, your marketing, sales, and service teams work much better together at playing the long game. Relationship marketing won’t score you consistent quick wins that you can measure with hard numbers in a dashboard. But you’ll find that staying the course and nurturing the customer will yield happier and more loyal brand advocates for quarters to come.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in February 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Frelationship-marketing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 28 Jun 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png","linkMd5":"5b0368da4b7e15ee41fb105cf9b1c98f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn4@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-44-409_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","destWidth":433,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5125,"destBytes":6842,"author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn4@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-44-409_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn44@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-49-901_b69ef96b2d492171.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Frelationship-marketing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn7@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-51-355_d006360983e2da4f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938161},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"How HubSpot Helps Users Prepare for Google's Core Web Vitals","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/hubspot-core-web-vitals","description":"<p>It's no secret that poor <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ux-user-experience\">user experience (UX)</a> <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">isn’t</span> going to keep your customers and target audience coming back to your website. Poor UX also negatively impacts your ability to rank on Google's search engine results page (SERP).</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=1d7211ac-7b1b-4405-b940-54b8acedb26e&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: SEO Starter Pack [Free Kit]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1d7211ac-7b1b-4405-b940-54b8acedb26e.png\" align=\"middle\" /></a></p> \n<p>To ensure your website has delightful UX for your visitors as well as one that meets Google's standards for ranking, you'll want to focus on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/core-web-vitals\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Core Web Vitals.</span></a></p> \n<h2>Core Web Vitals</h2> \n<p>At a high level, <a href=\"https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/9205520?hl=en\">Google's Core Web Vitals exist to fix poor user experiences on your website</a> — Google knows that poor UX leads to higher bounce rates and that's why they take page performance into consideration when determining your page's ranking.</p> \n<p>Core Web Vitals are meant to be applied by all site owners on each of their web pages to ensure all three Vitals — <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/hubspot-core-web-vitals#three-google-core-web-vitals\">which we'll talk more about below</a> — are measured.</p> \n<h2>HubSpot Core Web Vitals</h2> \n<p>HubSpot’s SEO audit tool reviews all three of Google's Core Web Vitals metrics for you. Below, we’ll cover the ways in which HubSpot can help you prepare for Core Web Vitals.</p> \n<h3>How HubSpot Helps Users Prep for Core Web Vitals</h3> \n<p>Google’s Core Web Vitals metrics are part of the search engine’s page ranking algorithm. <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">HubSpot’s SEO audit tool flags pages with unsatisfactory scores based on Google’s Core Web Vitals metrics. </span><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Specifically,</span> HubSpot uses <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse\">Google Lighthouse</a> to automatically scan all pages that make up a website. The tool then flags pages that fail any of these metrics.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Three Core Web Vitals that HubSpot’s SEO audit tool flags:</h3> \n<p style=\"font-weight: bold; text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-06-24%20at%2011.08.40%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-06-24%20at%2011.08.40%20PM.png\" alt=\"hubspot helps you prep these three core website vitals of google\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><a href=\"https://web.dev/vitals/\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Source</span></em></span></a></img></p> \n<h4>1. <a href=\"https://web.dev/lcp/\">Largest Contentful Paint (LCP)</a></h4> \n<p><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">LCP is perceived page load speed. It refers to how quickly a page can load and render all of its visual elements to the screen.</span></p> \n<h4><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">2. <a href=\"https://web.dev/cls/\">Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS)</a></span></h4> \n<p><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">CLS is visual stability. It refers to how often users experience unexpected layout shifts on a web page.</span></p> \n<h4><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">3. <a href=\"https://web.dev/fid/\">First Input Delay (FID)</a></span></h4> \n<p><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">FID is load responsiveness. It's a quantifiable measurement of how users feel when a page is unresponsive.</span></p> \n<p><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">An alternative measurement for FID is <a href=\"https://web.dev/tbt/\" style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Total Blocking Time</a><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"> (TBT)</span></span></span>. TBT&nbsp;is the quantifiable measurement of how much a non-interactive page is before becoming interactive. In other words, TBT measures the total amount of time that a page is blocked from responding to user input.<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"> </span></span></span></span><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">HubSpot scans and flags web pages that have a TBT of <a href=\"https://web.dev/tbt/\">over 300 milliseconds</a> for you (because Google believes a good TBT is anything less than 300 milliseconds).</span></span></span></span></span></p> \n<h3>Who benefits from HubSpot’s SEO audit tool?</h3> \n<p>HubSpot can help you prepare for Core Web Vitals whether or not you’re a <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/cms?__hstc=45788219.e23386fb1d8aca6c541438551fbd2a5a.1624559111652.1624559111652.1624559111652.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1624559111652&amp;__hsfp=656685893&amp;_ga=2.20287675.283892421.1624559110-150579560.1624559110\">CMS Hub</a> user — in fact, it’s available to those who are CMS Hub Professional and Enterprise users as well as <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing?_ga=2.113868935.1003919981.1624556266-1934227427.1624556266\">Marketing Hub</a> Professional and Enterprise users. You can use HubSpot's SEO audit tool whether you're on a HubSpot-hosted website or a website hosted by another platform.</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><em>Pro Tip: Get <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/cms?hubs_post-cta=producttest\">HubSpot CMS Hub</a> or <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing?hubs_post-cta=producttest\">Marketing Hub</a> to begin measuring your web pages' UX against Google's Core Web Vitals.&nbsp;</em></p> \n<h3><span style=\"font-size: 2rem; font-weight: bold;\">Start Prepping For Core Web Vitals With HubSpot</span></h3> \n<p>With HubSpot, you'll know if your web pages meet Google Core Web Vitals. As a result, you'll be able to ensure your web pages are offering your visitors delightful UX. Additionally, you'll know that your web pages have a significantly better chance at ranking for your keywords and phrases than they would if they didn't meet Google's criteria.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=05aa9467-4eda-4dd6-8b7f-ad9855abfe33&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"marketing\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/05aa9467-4eda-4dd6-8b7f-ad9855abfe33.png\" /></a></p> \n<img \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 07 Jul 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1d7211ac-7b1b-4405-b940-54b8acedb26e.png","linkMd5":"936037c09ef69df73174b71733edfa09","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn60@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-38-381_ac504860637ee534.webp","destWidth":368,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":4411,"destBytes":6042,"author":"krbaker@hubspot.com (Kristen Baker)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1d7211ac-7b1b-4405-b940-54b8acedb26e.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn60@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-38-381_ac504860637ee534.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-06-24%20at%2011.08.40%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-06-24%20at%2011.08.40%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn95@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-51-664_45c414f039b93420.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/05aa9467-4eda-4dd6-8b7f-ad9855abfe33.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-53-180_339ca67d143927cd.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhubspot-core-web-vitals&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn51@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-52-181_b592e5b56bf3fe64.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938126},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"Sitemaps: What They Are, How to Create One & Submit it to Google","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/build-sitemap-website","description":"<p>Sitemaps are one of SEO's oldies but goodies.</p> \n<p>In fact, they're one of the most important elements of SEO, because they help Google and other search engines find the pages on your website.</p> \n<p>Not to mention they also help you rank better, because Google is able to locate new pages and identify updates to old pages much more quickly.</p> \n<p>In a nutshell: you can't live without 'em.</p> \n<p>I've often heard that they can feel overwhelming and quite technical to understand.</p> \n<p>But don't let the frustration of their technicality make you throw your computer out the window — I've got your back!</p> \n<p>I will show you what sitemaps are, how to create one, how to submit them to Google, and all the essential best practices.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=1d7211ac-7b1b-4405-b940-54b8acedb26e&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: SEO Starter Pack [Free Kit]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1d7211ac-7b1b-4405-b940-54b8acedb26e.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">What is a sitemap?</h2> \n<p>To start off with the basics, a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/build-sitemap-website\">sitemap</a> is a file that provides information about the pages, videos, images, and other files on your website. It's important for various reasons, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Acting as a roadmap for Google and other search engines to find and better understand your content.</li> \n <li>Leading search engines through your website to crawl and index the essential pages.</li> \n <li>Helping search identify when new pages and updates to old pages are available.</li> \n <li>Helping search engines find alternate language versions of your page.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>But before I go further, you must know that there are two types of sitemap formats: HTML and XML. Here's the basic difference:</p> \n<p><strong>HTML sitemaps:</strong>&nbsp;This is more like your content sitemap that users can see and use to navigate your site. They're also commonly referred to as your \"website archive.\" Some marketers view HTML sitemaps as outdated or even entirely unnecessary.</p> \n<p><strong>XML sitemaps:</strong>&nbsp;This is the sitemap that's purely used for indexing and crawling your website and is manually submitted. It's the more modern form of handling how all your content is stored across your website.</p> \n<p>While HTML sitemaps might help users find pages on your site, as <a href=\"https://www.reddit.com/r/bigseo/comments/dbqcmh/still_worth_making_html_sitemaps/\">John Mueller said</a>, your internal linking should take care of that anyways. So the focus from an SEO perspective should be on XML sitemaps.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Types of Sitemaps</h2> \n<p>From these two types of sitemaps described above, there are also subsections within them. I'll now go over these in more detail.</p> \n<h3>1. Page Sitemap</h3> \n<p>A page sitemap or <em>regular </em>sitemap improves the indexations of pages and posts. For sites that are not image-focused or video-focused, like photography and videography sites, a page sitemap can also include the images and videos on each page.</p> \n<p>A page sitemap without an image would look like this:</p> \n<p><em>&lt;?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"utf-8\"?&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&lt;urlset xmlns=\"http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9\" &gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &lt;url&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;loc&gt;https://example.com/&lt;/loc&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;lastmod&gt;2020-09-17&lt;/lastmod&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;changefreq&gt;daily&lt;/changefreq&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;priority&gt;0.9&lt;/priority&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;/url&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&lt;/urlset&gt;</em></p> \n<p>Include&nbsp;your URLs in &lt;loc&gt; tags. &lt;lastmod&gt; indicates when the page was last edited. &lt;changefreq&gt; indicates how often the page is edited and &lt;priority&gt; indicates how important the page is to other pages on the website as a whole. You can take a look at<a href=\"https://www.sitemaps.org/protocol.html\">&nbsp;</a><a href=\"https://www.sitemaps.org/protocol.html\">Sitemaps XML format</a>&nbsp;for more information on these parameters.</p> \n<h3>2. Video Sitemap</h3> \n<p>An XML video sitemap is similar to a page sitemap, but of course focuses largely on video content, which means they are only necessary if videos are critical to your business. If they aren't, save your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/technical-seo-guide/crawlability-checklist#:~:text=Your%20crawl%20budget%20refers%20to,most%20important%20pages%20for%20crawling.&amp;text=Watch%20out%20for%20dynamically%20generated,pages%20on%20your%20site%20skyrocket.\">crawl budget</a>&nbsp;(the finite amount of crawlable pages and resources across your site) and add the video link to your page sitemap.</p> \n<p>But if you do need a video sitemap, it would look like this:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/HubSpot%20Sitemaps%20What%20They%20Are,%20How%20to%20Create%20One%20%26%20Submit%20it%20to%20Google-4.png\" style=\"margin-left: 0.00px;\" title=\"\"></p> \n<p><em>Note: This is what a video sitemap looks like. Implement it only if videos are critical to your business.</em></p> \n<h3>3. News Sitemap</h3> \n<p>If you publish news and want to get those news articles featured&nbsp;on top stories and Google News, you need a news sitemap. There's a crucial rule here: do not include articles that were published longer than the last two days in the file.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/sitemaps/news-sitemap\">Google News sitemaps aren't favored in regular ranking results</a>, so make sure you only add news articles. Also, they do not support image links, so Google recommends you use structured data to specify your article thumbnail.</p> \n<h3>4. Image Sitemap</h3> \n<p>Like the video sitemaps, image sitemaps are only necessary if images are critical to your business, such as a photography or stock photo site. If they aren't, you can leave them in your page sitemap and mark them up with the image object schema, and they will be crawled along with the page content/URL.</p> \n<p>If you believe an image sitemap is needed, it will look like this:</p> \n<p><em>&lt;?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"utf-8\"?&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&lt;urlset xmlns=\"http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9\" xmlns:image=\"http://www.google.com/schemas/sitemap-image/1.1\" &gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &lt;url&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;loc&gt;https://example.com/&lt;/loc&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;image:image&gt;</em></p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>&lt;image:loc&gt;https://example.com/image-url.png&lt;/image:loc&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;/image:image&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;image:image&gt;</em></p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>&lt;image:loc&gt;https://example.com/second-image-url.png&lt;/image:loc&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;/image:image&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&nbsp; &lt;/url&gt;</em></p> \n<p><em>&lt;/urlset&gt;</em></p> \n<h3>5. Sitemap Index</h3> \n<p>There are a few limitations you'll want to keep in mind for sitemaps:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Having too many URLs will only lead to no indexation of some of your pages.</li> \n <li>All sitemaps, except the news sitemap, should have a maximum of 50,000 URLs.</li> \n <li>News sitemaps should have a maximum of 1000 URLs.</li> \n <li>A sitemap should be a maximum of 50MB in uncompressed file size.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>As a result of those limitations, you might need to have more than one sitemap. When you use more than one sitemap file, you need an index file that lists all of those sitemaps. It's the index file that you submit in Google Search Console and Bing Webmaster Tools. That file should look like this:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/HubSpot%20Sitemaps%20What%20They%20Are,%20How%20to%20Create%20One%20%26%20Submit%20it%20to%20Google.png?width=530&amp;height=168&amp;name=HubSpot%20Sitemaps%20What%20They%20Are,%20How%20to%20Create%20One%20%26%20Submit%20it%20to%20Google.png\" style=\"margin-left: 0.00px;\" title=\"\" width=\"530\" height=\"168\"></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">XML Sitemap Example</h2> \n<p>So far, you have seen each sitemap's structure. Most websites will only need the page sitemap that includes the images on each page. That looks like this:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/HubSpot%20Sitemaps%20What%20They%20Are,%20How%20to%20Create%20One%20%26%20Submit%20it%20to%20Google-2.png?height=248&amp;name=HubSpot%20Sitemaps%20What%20They%20Are,%20How%20to%20Create%20One%20%26%20Submit%20it%20to%20Google-2.png\" style=\"margin-left: 0.00px;\" title=\"\" height=\"248\"></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Sitemap Priorities</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.searchenginejournal.com/xml-sitemap-best-practices/237649/#close\">Adding priorities to your sitemap</a>&nbsp;is one of the things many people do to differentiate between how important different pages are, but Google's Gary Illyes mentioned that Google ignores these priorities. In his exact words:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/HubSpot%20Sitemaps%20What%20They%20Are,%20How%20to%20Create%20One%20%26%20Submit%20it%20to%20Google-1.png\" style=\"margin-left: 0.00px;\" title=\"\"></p> \n<p>Generally speaking, as long as you are honest about when your content was actually modified, include it in your sitemap so that Google and other search engines know to re-crawl the modified page and index the new content.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">How to Create a Sitemap</h2> \n<p>In this section, I will show you how to create a sitemap without using any generator or plugin. If your website is on WordPress or you'd rather use a generator (which makes this easy), skip to the next section.</p> \n<p>These are the exact steps to follow to create a sitemap manually:</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">1. Decide which pages on your site should be crawled by Google, and determine the <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/crawling/consolidate-duplicate-urls\">canonical version</a> of each page.</h3> \n<p>Canonical versions are necessary when you have duplicate pages. For example, suppose you serve an international community and have pages for each location with the same language and content, like <em>example.com/us/page</em>&nbsp;and <em>example.com/ca/page </em>for US and Canada visitors, respectively.</p> \n<p>In that case, it's important that you point to the original, which might be <em>example.com/page or </em>one of the two<em>&nbsp;</em>as the canonical. If you'd like to learn more about how this works, this <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/canonical-url\">post explains canonicalization</a>&nbsp;in depth.</p> \n<p>Furthermore, do not include URLs that are blocked by robots.txt files, require a login to access, or are password-protected, as search bots can't crawl them. You'll only get coverage errors in GSC if you add them.</p> \n<h3><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">2. Determine if you need more than one sitemap.</span></h3> \n<p>Several websites use separate files for pages, posts, and categories. Remember that if you have more than 50,000 URLs, you need multiple sitemaps.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">3. Code all your URLs in XML tags to look like the type of sitemap you want to create.</h3> \n<p>This <a href=\"https://www.sitemaps.org/protocol.html\">page explains how to use XML tags</a>&nbsp;in further detail.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">4. If you have multiple sitemap files, create a sitemap index file and include the links to the individual sitemaps you created.</h3> \n<p>This one is already described in the section titled \"Sitemap Index\".</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Sitemap Generators</h2> \n<p>Most of us marketers do not have a web development background, so we can't code to save our lives. If the thought of manually crafting a sitemap gives you a headache, use a sitemap generator and save yourself 12 days of looking through complex coding.</p> \n<p>There are several <a href=\"https://code.google.com/archive/p/sitemap-generators/wikis/SitemapGenerators.wiki\">sitemap generators</a>&nbsp;that you can use:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://technicalseo.com/tools/xml-sitemap/\">TechnicalSEO</a> by Merkle has one where you can upload a CSV file with your URLs. It's especially great if you have different language versions of your pages (hreflang tags).If your website is custom-coded and is not on any CMS or builder that generates a sitemap, you need to use a generator like TechnicalSEO.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.screamingfrog.co.uk/seo-spider/\">Screaming Frog SEO Spider</a>&nbsp;also has one that I like to use with simple custom-built sites. In Screaming Frog, ensure you are using the spider mode. You can do that by clicking on \"Mode\" and selecting \"spider\". Then type the URL of your home page and let it crawl. When it's done, click on \"Sitemaps.\"</li> \n</ul> \n<p>For clarification on how to use Screaming Frog, take a look at the image below:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/HubSpot%20Sitemaps%20What%20They%20Are,%20How%20to%20Create%20One%20%26%20Submit%20it%20to%20Google-Jun-30-2021-03-31-31-54-PM.png\" style=\"margin-left: 0.00px;\" title=\"\"></p> \n<p>In order to save the XML file to your computer, tick all the options that matter to your site and click on \"export\". Then, upload that file to your server in the root directory.</p> \n<p>Both tools do not automatically update the sitemap file. Some tools do but are premium, so you pay for the service.</p> \n<p>However, you won't need to deal with any of the above if your website is on WordPress or an ecommerce platform like Shopify.</p> \n<p>For WordPress sites, <a href=\"https://yoast.com/\">Yoast</a> and <a href=\"https://rankmath.com/\">Rank Math</a> are popular SEO plugins that generate sitemaps and update them when you edit your posts and pages and Shopify even generates sitemaps automatically.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">How to Submit Your Sitemap to Google</h2> \n<p>The best way to submit your sitemap to Google is through <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-search-console\">Google Search Console</a>&nbsp;(GSC). There are other ways and additional steps as well, but I will start with GSC, because it's the most common method.</p> \n<p>Follow these steps:</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">1. Go to Google Search Console and click on \"sitemap.\"</h3> \n<h3><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/HubSpot%20Sitemaps%20What%20They%20Are,%20How%20to%20Create%20One%20%26%20Submit%20it%20to%20Google-3.png\" style=\"margin-left: 0.00px;\" title=\"\"></h3> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">2. Type your sitemap URL and click Submit. If you have multiple sitemaps with a sitemap index file, you only need to type the URL for the index file.</h3> \n<p>As an alternative, if you haven't submitted it to GSC, there is another way to let Google know you have one by adding this line in your robots.txt:</p> \n<p><em>Sitemap: http://example.com/sitemap.xml</em></p> \n<p>But of course the URL here with the one you actually have. And if you have an index file, include only your index file here.</p> \n<p>If (for some weird reason) you aren't using GSC, use the ping service to let Google know it should crawl your file. To do that, type the URL below in your browser:</p> \n<p><em>http://www.google.com/ping?sitemap=https://example.com/sitemap.xml</em></p> \n<p>Replace <em>https://example.com/sitemap.xml </em>with your sitemap URL.</p> \n<p>And it's done!</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Sitemap Best Practices</h2> \n<p>Now that you understand the importance of sitemaps, how they work, and your options for submitting them, let's make sure the final one you create is in tip-top shape by following these best practices.</p> \n<h3>1. Use tools to generate automatic sitemaps.</h3> \n<p>Manually creating and updating an XML sitemap will cost you a lot of time (and is unnecessarily complex). To save time so you can focus on other things like your next Netflix binge, it's best to use an automatic sitemap generator.</p> \n<p>The ones mentioned for WordPress above come with that feature for free. For custom-built sites, you will have to pay, but in my opinion it's absolutely something worth paying for.</p> \n<h3>2. Do regular sitemap maintenance checks and updates.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-strategy\">All parts of SEO are an ongoing effort</a>, so check your sitemaps regularly. Search console does an excellent job of letting you know if your submitted URLs have issues with crawling or indexing.</p> \n<p>Check the 'Coverage' section in GSC regularly and update your site or sitemap when there are errors. The great thing about this is that it tells you what the exact error is with suggestions on how to fix it.</p> \n<p>You can also use Screaming Frog for sitemap maintenance. After crawling your website or sitemap URL, check the response code tab for 404 or 5xx errors.</p> \n<p>If you are using an automatic sitemap generator tool or plugin, update it when updates are available. Furthermore, periodically view the sitemap by going to your sitemap URL and checking if any page is missing or the last updated time is incorrect.</p> \n<h3>3. Prioritize high-quality pages in your sitemap.</h3> \n<p>Although Google no longer pays attention to the priority tag (or so they say), you can still add it because there's more than Google out there (yes, as an SEO I will admit it). Bing might pay attention to that tag, so it's still good practice to prioritize high-quality pages in your sitemap.</p> \n<p>Sitemap priority shows which pages to crawl and index faster, so you can set priorities using values ranging from 0.00 to 1.00. But make sure not to use the same value for all pages or else Google won't be able to tell which is most important.</p> \n<p>For values, you can go with something like this:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Homepage - 1.00</li> \n <li>Main landing pages - 0.90</li> \n <li>Other landing pages - 0.85</li> \n <li>Main links on navigation bar - 0.80</li> \n <li>Other pages on site - 0.75</li> \n <li>Top articles/blog posts like hub pages - 0.80</li> \n <li>Blog category pages - 0.75</li> \n <li>Other posts - 0.64</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Include only canonical versions of URLs in your sitemap.</h3> \n<p>Your sitemap should only contain URLs that you want search engines to index. That means if a URL points to another as its <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/seo/set-canonical-urls-for-duplicate-content\">canonical version</a>, you shouldn't include it, as it's a statement to Google and other search engines that you don't wish for that URL to be indexed.</p> \n<p>Ignoring that and including that URL in your sitemap provides conflicting information to Google. The unintended URL might get indexed, or you will get coverage errors in GSC. So, only include the canonical versions, so you can consolidate your position in search engine results.</p> \n<h3>5. Split up your large sitemaps.</h3> \n<p>I mentioned this above already that you need to split your sitemap into multiple files if it exceeds 50MB or has more than 50,000 URLs. Never submit large <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/what-is-xml-file\">XML files</a>&nbsp;to Google, otherwise some of your URLs will not be indexed - and you know well that every URL matters!</p> \n<p>One quick tip here is to save each file with easy to understand names (for you) like page_sitemap1.xml and page_sitemap2.xml.</p> \n<p>And with that, I wish you happy sitemapping!</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=05aa9467-4eda-4dd6-8b7f-ad9855abfe33&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img gle-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn68@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-50-520_8fd38dfc7f7f626f.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/05aa9467-4eda-4dd6-8b7f-ad9855abfe33.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-53-180_339ca67d143927cd.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbuild-sitemap-website&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn54@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-48-856_d4c0d512fef8aaa5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938162},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"80 Things to Check Before, During, and After Launching a Website","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/website-launch-checklist","description":"<p>Admit it: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-make-a-website\">Launching a new website</a> is stressful — even for the most seasoned digital marketers.</p>  \n<p>Websites are complex. There are so many things that are easily overlooked, like a broken link or a misspelled word.</p> \n<p>And of course, a handful of things could go very, very wrong.&nbsp;Like what if you forget to test an important data capture form and then lose out on generating a bunch of new leads?&nbsp;Or worse, what if you forget to properly set up site redirects, and those valuable search engine visitors get a <em>page not found</em> message?</p> \n<p>Instead of worrying about the what ifs, wouldn't it be much easier to have a comprehensive website checklist to run down before every site launch? One that you could use for enterprise websites, microsites, landing pages, and everything in between?</p> \n<p>Fortunately, we've created just that. Keep reading to learn everything you need to do before, during, and after launching a website.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=00d9cc96-eff7-4cea-8ff3-583374c3dcd5&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Free Resource: Website Optimization Checklist [Download Now]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/00d9cc96-eff7-4cea-8ff3-583374c3dcd5.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2>What You Should Do Before Beginning Your Site Design</h2> \n<p>Whether this is your first website that is being built from scratch or you are doing a <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/resources/website-design\">website redesign</a>, there are a few steps that you should take before hiring a web designer or diving in yourself.</p> \n<h3>1. Analyze your previous website (if applicable).</h3> \n<p>In order to make good decisions, you must first understand where you've been. That starts with your existing website if you have one. Ask yourself:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>What is the purpose of a new design or overhaul?</li> \n <li>What haven't hasn't been accomplished with this existing site?</li> \n <li>How will a new design serve the new organization?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The answers to these questions can help you identify your gaps, which can then inform goal setting for the new site.</p> \n<h3>2. Crawl your old site (if applicable) and document its structure.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>You can get an idea of your site's existing structure, pages, and assets by using a crawling tool such as Screaming Frog. This is a necessary step in creating your <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/developing-a-website-strategy\">website development plan</a> because you'll have a more concrete view of what pages existed before, what redirects are in place, and what the meta data currently looks like.</p> \n<h3>3. Obtain benchmark data from your previous website (if applicable), and confirm testing procedures.</h3> \n<p>Not only will you want to compare how your new site performs compared to the old, but you'll also want to continue identifying gaps that will provide data-driven insights to aid your new strategy.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you'll want to confirm testing procedures. Soon, you'll begin testing your website to make sure all the different components are working, everything flows, and there's a system for tracking bugs and enhancements.</p> \n<p>Use a form (like Google Forms) instead of asking people to email their thoughts so the feedback-gathering process is more streamlined. Then, put one person in charge of choosing which bugs to prioritize, and filtering all the creative feedback you receive through the form.</p> \n<h3>4. Identify your goals for the new design, how you'll achieve them, and how you'll measure success.</h3> \n<p>Once the gaps are fully fleshed out, you can begin crafting your goals for the design. You may come to conclusions such as:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>The current site is unwieldy, and we need ease of use.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>The current site no longer looks trendy, so we need a visual refresh.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>The current site doesn't perform, so we need a more SEO-friendly structure with a better UX.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Whatever your goals, you'll want to understand exactly how a new site will help you achieve them so that you can craft its implementation accordingly.</p> \n<h3>5. List out action items, roles, and responsibilities.</h3> \n<p>Make a project management checklist for the website. What content needs to be written? What calls-to-action need to be created?&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Make a master list of the things you need for your website and deadlines for when they should be completed.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Then, assign each action item to an individual or team.&nbsp;It usually takes a lot of people to launch a website: You have marketers writing the content;&nbsp;designers choosing images and laying out the overall look and feel; a technical team doing all the back-end development.&nbsp;To ensure everyone's on the same page and there's no role confusion, you'll want to lay out a comprehensive plan for what each team or person is responsible for.</p> \n<p>One great way to do this is by using the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/migration-project-management-model\">DARCI model</a>, which stands for Decision Maker(s), Accountable, Responsible, Consulted, Informed. It's a powerful tool that'll help everyone understand which individual is responsible for completing which action items, which individual(s) or group(s) need to be consulted before any final decisions are made, and who needs to be consulted once a final decision has been made or an action has been taken.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>6. Prepare for worst-case scenarios.</h3> \n<p>Poll everyone involved in your website launch on their concerns about what could go wrong, and then devise a few backup plans for what to do when — not if — some of these things go wrong.</p> \n<h3>7. Choose a Solid CMS.</h3> \n<p>If you've never launched a site before, the long list below might intimidate you. However, it actually shouldn't take too long to run through most of the aspects on this list — especially if you built your website with a solid CMS.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>A CMS, or content management system, often allows you to design a website from a pre-created template, optimize your content for SEO, and edit content after it's published. If you've already built your website, you might have already gained experience with using a CMS.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>But, if you're still building a website, one way to make going through this checklist less time consuming is by building your pages on a CMS that already does a lot of the work for you.</p> \n<p>For example, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/cms\">HubSpot's CMS </a>that allows you to create and edit content including landing pages and blog posts. It's features also allow you to organize your content, schedule it, track analytics, and optimize it for SEO.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Alternatively, you can also test out CMS platforms like WordPress, Wix, or even Drupal.</p> \n<h3>8. Develop a consistent brand.</h3> \n<p>Decide on a consistent brand message and tone, one that you're committed to presenting consistently across. This will make you look more legitimate, credible, and memorable.</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Understand your value proposition.</li> \n <li>Choose a mission statement, vision statement, and tagline that represents that value as well as your brand identity.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Choose colors and fonts that convey that identity well.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Decide on the type of imagery that you'll use to further convey your messaging.</li> \n</ol> \n<h3>9. Create your technical SEO strategy.</h3> \n<p>Take some time to ensure that your website has been given a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-strategy\">solid foundation for SEO success</a>. From site architecture and content hierarchy to metadata and XML sitemaps, do not leave any stone unturned.</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Perform keyword research and decide what you want to rank for.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Create a content strategy that satisfies those keywords.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Understand how your existing pages (if applicable) can be adjusted and which pages will need to be created new.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Figure out which pages are no longer necessary.</li> \n <li>Map out where unnecessary pages can be redirected to (using a 301 redirect).</li> \n</ol> \n<h3>10. Strategize your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/conversion-rate-optimization-guide\">conversion paths</a>.</h3> \n<p>Once you have an understanding of the primary pages that will exist on your site, you'll need to figure out exactly what actions you want users to take and how you'll capture their information. This includes thinking through:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>What premium top-of-the-funnel offers are needed</li> \n <li>What bottom-of-the-funnel action will be presented on main pages</li> \n <li>What forms need to be created</li> \n <li>What landing pages and thank you pages need to be created</li> \n <li>How conversions will be tracked</li> \n <li>What actions will happen after a website visitor converts (email responder, etc.)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>11. Set up analytics software.</h3> \n<ol> \n <li>Choose which analytics platforms you will be using on the new site.</li> \n <li>Decide if any previous Analytics tracking scripts will be used or if new accounts/scripts are needed.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Set up new accounts (if applicable).</li> \n</ol> \n<h3>12. Set a launch date.</h3> \n<p>Once you have an idea of what needs to get done before the launch, pick a launch date. Give yourself at least a month. Most agencies plan for two-to-three months of research, design, and development.</p> \n<h2>What to Check Once You've Built Your Site</h2> \n<p>Once you've chosen a CMS and built a site that you're ready to launch, here's a list of 80 things to check before, during, and after going live. Feel free to copy, edit, and make your own based on the software you're using to launch and host your website.</p> \n<p>Don't have time to check all 80? Here's a list of the most important highlights from each section:</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>Website Launch Checklist</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Make sure text is accurate and error free.</li> \n  <li>Replace all placeholder images with final images and designs.&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Ensure copy aligns with the new brand.</li> \n  <li>Check that all styling preferences have been implemented.</li> \n  <li>Ensure your design is aesthetically pleasing.</li> \n  <li>Ensure that rights to images, fonts, and other content have been properly licensed or cited.</li> \n  <li>Test the site for User Experience (UX).</li> \n  <li>Check that the conversion paths have been implemented properly.</li> \n  <li>Create your site backup strategy.&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Store passwords and credentials in a secure place.&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Audit the technical SEO implementation for errors.</li> \n  <li>Test the site for user experience again.&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Test your conversion path's functionality.</li> \n  <li>Check that integrations with third-party tools are running smoothly.</li> \n  <li>Make a copy of the final website for backup purposes.&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Ensure that backups are running properly.&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Make sure your site is secure.</li> \n  <li>Comply with all applicable laws.</li> \n  <li>Crawl the site to ensure no errors happened on launch.</li> \n  <li>Check the technical SEO components for errors.&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Optimize your metadata.</li> \n  <li>Set up analytics.</li> \n  <li>Build anticipation with teasers before the site is live.&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Create a social media strategy for the announcement.&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Identify exciting ways to promote engagement for the new site.&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Send an email to your existing database.&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Continue to promote the launch for a month.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<p>We've grouped items based on pre-launch and post-launch, making sure to touch on page content, design, functionality, SEO, branding, analytics, security, and compliance. Keep on reading to make sure you don't forget a thing before your next launch.</p> \n<h2>Website Pre-Launch Checklist</h2> \n<p>Before you launch, it's important to review all of the content on your website with a fine-tooth comb. Of course, that means page content, but don't forget about your premium content, too. From data-driven content and downloadable documents to rich media such as videos and images, you want to make sure everything is in place, working properly, and looking beautiful.</p> \n<p>It's important to note — you'll want to set up a staging site to prepare your new website before going live. Staging sites are exact copies of your website on a private server that are used to prepare and proof content and code changes before they go live. The staging site is a place to edit and play around with updates in an environment that's almost identical to the one that will be live. This is so you don't have to worry about crashing your site or screwing something up when you make a change.<br><br>Later, you'll sync content and templates between the staging environment and your live website via your content management system (CMS).&nbsp;If you're a HubSpot customer with the website platform, you'll find there's&nbsp;a <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/website-pages/redesign-and-relaunch-your-site-with-content-staging\">staging environment</a> built right into the software. It allows you to generate a preview URL of the entire site, so you can click around and test things in context.</p> \n<h3>1. Make sure text is accurate and error-free.</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Site content has been proofread for spelling and grammar.</li> \n <li>Company contact details are accurate throughout the website.</li> \n <li>Generic content, such as <em>lorem ipsum</em>, has been properly removed and replaced.</li> \n <li>All premium content, such as case studies, ebooks, and whitepapers, have been proofread. Spelling and grammar are correct.</li> \n <li>Copyright date (perhaps in the footer) includes the current year.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Replace all placeholder images with final images and designs.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>On occasion, a website designer may use a placeholder image if they didn't have the correct asset at the time of the page's creation. It's up to you to make sure each page is picture-perfect.</p> \n<h3>3. Ensure copy aligns with the new brand.</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>The text has been copy-edited to ensure consistent brand voice and style.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>All company tag lines and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/inspiring-company-mission-statements\">mission statements</a> are up-to-date.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Check that all styling preferences have been implemented.</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Paragraphs, headers, lists, and other formatting are correct.</li> \n <li>Brand colors have been implemented correctly, including link and button colors.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>5. Ensure your design is aesthetically pleasing.</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Scripts are optimized across web pages.</li> \n <li>Images are optimized across web pages.</li> \n <li>CSS is optimized across web pages.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>6. Ensure that rights to images, fonts, and other content have been properly licensed or cited.</h3> \n<p>Even if you outsourced the design to a web designer/developer, the responsibility falls on you to ensure there are no copyright licensing issues. Otherwise, you could end up with a hefty infringement settlement on your hands.</p> \n<h3>7. Test the site for User Experience (UX).</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Website pages are compatible across browsers.</li> \n <li>Website pages are compatible across devices.</li> \n <li>Images, videos, and audio files are in the correct places, formatted and working on all devices.</li> \n <li>All premium content, such as case studies, ebooks, and whitepapers, are stored in their proper libraries/databases and work properly.</li> \n <li>Internal links across web pages are working properly.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Social media share icons are associated with the correct accounts.</li> \n <li>Company logo is linked to the homepage.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>8. Check that the conversion paths have been implemented properly.</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>All necessary forms are present.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Landing pages and thank you pages have been implemented.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>The correct buttons and calls-to-action (CTAs) are present in the proper locations.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Everything is linked together appropriately.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>9. Create your site backup strategy.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>You can prevent loss of data and protect against malware and other damages by properly setting up site security and regular backups. Check that:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Backup schedule has been created.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Backup location has been identified.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>A plan for implementation is set to be put in motion after launch.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>10. Store passwords and credentials in a secure place.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Many individuals have likely been involved in the website launch up until this point, so ensure that passwords are reset when the time comes and proper password etiquette is followed.</p> \n<h3>11. Audit the technical SEO implementation for errors.&nbsp;</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Pages have unique page titles.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Pages have unique meta descriptions.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Each page has a specific purpose, and pages meant to rank organically are optimized around a single keyword or set of keywords.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>12. Conduct a stress test.</h3> \n<p>In a <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/website-optimization?utm_source=marketing_blog&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=website_optimization\">typical website redesign</a>, it may not be 100% necessary to do a stress test because the traffic spike may not overrun your server's capacity. But a stress test (also called a load test) is a must for any company that plans for a large influx of visitors during specific times — such as the holidays or after a major press event. It'll help you figure out how much simultaneous traffic your website can handle by simulating up to tens of thousands of simultaneous virtual users from different locations around the world.</p> \n<p>While stress tests simulate virtual users, the test won't be totally replicating a real-life scenario — so you'll want to find a test that brings you as close to reality as possible. Ask a developer which load tests they recommend. Here at HubSpot, many of our developers use <a href=\"http://jmeter.apache.org/\">JMeter by Apache</a>, but this is a pretty technical tool that's not ideal for&nbsp;someone who's new to the concept.</p> \n<p>Be sure to notify your host or provider that you want to perform a stress test before you actually do one.&nbsp;Otherwise, your test might look like a DDoS&nbsp;(Distributed Denial of Service)<em>&nbsp;</em>attack on your provider.&nbsp;Many providers (including HubSpot) consider an unauthorized load test a violation of terms of service.</p> \n<p>User experience is a key aspect of how they view your company, so testing your website before it goes live will bring more confidence that visitors will not be immediately displeased with your offerings.</p> \n<h2>Website Post-Launch Checklist</h2> \n<p>Let's say you've done it. The button has been pushed, the domain is pointing to the new site, and you're about ready to tell the world...</p> \n<p>But wait just one second because you still have things to check for now that your site is officially live.</p> \n<h3>13. Test the site for user experience again.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Just in case there was an issue with the implementation, you'll want to ensure the experience is consistent with what you reviewed before it went live.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Ensure your design is rendering as you expected it to across browsers.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Ensure your design is rendering as you expected it to across devices.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Ensure CSS/HTML is properly validated.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>CSS styling is rendering properly.</li> \n <li>Favicon is in place and rendering properly.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Internal links across web pages are working properly.</li> \n <li>External links across web pages are working properly, and open in a new tab.</li> \n <li>Social media share icons are working properly.</li> \n <li>Feeds are working properly (RSS, news, social media).</li> \n <li>Company logo is linked to the homepage.</li> \n <li>404 Redirect pages are in place (page-not-found.aspx).</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>14. Test your conversion path's functionality.</h3> \n<p>Take some time to test and validate all of the different features on your website. Lead generation forms, CRM integration, and any other technology should work flawlessly across your website.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Forms are submitting data properly.</li> \n <li>Thank you message or page displays after form is submitted.</li> \n <li>Form data is being emailed to a recipient and/or stored in a company database.</li> \n <li>Auto-responders are working properly (if applicable).</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>15. Check that integrations with third-party tools are running smoothly.</h3> \n<p>Integrations such as your CRM, e-commerce software, and/or marketing platform link to your site and help you run your business. If there is a potential issue that can cause data loss, you don't want to find out way after the fact.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>16. Make a copy of the final website for backup purposes.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Now that everything is in place and finalized, you want to have a pristine copy of it should you experience data corruption or loss.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>17. Ensure that backups are running properly.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Now is the time to check the implementation of your backup strategy. Check that ongoing copies of the website are being created and stored on a regular basis.</p> \n<h3>18. Make sure your site is secure.</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>24/7 monitoring scripts are installed.</li> \n <li>There's a plan in place for updating plugins (if applicable).&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Ensure that all applicable parties are aware of your organization's password etiquette policies.</li> \n <li>Purchase an SSL certificate if need-be. An SSL certificate takes up to two weeks to purchase and set up, so ensure you have it prior to launch. (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-ssl\">An SSL certificate</a> will ensure&nbsp;your website is encrypted so hackers can't intercept any of your data. Not only will this put your website visitors at ease, but it'll also boost your website's SEO since&nbsp;<a href=\"http://googlewebmastercentral.blogspot.com/2014/08/https-as-ranking-signal.html\">SSL is now part of Google's search ranking algorithm</a>.)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>19. Comply with all applicable laws.</h3> \n<p>Make sure your website complies with any applicable laws and regulations. Internet law can be sticky, and each industry has its own set of rules to follow. <strong>So it's best to consult with your legal counsel to make sure you aren't missing anything — this post is not legal guidance. </strong>Here are a few you might need to know about:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Web pages offer accessibility for users with disabilities (WAI-ARIA).</li> \n <li>Web pages announce if the website uses cookies (required in some countries).</li> \n <li>Website is compliant with usage rights for purchased or borrowed code, images, and fonts.</li> \n <li>Terms and privacy policies are visible to website visitors.</li> \n <li>Website is <a href=\"https://www.pcisecuritystandards.org/\">PCI compliant</a> (if you're storing and processing credit cards).</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>20. Crawl the site to ensure no errors happened on launch.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Compare the crawl to the previous crawl and see if you find any inconsistencies that were not intentional. You'll also want to ensure that all pages have the proper search engine indexing settings.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you'll want to check for formatting consistency. Sometimes, font codes get dropped into a page accidentally, so you'll want to scour your site for any of these weird formatting errors. Make sure all your formatting is consistent and there are no weird blips in your copy.</p> \n<h3>21. Check the technical SEO components for errors.</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Page titles, meta descriptions, and URLs are all present and match the original technical SEO strategy.</li> \n <li>Load time for site pages is optimized.</li> \n <li>A <a href=\"https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/156184?hl=en\">dynamic XML sitemap</a> has been created.</li> \n <li>The XML sitemap has been submitted to search engines.</li> \n <li>Page URLs consistently reflect site information architecture.</li> \n <li>301 redirects are in place for all old URLs (redirecting old to new pages).</li> \n <li>rel=\"nofollow\" tags are in place on applicable links and pages.</li> \n <li>Images on the website are properly compressed (which helps with load time).&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>22. Optimize your metadata.</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Metadata is properly in place for any content in an RSS feed.</li> \n <li>Metadata is properly in place for any social media sharing content.</li> \n <li>Spelling and grammar are correct in all metadata.</li> \n <li>Alt tags have been added to every image.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>23. Set up analytics.</h3> \n<p>Make sure your website is set up to capture web data and analytics. This valuable information will allow you to continually improve your website going forward, so you don't want to forget this stuff.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Your website analytics codes and tracking scripts have been inserted on website.</li> \n <li>Relevant IP addresses have been excluded from analytics tracking.</li> \n <li>Funnels and goals have been properly created in your analytics software (if applicable).</li> \n <li>Google Webmaster and Google Analytics accounts have been properly synced.</li> \n <li>Google Ads accounts have been properly synced (if applicable).</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>24.
