Start a post-launch enhancement list.</h3> \n<p>The website you launch should be functional, well-designed, and well-positioned. But it probably won't be everything you hoped and dreamed on the first go — and you certainly don't want to spend months of effort designing a site that people may not react well to. What if your client doesn't like it? What if conversion rates plummet? That could add up to lost money and effort.</p> \n<p>Instead, it's best to publish a solid website, and then test and build on top of it <span>—</span> a website creation approach known as <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/growth-driven-design\">growth-driven design</a>. Create a document that lists out all&nbsp;the things you can't get done for the launch itself but want to add in the future, and add features and elements to it as you discover more about how users interact with the site. This you can do by using one of these <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/website-user-testing-tools\">user testing tools</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<h2>How Do You Announce a New Website Launch?</h2> \n<p>This (hopefully) wasn't a vanity project; you did all of this work so far for the benefit of your website visitors, prospects, and existing customers. Your next step is to tell the world about your new site design. Here's how:</p> \n<h3>25. Build anticipation with teasers before the site is live.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>A launch of a new product, a launch of a new movie, and — yes — a new site launch all require marketing before the actual release. Think of the last movie you watched in the theater. Did you see the trailer before you decided to buy those movie tickets and popcorn?</p> \n<p>Teasers for your website launch can only help to build anticipation and get users wondering what the new experience will be like. This can build buzz and interest once you finally break the news.</p> \n<h3>26. Create a social media strategy for the announcement.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Decide what channels you want to promote the news on, how you will make the announcement, and how long the promotion will last.</p> \n<p>As you craft your messaging, remember to focus on new features and how they benefit your audience.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>27. Identify exciting ways to promote engagement for the new site.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>For users who aren't as involved in your brand, a new site launch might not seem like a big deal. Your goal, then, is to make it one. Provide an exclusive offer for the first users who visit the site. Or, create a contest that promotes engaging with the site's new features. Whatever you choose, make sure you make it fun and interesting.</p> \n<h3>28. Send an email to your existing database.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>You may want to give existing leads and customers a head's up about the new design, especially if it will cause any confusion when they next visit. You can break the news as a matter of courtesy but also sneak in ways to underscore the value you're providing.</p> \n<p>You can also alert all stakeholders of the redesign and ask them to spread the word of the new website.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>29. Continue to promote the launch for a month.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Just because you post about your new website once on social media does not mean that your audience will drop everything to visit the site in droves. Make your launch a big deal, and keep the new functionality top of mind so that your audience is prompted multiple times to check it out.</p> \n<p>(Once your website is launched, remember&nbsp;to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/build-sitemap-website\">resubmit your XML sitemap</a> to all major search engines once you're done, too.)</p> \n<h2>Resources for Launching Your First Website</h2> \n<p>Launching a new website can be a tedious task, but you can alleviate some of the stress by using this comprehensive website launch checklist.</p> \n<p>If you're just getting started on your first website, here are a few tools that can help you streamline your process</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>CMS:</strong> As mentioned above, a CMS can help you design your website, optimize and publish content, and track your analytics once it's launched. If you're looking to test out a few CMS options, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-trial\">start by checking out our 14-day free CMS trial</a>.</li> \n <li><strong>Blogging Guides:</strong> If you're interested in using your website to publish a blog that could help you boost brand awareness, it can be helpful to start brainstorming topics. Here's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blogging-team-tips\">a great guide</a> to how to be a better blogger with tips from our team.</li> \n <li><strong>Landing Page Templates:</strong> A landing page is a great way to highlight a product or resource that your brand is offering. It's important to know what elements lead to a landing page that will convert. Here's a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/landing-page-best-practices\">guide with examples</a>. Additionally, when using a <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/cms\">CMS like HubSpot's,</a> you can create landing pages from pre-designed templates.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This blog post was originally published in August 2014, but was updated for comprehensiveness and freshness in June 2021.</em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=01322824-7427-4d28-bf11-5092707c1bbf&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/01322824-7427-4d28-bf11-5092707c1bbf.png\"></a></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwebsite-launch-checklist&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 23 Jun 2021 11:04:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/00d9cc96-eff7-4cea-8ff3-583374c3dcd5.png","linkMd5":"72d19d0dc970a848bc81f695f916d9f4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn89@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-38-539_49e1244c57fbadc9.webp","destWidth":571,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":6565,"destBytes":9078,"author":"shannakurpe@gmail.com (Shanna Kurpe)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/00d9cc96-eff7-4cea-8ff3-583374c3dcd5.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn89@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-38-539_49e1244c57fbadc9.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/01322824-7427-4d28-bf11-5092707c1bbf.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn51@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-51-527_83b8efb660d58f95.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwebsite-launch-checklist&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn3@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-51-647_e2a5674cb66b2681.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938168},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"The Scarcity Principle: How 7 Brands Created High Demand [Research]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/the-scarcity-principle","description":"<p>If you took the same <em>Introduction to Economics</em> class that I struggled through in college, you might remember this key lesson:</p> \n<p>The <a href=\"http://www.investopedia.com/terms/l/law-of-supply-demand.asp\">law of supply and demand</a> states that a low supply and high demand for a product will typically increase its price.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Why am I telling you about basic economic rules? Because changes in the supply and demand of products can result in the scarcity principle coming into play.</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll learn what the scarcity principle is and how you can use it to create high demand.</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: State of Marketing in 2021 Report\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7.png\" align=\"middle\"></a> \n<h2>What is the scarcity principle?</h2> \n<p>The scarcity principle of persuasion coined by <a href=\"https://www.influenceatwork.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/E_Brand_principles.pdf\">Dr. Robert Cialdini</a> means the rarer or more difficult it is to obtain a product, offer, or piece of content is, the more valuable it becomes. Because we think the product will soon be unavailable to us, we're more likely to buy it than if there were no impression of scarcity.</p> \n<p>Brands can use the scarcity principle to persuade people to fill out a lead form, purchase a product, or take another desired action. Here's an example: On many air travel booking sites, such as <a href=\"https://www.kayak.com/\">KAYAK</a>, flight listings are displayed with a note that only a few seats are left at a certain price. Check it out below:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/kayak-scarcity-principle.png?width=548&amp;name=kayak-scarcity-principle.png\" alt=\"Kayak scarcity principle\" width=\"548\" style=\"width: 548px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>We know that airfare pricing is incredibly volatile -- that's why some of us wait until <a href=\"http://clark.com/travel/best-day-book-cheap-flight/\">certain times or days of the week</a> to make purchases -- so the knowledge that only one seat is available at that price makes me think I should buy it now, instead of waiting and running the risk of paying more later.</p> \n<p>To learn about general consumers, we decided to survey 300 people to see if they were more interested in products that had a limited supply.</p> \n<p>45% of respondents said that scarcity makes them want to learn more about a product, while only 17% said that if it was too hard to purchase a product, they'd find it at another company.</p> \n<p>See results below:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scarcity-principle-research.png?width=1206&amp;name=scarcity-principle-research.png\" alt=\"Scarcity principle survey results\" width=\"1206\" style=\"width: 1206px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://luc.id/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Data Source</a></p> \n<p>Now that we're all up to speed on scarcity, we wanted to highlight brands that have successfully used the scarcity principle to market and sell different products.</p> \n<h2>7 Brands That Used the Scarcity Principle to Promote and Sell Products</h2> \n<h3>1. Snap Inc.</h3> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/og-map.png?width=730&amp;height=383&amp;name=og-map.png\" alt=\"Snapchat high demand\" width=\"730\" height=\"383\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.spectacles.com/\">Image Source</a></em></span></p> \n<p>Ephemeral social media app Snapchat's parent company, Snap Inc., unveiled Snapchat Spectacles in <a href=\"https://www.snap.com/en-US/news/post/introducing-spectacles/\">September 2016</a>: sunglasses that could record 10-second videos from the perspective of the wearer. But instead of selling the new gadget online or at a storefront, Spectacles were initially only sold via Snapbots -- smiling, Snapchat-themed vending machines that were randomly dropped in cities around the United States.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Snapchat-Spectacles-Snapbot-640x447.jpg?width=640&amp;height=447&amp;name=Snapchat-Spectacles-Snapbot-640x447.jpg\" alt=\"Snapbot spectacle\" width=\"640\" height=\"447\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"http://phandroid.com/2016/11/21/snapchat-spectacles-new-york-city/\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<p>There were never announcements in advance of the arrival of Snapbots -- most awareness was generated on <a href=\"https://twitter.com/snapbotsighting\">social media</a> <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/snapbotlocations/\">channels</a>, and huge lines of people would queue hoping to purchase Spectacles before the Snapbot ran out of stock for the day.</p> \n<p>Now, Spectacles are <a href=\"https://www.spectacles.com/\">sold online</a> or at a few more permanent pop-up locations, so there's no need to line up outside a vending machine if you don't want to. But for the initial launch, the Snapbots was a unique approach to the scarcity complex. Spectacles were available for a limited time only -- just the day the Snapbot was in your city, and you had to beat everyone else trying to buy Spectacles before the machine sold out.</p> \n<p>Plus, the product's scarcity meant nobody -- ourselves included here at HubSpot -- could stop talking about the Spectacles. Blog posts and social media comments about the unique selling approach helped fuel even more interest in the products.</p> \n<p>MediaKix predicted Snap would achieve <a href=\"http://mediakix.com/2017/01/snapchat-spectacles-sales-projections-forecast-infographic/#gs.wxacByc\">$5 billion in Spectacles sales by 2020</a>, however, <a href=\"https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2019/08/evan-spiegel-triples-down-on-snapchat-spectacles-3-at-twice-the-price\">Spectacles failed to make an impression</a> in the market and the company had to swallow about<a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/talkingtech/2017/11/20/tech-turkeys-2017-spectacles-beats-bixby-and-juicero-list-biggest-misses/872697001/\">$40 million</a><span> in unsold inventory after it released the first version</span>. Despite that failure, the company is still developing several iterations of the product.</p> \n<p>Regardless of how well the products sold, the marketing strategy to use scarcity helped pull people into a product that they might not have been interested in otherwise.</p> \n<h3>2. Nintendo</h3> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/wii-production-line.jpg?width=480&amp;height=223&amp;name=wii-production-line.jpg\" alt=\"Wii production line\" width=\"480\" height=\"223\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-style: italic;\"><a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2009/12/02/nintendo-slowing-wii-production-lines/\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">If you weren't a big gamer back when Nintendo released the Wii gaming console in 2006, you might not remember that the Wii was one of the hottest commodities on the market. When it was officially released in <a href=\"https://www.cnet.com/news/its-all-fun-and-games-at-nycs-wii-launch/\">November 2006</a>, people lined up to get their hands on the Wii as soon as possible, but the mania didn't end there. For nearly three years, the Wii was flying off the shelves, and <a href=\"http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=22805\">gaming stores couldn't keep shelves stocked</a> -- despite Nintendo <a href=\"http://www.abcnews.go.com/Technology/GadgetGuide/story?id=4001054&amp;page=1\">increasing its supply</a> to 1.8 million and then 2.4 million units of production per month.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Supply eventually caught up with demand -- <a href=\"https://www.cnet.com/news/nintendo-wii-supply-finally-catches-up-to-demand/\">48 million Wiis</a> sold later. By starting out with a low monthly production number, Nintendo ensured that customers would be clamoring to buy more right off the bat. The scarcity complex here made people desperate to buy a Wii whenever they could -- especially after a Nintendo executive <a href=\"https://www.wired.com/2007/11/wii-shortage/\">advised shoppers</a> to \"stalk the UPS driver\" and to figure out when Wiis were being delivered to stores to get their hands on one.</p> \n<h3>3. Starbucks</h3>  \n<blockquote class=\"instagram-media\" style=\"background: #FFF; border: 0; border-radius: 3px; box-shadow: 0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width: 658px; padding: 0; width: calc(100% - 2px);\"> \n <div style=\"padding: 8px;\"> \n  <div style=\"background: #F8F8F8; line-height: 0; margin-top: 40px; padding: 50.0% 0; text-align: center; width: 100%;\">\n   &nbsp;\n  </div> \n  <p style=\"margin: 8px 0 0 0; padding: 0 4px;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/BTEWcNHjACU/\" style=\"color: #000; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: 17px; text-decoration: none; word-wrap: break-word;\">As majestic as it is magenta... #UnicornFrappuccino. Color-changing, flavor-changing, potentially life-changing. #🦄 Available for a limited time at participating stores in the US, Canada &amp; Mexico.</a></p> \n  <p style=\"color: #c9c8cd; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: 17px; margin-bottom: 0; margin-top: 8px; overflow: hidden; padding: 8px 0 7px; text-align: center; text-overflow: ellipsis; white-space: nowrap;\">A post shared by Starbucks Coffee ☕ (@starbucks) on Apr 19, 2017 at 6:05am PDT</p> \n </div> \n</blockquote>  \n<p>Coffee lovers have decried Starbucks for adding the \"unicorn frappuccino\" to its menu -- made of ice cream, fruit flavors, and sour candy -- but people couldn't get enough of the brightly colored, highly Instagrammable drink. After stating on its website that the specialty drink would only be available for a few days, Starbucks was flooded with unicorn frappuccino orders -- which <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/starbucks-runs-out-of-unicorn-frappuccino-2017-4\">quickly sold out</a> within the first day. There are no sales numbers available for the specialty drink, but there are nearly 160,000 <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/explore/tags/unicornfrappuccino/\">#unicornfrappuccino</a> posts on Instagram.</p> \n<p>Starbucks gets a lot of orders -- and social media engagement -- during another of its notorious limited-time offers -- the <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/BMoWwfNBOpP/?taken-by=starbucks\">Starbucks Red Cups</a>. During the holiday season in December, Starbucks starts serving coffee in red cups for a limited time only to drive people into cafes and to get them to share #RedCups photos on social media. In this case, scarcity + food and drink is the magic equation.</p> \n<h3>4. Girlfriend Collective</h3>  \n<blockquote class=\"instagram-media\" style=\"background: #FFF; border: 0; border-radius: 3px; box-shadow: 0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width: 658px; padding: 0; width: calc(100% - 2px);\"> \n <div style=\"padding: 8px;\"> \n  <div style=\"background: #F8F8F8; line-height: 0; margin-top: 40px; padding: 62.4537037037037% 0; text-align: center; width: 100%;\">\n   &nbsp;\n  </div> \n  <p style=\"margin: 8px 0 0 0; padding: 0 4px;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/BDzbOu4s4pN/\" style=\"color: #000; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: 17px; text-decoration: none; word-wrap: break-word;\">The Girlfriend legging is here. 🍾✨ The new generation of activewear is yours for just the cost of shipping. You read that right. Our super soft, sheer-proof leggings are designed by veterans of Acne Studios and lululemon, which means you're not only getting a deal, you're getting your new best friend. Get yours at girlfriend.com</a></p> \n  <p style=\"color: #c9c8cd; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: 17px; margin-bottom: 0; margin-top: 8px; overflow: hidden; padding: 8px 0 7px; text-align: center; text-overflow: ellipsis; white-space: nowrap;\">A post shared by Girlfriend Collective (@girlfriendcollective) on Apr 4, 2016 at 8:29pm PDT</p> \n </div> \n</blockquote>   \n<p>Girlfriend Collective's offer was simple: For a limited time, if you paid for the cost of shipping, the brand would send you a pair of $100 leggings for free. All you had to do was share a link to its website on Facebook.</p> \n<p>Girlfriend Collective had just launched its website, and it was asking its female consumers to spread the word about the leggings so it could dedicate 100% of its advertising budget to leggings production. And if you think about it, that was a smart approach. After all, which are you more willing to trust: a Facebook ad offering free leggings or half of your friends in your News Feed advocating for the offer?</p> \n<p>Using this model, Girlfriend Collective \"sold\" <a href=\"http://www.instyle.com/fashion/girlfriend-collective-free-leggings\">10,000 pairs of leggings</a> just on the first day of the campaign -- in addition to the myriad of fans and buzz it scored as a by-product. The one-two punch of \"limited supply\" and \"free\" made this offer irresistible -- even to me.</p> \n<h3>5. Groupon</h3> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/groupon-limited-time.png\" alt=\"Groupon limited time offer\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.groupon.com/deals/intercontinental-spa-boston\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Groupon partners with different businesses to offer discounted services in exchange for new customers -- and a split of the revenue. The site often uses a limited-time remaining warning (pictured above) to encourage visitors to buy quickly at the risk of missing out on a good deal.</p> \n<p>For some deals, Groupon uses a few marketing psychology persuasion tactics to encourage you to buy. Check out the deal below:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/groupon-example-2.png?width=248&amp;name=groupon-example-2.png\" alt=\"Groupon scarcity principle\" width=\"248\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 248px;\"></p> \n<p>This deal uses the scarcity principle and social proof to encourage you to buy it -- it's only available for a limited time, <em>and</em> almost 600 other people have already purchased it and rated it highly. These strategies work well -- Groupon made <a href=\"http://www.marketwatch.com/investing/stock/GRPN/financials\">more than $3 billion</a> last year.</p> \n<h3>6. Spotify</h3> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Spotify-US-Invites.png?width=730&amp;height=368&amp;name=Spotify-US-Invites.png\" alt=\"Spotify invite\" width=\"730\" height=\"368\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://geek.com/\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">When the music streaming service Spotify was first launched, the United Kingdom was the only area that <a href=\"https://www.cnet.com/news/spotify-goes-invite-only/?_escaped_fragment_=\">didn't require an invitation</a> from a friend or from Spotify to sign up. But due to high demand, Spotify U.K. actually had to start requiring invitations to manage all of the news users. The caveat to the invitation-only launches of Spotify around the world? Anyone could sign up for a premium, paid Spotify account. Using the scarcity principle, Spotify managed high levels of consumer demand by offering them a way in -- for a price. Now, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-02/spotify-hits-50-million-paid-subscribers-lifting-music-industry\">half of Spotify's 100 million users</a> are paid, subscribers.</p> \n<h3>7. TOMS</h3> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/toms-wild-aid.png?width=730&amp;height=417&amp;name=toms-wild-aid.png\" alt=\"TOMS wild aid initiative\" width=\"730\" height=\"417\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.toms.com/\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">The beloved TOMS shoes offer a great value proposition beyond comfort and style: For every pair of shoes purchased, TOMS donates a pair to a child in need. TOMS takes that a step further by partnering with other advocacy organizations to share sales revenue to benefit other worthy causes.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Because the brand knows its customers are already philanthropic, it's a safe bet they'll want to purchase shoes benefiting other causes (such as pandas in the example above), but they still might need a push. So TOMS created a mini-site about why TOMS and WildAid are partnering, along with some fun facts about pandas and unique panda-themed shoe designs.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Then, once the visitor has read the entire compelling site and started browsing the vegan, panda-friendly footwear options, TOMS subtly lets them know that the shoes are only available for a short period of time. In other words, helping cute pandas is only an option for a limited time, too.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/toms-wildaid-pandas.png?width=730&amp;height=98&amp;name=toms-wildaid-pandas.png\" alt=\"TOMS wild aid panda collection\" width=\"730\" height=\"98\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">TOMS' approach of using the scarcity complex to encourage shopping and philanthropy works here.</p> \n<h2>Sometimes, Less Is More</h2> \n<p>Invoking the scarcity principle to promote and sell a product can be an effective persuasion strategy, but you have to do it correctly. If you phrase the product scarcity as if there used to be a large supply, but due to increased demand, only a few products were left, consumers will be more receptive. But if you phrase the product scarcity as if only a few units of product were ever available, the principle of scarcity won't be as effective at generating sales.</p> \n<p><i><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in May 2017 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></i></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"state of marketing\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fthe-scarcity-principle&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 01 Jul 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7.png","linkMd5":"aad77e7209fdad88cd9527dadf757114","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn5@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-586_88b93bfb7be7b212.webp","destWidth":442,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5404,"destBytes":7216,"author":"sbernazzani@hubspot.com (Sophia Bernazzani)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn5@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-586_88b93bfb7be7b212.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/kayak-scarcity-principle.png?width=548&name=kayak-scarcity-principle.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn34@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-49-964_9d0893612cd1bfd8.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scarcity-principle-research.png?width=1206&name=scarcity-principle-research.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn57@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-53-607_9a365d96317f8248.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/og-map.png?width=730&height=383&name=og-map.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn96@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-52-499_61a930114c6f0c4f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Snapchat-Spectacles-Snapbot-640x447.jpg?width=640&height=447&name=Snapchat-Spectacles-Snapbot-640x447.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn15@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-52-915_ccea3d21a539cfd0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/wii-production-line.jpg?width=480&height=223&name=wii-production-line.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn24@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-51-753_e0cc3a3fd2491ec0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/groupon-limited-time.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn4@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-51-429_4cfa44e95dd3cbae.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/groupon-example-2.png?width=248&name=groupon-example-2.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Spotify-US-Invites.png?width=730&height=368&name=Spotify-US-Invites.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn17@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-51-011_f1d3d79c9dedce4a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/toms-wild-aid.png?width=730&height=417&name=toms-wild-aid.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn43@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-49-235_b666a39c257aa56f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/toms-wildaid-pandas.png?width=730&height=98&name=toms-wildaid-pandas.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn90@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-51-978_42008929bc51de64.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn78@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-48-782_ba6ee21c8b9c368e.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fthe-scarcity-principle&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn81@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-52-307_09e8d06f65c87b19.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938147},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"How to Set & Achieve Marketing Objectives in 2021","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-objectives","description":"<p>In the marketing industry, setting objectives can be a double-edged sword. On the one hand, constantly raising the bar can incentivize your team to sustain your growth rate over long periods. On the other hand, it can incentivize your team to prioritize your company’s needs over your customers’ needs.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=a482387e-c9f6-456b-b92f-4ba795780b19&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download your free marketing goal-setting template here.&nbsp;\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/a482387e-c9f6-456b-b92f-4ba795780b19.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>Contrary to popular belief, solely focusing on the results doesn’t actually produce results. Focusing on <a href=\"https://contently.com/2018/03/16/drive-grow-vs-drive-serve/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">serving your customers is what produces results</a>. Tim Cook, Apple’s CEO, is famous for sparking this customer-centric movement.</p>  \n<p>In 2015, he <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tim-cook-goldman-sachs-conerence-2015-2\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">spoke at Goldman Sach’s Technology and Internet Conference in San Francisco</a>, and a reporter asked him what some of Apple’s biggest accomplishments from the past year were. He responded, “We're not focused on the numbers. We're focused on the things that produce the numbers.\"</p> \n<p>In this blog post, we’ll show you how to set realistic marketing objectives that will help you craft audience-centric content, prioritize your customers' needs, and hit your numbers, all at the same time.</p> \n<p>Read on to learn how to identify your marketing objectives’ purpose and process and why it's just as important as the numbers you aim to hit.</p> \n<p></p> \n<div> \n <p>In his <a href=\"http://jayacunzo.com/blog/problem-with-goals\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">insightful blog post about setting goals</a>, Jay Acunzo, the founder of Unthinkable Media, reveals a subtle yet potent problem that has pervaded the content marketing industry over the years — traditional goal-setting lets you measure what you do, but it doesn’t lend itself to gauging how you do it or why which is what ultimately gives your work meaning and resonates with prospects.</p> \n <p>In marketing, you obviously need to aim for concrete targets. But, as we said earlier, only focusing on the results can sometimes incentivize you to take a course of action that prioritizes your organization’s needs over your customers’ needs.</p> \n <p>To help you focus more on your purpose and process instead of just your results, Acunzo recommends considering two additional factors when setting a marketing objective — your hunger and your aspirational anchor.</p> \n <p>Your hunger is your current dissatisfaction with your work today or why you want to achieve your goal. Your aspirational anchor is your vision of your work in the future or how you’ll achieve your goal.</p> \n <p>These two factors drive your motivation and keep you on track to create work that better serves your customers. When you add your numerical goal to the equation, you’ll be able to simultaneously produce customer-centric work and create business impact.</p> \n <h2>How to Set Realistic Marketing Objectives</h2> \n <p>The first thing to understand is the subtle <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/goals-vs-objectives?_ga=2.175461482.933151706.1623427346-1058722707.1623427346\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">difference between a goal and an objective</a>. A general goal is going to be your broader vision while your marketing objective is that more concrete specification of how that vision is achieved. In order to craft your marketing objective, you must start with vision first by defining three main things:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Hunger - What is the driving force — or the “why” — behind what you want to achieve? What pain or problem has led you to this point, and why must it be solved?</li> \n  <li>Aspirational Anchor - What does success look like — or “how” does the end vision solve that problem?</li> \n  <li>Goal - What steps must be taken — or the “what” — for that aspiration to come to fruition?</li> \n </ul> \n <p>Now that we understand the “why” and the “how” behind setting marketing objectives, let’s go over how you can root the \"what\" in reality with the SMART goal framework.</p> \n <p>SMART goals are realistic, quantifiable, and focused targets that you can easily aim for. If you’re wondering what SMART means, it’s an acronym that helps you clearly define your goals.</p> \n <h4><strong>Specific</strong></h4> \n <p>In terms of marketing, you should choose the particular metric you want to improve upon, like visitors, leads, or customers. You should also determine what each team member will work on, the resources they’ll have, and their plan of action.</p> \n <h4><strong>Measurable</strong></h4> \n <p>If you want to gauge your team’s progress, you need to quantify your goals, like achieving an X% increase in visitors, leads, or customers.</p> \n <h4><strong>Attainable</strong></h4> \n <p>Make sure that X% increase is achievable in your specific situation. If your blog traffic increased by 5% last month, try to increase it by 8-10% this month, not 30%. It’s crucial to base your goals on your own analytics, not industry benchmarks, or else you might bite off more than you can chew.</p> \n <h4><strong>Relevant</strong></h4> \n <p>Your goal needs to relate to your company’s overall goal and account for current trends in your industry. For instance, will growing your Facebook following lead to more revenue? And is it actually possible for you to significantly boost your organic reach on Facebook after their most recent algorithm change? If you’re aware of these factors, you’ll be more likely to set goals that are realistic, achievable, and beneficial to your company.</p> \n <h4><strong>Time-bound</strong></h4> \n <p>Attaching deadlines to your goals puts pressure on your team to accomplish them. And this helps you make consistent and significant progress in the long term. If you don’t give yourself a deadline, you can very easily fall into the trap of procrastinating on action items, leading to a slower rate of success.</p> \n <p>For example, which would you prefer: Increasing leads by 5% every month, leading to a 30-35% increase in half a year, or trying to increase leads by 15% with no deadline and achieving that goal in a year?</p> \n <p>By analyzing two different goal-setting frameworks, we’ve learned how to identify the “why,” “how,” and “what” behind your marketing objectives. Now, we can blend the two frameworks to set a realistic goal that fulfills your customers’ needs and helps you hit your numbers at the same time. Check out the examples below for more detail.</p> \n</div> \n<div></div> \n<div> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Now that you know how to write a marketing objective, you can get ideas from some metaphorical samples. Below, we’ll start with one long example breaking out the above methodology step-by-step, and then we’ll provide other examples to fuel your inspiration.</span></p> \n <h3><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">1. Increase blog subscribers.</span></h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">In this example, we’ll set a target of increasing blog subscribers by 25% month-over-month this year — it’s a substantive increase, but possible with the SMART framework.</span></p> \n <ul> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Hunger (Why) - Our blog educates our audience well but it doesn’t resonate emotionally with them enough.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Aspirational Anchor (How) - Run a blog that consistently resonates with our audience and that people look forward to reading every time they receive our email digest.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Goal (What) - Increase blog subscribers as an indication of our success.</span></li> \n </ul> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">With this goal-setting framework, you can see how the “why” and “how” behind a goal incentivizes behavior that better serves customers and hits numbers at the same time.</span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">For instance, in the example above, this blog team refuses to just do whatever it takes to boost their blog subscription. They want to craft emotionally resonant stories that their audience actually values or content that’s worth subscribing to, and this is what will lead to their growth in subscribers and create long-term value for their business.</span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">If this blog team didn’t identify their hunger or set an aspirational anchor, however, the only thing that would guide them toward the finish line is the finish line itself. And that could incentivize short-sighted behavior that helps them achieve their goal at the expense of prioritizing their audience’s needs over their own.</span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Once the aspirational vision and the general goal has been defined, now it’s time to pivot to a concrete objective using the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-a-smart-goal-template?_ga=2.175461482.933151706.1623427346-1058722707.1623427346\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">SMART goal framework</a><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">:</span></span></p> \n <h4><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Specific</span></h4> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Our blog educates our audience well, but it doesn’t resonate emotionally with them enough. Let’s start running a blog that can consistently provide value, that people look forward to reading every time they receive our email digest, and that can attract more subscribers.</span></p> \n <h4><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Measurable</span></h4> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Increase month-over-month blog subscribers by 25% this year.</span></p> \n <h4><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Attainable</span></h4> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Last year, we increased month-over-month blog subscribers by 15%, so we know this is doable.</span></p> \n <h4><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Relevant</span></h4> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">If we can craft emotionally resonant stories that our audience actually values, we can build deeper relationships with them, attract more subscribers with whom we can also build deep relationships, and hopefully do business in the future.</span></p> \n <h4><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Time-Bound</span></h4> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Monthly over the course of a year.</span></p> \n <h3><strong><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">2. Reach more visitors with organic search traffic.</span></strong></h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Let's say our organization's goal is to grow its online organic presence to attract more leads and reach 35,000 visitors via organic search monthly by the end of the year. These are Hunger and Aspirational anchors, so they must be translated into a SMART goal if we want to take steps to achieve it:</span></p> \n <ul> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Specific - Increase website visitors from organic search.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Measurable - Reach 35,000 visitors monthly.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Attainable - Must be sure that the number is reachable by increasing or improving variables within our control.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Relevant - Must be the right traffic since the ultimate goal is to increase leads.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Time-bound - By the end of the year.</span></li> \n </ul> \n <h3><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">3. Improve the mobile traffic conversion rate site-wide.</span></h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Traffic alone is not enough to generate leads and, ultimately, revenue. We need mechanisms in place to convert the traffic we're already getting. </span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Let's say we notice that our site converts a lot better on desktop than mobile. This means we could be losing a ton of lead opportunities who arrived at our site on a mobile device. That's why we decide to enhance the mobile experience and set a goal of improving mobile traffic conversion rates site-wide from 2.3% to 5% by Q3 Here's how we turn that goal into an objective:</span></p> \n <ul> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Specific - Improve mobile traffic conversion rate.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Measurable - From 2.3% to 5%.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Attainable - Must identify roadblocks to conversion and how we plan to remove them.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Relevant - Must actually have enough mobile traffic to justify the effort.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Time-bound - By Q3.</span></li> \n </ul> \n <h3><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">4. Increase MQL conversions.</span></h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">With inbound marketing, it's easy to get swept up in blogging, offer creation, and lead conversions. At the same time, if we don't have mechanisms in place to move those leads closer to a purchasing decision, these efforts don't pay off the way they could. <span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Part of our jobs as marketers is to foster relationships with our leads while qualifying them so that the sales team focuses on prospects who are ready to buy.</span></span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Let's say we have a top-of-the-funnel lead generation engine where website visitors convert on eBooks and guides. Our goal is now to bridge the gap between where they're at in their journey vs. where we want them to go and so we aim to convert 500 leads to MQLs by the end of the year. We decide to do that through an ongoing educational email drip sequence, and we start with our objective:</span></p> \n <ul> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Specific - Convert Leads to MQLs.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Measurable - From the existing number to 500.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Attainable - Must ensure we already have a large enough pool to extract those MQLs from (or a fast-enough lead generation engine to supply them).</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Relevant - Must have a clear definition of what constitutes an MQL and a plan to obtain those parameters.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Time-bound - By the year's end.</span></li> \n </ul> \n <h3><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">5. Boost the average monthly open rate.</span></h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">In order for us to effectively nurture leads, we want people to be reading our content... which they won't do if they don't get past the subject line of the email. Here's how we position this concept into the concrete objective of increasing the monthly open rate from 25% to 40% in one quarter:</span></p> \n <ul> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Specific - Increase average monthly open rate.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Measurable - From 25% to 40%.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Attainable - Must analyze existing email tactics to identify gaps.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Relevant - Must only include the most relevant marketing emails in the metrics to avoid skewing data.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Time-bound - In one quarter</span></li> \n </ul> \n <h3>6. Increase our MQL to SQL conversion rate.</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Never forget the primary goal of marketing, which is to promote an organization's goods or services in the effort of generating more sales. At the same time, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34212/how-to-create-a-service-level-agreement-sla-for-better-sales-marketing-alignment.aspx?_ga=2.175461482.933151706.1623427346-1058722707.1623427346\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">fewer than half of marketers consider their departments aligned with sales</a><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">.</span></span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">A relevant goal might be to improve the effectiveness of our marketing efforts by solidifying the marketing to sales hand-off. Specifically, we’re aiming to increase MQL to SQL conversion rate from 25% to 35% by Q2. Our concrete objective might break down like this:</span></p> \n <ul> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Specific - Increase the MQL to SQL conversion rate.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Measurable - From 25% to 35%.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Attainable - Must ensure we already have a large enough pool to extract those SQLs from (or a fast-enough lead generation engine to supply them).</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Relevant - Must have a clear agreement between the marketing and sales departments for what constitutes an SQL.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Time-bound - By Q2.</span></li> \n </ul> \n <h3>7. Improve overall NPS score.</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Marketing doesn't end once the prospect becomes a customer, and that means also working on ways to fuel the flywheel i.e. turning customers into brand advocates who purchase from us and tell their friends to do the same. </span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">NPS is a solid measurement of customer happiness, so improving that score — from 31 to 35 within 6 month — is a solid place to start building our objective:</span></p> \n <ul> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Specific - Improve the NPS score.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Measurable - From 31 to 35.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Attainable - Must analyze existing NPS roadblocks to identify gaps.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Relevant - Must ensure there's a mechanism for collecting and analyzing NPS input.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Time-bound - In 6 months.</span></li> \n </ul> \n <h3>8. Enhance Facebook engagement.</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">One of the best ways to grow a brand’s marketing efforts exponentially is by investing in its community of customers and prospects. The goal might be to stay top of mind and energize the community by raising the bar on each social media platform. For example, we might look to improve Facebook engagement by 30% month-over-month:</span></p> \n <ul> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Specific - Improve engagement on Facebook.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Measurable - By 30%.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Attainable - Must identify the content that's engaging our existing user base and see if 30% is a reasonable number to strive for.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Relevant - Must ensure that there's a solid definition of what metrics are being counted as engagement.</span></li> \n  <li style=\"color: #33475b;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Time-bound - On a monthly rolling basis.</span></li> \n </ul> \n <h3>9. Increase total market share.</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">As digital markets become more crowded, it’s critical for companies to claim as much market share as possible — pulling even a few percentage points away from the competition can have significant benefits for your bottom line.</span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Let’s set a reasonable goal: Increasing total market share a 5% by the end of the year:</span></p> \n <ul> \n  <li><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Specific - Improve total market share</span></li> \n  <li><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Measurable - By 5%</span></li> \n  <li><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Attainable - Must identify areas of potential loss, such as customer churn, and areas of gain such as targeted advertising</span></li> \n  <li><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Relevant - Must ensure there’s a reliable way to regularly measure market share</span></li> \n  <li><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Time-bound - By the end of the year</span></li> \n </ul> \n <h3>10. Evaluate ad impact.</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Advertisements help your brand get noticed — but are your ads doing their job? Here, our marketing objective is to compare the cost-per-click and conversion rate of two different ads using A/B testing on social media over the period of a month to determine which one drives better ROI:</span></p> \n <ul> \n  <li><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Specific - Determine the highest ad impact</span></li> \n  <li><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Measurable - Evaluated using cost-per-click</span></li> \n  <li><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Attainable - Must assess the impact of each ad and how many click-throughs it generates</span></li> \n  <li><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Relevant - Must ensure the same metrics are used for each ad to ensure an accurate comparison</span></li> \n  <li><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Time-bound - In one month</span></li> \n  <li>Marketing Objectives: Metrics and KPIs</li> \n </ul> \n <p>Once marketing objectives have been established, companies must identify and track specific metrics and key performance indicators (KPIs) to provide both immediate insights and set the stage for long-term strategic planning. Some of the most common metrics and KPIs include:</p> \n <h3><span style=\"color: #444444;\">Sales Growth</span></h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Sales growth is measured using total revenue volume, number of units sold, or both. Increasing numbers mean growing sales — for best effect, monitor sales growth as a baseline and then during new marketing campaigns to evaluate your impact.</span></p> \n <h3>Profit Variance</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Profit — also called return on investment (ROI) — isn’t simply a factor of sales and revenue. Instead, it depends on the amount of money your brand makes after material costs, marketing expenses, and other spending is subtracted. If material costs increase but sales remain steady, for example, profit will decrease. Monitoring profit variance helps ensure product prices drive ROI.</span></p> \n <h3>Total Market Share</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">The bigger your market share, the better. To calculate this metric, you need the market size of your local industry and its approximate total revenue. </span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Multiple your brand’s revenue by 100 and divide by the market’s total revenue to get a percentage market share. Recalculate this regularly to see if your share has improved.</span></p> \n <h3>New Customer Volumes</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">More customers mean more sales and more revenue. Along with measuring the total number of new customers over a specific time frame, it’s also worth evaluating customer increases in comparison to other time frames — such as when you’re running a sales or marketing event — along with considering the cost per customer, which is the total amount of money spent to acquire a new customer.</span></p> \n <h3>Lifetime Customer Value</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Higher lifetime customer values mean more reliable revenue streams. To calculate this metric, multiply the average number of purchases made by return customers over a specific period with the average total value of these purchases. This provides an approximation of lifetime customer value to help inform ongoing marketing strategy.</span></p> \n <h3>Conversion Rates</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Conversion rates measure the percentage of people who take action when presented with the choice to opt-in for sales notifications, email newsletters, free trials, or who ultimately decide to make a purchase. It’s worth tracking conversion rates across all aspects of your website to see which marketing tools are delivering reliable results.</span></p> \n <h3>SEO Impact</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Search engine optimization (SEO) helps your brand rank higher with popular engines such as Google, in turn making it easier for customers to find your site. </span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Tools such as <a href=\"https://ads.google.com/intl/en_ca/home/tools/keyword-planner/\">Google’s Keyword Planner </a><span style=\"color: #000000;\">can help you identify ways to improve your SEO, and you can quickly test how you stack up by searching for your brand’s target keyword and seeing where you show up in current search rankings.</span></span></p> \n <h3>Social Media Performance</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Social media marketing is now critical to generate organic engagement and customer referrals. As a result, it’s worth tracking metrics such as the increase in follower numbers on a certain platform over a specific period, the number of comments left on your posts, and the number of times your posts are shared.</span></p> \n <h2>Tools to Track Marketing Objectives</h2> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">You’ve got the model. You’ve identified the objectives, and you’ve defined the metrics. Now you need the right tools to track marketing objective success across your organization.</span></p> \n <h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing\">HubSpot Marketing Hub</a></h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">The HubSpot Marketing Hub offers all the marketing tools and data you need, and all under one roof. From SEO strategy tools to ad tracking, social media management and live chat support, and a robust content creation platform, HubSpot can help your brand reach more people more quickly and boost total ROI.</span></p> \n <h3>2. Real-time Dashboards</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Real-time dashboard tools provide right-now, single-pane-of-glass analysis of current sales performance, KPI progress, and other key metrics. Often hosted in the cloud, real-time dashboards make it possible for everyone in the organization to view current marketing goals and ensure business operations are aligned with specific outcomes.</span></p> \n <h3>3. Spreadsheets</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">While spreadsheets are often considered relatively low-tech and legacy deployments when compared to more robust marketing tools, they nonetheless offer actionable value. Tools such as Google Sheets and Excel are easy to use, easy to view, and offer an understanding of specific metric performance at a glance that can help inform current marketing efforts.</span></p> \n <h3>4. Website Analytics Trackers</h3> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Tools such as Webtrends and <a href=\"https://analytics.google.com/analytics/web/provision/#/provision\">Google Analytics</a><span style=\"color: #000000;\"> provide in-depth statistics about the number and type of users that visit your web page, along with key data such as how long they stayed, what they clicked on, and which actions (if any) were taken. </span></span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #000000;\">While website analytics alone aren’t enough to inform marketing efforts, they’re essential to help marketing teams refine overall strategy for maximum effect.</span></p> \n <h2><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Starting SMART</span></h2> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Once you understand the importance of vision, identifying broad goals, and using the SMART goal framework to make concrete marketing objectives for those goals, it’s time to identify the gaps in your marketing and begin outlining your objectives.</span></p> \n <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Once you do, it’s important to write those objectives down and commit to creating a solid plan of action to achieving them.</span></p> \n <p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in [Insert original publish date] and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n <p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=98f8807c-91d0-4663-ae55-e1f0d07effbd&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call to action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/98f8807c-91d0-4663-ae55-e1f0d07effbd.png\"></a></p> \n <p></p> \n</div>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-objectives&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 23 Jun 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/a482387e-c9f6-456b-b92f-4ba795780b19.png","linkMd5":"4f20b01b1f5783e70fa25cfa72cca39a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn41@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-38-384_f9874034bd791f68.webp","destWidth":523,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":4586,"destBytes":7842,"author":"cchi@hubspot.com (Clifford Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/a482387e-c9f6-456b-b92f-4ba795780b19.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn41@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-38-384_f9874034bd791f68.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/98f8807c-91d0-4663-ae55-e1f0d07effbd.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn54@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-52-552_5ac38f911d257768.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-objectives&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn99@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-52-790_672d4cccbe904b2d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938168},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"Does your Website Make the Grade in 2021?","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/website-grader","description":"<p>A while ago (as in 13 years ago) we created the first <a href=\"https://website.grader.com/?utm_campaign=Website%20Grader%20ACQ&amp;utm_source=Exec%20Post&amp;utm_medium=Blog&amp;__hstc=45788219.75198103554ac7f04573066affdadbff.1623431485049.1623431485049.1623431485049.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1623431485049&amp;__hsfp=3403196935\">Website Grader</a>. The goal was simple: help anyone with a website evaluate its effectiveness at attracting an audience of interested and relevant buyers.</p> \n<p>We founded HubSpot in 2006 and created Website Grader in 2008 because we believed that the inbound methodology — building meaningful, lasting relationships with prospects and customers — was not only a more effective way to grow a business, it was the right way to grow a business. And we knew how important it was for people to leverage their websites to attract visitors and connect with customers to grow.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=4ec26392-01d3-42c6-883a-7e018c4864de&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"How strong is your website? Grade it using HubSpot's free Website Grader.\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4ec26392-01d3-42c6-883a-7e018c4864de.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>Fast forward to 2021, and websites do a whole lot more than attract visitors.</p> \n<p>Your website is a sales rep, providing prospects with the features and pricing of your offering. And helping them book a meeting to learn more.</p> \n<p>Your website is part of your customer service team, answering questions about your products and services through a knowledge base or chatbot.</p> \n<p>Your website is a member of your HR team, sharing information about your company culture and open positions.</p> \n<p>The list goes on...</p> \n<p>To put it bluntly: your website is really freaking important! Today, <a href=\"https://smallbiztrends.com/2019/04/need-a-website-small-business.html\">86%</a> of people will find your business online. Your website is your first impression, your primary spokesperson, your around-the-clock inbound sales team — you get my point. It’s one of the most important assets to your business.</p> \n<p>It’s no wonder we see businesses invest so much in their websites. In a recent<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing/website-strategy?_ga=2.40047268.743952961.1592515403-112379962.1552485402\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing/website-strategy?_ga=2.40047268.743952961.1592515403-112379962.1552485402\">HubSpot Research study</a>, 63% of marketers indicated that they were going to upgrade their website this year.</p> \n<p>Website upgrades can include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Performance: Page speed, load time, page requests, page size, and more</li> \n <li>Search Engine Optimization (SEO): Page index, meta descriptions, content plugins, and descriptive link text</li> \n <li>Design: Responsive design, legible font size, and tap targets</li> \n <li>Security: HTTPS and secure javascript libraries</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Since 2008, we’ve graded over 1 million unique websites on the above four factors. With all this investment, are they actually getting better? Are businesses focusing on the right website upgrades? For example, are websites providing better security for their visitors. Are they offering faster load speeds for quick access? What about mobile accessibility and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-tips\">SEO best practices</a>?</p> \n<p>Let’s take a look at average performance in 2015 compared to this year to see what’s changed.</p> \n<h2>Website Performance Data (2015 vs 2021)</h2> \n<p><img alt=\"Website Performance data from 2015 to 2021 HubSpot Research\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F-1.png?width=624&amp;name=Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F-1.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>What surprises me the most about this data is that the improvements in technology over the past five years haven’t led to the same improvement in website performance. The overall grade average has only improved 17.1% in little over five years, and performance has actually decreased by 23.3%. The average website grade in 2020 is a D+ (69.1 out of 100). My mother wouldn’t be happy if I came home with that kind of grade.</p> \n<p>We also found that only 3.8% of websites have an overall score of 90 or more. If your website scores above a 90, pat yourself on the back. Here are the percentile ranges from our data:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>80 overall score: 82nd percentile</li> \n <li>85 overall score: 91st percentile</li> \n <li>90 overall score: 96th percentile</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Here are some observations of the individual benchmark scores:</p> \n<h3>Website performance has decreased in the past half-decade.</h3> \n<p>Websites should load faster in 2021 than they did in 2015 — but the exact opposite is true. Performance was the only benchmark metric that decreased in five years. This includes testing for page size, page requests, page speed, and five additional tests that offer a holistic performance grading.</p> \n<p>The result? Websites are slower today than they were in 2015.</p> \n<p>This is a risk for businesses: the longer visitors wait for your page to load, the more likely they’ll leave your page.</p> \n<p>For every second that your website takes to load, people are leaving your business. Good performance should be a priority when improving your website.<a href=\"https://hubs.ly/H0rGVT00\"> </a><a href=\"https://hubs.ly/H0rGVT00\">How does your website’s performance compare</a>?</p> \n<h3>Search engine optimization is the biggest winner.</h3> \n<p>In a 2020 survey, we found that 64% of marketers are <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing/seo-trends?_ga=2.48521120.743952961.1592515403-112379962.1552485402\">actively investing in search engine optimization (SEO)</a> and growing their organic presence.</p> \n<p>Marketers care about SEO, and this has led to significant progress in the SEO benchmark since 2015 — a 51.9% improvement. Search engine optimization is essential to getting discovered online. It’s good that so many websites are following SEO best practices to improve the discovery of their business.<a href=\"https://hubs.ly/H0rGVT00\"> </a><a href=\"https://hubs.ly/H0rGVT00\">How does your SEO compare</a>?</p> \n<h3>Security had the second-biggest gain, but the total average falls short.</h3> \n<p>Our security benchmark shows that websites have improved their security by 142.3% over five years. This is a huge gain but there’s still a lot of room for improvement — the 2021 average score is only 6.3 out of 10.</p> \n<p>Security is essential to have on your site to protect customer data. If your website isn’t secure, your visitors might lose trust in your business, especially when shopping on your site. We found that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-ssl?_ga=2.48521120.743952961.1592515403-112379962.1552485402\">85%</a> of people won’t visit a site if it’s not secure.</p> \n<p>Additionally, security improves discoverability. Starting in 2019, <a href=\"https://thenextweb.com/google/2015/12/17/unsecured-websites-are-about-to-get-hammered-in-googles-search-ranking/\">Google prioritized displaying websites with HTTPS</a> in search results. Website Grader checks that your website uses HTTPS and has secure JavaScript libraries.</p> \n<p>These two security factors are critical for delivering a secure experience for your visitors.<a href=\"https://hubs.ly/H0rGVT00\"> </a><a href=\"https://hubs.ly/H0rGVT00\">How does your website security compare</a>?</p> \n<h3>Mobile optimized websites improved marginally.</h3> \n<p>In the mid-2010s, it felt like every website was going responsive — that is, investing in mobile-first website design. It made sense.</p> \n<p>Everywhere I looked, people were heads down on their phones, reading the latest Facebook post or watching a viral YouTube video. And, things haven’t changed much. Well, they have, but now people are scrolling through Instagram or browsing the latest TikTok dance challenge.</p> \n<p>Responsiveness wasn’t just a trend — in the first quarter of 2021, mobile devices (excluding tablets) generated <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/277125/share-of-website-traffic-coming-from-mobile-devices/#:~:text=Mobile%20accounts%20for%20approximately%20half,since%20the%20beginning%20of%202017.\">54.8%</a> of global website traffic. So how do websites stack up on small screens?</p> \n<p>We found that our mobile design benchmark average improved by 8% over five years. Today, average websites score 21.6 out of 30 on mobile design. A great improvement, though I’d love to see that number go up even more.</p> \n<p>Instagram, for example, is a website that does exceptionally well in how they design and optimize users’ mobile experience. It has a seamless mobile shopping feature for businesses to sell products directly through its mobile website or in-app.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"mobile optimized website for shopping on Instagram and Facebook\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F.gif?width=360&amp;height=667&amp;name=Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F.gif\" title=\"\" width=\"360\" height=\"667\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://woocommerce.com/products/facebook/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>One study by Google found that 59% of shoppers surveyed said that <a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/data/global-shopper-product-research-statistics/\">shopping on mobile is important when deciding</a> which brand or retailer to buy from.</p> \n<p>That’s a huge portion of people looking at your website on mobile and making a decision of whether or not to buy from you. Mobile design will not only impact the experience that people have with your site, but also influences social media posts and your rankings in search engines.</p> \n<p>Check your mobile design score on<a href=\"https://hubs.ly/H0rGVT00\"> </a><a href=\"https://hubs.ly/H0rGVT00\">Website Grader</a>.</p> \n<h3>Where do we go from here?</h3> \n<p>Our goal with the original Website Grader was to help anyone with a website —developer, marketer, or entrepreneur — to quickly grade their website’s performance. We’ve received good feedback from our users, but we are always growing and evolving.</p> \n<p>So we asked ourselves, how could we make Website Grader better?</p> \n<p>Our users’ comments had a common thread. They graded their site. They saw where their websites fell short. But we stopped short of teaching them how to improve:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>\"More information about how to solve website problems\"</li> \n <li>\"Instructions on how to get better performance and SEO to get our score higher\"</li> \n <li>\"How about putting explanations and guidelines for beginners?\"</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>Introducing the New Website Grader</h2> \n<p>You talked. We listened. Not only have we updated Website Grader’s grading system and foundational technology to get you a more accurate score, but we’ve also created a five-lesson video course that helps you improve your grade. All for free.</p> \n<p>You can find the <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/web-optimization\">Website Optimization course</a> inside Website Grader starting today.</p> \n<h3>One last question: How did HubSpot.com score?</h3> \n<p>HubSpot’s score has not historically been the best. At one point, we averaged 70-80 on Website Grader. Years of marketing updates had slowed things down over time.</p> \n<p>Since then, we’ve<a href=\"https://developers.hubspot.com/blog/how-we-improved-page-speed-on-hubspot.com?_ga=2.220969886.743952961.1592515403-112379962.1552485402\"> </a><a href=\"https://developers.hubspot.com/blog/how-we-improved-page-speed-on-hubspot.com?_ga=2.220969886.743952961.1592515403-112379962.1552485402\">worked hard</a> to improve HubSpot.com’s design and performance over the last five years for our visitors and customers. Powered by<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/cms?_ga=2.220969886.743952961.1592515403-112379962.1552485402\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/cms?_ga=2.220969886.743952961.1592515403-112379962.1552485402\">HubSpot CMS Hub</a>, our website now scores a 97 out of 100 on Website Grader — no kidding. It’s something we're extremely proud of.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"HubSpot Website Grader 2021 grade\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F.png?width=624&amp;height=343&amp;name=Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"343\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Your website is one of your most important assets in attracting business. A bad user experience could lose customer interest, but that doesn’t have to happen if you take the necessary steps to optimize it. If you’re curious to see how your site measures up, run it through our Website Grader and find out how you can make your site more delightful.</p> \n<p><em>Editor’s note: This post was originally published in June 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=773b8b5a-95fa-4754-80e2-47a4bfbbc99d&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Improve your website with effective technical SEO. Start by conducting this  audit.&nbsp;&nbsp;\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/773b8b5a-95fa-4754-80e2-47a4bfbbc99d.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img
