Flanagan)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4ec26392-01d3-42c6-883a-7e018c4864de.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn1@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-38-389_830f5cddc1433932.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F-1.png?width=624&name=Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn61@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-50-790_dce8d335fb9a48f4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F.gif?width=360&height=667&name=Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn25@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-56-932_cce44b2bf5b03c3a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F.png?width=624&height=343&name=Does%20your%20Website%20Make%20the%20Grade%20in%202021%3F.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn9@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-49-803_b90214fe27639405.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/773b8b5a-95fa-4754-80e2-47a4bfbbc99d.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn81@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-48-759_2c5a0ec90f181571.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwebsite-grader&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938123},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"The Best Video Formats on Instagram [New Data]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-video-formats","description":"<p>As a millennial, it's no surprise that Instagram is one of my favorite social media platforms. This network is the <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/471543/millennials-usa-social-media-reach-gender/\">third most popular social media site</a> for Gen Z and millennial audiences.</p> \n<p>While scrolling through the site is the easiest thing to do, posting the right content for your audience isn't.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>As a marketer, you've probably wondered what type of Instagram content would perform the best for your audience. To help you, we decided to ask consumers what type of video formats they watch the most.</p> \n<p>In this post, you'll learn what video format users like to watch on Instagram, and what size, length, and aspect ratio those videos should be.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=9294dd33-9827-4b39-8fc2-b7fbece7fdb9&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"New Data: Instagram Engagement Report [2021 Version]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9294dd33-9827-4b39-8fc2-b7fbece7fdb9.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2>Best Video Format for Instagram</h2> \n<p>Instagram is extremely popular, but did you know there is more than one kind of video format you could use for your content?</p> \n<p>To find out which is the most popular we surveyed more than 300 people to see which videos they watch the most.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-stories\">Instagram Story</a> videos were the most popular video format to watch on the social media site, with 43% of those surveyed watching this type of video content the most.</p> \n<p>Besides survey respondents who didn't use Instagram, the next highest video format to watch were live videos and then videos shared directly in the feed.</p> \n<p>The least popular video formats to watch on Instagram were <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-reels\">Instagram Reels</a> and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/igtv\">IGTV</a>, with only 19% and 13% of respondents watching them respectively.</p> \n<p>To view the results, see the graphic below.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Instagram video formats.\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png?width=624&amp;name=The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://luc.id/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Data Source</a></p> \n<p>Now that we know what kind of video formats users like to see, let's find out how you can post the best video content on Instagram.</p> \n<p>This is the proper video quality for a post on the <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads-guide/video/instagram-feed/video-views\">Instagram feed</a>. It will look something like the screenshot below.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Instagram feed video.\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png?width=236&amp;name=The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 236px;\" title=\"\" width=\"236\"></p> \n<p>For an Instagram Story, the video should be 1080 x 1080 pixels, with an aspect ratio of 9:16. The maximum file size should be 250MB.</p> \n<p>It will look something like this screenshot:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Instagram Story video\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png?width=258&amp;name=The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 258px;\" title=\"\" width=\"258\"></p> \n<p>While these are the main types of videos to upload on Instagram, you can explore other spec requirements on the <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads-guide/video/instagram-story\">Instagram site</a>.</p> \n<p>While all these stats are important, one of the ways to keep <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads-guide/video/instagram-feed/video-views\">file size down</a> is to shorten the video. You can't just upload 24 hours of video content on the platform. Now you might be wondering, <em>\"How long can my Instagram videos be?\"</em> Let's dive in below.</p> \n<h2>How Long Can Instagram Videos Be?</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>Instagram Feed -- 60 seconds</li> \n <li>Stories -- 15 seconds</li> \n <li>Livestream Videos -- 60 minutes</li> \n <li>IGTV -- 15 seconds - 10 minutes. Verified accounts can post up to 60 minutes of video on IGTV.</li> \n <li>Instagram Feed ads -- 2 minutes</li> \n <li>Instagram Carousel Video ads -- 60 seconds</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Instagram videos are a great way to reach Gen Z or millennial audiences. However, it's important to think about the type of video content that performs best on the platform. Additionally, knowing the right size and video specifications before filming your videos can help you reach success quicker.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b1268983-9da6-4d67-9d3a-cfef2d9f3cff&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"instagram statistics\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b1268983-9da6-4d67-9d3a-cfef2d9f3cff.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Finstagram-video-formats&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 30 Jun 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9294dd33-9827-4b39-8fc2-b7fbece7fdb9.png","linkMd5":"ab3a34aa261f83cd846ea231dc9649f9","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn31@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-38-585_7e54748a32aeb250.webp","destWidth":500,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5752,"destBytes":7844,"author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9294dd33-9827-4b39-8fc2-b7fbece7fdb9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn31@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-38-585_7e54748a32aeb250.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png?width=624&name=The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn11@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-49-457_9214d09ce6eca111.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png?width=236&name=The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn41@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-53-038_00887798554dcbea.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png?width=258&name=The%20Best%20Video%20Formats%20on%20Instagram%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn86@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-48-798_5a3c32bbb2b0eb26.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b1268983-9da6-4d67-9d3a-cfef2d9f3cff.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn6@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-49-299_a4245cc995397db3.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Finstagram-video-formats&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn74@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-51-557_a469a2b5cd2ffa62.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938126},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"12 Tips on How to Become a Manager: From 5 People Who Did","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/be-a-good-manager","description":"<span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">So, you want to become a manager.</span> \n<p>The million-dollar question is, how do you get noticed?</p> \n<p>Some say it's by taking on big projects. Others believe face-to-face interactions with upper management are key. The truth is, it's a combination of those two steps and many others.</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"→ Click here to download leadership lessons from HubSpot founder, Dharmesh  Shah [Free Guide].\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png\"></a> \n<p>We'll cover them all in this article, featuring five HubSpot managers who share their journeys to becoming managers and what they now look for in managerial candidates.</p> \n<h2>1. Add value to your team.</h2> \n<p>The number one way to get noticed as management material is by adding value to your team in your current role.</p> \n<p>What does that look like? Well, it depends on your position.</p> \n<p>For Diversity, Inclusion, and Belonging Team Manager at HubSpot <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/ashley-ladd/\">Ashley Ladd</a>, it started by volunteering for presentation slides on diversity and inclusion during quarterly meetings.</p> \n<p>\"It's very easy for our leadership team to be like, 'I can do that,' or 'our chief legal officer can do that,' or 'somebody could do it,'\" said Ladd, then program manager, \"but I was able to raise my hand and say 'Hey, I'm willing to take on this part of the presentation' or 'I'd love to have that opportunity.'\"</p> \n<p>Ladd said it pushed her outside of her comfort zone but also gave her visibility with upper management. Furthermore, it allowed her to share more about what she did, and show why she was passionate about her work.</p> \n<p>\"Those were some of the things earlier on that set me up for being seen as a leader in our space,\" said Ladd.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/carinacarlos/\">Carina Carlos</a>, product expert manager at HubSpot, added value by identifying a problem in her previous company's ticket management system and solving for it.</p> \n<p>\"Solutions aren't just waiting,\" said Carlos. \"They're not just there, you have to think about them, be creative and cover them.\"</p> \n<p>And that's exactly what she did. After brainstorming and developing a solution, Carlos pitched it to management and reduced ticket volume by around 40%.</p> \n<p>\"Taking ownership [is what gets you noticed for management roles], leading projects and thinking of projects that can have a bigger impact in terms of scalability and solving for the root,\" she said.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/christopher-simmons-0ab80936\">Christopher Simmons</a>, small business sales manager at HubSpot, says adding value looks like a combination of the following:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Being successful in your role</li> \n <li>Aligning with the company strategy</li> \n <li>Filling in gaps leadership may have</li> \n <li>Giving your perspective proactively</li> \n <li>Speaking up on behalf of people</li> \n</ul> \n<p>He believes it requires shifting from an individual contributor mindset to a team one. But as you identify these opportunities, make sure you're not stepping on other people to do it.</p> \n<p>\"A key to adding value is dropping pretense,\" Simmons says. \"What often happens is that people can feel like you are using them as a piece to get to wherever you're trying to go.\"</p> \n<p>Whether you start small or go big, there's always an opportunity for you to add value without pushing others to the side.</p> \n<h2>2. Volunteer for projects that give you visibility.</h2> \n<p>One of the best ways to be noticed by upper management&nbsp;is by working on projects your leadership team cares about.</p> \n<p>\"I was always raising my hand for something because I knew it would give me experience as well as exposure to what I wanted to do and what I didn't want to do,\" said Customer Success Manager at HubSpot <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/shadaviamjones/\">Davey Jones</a>.</p> \n<p>\"So, I had my shortlist of non-negotiables for whatever my next opportunity would be, even if I was leading people,\" she continued, \"and that came from raising my hand and volunteering.\"</p> \n<p>Your first step is identifying what those projects are, through company meetings and conversations with your managers and other leaders. Next, break the projects up into two categories: small, low-commitment versus long, high-impact.</p> \n<p>Jones emphasizes the importance of having measurable goals to prevent overextending yourself. Because then, you end up underperforming.</p> \n<p>The formula is this: Identify projects you'd like to work on and decide how many you will work on per quarter.</p> \n<p>\"It circles back to leveraging those additional opportunities because a lot of that has a leadership undertone in its own right,\" said Jones. \"And when you take advantage of those opportunities, you realize 'Do I want to manage people?'\"</p> \n<p>During this process, Ladd offers a key piece of advice: zoom out and up.</p> \n<p>\"As a manager, you have to be able to take yourself out and up and be like, 'Who is this impacting? Who else do I need to talk to and who else do I need to collaborate with?' she said.</p> \n<p>She continued, \"I think sometimes in those moments where I felt that sense of urgency to get something done, I definitely missed the opportunity to say 'How else can I think about this from a global perspective or a manager perspective?'\"</p> \n<p>Being solution-oriented is great, but make sure you don't rush. Have conversations with your colleagues about the best ways to move forward, get their input, and go from there.</p> \n<p>Jones adds one more thing to keep in mind when volunteering for projects: Don't be afraid to change your mind in the middle of it, if it goes beyond the original scope.</p> \n<p>\"Having a conversation or ongoing conversations with your manager helps because then, they can say, 'What's on your plate and what do you want to take off of your plate?'\" said Jones. \"And then, you look at your projects and say, 'I don't like this one, so I'm going to take it off.'\"</p> \n<p>This is where leveraging your manager's help is key.</p> \n<h2>3. Take calculated risks.</h2> \n<p>When I asked <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/vrnda-levalley/\">Vrnda LeValley</a>, customer training manager at HubSpot, if there's a particular moment that stands out to her as a manager-making moment, this is what she answered.</p> \n<p>\"Yes, a lot of them do and usually they were linked to 'This might be the day I lose my job,'\" she says.</p> \n<p>Needless to say, risky moves get you noticed.</p> \n<p>\"I actually prefer people who do too much. I would rather reel you back instead of push you out there because leadership is a vulnerable position,\" said Simmons. \"When you're a leader, you're going to have to step out and be vulnerable and be exposed.\"</p> \n<p>He continues, \"And it's a lonely place so, I want people who kind of push the boundaries a little bit. Then, we can teach, tailor, and cultivate.\"</p> \n<p>However, taking risks doesn't mean being reckless or a bully.</p> \n<p>You need to have a pioneering spirit to be <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/people-manager-skills\">an effective leader</a>, Simmons says, so shrinking back isn't the answer.</p> \n<p>Pay attention to what the business needs and be ready to act on it. This can mean having difficult conversations or stepping up when it's the right thing to do.</p> \n<p>\"Ask yourself, 'How can I do this in a way that is authentically who I am and honors people at the same time?\" says Simmons.</p> \n<p>If it seems scary to take the risk, Carlos suggests looking at the bigger picture and framing it as a service to the company, your customers, and the team.</p> \n<p>And if you mess up, own up to it.</p> \n<p>\"There needs to be a self-awareness there and an opportunity for you to raise your hand and say 'I didn't do something well,'\" said Ladd. \"Being able to apologize as a manager – it's humbling work and you have to be able to say, 'I totally messed that up' and 'Here's my action plan going forward,' I think that builds trust.\"</p> \n<h2>4. Mentor and be mentored.</h2> \n<p>Every manager I interviewed spoke of a commitment to mentor and/or be mentored.</p> \n<p>Why is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/sales-mentorship-program\">mentorship</a> vital to becoming a manager? LeValley says it helps you broaden your thinking.</p> \n<p>\"You won't know when you're thinking small cause you don't know what big is, so you need a sounding board for that,\" she said.</p> \n<p>The question is, how do you identify the right people to seek out mentorship from? LeValley suggests asking yourself who impresses you.</p> \n<p>\"Who do you see that is making the moves that matter and that is coming up with the ideas that are implemented?\" says LeValley.</p> \n<p>From there, she has a pro-tip: Meet with the leaders' executive assistants within your first 90 days because they know what matters most to their supervisors.</p> \n<p>\"They're designed to have their finger on the pulse,\" LeValley says. \"They're designed to assist, so it's right up their alley.\"</p> \n<p>However, that's not the only route toward mentorship. Simmons got informal mentoring at first.</p> \n<p>\"I went to a group, had a leader – she was amazing, phenomenal [and] she mentored me but it wasn't labeled as a mentoring relationship,\" he said. \"Once I decided to move toward management, I went and got formal mentoring.\"</p> \n<p>He reached out to his then-VP for advice on how to take the next step in his career and asked for mentorship.</p> \n<p>Figuring out who to meet with is only one step of the process, the next step is having an action plan for these conversations.</p> \n<p>\"Whenever I would work with him (my mentor), I would bring what I wanted to talk about. I was proactive,\" said Simmons. \"I didn't want to be another deduction from his time, another liability. I wanted to be an asset.\"</p> \n<p>Simmons didn't necessarily want answers to specific tactical questions but instead, learn how a leader thinks.</p> \n<p>\"I wanted to first connect to the story. We learn best through stories,\" he said. \"So, I want to hear their career path, what their journey has been like. If I can figure out how you think, I can replicate the results.\"</p> \n<p>He also leveraged peer mentors.</p> \n<p>\"That really is the secret sauce for me,\" said Simmons. \"We would kind of mentor each other informally and teach each other things. And I adopted that throughout my career.\"</p> \n<p>When Simmons came to HubSpot, he adds that his first step wasn't meeting with the directors, it was networking across with his fellow managers. In particular, those who could offer diversity of thought.</p> \n<p>\"I am trying to think with people who can supplement my weaknesses or development areas. I know I'm strong in the art of leadership so, I like talking to people who like being in that space,\" he said.</p> \n<p>\"But I am also trying to think like a person who loves systems. So, I'm trying to find people who can think about the business systems, [and learn about] the processes they used.\"</p> \n<p>With mentoring, there's humbleness in knowing that you don't know everything and a willingness to learn from both your peers and your leaders.</p> \n<h2>5. Speak up and be bold.</h2> \n<p>Speaking up can be hard, especially at work. But, these five managers agree it's necessary to become a manager.</p> \n<p>\"You need to be the voice of reason and fairness on the team you're on,\" said LeValley. \"You need to be the person who says, 'Hey, that's not nice and that's not necessary,' and 'Let's hear the idea out.'\"</p> \n<p>Simmons echoes this sentiment and thinks back to his own experience.</p> \n<p>\"There were moments early in my career when I had a platform and I didn't say what I know I needed to say, my gut was saying 'Say something' but I was like, 'Oh they can't handle this,'\" he said. \"Those were missed opportunities because leaders have a pioneering spirit, that's part of the DNA of the best leaders that I've studied.\"</p> \n<p>Simmons' point is that leaders can handle a little pushback.</p> \n<p>If you feel scared, Ladd says it helps to think of the bigger picture.</p> \n<p>\"it's very easy to get very granular and be like 'This impacts me and this is the issue I'm having' but what I try to do is take a step back and realize that this can't be just a me thing,\" she says. \"I could be feeling this way, but I bet you, eight or 10 other people are feeling this way, too.\"</p> \n<p>It's about lending your voice to be that bridge between all these voices, she says, and articulating it in a way that feels it doesn't feel like an attack but empowering instead.</p> \n<p>Ladd recalls last year being a pivotal moment for her to speak up when the conversation around social justice was at the forefront.</p> \n<p>\"I could just continue to do my job, keep doing what I'm doing and giving feedback here and there,\" she said, \"but I was able to step up and say 'It's not just about me anymore, it's about our community here.\"</p> \n<p>Speaking up can (and should) also extend to your customers.</p> \n<p>In her role in customer success, Jones fiercely advocated for her customers.</p> \n<p>\"When I think back to my role as an individual contributor, it was mostly around doing what was right for the customer, no matter how many people disagreed with me,\" she said, \"and being able to advocate for them in a way that somebody else, who was a little bit shyer or didn't think they had enough buy-in or support, would.\"</p> \n<p>And because she did that, customers returned the favor by singing her praises to upper management.</p> \n<p>One thing you want to keep in mind though is your timing. LeValley had to learn that lesson.</p> \n<p>\"I would ask these questions in a group and the whole group would reel and I'd be like 'I just wanted to know' and not realizing the impact,\" said LeValley. \"So, be very aware of your influence as you're building your brand.\"</p> \n<p>It won't always be clear when the right time is, but consider what stage the company is in and what its priorities are.</p> \n<h2>6. Connect with your leadership team.</h2> \n<p>Part of becoming a manager is forging connections with the leaders at your company and understanding the bigger picture.</p> \n<p>\"Put yourself in the rooms that matter when you can,\" said LeValley, \"even if it's 'Hey I just want to touch base for 15 minutes,' or 'I had an idea about this,' 'Can you explain the strategy behind this?'\"</p> \n<p>This requires some visibility, which some would say it's harder to get these days as <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/topic-learning-path/remote-work\">working remotely</a> is the new norm. You can't exactly start a conversation with upper management after a meeting, or have a quick word while getting coffee in the communal kitchen or get to know them at a happy hour.</p> \n<p>But LeValley thinks it's actually easier now: fewer interruptions and distractions.</p> \n<p>Set up an initial coffee chat with those key people you're interested in speaking with and go from there.</p> \n<p><strong>LeValley pro-tip:</strong> Call your first meeting a coffee chat and everything thereafter a strategic touch base or something similar.</p> \n<p>\"Don't marginalize yourself by calling it a coffee chat after the first one.\"</p> \n<p>It's all about framing your conversations in a strategic light because that's how you want to be viewed.</p> \n<h2>7. Be a resource to others.</h2> \n<p>One thing Simmons learned from his mentors is the importance of supporting your peers.</p> \n<p>\"My leader would say, 'Whenever we promote someone, we want everybody in the org to say, 'OK, that makes sense,\" he said. \"It makes sense for that person to be in that role because they've been adding value for so long.'\"</p> \n<p>Jones did it by always making herself available to assist her colleagues.</p> \n<p>\"I was called somewhere between like the 'mama bear' on the team and then also be a first responder,\" said Jones, \"because whenever there was an issue, somebody would call me in and say, 'Davey, I know you're not a part of this thing, but can you help us put this fire out?' And I'm like, 'OK, give me the problem.'\"</p> \n<p>She also got involved with new hire onboarding, unofficially mentoring others on her team.</p> \n<p>\"Typically, what happens before somebody goes into leadership, you're going to ask somebody else, 'Hey, tell me about X. Have you worked with them before? What were your experiences?' Simmons said. \"And if you're a person who burns bridges because you're not people-smart, then we should know that before.\"</p> \n<p>Wondering what are some actions you can take today to support your colleagues? Listen to their concerns, offer to help when you can, and provide resources.</p> \n<h2>8. Have career conversations with your manager.</h2> \n<p>As you start making plans to become a manager, leverage your manager's insight and support.</p> \n<p>\"Every single day, I would ask my manager, 'What can I do to make your job easier,?' which is different from 'How are you?'\" said LeValley. \"I asked my manager and my skip-level, whom you should definitely be meeting with at least once a quarter, 'What could I learn or be good at that would make this organization better?' and then you do it.\"</p> \n<p>This is an opportunity to make your aspirations clear with your manager and find opportunities to show what you're made of.</p> \n<p>\"Being able to make the space and time for conversations with your manager is the thing that helps move the needle,\" said Ladd.</p> \n<p>Start by asking your manager for quarterly career chats. Then, prepare talking points and areas of focus. Lastly, keep your manager informed on your progress, the projects you're working on, and leverage their help to identify career development opportunities.</p> \n<h2>9. Act with empathy and vulnerability.</h2> \n<p>Now more than ever, having empathy is central to being a good manager.</p> \n<p>\"I think companies tend to hire managers because they're functional, right? You can get the job done right. You had experience in this thing for three to six years,\" said Jones, \"but they never really have the behavioral questions in there like, how do you manage your people and how do you manage the culture of your team?\"</p> \n<p>During the height of the COVID-19 pandemic and the fight for social justice, Jones was hiring managers and she looked for people who made concessions for their team, ones that weren't mandated by HR.</p> \n<p>\"How do you show up for somebody in a way that you may not have considered had you not gotten to know them a little bit more?\" she says.</p> \n<p>Managing people is a very delicate balancing act, adds Carlos, so it requires someone who can be vulnerable, create psychological safety, and show up for their team.</p> \n<p>\"Being able to bring out the best performance in them is a dance you have to learn to do each time,\" she says.</p> \n<p>So, how do you <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/empathy-leadership\">practice empathy</a>? It starts in your role. Look at how you speak to customers. Do you understand their struggles? Do you prioritize their needs?</p> \n<p>What about your peers, do you listen actively to their ideas and concerns? Do you ask questions to get to the root of their problems?</p> \n<p>These are all ways to lead with empathy before you step into a managerial role.</p> \n<h2>10. Know the bigger picture.</h2> \n<p>When you become a manager, your priorities take a backseat and the company's needs take the wheel.</p> \n<p>This requires understanding the company's broader strategy and investing in projects that align with them.</p> \n<p>It begs the question: Does your purpose align with your company's?</p> \n<p>That's why before you seek out that management role, LeValley recommends getting clear on your 'why.'</p> \n<p>\"If you ask me why I want to get promoted and why I want to become a manager, [the answer is] because before I retire, I want to be responsible for supporting 15 people from marginalized communities to senior manager level,\" she says. \"You can't argue with that answer.\"</p> \n<p>Once you identify your 'why,' mean it, voice it, and take action.</p> \n<p>\"I look for why they come to work, why they say the things that they do, why they support the decisions they support, why they speak up on behalf of others,\" LeValley says. \"If they do, I look a lot of what really motivates them, because if it's money, you're not my type of manager.\"</p> \n<p>For LeValley, your 'why' should go beyond yourself. It should be a desire to elevate others and support their success.</p> \n<p>A big red flag is me-statements.</p> \n<p>Phrases like: \"<em>I can do it but I don't see how this is going to get me noticed</em>,\" or personal success stories that don't mention anyone else.</p> \n<p>\"People that see the train heading off the tracks, and maybe they get off, but they don't bring anybody else with them,\" says LeValley.</p> \n<p>Carlos says another concern is someone focused on just hitting their own goals.</p> \n<p>\"It would be a little concerning if someone was not looking at things holistically, [saying things like] 'I hit like this metric of X tickets, therefore, I should be a manager,' she said. \"It's not just about that, there's a lot more to consider.\"</p> \n<p>She adds that you have to focus on empowering those around you.</p> \n<p>\"What the mindset shift for a manager is, how do you multiply your impact through these people and empower them, work through them, lead them toward this conclusion and this performance?\" says Carlos.</p> \n<h2>11. Learn and practice.</h2> \n<p>Who better to learn from than people who have done it before?</p> \n<p>You already know this, of course, that's why you're reading this article. But let's explore how our HubSpot managers learned and practiced leadership before they stepped into their roles.</p> \n<p>\"One of my mentors would say the call to leadership is a call to preparation,\" Simmons said. \"So, one of the things I would do, and I'm kind of maniacal about this, is read everything I could on leadership, watch videos, listen to talks.</p> \n<p>Simmons' favorite books on leadership include <a href=\"https://simonsinek.com/product/start-with-why/\">\"Start With Why\" by Simon Sinek</a>, \"<a href=\"https://thewisemangroup.com/books/multipliers/\">Multipliers\" by Liz Wiseman</a>, \"<a href=\"https://us.macmillan.com/books/9781250183866\">Extreme Ownership\" by Jocko Willink and Leif Babin</a>, and \"<a href=\"https://www.tablegroup.com/product/ideal-team-player/\">The Ideal Team Player\" by Patrick Lencioni</a>. Oh, and anything by <a href=\"https://www.johnmaxwell.com/\">John Maxwell</a>.</p> \n<p>Simmons also volunteered for leadership roles outside of his company.</p> \n<p>\"Following the 10,000-hour rule, I was spending two hours every Saturday for eight years, not only facilitating conversation within the group but also taking leadership roles, organizing community service projects,\" he says.</p> \n<p>\"[Part of that preparation] is volunteering out the time to become a better leader because again, you are a leader before you actually have the role.\"</p> \n<p>On her end, Ladd leaned on her colleagues who exhibited behaviors she wanted to replicate.</p> \n<p>\"Doing the work before you get there is so important,\" she says. \"For me, it was 'What's that thing Maggie does to ensure that folks feel psychologically safe in meetings?' I want to make sure I do that, too.\"</p> \n<p>She continued, \"How do you facilitate an in-depth conversation like Alex does and make sure that it's something that folks want to engage with?\"</p> \n<p>Learning from your peers is as valuable&nbsp;as learning from the greats. Once you learn the strategies, practice, practice, practice.</p> \n<h2>12. Network across.</h2> \n<p>One of the biggest missed opportunities you can make on your journey to becoming a manager is not connecting with your peers.</p> \n<p>LeValley recalls her own experience with this.</p> \n<p>\"I was in an environment where I was considerably older than the colleagues in my office and I wasn't into what they were into. So, I did a lot of separating myself because look, I'm here to do a job [and] I'm going to go to work,\" she says, \"but that wasn't good because I didn't receive feedback like 'Are you a fit?' That shouldn't matter, but it does. Are you a fit for management?\"</p> \n<p>She was trustworthy, professional, and capable, but one thing she hadn't thought about was the social aspect of being a manager.</p> \n<p>\"When we go out for beers as a management team, do we want you there? And I contrast that with my friend who doesn't drink at all, but they still wanted her there,\" LeValley adds. \"So it's not that you have to drink.\"</p> \n<p>Not only is networking important for getting that approval from your peers, but also getting to know them.</p> \n<p>\"One indication of a good manager is what they know individually about all the other people that they used to work with,\" Jones says. \"If you don't know much about them, like their individual working styles, then that tells me that you are managing them in a one-size-fits-all approach.\"</p> \n<p>Being a manager means understanding that it takes different tactics to manage different people. You'll only know what those are by getting to know everyone on a personal level.</p> \n<p>At the core of all these tips is a commitment to elevating those around you and being aligned with the company's needs.</p> \n<p>By using a combination of the tactics outlined above, you'll become a manager in no time – just as these five managers did.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5174aed9-1caa-4a36-b2d6-84c4d96c25fb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5174aed9-1caa-4a36-b2d6-84c4d96c25fb.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbe-a-good-manager&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 29 Jun 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png","linkMd5":"662dec0a3752c72c165c0eaa22330c8e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn16@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-38-375_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","destWidth":660,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":7430,"destBytes":10618,"author":"mbretous@hubspot.com (Martina Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn16@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-38-375_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5174aed9-1caa-4a36-b2d6-84c4d96c25fb.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn98@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-49-785_5d7cf3090735f322.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbe-a-good-manager&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn67@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-50-001_8083001f56e17333.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938151},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"10 Best Email Previewing, Testing, & Rendering Tools","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/free-email-preview-tools","description":"<p>You know the expression, <em>\"What you see is what you get\"</em>?</p> \n<p>Well, when it comes to email marketing campaigns, that might not always be the case.</p> \n<p>Since everyone uses different email providers such as Gmail, Outlook, or Yahoo, emails can appear differently for various subscribers.</p>  \n<p>Sometimes images are blocked, alt text is missing, or fonts won't render. If this happens, you could damage your credibility and lose subscribers. That's why it's important to test your emails before you send them.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=4d91cc7a-0d35-48ce-89af-31794c494de9&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Boost Opens &amp; CTRs with HubSpot’s Free Email Marketing Software\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4d91cc7a-0d35-48ce-89af-31794c494de9.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>In this post, we'll discuss the best free and paid email testing, previewing, and rendering tools you can use to make sure your emails are ready for the eyes of your leads and customers.</p> \n<p>Before we get started let's take a moment to review <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/plain-text-vs-html-emails-data\">HTML versus plain text emails</a> and previews.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>There are <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/plain-text-vs-html-emails-data\">benefits to both HTML and plain text emails</a> and specific use cases in which it's wise to use one option over the other.</p> \n<p>No matter which email type you choose, you should preview your emails to make sure they're ready for your audience. This is especially important if you go with an HTML email since it inherently includes multimedia elements, colors, fonts, branded elements, images, and more.</p> \n<h2>HTML Email Preview</h2> \n<p>As your HTML emails become more sophisticated and as your email list grows, it's important to preview and test your emails prior to them being sent to recipients. By previewing your messages, you'll ensure your emails are professional, error-free, easy-to-read, and ready for your leads and customers.</p> \n<p>An HTML preview allows you to adjust anything necessary prior to the final version being sent to your audience. That way, you can send your messages to the people who matter most — your customers — with complete confidence.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h4>Free Email Testing Tools</h4> \n<p>It's important to note that <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">the following free email <em>preview</em> tools are also free <em>email</em> testing tools</span>. Meaning, they have the ability to assist with email previews <em>and</em> email testing.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email-b\">HubSpot Email Marketing Tool</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.04.55%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.04.55%20PM.png\" alt=\"HubSpot Email Marketing Tool best email previewing, testing, and rendering tool\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>With HubSpot's Email Marketing Tools, you can create, personalize, and optimize all of your marketing emails without the need for any code or help from designers.</p> \n<p>Since this tool is part of your all-in-one HubSpot CRM platform, you'll know the data that you're using to customize your emails is accurate. For instance, personalize emails by referring to the recipient's lifecycle stage, membership status — then schedule your campaign so your customized emails are sent automatically.</p> \n<p>Pre-made and customizable email templates as well as the tool's drag-and-drop editor allow you to quickly create and send beautiful and professional emails to your recipient list. Lastly, A/B test different elements of your emails — such as subject lines or the time that you send your emails — to determine what works best for your audience.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.subjectline.com/\">SubjectLine.com</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.07.52%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.07.52%20PM.png\" alt=\"SubjectLine.com subject line email testing tool \" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Testing the visual design of your emails is important. However, don't forget to preview your actual content as well.</p> \n<p>With SubjectLine.com, you can test your subject lines and receive a free rating out of 100. The tool considers the total length, word length, urgency, and more.</p> \n<p>Word choice matters in your subject lines and this tool will help you come up with more clickable subjects so your readers are more likely to open.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://mailninja.co.uk/email-previewer\">MailNinja Email Previewer</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.09.24%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.09.24%20PM.png\" alt=\"MailNinja Email Previewer email tool\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>MailNinja is a free, easy-to-use, uncluttered email preview tool. With this tool, you can see instant previews of your HTML emails. Additionally, you can double-check your alt text, send test emails, and see how your email will look on different devices.</p> \n<p>If you don't trust or want to use a different preview tool than your email marketing software, this is a simple, free option.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://inboxanalyzer.io/features\">Inbox Analyzer</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.13.15%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.13.15%20PM.png\" alt=\"Inbox Analyzer free email preview tool\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Inbox Analyzer, another free email preview tool, helps take the pain out of inbox and spam testing your emails.</p> \n<p>Send your emails to the most popular inbox providers to see how they appear and if they deliver — this tool will let you know if your email hits the inbox, spam folder, or is undelivered.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you'll receive instant reports on your sender scores, reputation alerts, and even blacklists. With this tool, you'll be able to find issues and learn how to resolve them.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://putsmail.com/\">PutsMail</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.14.19%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.14.19%20PM.png\" alt=\"PutsMail html free email testing tool by litmus\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>PutsMail is a free email testing tool by Litmus. With PutsMail, you can see how your email will look across 50+ different platforms and devices. This is a great tool if you're just looking for a quick and easy way to preview your emails.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.getresponse.com/\">Get Response</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.16.28%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.16.28%20PM.png\" alt=\"get response email marketing software and email previewing and testing tool\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Price: $15/mo (Basic), $49/mo (Plus), $99/mo (Professional), request custom pricing (Max)</span></p> \n<p>Get Response is an email marketing software that can help you create content, boost sales, and increase traffic to your site. Preview your emails in more than 25 popular email clients, and determine if and when multimedia elements like images are blocked.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.litmus.com/email-testing/\">Litmus</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.18.13%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.18.13%20PM.png\" alt=\"litmus email preview and testing tool\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Price: $99/mo (Litmus Basic), $199/mo (Litmus Plus), request custom pricing (Litmus Enterprise) </span></p> \n<p>Litmus is a tool for testing and developing email campaigns. With a paid account, you'll gain access to an email preview testing tool that allows you to see screenshots of your emails across 90+ different apps and devices.</p> \n<p>If you have a Litmus account, you can add a Chrome extension to your browser and test your emails without ever leaving your email service provider. With the extension, you can validate your links, images, and tracking. Plus, the extension will instantly run a new checklist with every edit.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://stripo.email/\">Stripo</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.25.36%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.25.36%20PM.png\" alt=\"stripo email templates, email testing, and dynamic AMP email building tool\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Price: Free, $12.50/mo (Business), $40/mo (Agency)</span></p> \n<p>Stripo is an email builder with email testing and a variety of available email service provider (ESP) integrations (including HubSpot, Gmail, Outlook, and Mailchimp). There's a library of custom modules so you can use them across various campaigns.</p> \n<p>All of the emails you design with Stripo's HTML editor are responsive so you'll never have to worry about how they render for recipients across different devices. Additionally, after building dynamic AMP emails with Stripo, the tool's code validator checks the email for errors for you.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://previewmyemail.com/\">Preview My Email</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.27.42%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.27.42%20PM.png\" alt=\"Preview My Email email testing tool\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Price: $25/mo (Standard), $45/mo (Business), $160/mo (Professional), $399/mo (Enterprise)</span></p> \n<p>Preview My Email is another email testing solution that can help you improve your performance. With it, you'll get real screenshots of your email across all the popular email providers in one click. Additionally, this tool offers email analytics that can help you understand your email audience better.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://www.emailonacid.com/email-previews/\">Email on Acid</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.31.35%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.31.35%20PM.png\" alt=\"email on acid email testing tool\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Price: $73/mo (The Basics), $112/mo (Premium), $424/mo (Professional), request custom pricing (Enterprise)</span></p> \n<p>Email on Acid is an email preview tool designed to help you display emails properly, across all clients. The email previews are live clients, so you'll see exactly what your subscribers see.</p> \n<p>This tool gives you screenshots so you have no questions about what your email will look like on 90 clients and devices. It also tests for poor formatting, broken links, and code problems.</p> \n<p>Email on Acid also offers the ability to comment, edit, and review email previews directly in the software for a faster and more efficient testing process.</p> \n<h2>Start Previewing, Testing, and Rendering Your Emails</h2> \n<p>Previewing your emails is an important part of email marketing. If people can't see your emails or your credibility is ruined, those emails haven't done their job. Use an email previewing and testing tool to ensure they're perfect for recipients.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in June 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=9b0b29cd-26b5-4604-bd6f-11b038928e74&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9b0b29cd-26b5-4604-bd6f-11b038928e74.png\"></a></em></p>  \n<img \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 01 Jul 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4d91cc7a-0d35-48ce-89af-31794c494de9.png","linkMd5":"646269f743d7eb47e7901ff4457a57fb","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn35@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-38-563_845a7172d026d707.webp","destWidth":615,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":6710,"destBytes":9638,"author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4d91cc7a-0d35-48ce-89af-31794c494de9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn35@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-38-563_845a7172d026d707.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.04.55%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.04.55%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn63@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-52-385_257f18a73390b4ae.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.07.52%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.07.52%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn22@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-50-620_f3930588b33c6afb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.09.24%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.09.24%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn23@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-49-472_869650a6c3316748.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.13.15%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.13.15%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn66@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-48-950_ac96e07901b287d6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.14.19%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.14.19%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn77@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-51-234_702099394bddf85f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.16.28%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.16.28%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn76@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-52-023_77738e7dc1b15516.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.18.13%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.18.13%20PM.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.25.36%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.25.36%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn17@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-51-230_36865d79de49cbc9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.27.42%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.27.42%20PM.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.31.35%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-05-31%20at%209.31.35%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn69@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-50-991_22ec4cc22c8b4fb6.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9b0b29cd-26b5-4604-bd6f-11b038928e74.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn28@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-50-210_81deda6441965465.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffree-email-preview-tools&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938123},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"What is Brand Salience? [+How Do You Measure It?]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-salience","description":"<p>While branding can feel like a vague concept, it's one of the most important elements of a marketing strategy.</p> \n<p>Did you know that presenting a brand consistently across all platforms can <a href=\"https://www.smallbizgenius.net/by-the-numbers/branding-statistics/\">increase revenue by up to 23%</a>?</p> \n<p>Plus, consistently presented brands are <a href=\"https://www.smallbizgenius.net/by-the-numbers/branding-statistics/\">3.5 times more likely</a> to have excellent brand visibility than those with inconsistent branding.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>In fact, <a href=\"https://www.smallbizgenius.net/by-the-numbers/branding-statistics/\">82% of investors</a> say name recognition is an important factor guiding them in their investment decisions.</p> \n<p>So, what does all this mean? Well, consistent branding leads to increased brand awareness which can then help gain investors and drive revenue to your business. Needless to say, branding is important for your business to succeed.</p> \n<p>In this post, let's review what brand salience is, how you can increase your brand visibility, and how to measure it.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=814dd420-0d49-40e0-b59c-f01066e186c1&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Free Brand Building Guide\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/814dd420-0d49-40e0-b59c-f01066e186c1.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>If you have high brand salience, then you have a strong brand presence that consumers recognize and think about when they need a product. If you have low brand salience, then consumers might not know your brand exists and therefore won't think of your brand when they need to make a purchase.</p> \n<p>Essentially, brand salience is a similar metric as <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-awareness\">brand awareness</a> except it's focused on measuring awareness during the actual purchasing decision instead of overall brand visibility.</p> \n<p>For example, when someone wants to get a cup of coffee and is driving around, what's the first brand they think of? Probably Starbucks. When they want to buy tissues, they think of Kleenex. When they want to search for something online, they Google it.</p> \n<p>All of these brands have transcended the perception of being a random company, and are now household names in their own right. Most people think of these brands and know of them whether they've been there or used those products before.</p> \n<p>These brands have high brand salience. To have high brand salience, your customers need to think about your brand as the first solution to their wants or needs when they have to make a purchasing decision.</p> \n<p>The concept of brand salience is actually psychological in nature. According to <a href=\"https://www.marketingscience.info/wp-content/uploads/staff/2015/08/9419.pdf\">research</a> done by Jenni Romaniuk and Byron Sharp, brand salience is \"a brand's propensity to be noticed or come to mind in buying situations.\"</p> \n<p>This means that you have to capture people's attention and be memorable enough for consumers to recall your brand when they're purchasing something.</p> \n<p>For example, when a consumer has a choice of brands to purchase from, they'll rely both on their memory and attention salience. This means they'll recall brands they know and then see what captures their attention.</p> \n<p>This process is actually scientific. People who have studied brand salience have studied the human brain -- how do people recall information and how does a brand associate positive memory structure with their product?</p> \n<p>To increase your brand salience, some of your marketing campaigns probably won't even focus on persuading consumers to buy your product. The goal of many <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/branding\">branding</a> campaigns is to constantly reinforce positive associations with your brand. Familiarity is important. Constant marketing messages from a brand ensure that the brand is top-of-mind when a consumer is making a purchasing decision.</p> \n<p>Brands create high brand salience by using distinctive brand assets that capture attention and create positive memories for their audience. This means your marketing assets promote positive storytelling and create a meaning associated with your brand. When you promote your values, you're differentiating your brand from the competition and increasing brand salience.</p> \n<p>To create campaigns that will improve brand salience, think about the emotional impact of your assets. Your campaigns should be meaningful, authentic, and portray your values as a company.</p> \n<p>All of this will help customers create a positive association with your brand and remember your brand when it comes time to make a purchase.</p> \n<p>For example, let's say I want to buy some gum. When I think about gum, one of the first things I think of are the commercials for <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NemtQx0m0Ss\">Extra</a>. I've never forgotten those commercials because they were emotional and created a positive experience for me.</p> \n<p>Now, when I think about gum, I usually buy Extra even though that brand has never been my favorite gum company (I used to buy Orbit). But since those commercials, I've leaned toward Extra because of the positive association and it's one of the first brands I recall because of those commercials.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, brand salience is a combination of brand awareness, familiarity, relevance, frequent communication, and emotional connections between brand and consumer.</p> \n<p>Now, you might be thinking,<em> \"This all sounds great, but how can I measure this and prove its effectiveness to my managers?\"</em></p> \n<p>Let's dive into that below.</p> \n<h2>How to Measure Brand Salience</h2> \n<p>Brand salience is rather conceptual in nature. Unfortunately, it's not a mathematical metric that is easily measured. So, what do brands do?</p> \n<p>Well, one of the only ways to <a href=\"https://www.marketingscience.info/wp-content/uploads/staff/2015/08/9419.pdf\">measure brand salience</a> is through surveys and focus groups. It's important to ask your customers when they think of you, what they associate with your brand, and if they recall your company when making a purchasing decision.</p> \n<p>You can ask customers whether they recall or notice your brand relative to competitors. Then, ask whether your brand is just thought of or sought after to determine how favorably your brand is judged.</p> \n<p>Your survey can include descriptive assets to track your brand's distinctive assets. For instance, what tone of voice, logo, color, or slogan comes to mind when users think of soda. They might say red, because they've associated Coca-Cola branding with soda in general.</p> \n<p>To measure this, you can present survey respondents with a randomized list of cues and attributes by asking them which brands they associate with each statement. It could be questions like \"when I want to eat something quick and healthy\" or \"I know I will not overpay there.\"</p> \n<p>Using a survey or focus group will help you determine how high your brand salience is compared to competitors.</p> \n<p>Now, let's look at the brand salience model that you can use to strategize your brand positioning.</p> \n<h2>Brand Salience Model</h2> \n<p>In his book, <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Strategic-Brand-Management-Building-Measuring-dp-0134892496/dp/0134892496/ref=dp_ob_title_bk\">Strategic Brand Management: Building, Measuring, and Managing Brand Equity</a>, Kevin Keller developed a model for brand salience that has become popular in digital marketing.</p> \n<p>In the graphic below, Keller creates a pyramid of building blocks to pay attention to when you're trying to increase your brand salience.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Keller's brand resonance model\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Brand%20Salience%3F%20%5B+How%20Do%20You%20Measure%20It%3F%5D.png?width=624&amp;name=What%20is%20Brand%20Salience%3F%20%5B+How%20Do%20You%20Measure%20It%3F%5D.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Strategic-Brand-Management-Building-Measuring-dp-0134892496/dp/0134892496/ref=dp_ob_title_bk\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>This model focuses on increasing deep, broad brand awareness by creating an identity that customers remember. At the foundation of the pyramid is salience, which you can increase by defining your brand in detail, frequently communicating with your audience, and using creative assets to tell a story.</p> \n<p>Then, you create meaning and authenticity to differentiate your brand from the competition. And then, you use frequent messages to create positive, accessible reactions in your customers. And then you create loyalty by building a relationship and emotional connection with your audience.</p> \n<p>With this model, you can increase brand salience, drive revenue, and even attract investors. Although this isn't the easiest metric to track, the science proves that focusing on branding will help your company become a household name for your customers.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=ddbf2eb7-04e8-44b2-9e05-b21264e09b65&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"brand consistency\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddbf2eb7-04e8-44b2-9e05-b21264e09b65.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbrand-salience&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\"
