Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Is%20SMS%20Marketing%20Dead%3F%20New%20Data%20Says%20Maybe%20Not.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn19@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-38-492_db96ded43df7533e.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/c1b4a8fb-6392-4143-b13c-fc0e3be221e1.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Is%20SMS%20Marketing%20Dead%3F%20New%20Data%20Says%20Maybe%20Not-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn29@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-50-688_03087bc69977613a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Is%20SMS%20Marketing%20Dead%3F%20New%20Data%20Says%20Maybe%20Not-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn6@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-49-798_5664ccfa7347654d.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/27a0c42e-ac29-4f9a-8b46-23bf884ee76b.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn47@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-52-358_ac8bd14c17387117.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fis-sms-marketing-dead&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn16@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-50-166_5cc2fc454a23576e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938151},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"8 of the Top Marketing Challenges Faced Globally [New Data + Expert Tips]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33820/5-major-challenges-marketers-face-and-how-to-solve-them.aspx","description":"<p>Every marketer faces different challenges. Although we typically share similar goals, some teams are stuck on hiring top talent, while others are having trouble finding the right technology for their needs.</p>  \n<p>Whatever the case may be, there's always at least one area you can improve to turn your marketing into an even more effective revenue generator.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>But marketing is often fast-paced, so it can be difficult to identify which areas you'll want to develop to facilitate stronger growth in 2021 and beyond. For that reason, it's important to pause for a moment and reflect on the biggest challenges marketers feel they're going to face this year.</p> \n<p>Why? Because problems are much easier to tackle once you've correctly identified them.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>So ... what's happening in 2021?</p> \n<p>Below, let's review the current global marketing issues impacting the industry, according to marketing experts.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: State of Marketing in 2021 Report\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Biggest Marketing Challenges [New Data]</h2> \n<p>To start, I surveyed over 120 marketers to gauge the biggest challenges affecting the industry as a whole.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/biggest%20challenges%20for%20marketers%202021.png?width=1080&amp;name=biggest%20challenges%20for%20marketers%202021.png\" alt=\"biggest challenges for marketers 2021\" width=\"1080\" style=\"width: 1080px;\">By far, \"Generating traffic and leads\" was marked by nearly half as the biggest challenge marketers are facing this year.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>This challenge was followed by 21% who said \"providing ROI for your marketing activities\" was their biggest challenge.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>\"Delivering an account-based marketing strategy\" (8%), \"securing enough budget\" (6%), and \"managing your website\" (5%) were the other three notable challenges marketers feel they're facing in 2021.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>It's important to note, a few other marketers marked \"targeting content for an international audience\", \"training your team\", and \"hiring top talent\" as their top challenge ... but these three challenges were marked by less than 3% of the respondent pool, so they're less statistically significant.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Let's dive into these in more detail, along with expert tips to combat these challenges, next.&nbsp;</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">1. Generating Traffic and Leads</h3> \n<p>Generating enough traffic and leads is the top global marketing challenge in 2021, according to the data mentioned above.</p> \n<p>HubSpot's new <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\">State of Marketing report</a> supports this — in fact, \"Generating more leads\" is the top priority of marketers in 2021.&nbsp;</p> \n<h4>Why It's a Challenge</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/thejohnalee/\">John Lee</a>, Head of Evangelism at <a href=\"https://ads.microsoft.com/\">Microsoft Advertising</a>, believes that generating leads will be a particularly big challenge for marketers in 2021. He told me, \"Getting quality traffic isn't a challenge today, and likely won't be tomorrow. There has been growth in search and content marketing in 2021. New channels continue to surface and show promise, too (TikTok or audio chat rooms anyone?).\"</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"Through the 2nd half of 2021 and beyond, the challenges will lie elsewhere – maintain and growing leads or sales, tracking and scaling, etc.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Lee adds, \"'Sea change' is the phrase that comes to mind for the state of digital marketing today. Change in the realm of <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/data-privacy/gdpr\">privacy</a>, identity, and changes to cookies. Change in the form of lost data clarity (will cookie-based conversion tracking continue to work, GA4, access to search queries, etc.). And all of this sits within the context of change to how and where we work and economies in flux as the world continues to move through the pandemic.\"</p> \n<p>Fortunately, privacy changes doesn't mean the end of generating leads — it simply means learning how to re-think strategy. As Lee told me, \"To weather this storm of change, marketers need to be vigilant in monitoring and understanding industry-wide acceptance of privacy protocols and updates to search, social, and display/native platforms (consumer-side and marketing/advertising-side). And last, but not least — lean into the power of peer support and networking for sharing best practices and learning.\"</p> \n<p>Additionally, marketers are struggling with producing enough demand for their content. And as the years progress and competition stiffens, this will only become truer. With so many options of platforms for marketers to publish their content and even more ways to promote it, it's hard to know where to focus your efforts.</p> \n<h4>What Can You Do?</h4> \n<p>When it comes to creating content that produces enough traffic and leads, marketers should ask themselves two questions: Are you truly creating high-quality content — the type of content people would <em>pay</em> for? And, do you know the type of content your audience actually wants?</p> \n<p>For instance, when asked how they’d most like to learn about a product or service in 2021, <a href=\"https://www.wyzowl.com/video-marketing-statistics/\">69% said they’d prefer to watch a short video</a> over a text-based article, infographic, or ebook. This means, if most of your product-related content is in ebook format, you could be missing out on the majority of consumers who prefer video.</p> \n<p>Additionally, the length of videos produced by businesses is increasing. In fact, the number of videos in the 30-60 minute category grew 140% in 2021, compared to 2019 — suggesting that long-form video content is becoming a more popular option for companies.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>To ensure you're creating content that resonates best with your audience, you'll want to refer to analytics often. Use effective tools to properly track the types of content that performs best with your audience to generate more leads in 2021.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Additionally, once you know you're creating the <em>type</em> of content your audience wants, the focus shifts to promoting it in a way that makes your audience take notice.</p> \n<p>More than ever before, people are being flooded with content. Consumers don't have to use a search engine to find answers. Instead, articles fill their news feed or buzz in their pocket via mobile notifications. To keep up, consider exploring alternate distribution methods — like social media or podcasting — to increase brand awareness.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">2. Providing the ROI of Your Marketing Activities</h3> \n<p>Measuring the ROI (return on investment) of your marketing activities has remained a top marketing challenge globally year-over-year.</p> \n<p>In fact, when asked how confident marketers are when making budgeting decisions to invest in programs that influence revenue, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\">roughly half (48%) said they were only somewhat confident</a>.</p> \n<p>It continues to be a vital way for marketers to understand the effectiveness of each particular marketing campaign or piece of content.</p> \n<p>Plus, proving ROI often goes hand-in-hand with making an argument to increase budget: No ROI tracking, no demonstrable ROI. No ROI, no budget.</p> \n<h4>Why It's a Challenge</h4> \n<p>Although return on investment is a crucial stat that shows your campaigns success or progress, tracking the ROI of every single marketing activity isn't always easy, especially if you don't have two-way communication between your marketing activities and sales reports.</p> \n<h4>What Can You Do?</h4> \n<p>Providing ROI often comes down to using effective analytics measurement tools. For instance, <a href=\"https://www.beautiful.ai/\">Beautiful.ai</a> Director of Marketing <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/kimgiroux\">Kim Giroux</a> told me, \"Marketers are constantly challenged to illustrate the ROI of their efforts and 2021 is no exception. Proving ROI doesn't always have to mean extra work or effort though. In fact, certain technologies bake ROI into existing work processes.\"</p> \n<p>Giroux adds, \"Take presentation software, for instance. Savvy marketers today can create and use pitch decks with built-in presentation analytics that offer real-time data — such as how much time was spent viewing individual slides. Armed with these insights, marketers can better gauge stakeholder interest, inform their strategies, and adjust their campaigns.\"</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/christinamautz/\">Christina Mautz</a>, CMO of <a href=\"https://moz.com/\">Moz</a>, believes measuring ROI comes down to redefining the marketing process as a whole. She told me, \"My biggest challenge, and one all marketers face in providing ROI, is the prospect of meeting traditional KPIs in the modern workspace.\"</p> \n<p>Mautz says, \"Instead of leads and trade show success, marketing wins are now largely digital: engaging prospects and generating more clicks, downloads, and page visits.\"</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>CMO of Moz Christina Mautz says, \"To better measure marketing progress, we have to redefine the marketing process, encouraging collaboration with sales and reaching KPIs together.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>\"For example, statistics such as page visits per sale or rising higher in the search engine results page (SERP) give marketers and SEOs tangible evidence as to how their work is meeting their ROI. New buying patterns and a customer-centric world require a divergence from the old, but measuring ROI will look far different than it did before and some leaders may not understand how or why.\"</p> \n<p>When it comes to providing ROI, there's a strong case to be made for dedicating time and resources to establishing links between marketing activities and sales results. This means using both marketing software (<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/demo\">like HubSpot</a>) and a CRM solution (<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/crm\">like HubSpot's free CRM</a>), and then tying them together to close the loop between your marketing and sales efforts with a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-align-create-an-effective-sla#sm.00000wq1gwz9o4dk0qqexui71uyd0\">service-level agreement (SLA)</a>. That way, you can directly see how many leads and customers are generated through your marketing activities.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">3. Securing Enough Budget</h3> \n<p>How can you create a winning marketing campaign without a budget? The truth is, it's pretty hard. But, even when you have a great, revenue-generating idea, you still usually need to get your budget approved by a higher-up.</p> \n<p>Particularly in the aftermath of the global pandemic, some companies don't have the means to increase marketing budgets in 2021. As a result, marketers are faced with the challenge of achieving high levels of growth with minimal financial support.&nbsp;</p> \n<h4>Why It's a Challenge</h4> \n<p>Securing more budget is a pressing challenge for marketing globally. And often, getting more budget is easier said than done — especially for smaller organizations that aren't working with sizable or flexible marketing spend.</p> \n<p>But the key to securing more money for your team might not be that complex. Here's what you can do.</p> \n<h4>What Can You Do?</h4> \n<p>The key to unlocking budget lies in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/measure-content-marketing-roi\">being able to prove the ROI</a> of your marketing efforts. According to our report, organizations that can calculate ROI are more likely to receive higher budgets.</p> \n<p>Again, success with inbound marketing also plays a large role in driving higher budgets. Effective strategies obviously produce results and make a strong case for increasing budget. But remember, inbound marketing is a long game. If you get off to a slow start, you shouldn’t back off — in fact, you might consider doubling down.</p> \n<p>To learn more about how to understand and leverage marketing ROI, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/measure-content-marketing-roi\">check out this simple guide</a>.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">4. Managing Your Website</h3> \n<p>In 2021, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\">64% of companies are investing</a> in website upgrades.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Although managing a website is consistently a challenge to marketers, it seems to be growing less threatening. In the data mentioned above, only 5% of marketers listed \"managing your website\" as a top challenge.&nbsp;</p> \n<h4>Why It's Still a Challenge</h4> \n<p>Chances are, your website's performance is high on your list of priorities — particularly since website speed and performance <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo\">plays a major role in your website's SEO ranking</a>. It's an asset that works around the clock to draw in visitors, convert them, and help you hit your goals.</p> \n<p>Issues with website management include a variety of different factors, from writing and optimizing the content to designing beautiful webpages. Here are a few things marketers can do to deal with this challenge.</p> \n<h4>What Can You Do?</h4> \n<p>First, try <a href=\"https://website.grader.com/\">HubSpot's free website grader</a> to determine how your website stacks up on key metrics including SEO, mobile, and security performance — and how you can improve it.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>If your primary challenge with managing a website has to do with the skills and resources you have available, you aren't alone. This is especially true for small companies who don't have all the talent in-house required to cover content, optimization, design, and back-end website management.</p> \n<p>One solution? Hire freelancers and agency partners. To find freelancers, we recommend:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Tapping into your personal and professional network by posting on LinkedIn, Facebook, and other social networks with a description of what you're looking for.</li> \n <li>Browsing freelance writers and designers based on their portfolios and areas of interest. For writers, check out <a href=\"https://www.zerys.com/\">Zerys</a> and <a href=\"http://contently.net/\">Contently</a>. For designers, check out <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/\">Behance</a> &amp; <a href=\"https://www.elance.com/\">Elance</a>.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://app.hubspot.com/partner-directory/;jsessionid=16w0dtkne8pjl3qimryihk9j2\">Browsing HubSpot's Services Marketplace</a>, which lists a wide variety of designers from partner companies and agencies we've deemed credible.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Overall, you can make website management easier on your team by hosting your website on a platform that integrates all your marketing channels like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/content-optimization-system\">HubSpot's COS</a>.</p> \n<p>Finally, for the projects you want to keep in-house, here is a list of ebooks and guides that might be helpful to your team:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Run a <a href=\"https://website.grader.com/?__hstc=20629287.dd1bbe67148d2f1e02268291e8e05f46.1486135094155.1494633014128.1494794833458.380&amp;__hssc=20629287.7.1494794833458&amp;__hsfp=1612135321\">Website Grader</a> report</li> \n <li>Ebook: <a href=\"https://modassicmarketing.com/resource/website-redesign-guide\">Website Redesign Guide</a></li> \n <li>Ebook: <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/website-design-homepage-examples\">77 Brilliant Homepage Design Examples</a></li> \n <li>Ebook: <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-optimize-landing-pages-for-conversion?_ga=2.160828724.822469501.1494796402-798140974.1486135114\">How to Design and Optimize Landing Pages</a></li> \n <li>Blog: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/increase-website-traffic\">27 Ways to Drive Traffic to Your Website</a></li> \n <li>Ebook: <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/redesigning-your-website\">The Ultimate Workbook for Redesigning Your Website</a></li> \n <li>Ebook: <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketers-guide-to-mobile?_ga=2.206558609.327895349.1494796588-798140974.1486135114https://offers.hubspot.com/marketers-guide-to-mobile?_ga=2.206558609.327895349.1494796588-798140974.1486135114The%20Marketer's%20Guide%20to%20Mobile\">The Marketer's Guide to Mobile</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">5. Targeting Content for an International Audience</h3> \n<p>Targeting is a key component of all aspects of marketing.</p> \n<p>With <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\">65% of marketers currently marketing internationally</a>, and at least one-third of marketers planning to initiate an international strategy in 2021, it's important to have an international strategy.</p> \n<p>To be more effective at targeting, one of the first things any marketer needs do is <a title=\"identify their buyer personas\" href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/persona-templates?_ga=2.212494036.15433278.1494794859-798140974.1486135114\">identify their buyer personas </a>to determine to whom they should be marketing.</p> \n<h4>Why It's a Challenge</h4> \n<p>If you're expanding internationally, it can be a big challenge not only to figure out the best ways to market to an international audience, but also how to to organize and optimize your site for different countries.</p> \n<p>Here are a few other top challenges when marketing internationally:&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-06-14%20at%204.53.46%20PM.png?width=1218&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-06-14%20at%204.53.46%20PM.png\" alt=\"challenges marketers face with international marketing\" width=\"1218\" style=\"width: 1218px;\"><span style=\"font-size: 11px; font-style: italic;\"><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<h4>What Can You Do?</h4> \n<p>Download our free ebook, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/global-marketing-playbook\">The Global Marketing Playbook.</a> There are some really helpful tips in there that'll help give you some direction on global marketing, including how to identify your top three growth markets, how to explore local trends, and tips on choosing the best localization providers.</p> \n<p>Additionally, <a href=\"https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hubfs/53/tools/state-of-marketing/PDFs/Not%20Another%20State%20of%20Marketing%20Report%20-%20Web%20Version.pdf\">when marketing to a new region, the most common tactic marketers use is to shift their product offering</a>.</p> \n<p>Remember, your website visitors might speak a plethora of different languages and live in totally different time zones.</p> \n<p>To make your content appealing to a wide audience, you'll need to keep your global visitors top-of-mind when creating all your content. This means being aware of seasonal references, translating units of measure and monetary references, and giving translators the tools and permissions to customize and adapt content for a specific audience when they need to.</p> \n<p>When in doubt, solve for local or cultural challenges by hiring locally. With a newly hybrid workforce, physical location is no longer a limit to who you can hire.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Finally, be sure you're optimizing your website for international visitors, too. For more SEO-related tips and resources on global marketing expansion, take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-seo-varies-around-the-world\">How SEO is Different Around the World, According to HubSpot Content Strategists</a>.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">6. Training Your Team</h3> \n<p>As companies scale and technologies continue to evolve, training your team will become a greater challenge for marketers.</p> \n<h4>Why It's a Challenge</h4> \n<p>Whether it's training them on the concepts and tools they'll be using every day or making sure they're achieving their full potential, the struggle is real across the board.</p> \n<p>To combat this, I’ll share some tips I’ve used during my trainings to make sure the concepts and tool tips stick and have a lasting effect on your team and your marketing.</p> \n<h4>What Can You Do?</h4> \n<p>To get an overall idea of where your team stands, take a few minutes to assess each of your team members' marketing strengths and weaknesses, levels of expertise, and passion/commitment to your company.</p> \n<p>Then, objectively rate the priority (or level of importance) of their expertise and their contribution to bottom line objectives (ROI) to date. <a href=\"https://www.lean-labs.com/marketing-team-evaluation\">Here's a simple assessment tool from Lean Labs</a> to help you evaluate your team so you can figure out who needs recognition and who needs coaching.</p> \n<p>You also might consider requiring your team members to rack up some online marketing certification. <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/\">HubSpot Academy</a>, for example, offers certifications, documentation, and training programs to help people master the basics of inbound marketing. Google also offers training and certifications on analytics with their online <a href=\"https://analyticsacademy.withgoogle.com/explorer\">Analytics Academy</a>.</p> \n<p>What about new hire training, specifically? We recommend creating a training plan for new team members. Here at HubSpot, each new marketer is given a document to lay out specific goals and help new hires demonstrate their effectiveness. To create your own 30, 60, or 90 day plan for new hires, take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/30-60-90-day-plan\">The 30-60-90 Day Plan: Your Guide for Mastering a New Job [Template + Example]</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">7. Hiring Top Talent</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/content/dam/business/talent-solutions/global/en_us/c/pdfs/Ultimate-List-of-Hiring-Stats-v02.04.pdf\">Hiring top talent</a> is another challenge marketers commonly report experiencing.</p> \n<h4>Why It's a Challenge</h4> \n<p>Many companies are shifting more resources to inbound marketing, which means higher and higher demand for top marketing talent. But supply simply isn't keeping up. From sourcing the right candidates to evaluating for the right skills, finding the perfect person could take months ... or more.</p> \n<p>What's more, the type of marketing talent companies are looking for is changing, too. According to a <a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/talent-solutions/blog/trends-and-research/2020/most-in-demand-hard-and-soft-skills\">2020 report from LinkedIn</a>, employers are seeking marketers with soft creative skill sets as well as hard technical skills. And the quick rate at which the demand for these jobs are rising has caused a marketing skills gap, \"making it difficult to find candidates with the technical, creative, and business proficiencies needed to succeed in digital marketing.\"</p> \n<h4>What Can You Do?</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/stefaniegrieser/\">Stefanie Grieser</a>, co-founder of <a href=\"https://www.shinebootcamp.com/\">Shine Bootcamp</a>, a professional speaker accelerator for women, understands the challenge of hiring top talent.</p> \n<p>She told me, \"When I talk to high-growth companies or marketing agencies (and the marketers running those teams), I've found that hiring not only top talent, but <em>diverse</em> top talent is extremely challenging. In fact, I was just having a conversation with an agency owner who hires SEO and paid marketers, and he told me, 'Hiring is still the biggest challenge we face.'\"</p> \n<p>In 2021, hiring talent can be incredibly difficult — particularly as more companies become competitive with 4-day work weeks, transparent salaries on job descriptions, and the adoption of remote work, which enables companies to hire anywhere. <br><br>Fortunately, Grieser provided me with a few tips for employers to stand out from the crowd. She told me, \"My suggestion here is for marketers to invest heavily in their employer brand for the long-term. Just like you need to market your product, you also need to dedicate resources, time and energy into marketing your company as an employer.\"</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/biggest%20marketing%20challenges%202021.png?width=1104&amp;name=biggest%20marketing%20challenges%202021.png\" alt=\"biggest marketing challenges 2021 is hiring top talent\" width=\"1104\" style=\"width: 1104px;\">Grieser adds, \"I would suggest <a href=\"https://www.diversifytech.co/\">Diversity Tech Co</a>, <a href=\"https://www.hiretechladies.com/\">Tech Ladies</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.girlboss.com/\">Girlboss</a> as go-to resources to post jobs. These organizations are run by incredible individuals who really care about diversity, equity, inclusion and intersectionality. I'm also seeing niche communities and job boards pop up. For marketers specifically, I would post your open roles here: <a href=\"https://dgmgjobs.com/\">Dave Gerhardt Marketing Group</a>, <a href=\"https://heymarketers.com/\">Hey Marketers</a>, and <a href=\"https://jobs.superpath.co/\">Superpath</a> (which is focused on content marketers specifically).\"<br><br>While it might seem random to discuss employer branding in a post about marketing challenges, it isn't — since it's often the marketing team that cultivates a strong employer brand. <br><br>As Grieser points out, \"Airbnb has an <a href=\"https://airbnb.io/\">Engineering and Data Science blog</a>, Intercom has an <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/intercombrandstudio/\">Instagram</a> dedicated to their design team, and Dooly posts short, LinkedIn posts (see an example <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6803806600764252160/\">here</a>) interviewing their fun team with a few fun hashtags #doolydreamteam and #meetadooligan.\"</p> \n<p>\"Guess who leads this initiative? The marketing team. Think about how you and your team can showcase your work and your team's work. I won't try to assume that employer brand falls solely in your court, but as a marketer, you have natural skills that will lend themselves to marketing the company as whole.\"</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/content/dam/business/talent-solutions/global/en_us/c/pdfs/Ultimate-List-of-Hiring-Stats-v02.04.pdf\">LinkedIn data from 2020 </a>shows that 87% of active and passive job candidates will consider new job opportunities. Additionally, the number one reason candidates will consider or accept a job is career growth. This means that job listings and a company culture that offers employees a plan for growth will see the most interest from talent.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">8. Delivering an Account-Based Marketing Strategy</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-guide\">Account-based marketing (ABM)</a> is a new trend, which is a growth strategy in which marketing and sales collaborate to create a personalized buying experience for an identified set of accounts.</p> \n<p>However, interestingly, <a href=\"https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hubfs/53/tools/state-of-marketing/PDFs/Not%20Another%20State%20of%20Marketing%20Report%20-%20Web%20Version.pdf\">the most common challenge with ABM is delivering a personalized experience</a>.</p> \n<h4>Why It's a Challenge</h4> \n<p>Currently, there isn't a lot of software that's focused on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-automation\">account-based marketing</a>. Many companies that are implementing ABM strategies are using manual methods, which means some accounts are getting lost in the cracks.</p> \n<p>However,<a href=\"https://www.forrester.com/report/Forrester+Infographic+ABM+Maturity+Corresponds+To+Better+Revenue+Results/-/E-RES157155\"> marketers strongly agree that personalized content (56%) and advanced data management (43%) are keys to ABM's success</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-06-14%20at%205.26.18%20PM.png?width=479&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-06-14%20at%205.26.18%20PM.png\" alt=\"challenges marketers face with ABM\" width=\"479\" style=\"width: 479px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h4>What Can You Do?</h4> \n<p>To deliver a more personalized experience, you should use a software that helps you combine your sales and marketing information.</p> \n<p>For example, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/abm-software\">HubSpot's ABM software </a>help unite your marketing and sales teams with collaborative, intuitive ABM tools that create seamless buying experiences for your highest-value accounts.</p> \n<p>This software can enable collaboration among teams and personalize content.</p> \n<p>Additionally, HubSpot's software has account-level targeting added to the LinkedIn Ads integration, giving you the ability to target companies by target account status or tier, and contacts or subsets of contacts at target accounts.</p> \n<p>The account overview sidebar, the ABM playbook for sales reps, and a native integration to link your HubSpot and LinkedIn Sales Navigator accounts, help further deepen your relationships with people over time, helping build more authentic connections with stakeholders within each account.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Does your company face any of these marketing issues?</h3> \n<p>A thorough analysis of your marketing strategy and its current performance will help you discover where your biggest marketing opportunity lies. This will allow you to focus on improving the areas that need the most attention, so you can start making your marketing far more effective.</p> \n<p>If you're faced with a challenge and want ideas on how to best tackle it, you can always consider getting some help by any of the <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/marketing-training\">various types of marketing training that are available</a>.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in November 2012 and has been updated for freshness and comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"state of marketing\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F33820%2F5-major-challenges-marketers-face-and-how-to-solve-them.aspx&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 22 Jun 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7.png","linkMd5":"2aa427724dc829be6641840148648a85","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn5@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-586_88b93bfb7be7b212.webp","destWidth":442,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5404,"destBytes":7216,"author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn5@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-38-586_88b93bfb7be7b212.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/biggest%20challenges%20for%20marketers%202021.png?width=1080&name=biggest%20challenges%20for%20marketers%202021.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn100@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-52-398_87e7d5e4540e2392.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-06-14%20at%204.53.46%20PM.png?width=1218&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-06-14%20at%204.53.46%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn60@2020_4/2021/07/12/18-35-50-076_77d4acbcef47d6fd.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/biggest%20marketing%20challenges%202021.png?width=1104&name=biggest%20marketing%20challenges%202021.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn82@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-52-049_5a0ad27e145105c6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-06-14%20at%205.26.18%20PM.png?width=479&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-06-14%20at%205.26.18%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn21@2020_1/2021/07/12/18-35-52-510_ffc536da9e1f4672.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn78@2020_3/2021/07/12/18-35-48-782_ba6ee21c8b9c368e.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F33820%2F5-major-challenges-marketers-face-and-how-to-solve-them.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn61@2020_6/2021/07/12/18-35-48-738_71e71b31b27826e8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938158},{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","updatedTime":"2021-07-13 02:35:38","title":"Color Theory 101: A Complete Guide to Color Wheels & Color Schemes","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-theory-design","description":"<p>When you're sifting through your News Feed, what tends to catch your attention? More likely than not, it's YouTube videos, pictures, animated GIFs, and other visual content, right?</p> \n<p>While text-based content is always important when seeking answers to a question, creating visuals such as infographics, charts, graphs, animated GIFs, and other shareable images can do wonders for catching your readers' attention and enhancing your article or report.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>I know what you might be thinking: \"I don't know how to design awesome visuals. I'm not creative.\"</p> \n<p>Hi. I'm Bethany, and I will be the first to tell you that I'm not naturally artistic. And yet, I found a strength in data visualization at HubSpot, where I've spent most of my days creating infographics and other visuals for blog posts.</p> \n<p>So, while I wouldn't say I'm <em>naturally</em> artistic, I have learned how to create compelling visual content. So can you.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5478fa12-4cc3-4140-ba96-bc103eeb873e&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: 150+ Content Creation Templates [Free Kit]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5478fa12-4cc3-4140-ba96-bc103eeb873e.png\" align=\"middle\" /></a></p> \n<p>And you can do this by learning color theory. Consider this your introductory course, and we'll be covering the following topics:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-theory-design#what-is-color-theory\">What Is Color Theory?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-theory-design#why\">Why Is Color Theory Important in Web Design?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-theory-design#color-theory-101\">Color Theory 101</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-theory-design#additive-subtractive\">Additive &amp; Subtractive Color Theory</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-theory-design#mean\">The Meaning of Color</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-theory-design#seven\">The Seven Color Schemes</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-theory-design#how\">How to Choose a Color Scheme</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-theory-design#color-tools\">Color Tools</a></li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h2>What is color theory?</h2> \n<p>Color theory is the basis for the primary rules and guidelines that surround color and its use in creating aesthetically pleasing visuals. By understanding color theory basics, you can begin to parse the logical structure of color for yourself to create and use <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-palette-inspiration\">color palettes</a> more strategically. The result means evoking a particular emotion, vibe, or aesthetic.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>While there are many tools out there to help even the most inartistic of us to create compelling visuals, graphic design tasks require a little more background knowledge on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design\">design principles</a>.</p> \n<p>Take <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/website-color-schemes?_ga=2.84043481.1301447038.1622646346-1029200885.1622646346\">selecting the right color combination</a>, for instance. It's something that might seem easy at first but when you're staring down a color wheel, you're going to wish you had some information on what you're looking at. Understanding how colors work together, the impact they can have on mood and emotion, and how they change the look and feel of your website is critical to help you stand out from the crowd — for the right reasons.</p> \n<p>From effective CTAs to sales conversions and marketing efforts, the right color choice can highlight specific sections of your website, make it easier for users to navigate, or give them a sense of familiarity from the first moment they click through.</p> \n<p>But it’s not enough to simply select colors and hope for the best — from color theory to moods and schemes, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/website-color-schemes?_ga=2.63612527.1301447038.1622646346-1029200885.1622646346\">finding the right HTML color codes, </a>and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/how-to-identify-web-accessible-colors-for-products-websites?_ga=2.63612527.1301447038.1622646346-1029200885.1622646346\">identifying web-accessible colors for products and websites</a>, the more you know about using color, the better your chances are for success.</p> \n<p>Read on for our designer’s guide to color theory, color wheels, and color schemes for your site.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Color Theory 101</h2> \n<p>Let's first go back to high school art class to discuss the basics of color.</p> \n<p>Remember hearing about primary, secondary, and tertiary colors? They're pretty important if you want to understand, well, everything else about color.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/123b.png?width=292&amp;name=123b.png\" width=\"292\" style=\"font-family: AvenirNext, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 600; font-size: 17.6px; width: 292px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Circular color theory model with labels for primary colors, secondary colors, and tertiary colors\" /></p> \n<h3>Primary Colors</h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Primary colors are those you can't create by combining two or more other colors together. They're a lot like prime numbers, which can't be created by multiplying two other <em>numbers</em> together.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">There are three primary colors:</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>Red</strong></li> \n <li style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>Yellow</strong></li> \n <li style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>Blue</strong></li> \n</ul> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Think of primary colors as your parent colors, anchoring your design in a general color scheme. Any one or combination of these colors can give your brand guardrails when you move to explore other shades, tones, and tints (we'll talk about those in just a minute).</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">When designing or even painting with primary colors, don't feel restricted to just the three primary colors listed above. Orange isn't a primary color, for example, but brands can certainly use orange as their dominant color (as we at HubSpot know this quite well).</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Knowing which primary colors <em>create</em> orange is your ticket to identifying colors that might go well with orange — given the right shade, tone, or tint. This brings us to our next type of color ...</p> \n<h3>Secondary Colors</h3> \n<p>Secondary colors are the colors that are formed by combining any two of the three primary colors listed above. Check out the color theory model above — see how each secondary color is supported by two of the three primary colors?</p> \n<p>There are three secondary colors: <strong>orange</strong>, <strong>purple</strong>, and <strong>green</strong>. You can create each one using two of the three primary colors. Here are the general rules of secondary color creation:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Red + Yellow = <strong>Orange</strong></li> \n <li>Blue + Red = <strong>Purple</strong></li> \n <li>Yellow + Blue = <strong>Green</strong></li> \n</ul> \n<p>Keep in mind that the color mixtures above only work if you use the purest form of each primary color. This pure form is known as a color's <em>hue</em>, and you'll see how these hues compare to the variants underneath each color in the color wheel below.</p> \n<h3>Tertiary Colors</h3> \n<p>Tertiary colors are created when you mix a primary color with a secondary color.</p> \n<p>From here, color gets a little more complicated, and if you want to learn how the experts choose color in their design, you've got to first understand all the other components of color.</p> \n<p>The most important component of tertiary colors is that not every primary color can match with a secondary color to create a tertiary color. For example, red can't mix in harmony with green, and blue can't mix in harmony with orange -- both mixtures would result in a slightly brown color (unless of course, that's what you're looking for).</p> \n<p>Instead, tertiary colors are created when a primary color mixes with a secondary color that comes next to it on the color wheel below. There are six tertiary colors that fit this requirement:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Red + Purple = <strong>Red-Purple</strong> (magenta)</li> \n <li>Red + Orange = <strong>Red-Orange</strong> (vermillion)</li> \n <li>Blue + Purple = <strong>Blue-Purple</strong> (violet)</li> \n <li>Blue + Green = <strong>Blue-Green</strong> (teal)</li> \n <li>Yellow + Orange = <strong>Yellow-Orange</strong> (amber)</li> \n <li>Yellow + Green = <strong>Yellow-Green</strong> (chartreuse)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>The Color Theory Wheel</h3> \n<p>Okay, great. So now you know what the \"main\" colors are, but you and I both know that choosing <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-combinations\">color combinations</a>, especially on a computer, involves a much wider range than 12 basic colors.</p> \n<p>This is the impetus behind the color wheel, a circle graph that charts each primary, secondary, and tertiary color — as well as their respective hues, tints, tones, and shades. Visualizing colors in this way helps you choose color schemes by showing you how each color relates to the color that comes next to it on a rainbow color scale. (As you probably know, the colors of a rainbow, in order, are <strong>red</strong>, <strong>orange</strong>, <strong>yellow</strong>, <strong>green</strong>, <strong>blue</strong>, <strong>indigo</strong>, and <strong>violet</strong>.)</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/00-Blog-Related_Images/types_of_colors.png?width=450&amp;height=342&amp;name=types_of_colors.png\" style=\"width: 450px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Color theory wheel with labels for each color's hue, tint, tone, and shade\" width=\"450\" height=\"342\" /></p> \n<p>When choosing colors for a color scheme, the color wheel gives you opportunities to create brighter, lighter, softer, and darker colors by mixing white, black, and gray with the original colors. These mixes create the color variants described below:</p> \n<h4>Hue</h4> \n<p>Hue is pretty much synonymous with what we actually mean when we said the word \"color.\" All of the primary and secondary colors, for instance, are \"hues.\"</p> \n<p>Hues are important to remember when combining two primary colors to create a secondary color. If you don't use the hues of the two primary colors you're mixing together, you won't generate the hue of the secondary color. This is because a hue has the fewest other colors inside it. By mixing two primary colors that carry other tints, tones, and shades inside them, you're technically adding more than two colors to the mixture — making your final color dependent on the compatibility of more than two colors.</p> \n<p>If you were to mix the hues of red and blue together, for instance, you'd get purple, right? But mix a <em>tint </em>of red with the hue of blue, and you'll get a slightly tinted purple in return.</p> \n<h4>Shade</h4> \n<p>You may recognize the term \"shade\" because it's used quite often to refer to light and dark versions of the same hue. But actually, a shade is technically the color that you get when you add black to any given hue. The various \"shades\" just refer to how much black you're adding.</p> \n<h4>Tint</h4> \n<p>A tint is the opposite of a shade, but people don't often distinguish between a color's shade and a color's tint. You get a different tint when you add white to a color. So, a color can have a range of both shades and tints.</p> \n<h4>Tone (or Saturation)</h4> \n<p>You can also add both white and black to a color to create a tone. Tone and saturation essentially mean the same thing, but most people will use saturation if they're talking about colors being created for digital images. Tone will be used more often for painting.</p> \n<p>With the basics covered, let's dive into something a little more complicated — like additive and subtractive color theory.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Additive &amp; Subtractive Color Theory</h2> \n<p>If you've ever played around with color on any computer program, you've probably seen a module that listed RGB or CMYK colors with some numbers next to the letters.</p> \n<p>Ever wondered what those letters mean?</p> \n<h3>CMYK</h3> \n<p>CMYK stands for Cyan, Magenta, Yellow, Key (Black). Those also happen to be the colors listed on your ink cartridges for your printer. That's no coincidence.</p> \n<p>CMYK is the <strong>subtractive color model</strong>. It's called that because you have to <em>subtract</em> colors to get to white. That means the opposite is true — the more colors you add, the closer you get to black. Confusing, right?</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/cmyk.png?width=320&amp;height=314&amp;name=cmyk.png\" width=\"320\" height=\"314\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Subtractive color diagram with CMYK in the center\" /></p> \n<p>Think about printing on a piece of paper. When you first put a sheet in the printer, you're typically printing on a white piece of paper. By adding color, you're blocking the white wavelengths from getting through.</p> \n<p>Then, let's say you were to put that printed piece of paper back into the printer, and print something on it again. You'll notice the areas that have been printed on twice will have colors closer to black.</p> \n<p>I find it easier to think about CMYK in terms of its corresponding numbers. CMYK works on a scale of 0 to 100. If C=100, M=100, Y=100, and K=100, you end up with black. But, if all four colors equal 0, you end up with true white.</p> \n<h3>RGB</h3> \n<p>RGB color models, on the other hand, are designed for electronic displays, including computers.</p> \n<p>RGB stands for Red, Green, Blue, and is based on the <strong>additive color model</strong> of light waves. This means, the more color you <em>add,</em> the closer you get to white. For computers, RGB is created using scales from 0 to 255. So, black would be R=0, G=0, and B=0. White would be R=255, G=255, and B=255.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rgb-1.png?width=320&amp;height=304&amp;name=rgb-1.png\" width=\"320\" height=\"304\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Additive color model with RGB in the center\" /></p> \n<p>When you're creating color on a computer, your color module will usually list both RGB and CMYK numbers. In practice, you can use either one to find colors, and the other color model will adjust accordingly.</p> \n<p>However, many web programs will only give you the RGB values or a HEX code (the code assigned to color for CSS and HTML). So, if you're designing digital images or for web design, RGB is probably your best bet for choosing colors.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>You can always convert the design to CMYK and make adjustments should you ever need it for printed materials.</p> \n<h2>The Meaning of Color</h2> \n<p>Along with varying visual impact, different colors also carry different emotional symbolism.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Red — typically associated with power, passion, or energy, and can help encourage action on your site</li> \n <li>Orange — joy and enthusiasm, making it a good choice for positive messaging</li> \n <li>Yellow — happiness and intellect, but be wary of overuse</li> \n <li>Green — often connected to growth or ambition, green can help give the sense that your brand is on the rise</li> \n <li>Blue — tranquility and confidence, depending on the shade — lighter shades provide a sense of peace, darker colors are more confident</li> \n <li>Purple — luxury or creativity, especially when used deliberately and sparingly on your site</li> \n <li>Black — power and mystery, and using this color can help create necessary negative space</li> \n <li>White — safety and innocence, making it a great choice to help streamline your site</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<p>Worth noting? Different audiences may perceive colors differently. The meanings listed above are common for North American audiences, but if your brand moves into other parts of the world, it’s a good idea to research how users will perceive particular colors. For example, while red typically symbolizes passion or power in the United States, it’s considered a color of mourning in South Africa.</p> \n<p>While it’s possible to create your website using a combination of every color under the rainbow, chances are the final product won’t look great. Thankfully, color experts and designers have identified seven common color schemes to help jumpstart your creative process.</p> \n<p>Let’s examine each in more detail.</p> \n<h3>1. Monochromatic</h3> \n<p>Monochromatic color schemes use a single color with varying shades and tints to produce a consistent look and feel. Although it lacks color contrast, it often ends up looking very clean and polished. It also allows you to easily change the darkness and lightness of your colors.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/monochromatic-color-wheel.png?width=285&amp;name=monochromatic-color-wheel.png\" alt=\"Color wheel with two monochromatic colors plotted along the red hue\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 285px;\" width=\"285\" /></p> \n<p>Monochromatic color schemes are often used for charts and graphs when creating high contrast isn't necessary.</p> \n<p>Check out all the monochromatic colors that fall under the red hue, a primary color.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/monochromatic.png\" alt=\"Red color scheme example with red hue, tint, tone, and shade\" /></p> \n<h3>2. Analogous</h3> \n<p>Analogous color schemes are formed by pairing one main color with the two colors directly next to it on the color wheel. You can also add two additional colors (which are found next to the two outside colors) if you want to use a five-color scheme instead of just three colors.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/analogous-color-wheel.png?width=287&amp;name=analogous-color-wheel.png\" alt=\"Color wheel with five analogous colors plotted between blue and yellow\" width=\"287\" style=\"width: 287px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<p>Analogous structures do not create themes with high contrasting colors, so they're typically used to create a softer, less contrasting design. For example, you could use an analogous structure to create a color scheme with autumn or spring colors.</p> \n<p>This color scheme is great for creating warmer (red, oranges, and yellows) or cooler (purples, blues, and greens) color palettes like the one below.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/analogous.png\" alt=\"Analogous color scheme pallette\" /></p> \n<p>Analogous schemes are often used to design images rather than infographics or bar charts as all of the elements blend together nicely.</p> \n<h3>3. Complementary</h3> \n<p>You may have guessed it, but a complementary color scheme is based on the use of two colors directly across from each other on the color wheel and relevant tints of those colors.<a href=\"https://www.color-meanings.com/split-complementary-colors/\"></a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/complementary-color-wheel.png?width=321&amp;name=complementary-color-wheel.png\" alt=\"color wheel showing complementary colors on opposite sides of the wheel\" width=\"321\" style=\"width: 321px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<p>The complementary color scheme provides the greatest amount of color contrast. Because of this, you should be careful about how you use the complementary colors in a scheme.</p> \n<p>It's best to use one color predominantly and use the second color as accents in your design. The complementary color scheme is also great for charts and graphs. High contrast helps you highlight important points and takeaways.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/complementary.png\" style=\"width: 640px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"complementary color sceme example with oranges and blues\" /></p> \n<h3>4. Split Complementary</h3> \n<p>A split complementary scheme includes one dominant color and the two colors directly adjacent to the dominant color's complement. This creates a more nuanced color palette than a complementary color scheme while still retaining the benefits of contrasting colors.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/compound-color-wheel.png?width=277&amp;name=compound-color-wheel.png\" alt=\"color wheel with split complementary color scheme values plotted\" width=\"277\" style=\"width: 277px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<p>The split complementary color scheme can be difficult to balance because unlike analogous or monochromatic color schemes, the colors used all provide contrast (similar to the complementary scheme).</p> \n<p>The positive and negative aspect of the split complementary color model is that you can use any two colors in the scheme and get great contrast ... but that also means it can also be tricky to find the right balance between the colors. As a result, you may end up playing around with this one a bit more to find the right combination of contrast.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/compound.png\" alt=\"split complementary color scheme example with pale blue, peach, blue, and red\" /></p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">5. Triadic</h3> \n<p>Triadic color schemes offer high contrasting color schemes while retaining the same tone. Triadic color schemes are created by choosing three colors that are equally placed in lines around the color wheel.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/triadic-color-wheel.png?width=307&amp;name=triadic-color-wheel.png\" alt=\"Color wheel with three triadic colors plotted between purple, green, and orange\" width=\"307\" style=\"width: 307px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<p>Triad color schemes are useful for creating high contrast between each color in a design, but they can also seem overpowering if all of your colors are chosen on the same point in a line around the color wheel.</p> \n<p>To subdue some of your colors in a triadic scheme, you can choose one dominant color and use the others sparingly, or simply subdue the other two colors by choosing a softer tint.</p> \n<p>The triadic color scheme looks great in graphics like bar or pie charts because it offers the contrast you need to create comparisons.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Triadic.png\" alt=\"Color scheme example with purple, green, and orange triadic colors\" /></p> \n<h3>6. Square</h3> \n<p>The square color scheme uses four colors equidistant from each other on the color wheel to create a square or diamond shape. While this evenly-spaced color scheme provides substantial contrast to your design, it’s a good idea to select one dominant color rather than trying to balance all four.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://www.tigercolor.com/Images/Square.gif\" alt=\"Square color scheme\" width=\"265\" style=\"width: 265px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.tigercolor.com/color-lab/color-theory/color-theory-intro.htm\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Square color schemes are great for creating interest across your web designs. Not sure where to start? Pick your favorite color and work from there to see if this scheme suits your brand or website. It’s also a good idea to try square schemes against both black and white backgrounds to find the best fit.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://www.color-hex.com/palettes/79747.png\" alt=\"Capital Square Color Palette\"><a href=\"https://www.color-hex.com/color-palette/79747\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Image Source</span></em></a></img></p> \n<h3>7. Rectangle</h3> \n<p>Also called the tetradic color scheme, the rectangle approach is similar to its square counterpart but offers a more subtle approach to color selection.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://www.color-meanings.com/wp-content/uploads/rectangular-tetradic-color-wheel.png\" alt=\"Rectangle color Schme\" width=\"332\" style=\"width: 332px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.color-meanings.com/rectangular-tetradic-color-schemes/\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Image Source</span></em></a></p> \n<p>As you can see in the diagram above, while the blue and red shades are quite bold, the green and orange on the other side of the rectangle are more muted, in turn helping the bolder shades stand out.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://www.color-hex.com/palettes/21774.png\" alt=\"tetradic Color Palette\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.color-hex.com/color-palette/21774\"><em>Image Source</em></a></p> \n<p>No matter which color scheme you choose, keep in mind what your graphic needs. If you need to create contrast, then choose a color scheme that gives you that. On the other hand, if you just need to find the best \"versions\" of certain colors, then play around with the monochromatic color scheme to find the perfect shades and tints.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Remember, if you build a color scheme with five colors, that doesn't mean you have to use all five. Sometimes just choosing two colors from a color scheme looks much better than cramming all five colors together in one graphic.</p> \n<h3>1. Prioritize the user experience, first.</h3> \n<p>Before you add color to your website, app, product, or packaging, get the basic design downpat in greyscale.</p> \n<p>This lets you focus on what matters most: User experience. Instead of focusing on the color scheme of your overall site or the hue of specific buttons or links, make sure everything works like it’s supposed to. Make sure links aren’t broken, product pages are up-to-date and email opt-ins are ready to go.</p> \n<p>Here’s why: Even the best-looking website or product with perfect color selection won’t be enough to keep visitors if they can’t find what they’re looking for.</p> \n<h3>2. Leverage natural inspiration.</h3> \n<p>Once your site operations are solid, it’s time to start selecting colors.</p> \n<p>Not sure what looks good? Take a look outside. Nature is the best example of colors that complement each other — from the green stems and bright blooms of flowering plants to azure skies and white clouds, you can’t go wrong pulling context from natural colors and combinations.</p> \n<h3>3. Set a mood for your color scheme.</h3> \n<p>With a few color choices in mind, consider the mood you want your color scheme to set. If passion and energy are your priorities, lean more toward red or brighter yellows. If you’re looking to create a feeling of peace or tranquility, trend toward lighter blues and greens.</p> \n<p>It’s also worth thinking negatively. This is because negative space — in either black or white — can help keep your design from feeling too cluttered with color.</p> \n<h3>4. Consider color context.</h3> \n<p>It’s also worth considering how colors are perceived in contrast.</p> \n<p>In the image below, the middle of each of the circles is the same size, shape, and color. The only thing that changes is the background color.</p> \n<p>Yet, the middle circles appear softer or brighter depending on the contrasting color behind it. You may even notice movement or depth changes just based on one color change.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/2JkvG270JO78cadBYLbuHGT0yFABGnsqgWM_HDmuAUi4qYgHfuKdHKMRsIAgevHZ5pI54apNZzI2zyvZ525hG6aKDyLckgYHohwFMNxQbV50lVIRhPK2emQ65mI9QfSdg2qy5iHI\" width=\"624\" height=\"403\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"Color Context with backgrounds\" /></p> \n<p>This is because the way in which we use two colors together changes how we perceive it. So, when you're choosing colors for your graphic designs, think about how much contrast you want throughout the design.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you were creating a simple bar chart, would you want a dark background with dark bars? Probably not. You'd most likely want to create a contrast between your bars and the background itself since you want your viewers to focus on the bars, not the background.</p> \n<h3>5. Refer to your color wheel.</h3> \n<p>Next, consider your color wheel and the schemes mentioned above. Select a few different color combinations using schemes such as monochrome, complementary, and triad to see what stands out.</p> \n<p>Here, the goal isn’t to find exactly the right colors on the first try and create the perfect design, but rather to get a sense of which scheme naturally resonates with your personal perception and the look of your site.</p> \n<p>You may also find that schemes you select that look good in theory don’t work with your site design. This is part of the process — trial and error will help you find the color palette that both highlights your content and improves the user experience.</p> \n<h3>6. Use the 60-30-10 rule.</h3> \n<p>Often used in home design, the 60-30-10 rule is also useful for website or app design. The idea here is to use three colors: A main color for 60% of your design, a secondary color for 30% of your design and an accent color for the last 10%.</p> \n<p>While these aren’t hard-and-fast numbers, they help give a sense of proportion and balance to your site by providing a primary color with secondary and accent colors that all work together.</p> \n<h3>7. Draft multiple designs.</h3> \n<p>Draft and apply multiple color designs to your website and see which one(s) stand out. Then, take a step back, wait a few days and check again to see if your favorites have changed.</p> \n<p>Here’s why: While many designers go in with a vision of what they want to see and what looks good, the finished product often differs on digital screens that physical color wheels — what seemed like a perfect complement or an ideal color pop may end up looking drab or dated.</p> \n<p>Don’t be afraid to draft, review, draft again and throw out what doesn’t work — color, like website creation, is a constantly-evolving art form.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Put simply? Practice makes perfect. The more you play with color and practice design, the better you get. No one creates their masterpiece the first time around.</p> \n<h2>Color Tools</h2> \n<p>There's been a lot of theory and practical information for actually understanding which colors go best together and why. But when it comes down to the actual task of choosing colors while you're designing, it's always a great idea to have tools to help you actually do the work quickly and easily.</p> \n<p>Luckily, there are a number of tools to help you find and choose colors for your designs.</p> \n<h3>Adobe Color</h3> \n<p>One of my favorite color tools to use while I'm designing anything — whether it's an infographic or just a pie chart — is Adobe Color (previously Adobe Kuler).</p> \n<p>This free online tool allows you to quickly build color schemes based on the color structures that were explained earlier in this post. Once you've chosen the colors in the scheme you'd like, you can copy and paste the HEX or RGB codes into whatever program you're using.</p> \n<p>It also features hundreds of premade color schemes for you to explore and use in your own designs. If you're an Adobe user, you can easily save your themes to your account.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screenshot_2015-08-03_17.24.23.png?width=669&amp;height=312&amp;name=Screenshot_2015-08-03_17.24.23.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"669\" height=\"312\" alt=\"Color wheel on dashboard of Adobe Color\" /></p> \n<h3>Illustrator Color Guide</h3> \n<p>I spend a lot of time in Adobe Illustrator, and one of my most-used features is the color guide. The color guide allows you to choose one color, and it will automatically generate a five-color scheme for you. It will also give you a range of tints and shades for each color in the scheme.</p> \n<p>If you switch your main color, the color guide will switch the corresponding colors in that scheme. So if you've chosen a complementary color scheme with the main color of blue, once you switch your main color to red, the complementary color will also switch from orange to green.</p> \n<p>Like Adobe Color, the color guide has a number of preset modes to choose the kind of color scheme you want. This helps you pick the right color scheme style within the program you're already using.</p> \n<p>After you've created the color scheme that you want, you can save that scheme in the \"Color Themes\" module for you to use throughout your project or in the future.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Color_Guide.png?width=669&amp;height=352&amp;name=Color_Guide.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"352\" style=\"width: 669px;\" alt=\"Color options on Illustrator Color Guide tool\" /></p> \n<h3>Preset Color Guides</h3> \n<p>If you're not an Adobe user, you've probably used Microsoft Office products at least once. All of the Office products have preset colors that you can use and play around with to create color schemes. PowerPoint also has a number of color scheme presets that you can use to draw inspiration for your designs.</p> \n<p>Where the color schemes are located in PowerPoint will depend on which version you use, but once you find the color \"themes\" of your document, you can open up the preferences and locate the RGB and HEX codes for the colors used.</p> \n<p>You can then copy and paste those codes to be used in whatever program you're using to do your design work.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/powerpoint-themese.png?width=670&amp;height=406&amp;name=powerpoint-themese.png\" width=\"670\" height=\"406\" alt=\"Color swatches and meters in PowerPoint\" /></p> \n<h2>Finding the Right Color Scheme</h2> \n<p>There's a lot of theory in this post, I know. But when it comes to choosing colors, understanding the theory behind color can do wonders for how you actually use color. This can make creating branded visuals easy, especially when using design templates where you can customize colors.</p> \n<div>\n  &nbsp; \n</div> \n<div> \n <a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=69995f8d-caaf-4080-a787-5b4628f190f4&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"content templates\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/69995f8d-caaf-4080-a787-5b4628f190f4.png\" /></a> \n</div> \n<div></div> \n<img 4548f471d4f5f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/powerpoint-themese.png?width=670&height=406&name=powerpoint-themese.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn73@2020_5/2021/07/12/18-35-53-206_46144cacddffcfa2.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/69995f8d-caaf-4080-a787-5b4628f190f4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn37@2020_2/2021/07/12/18-35-48-760_a4192107130e731a.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcolor-theory-design&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1626114938161}],"record":{"createdTime":"2021-07-13 +0000","fetchMs":99,"handleMs":639,"totalMs":30894,"newArticles":0,"totalArticles":50,"status":1,"type":0,"ip":"79b59b7ab14b8d981e3d8a220e20848a","hostName":"us-024*","requestId":"938b8460b2e94e329716f4d9264c5bb5_54","contentType":"text/xml;charset=utf-8","totalBytes":21492594,"bgimgsTotal":40,"bgimgsGithubTotal":39,"articlesImgsTotal":355,"articlesImgsGithubTotal":320,"successGithubMap":{"myreaderx8":11,"myreaderx15":13,"myreaderx7":12,"myreaderx6":11,"myreaderx16":12,"myreaderx32":13,"myreaderx4":13,"myreaderx10":12,"myreaderx3":13,"myreaderx11":12,"myreaderx33":11,"myreaderx2":13,"myreaderx12":12,"myreaderx1":11,"myreaderx13":11,"myreaderx30":13,"myreaderx18":13,"myreaderx19":11,"myreaderx":13,"myreaderx25":13,"myreaderx27":13,"myreaderx21":13,"myreaderx22":13,"myreaderx23":1,"myreaderx24":13,"myreaderx5oss":11,"myreaderx29":13},"failGithubMap":{"myreaderx14":11,"myreaderx23":11,"myreaderx31":13}},"feed":{"createdTime":"2020-05-30
